questions.text: Pick the combination of immunohistopathological marker that is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Carcinoma: Desmin
 
  • Desmin in muscle cells forms the scaffold on which actin and myosin contract.
  • Desmin is mostly associated with muscle tumors like, rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • As there is no mention of type of carcinoma, so most appropriate answer is option 3
Cytokeratin is the tumour marker for Carcinoma

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 332.

questions.text: Pick the option that induces apoptosis in a cell.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glucocorticoids
 
  • Glucocorticoids are also potent inducers of apoptosis in many cell types.
  • In glucocorticoid sensitive cells, apoptosis and other cellular effects are induced through activating the glucocorticoid receptor (GR).
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids) have well-documented anti inflammatory effects, and their administration may result in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis.
Hence in treatment regimens of Acute Leukemias Steroids play a major role.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: Following an incised wound, one can observe fresh collagen fibrils and a thick layer of developing epithelium. The age of the wound is about:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) About 1 week

As there is mention of fresh collagen fibrils correct timeline would be about 1 week
As per the options, Granulation tissue appears on Day 3, but Thick layers of Developing epithelium comes in about 1 wk. so Answer should be Option 2> Option 1.
* Timeline Of Wound Healing by Primary Intention:
 
  • Within 24 hours, neutrophils are seen at the incision margin, migrating toward the fibrin clot.
  • Within 24 to 48 hours, epithelial cells from both edges have begun to migrate and proliferate along the dermis yielding a thin but continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound.
  • By day 3, neutrophils have been largely replaced by macrophages, and granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space. The macrophages clear extracellular debris, fibrin, and other foreign material and promote angiogenesis and ECM deposition.
  • By day 5, neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space. Thus, new granulation tissue is often edematous. Fibroblasts progressively migrate into the granulation tissue, where they proliferate and lay down collagen and ECM.
  • During the second week, there is continued collagen accumulation and fibroblast proliferation.
  • By the end of the first month, the scar comprises a cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells and covered by an essentially normal epidermis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 109.

choices.text: Hypersensitivity reaction with modified macrophages, lymphocytes and giant cells

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with fever, night sweats, and weight loss. On X-ray, a mass was seen in the apical lobe. On histopathology, caseous necrosis was present. What is the underlying process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Hypersensitivity reaction with modified macrophages, lymphocytes and giant cells
 
  • Clinical signs of fever, night sweats, weight loss along with X-ray finding of a mass in the apical lobe and histopathological evidence of caseous necrosis is suggestive of tuberculosis. 
  • The underlying pathophysiology involves Type IV hypersensitivity reaction which is characterized by the presence of giant cells, epithelioid cells and modified macrophage lymphocytes.
  • Immune Mechanisms: Activated T lymphocytes → (1) release of cytokines, inflammation and macrophage activation (2) T cell–mediated cytotoxicity
  • Histopathological markers: Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 204.

questions.text: What anomaly from the list below is present in the given karyotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (4) Gynecomastia with long thin limbs
  • The given Karyotype shows two X chromosome and single Y chromosome (XXY) pointing towards Klinefelter's syndrome.
  • Klinefelter syndrome is  male hypogonadism that occurs when there are two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes. It is the likely diagnosis (47, XXY) in the given karyotype
  • Clinical features of Klinefelter's include eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long thin legs; small atrophic hyalinized testes often associated with a small penis; and lack of such secondary male characteristics as deep voice, beard, and male distribution of pubic hair. Gynecomastia may be present. (Hence - option 4 is correct)
  • CVS abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse and varicose veins. 
Other options
High pitched cry is seen in Cri-du-chat syndrome (del 5p) ; Round face with protruding tongue is seen in trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) and short stature with webbed neck is afeature of Turner's syndrome(45, X0)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 171.

questions.text: Sweating does not occur in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Heat stroke

Sweating is not present in Heat stroke




Reference: Harrison's Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3637.

questions.text: Which specific stain has been used in the liver biopsy shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sweet's Reticulin Stain
 
  • Sweet's reticulin stain has been used in the liver biopsy.
  • Sweet's reticulin stain is a histochemical staining technique used to visualize the reticulin fibers in tissues, particularly in the liver.
  • It helps in assessing the architecture of liver tissue and detecting abnormalities such as fibrosis or cirrhosis.
  • The stain highlights the reticulin framework around hepatocytes and blood vessels, providing important information about the liver structure and any disruptions in the reticulin network.
Online Reference:
Krishna M. Role of special stains in diagnostic liver pathology. Clin Liver Dis (Hoboken). 2013 Mar 29;2(Suppl 1):S8-S10. doi: 10.1002/cld.148. PMID: 30992876; PMCID: PMC6448668.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases during the acute phase ie is a negative acute phase reactant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Albumin
 
  • Albumin decreases during the acute phase.
  • Acute-phase reactants are a group of proteins whose levels in the blood change in response to inflammation or infection.
  • While many acute-phase reactants increase during the acute phase, such as C-reactive protein and haptoglobin, albumin levels tend to decrease.
  • This decrease is due to factors like increased capillary permeability and liver dysfunction, which occur during the acute phase response.
*[Extra Edge] Acute Phase Reactants:





Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 75.

questions.text: 68-year-old man who experienced significant chest pain. On the route to the hospital, the patient passed away. Tetrazolium chloride staining of the heart was carried out during the autopsy in the hospital. What color will the myocardium be when it is viable?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Red 
 
  • It is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride.
  • This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, non-infarcted myocardium with preserved lactate dehydrogenase activity. Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.
  • Viable myocardium has active dehydrogenase enzymes that reduce tetrazolium chloride to form a red formazan pigment.

Fig: Acute myocardial infarct, predominantly of the posterolateral left ventricle, demonstrated histochemically by a lack of staining by triphenyl tetrazolium chloride in areas of necrosis (arrow)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 548.

choices.text: Cell cycle will stop at G1 phase
Cell cycle will stop at G2 phase
The cell cycle will progress and the cell will divide
There will be no effect on cell cycle as for Rb gene phosphorylation is not needed

questions.text: Which of the following will result if the phosphorylation of the RB gene is paused?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cell cycle will stop at G1 phase
 
  • If the phosphorylation of the RB gene is paused, it will result in the cell cycle stopping at the G1 phase.
  • The RB gene (retinoblastoma gene) is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates the cell cycle progression. When RB is phosphorylated, it becomes inactive and allows the cell cycle to proceed from G1 phase to S phase.
  • However, if RB phosphorylation is paused or inhibited, it prevents the release of transcription factors required for DNA replication, leading to cell cycle arrest at the G1 phase. 

                                                            

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 294.

questions.text: Cell growth can be halted at certain stages in the cell cycle. Which stage of the cell cycle displays the main major point in cell growth regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) End of G1

The first and most significant cell-cycle checkpoint is G1-S, or towards the end of the G1 phase, which is where the Rb gene and p53 both regulate the cell cycle.

*[Extra Edge]: RB Gene
 
  • If the phosphorylation of the RB gene is paused, it will result in the cell cycle stopping at the G1 phase.
  • The RB gene (retinoblastoma gene) is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates the cell cycle progression. When RB is phosphorylated, it becomes inactive and allows the cell cycle to proceed from G1 phase to S phase.
  • However, if RB phosphorylation is paused or inhibited, it prevents the release of transcription factors required for DNA replication, leading to cell cycle arrest at the G1 phase. 
                                                                     

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 295.

questions.text: Internal fixation was performed on a patient who had suffered a femur fracture. The patient experienced low-grade fever and rapid onset shortness of breath two days later. What's the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fat Embolism

The patient has a history of a lower limb fracture followed by internal fixation, which results in fat embolism since lengthy bone fractures (and/or their repair) cause microscopic fat globules to leak. Fat embolism is the most likely reason.

*[Extra Edge]: Fat Embolism Syndrome



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 131.

questions.text: A woman who had a normal vaginal delivery returned after five days with a headache/vomiting. Papilledema was visible in the fundus. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cortical vein thrombosis
 
  • The most likely diagnosis for the woman who had a normal vaginal delivery and presented with headache/vomiting and papilledema visible in the fundus is cortical vein thrombosis.
  • Cortical vein thrombosis is a form of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) where blood clots form in the veins draining the cerebral cortex.
  • It can lead to increased intracranial pressure, resulting in symptoms such as headache, vomiting, and visual disturbances.
Option 2 and 3 can't be the answer because there is no mention of Infection or Trauma.
Option 4 can't be the answer because migraine doesn't have a direct correlation with NVD.

Reference: Harrison's Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3342.

questions.text: Which of the following can recognize dead material during inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inflammasome

The inflammasome is a protein complex that recognizes products of dead cells and some microbes and induces the secretion of biologically active interleukins.
  • A protein complex called the inflammasome detects the byproducts of dead cells and some bacteria and triggers the release of physiologically active interleukin 1.
  • A sensor protein (NLRP3, a leucine-rich protein), an adaptor, and the enzyme caspase-1, which is changed from an inactive to an active form, make up the inflammasome.
  • The inflammasome has also been implicated in inflammatory reactions to urate crystals (the cause of gout), lipids (in metabolic syndrome and obesity-associated type 2 diabetes), cholesterol crystals (in atherosclerosis), and even amyloid deposits in the brain (in Alzheimer disease).

Fig: The Inflammasome


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 192.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about apoptosis is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cell swelling

  • Cell size is reduced, the cytoplasm is dense and eosinophilic, and the organelles, although relatively normal, are more tightly packed.
  • This contrasts with necrosis, in which an early feature is cell swelling, not shrinkage.
* [Extra Edge]: Morphologic features of Apoptotic cell

  • Cell shrinkage- Cell size is reduced, the cytoplasm is dense and eosinophilic, and the organelles although relatively normal, are more tightly packed. This contrasts with necrosis, in which an early feature is cell swelling, not shrinkage.
  • Chromatin condensation- This is the most characteristic feature of apoptosis. The chromatin aggregates peripherally, under the nuclear membrane, into dense masses of various shapes and sizes. The nucleus itself may break up into two or more fragments.
  • Formation of cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies- The apoptotic cell first shows extensive surface membrane blebbing, which is followed by fragmentation of the dead cells into membrane bound apoptotic bodies composed of cytoplasm and tightly packed organelles, with or without nuclear fragments.
  • Phagocytosis of apoptotic cells or cell bodies, usually by macrophages- The apoptotic bodies are rapidly ingested by phagocytes and degraded by the phagocyte’s lysosomal enzymes.
  • In H&E-stained tissue, the apoptotic cell appears as a round or oval mass of intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm with fragments of dense nuclear chromatin.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: Identify the star marked structure in the illustration below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lipofuscin granules
 
  • The marked structure in the given image is the accumulation of lipofuscin granules in perinuclear location. 
  • Lipofuscin, sometimes referred to as lipochrome or "wear-and-tear pigment," is an insoluble pigment.
  • Lipofuscin is composed of polymers of lipids and phospholipids in complex with protein, suggesting that it is derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of intracellular membranes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 64.

questions.text: Nephrotic Syndrome-related edema results from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Protein Loss
 
  • Loss of protein is the main mechanism of edema in nephrotic syndrome. 
  • Protein loss, especially albumin results in decreased oncotic pressure at the level of capillary bed which disturbs Frank-Starling's forces and favors movement of fluid from intra-vascular to extra-vascular compartment resulting in edema. 
* [Extra Edge]: Nephrotic Syndrome
  • Nephrotic syndrome is the clinical manifestation of glomerular diseases associated with heavy (nephrotic range) proteinuria.
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria is defined as proteinuria > 3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein: creatinine ratio > 2.
  • The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome arising from the large urinary losses of protein are hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol > 200 mg/dL).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text: Which of the following is most oftently used as a fixative in histopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Buffered Neutral 10% Formalin
 
  • Formalin, used most often in histopathology, is a 4% aqueous solution which is diluted tenfold to create 10% formalin.
  • To maintain its pH and osmotic pressure close to that of extracellular fluid found in mammals, neutral buffered formalin also includes inorganic salts.
  • This type of fixation is different from coagulation, as it acts by attaching to the side-chains of basic amino acids, especially lysine, and the amide nitrogen atoms found in peptide linkages.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 331.

questions.text: In case of acute inflammation, Bradykinin results in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pain at the site of inflammation

* The actions of Bradykinin are as follows- 

1. Vasodilatation

2. Increased vascular permeability

3. Pain at the site of inflammation 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 92.

questions.text: Of the following, which one suggests irreversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Amorphous Density in Mitochondria
 
  • Irreversible injury on electron microscopy involves the dilation of mitochondria, which can be seen as an increase in their size. This increase in size typically leads to the appearance of large, amorphous densities.
  • These densities are caused by an accumulation of material within the mitochondria due to the inability of the organelle to properly process, oxidize, and break down nutrients.
  • In other words, the decreased efficiency of the mitochondria prevents the normal breakdown of nutrients, resulting in a build-up of material within the organelle and the appearance of large amorphous densities.
Option 1, 3 and 4 are significant microscopic findings of Reversible injury.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: Which of the following does not describe tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypercalcemia
 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome is characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia - not hypercalcemia.

  • Hypocalcemia occurs due to the chelation of calcium by intracellular phosphate released extracellularly due to tumor cell death.

*[Extra Edge]: Tumor Lysis Syndrome



Reference: Harrison's Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: The liver biopsy histology of a patient with hemochromatosis is provided below. Which stain from the list below was applied?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Prussian blue

* [Extra Edge]: Uses of Prussian blue stain
 
  • Hemochromatosis is a metabolic disorder which results in deposition of excess iron in the body in the form of hemosiderin. Tissues having iron deposition can then be stained with the help of Prussian Blue Stain. 
  • Intracellular ferritin is located in the cytosol and in lysosomes, in which partially degraded protein shells of ferritin aggregate into hemosiderin granules. Iron in hemosiderin is chemically reactive and turns blue-black when exposed to potassium ferrocyanide, which is the basis for the Prussian blue stain.


In Heriditary Haemochromatosis, the gene affected is HFE gene chromosome 6.
                                 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 655.

questions.text: The resolving power of a microscope does not depend upon which of the following :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thickness of the film

The resolving power of a microscope refers to its ability to distinguish between two closely spaced objects as separate entities.
  • The resolving power is influenced by the numerical aperture of the objective lens, the wavelength of the light source used, and the size of the aperture in the condenser.
  • The resolving power depends on several factors, but it does not depend on the thickness of the film or specimen being observed.
  • The focal length of the eyepiece affects the magnification but not the resolving power.
Though focal length of eyepiece is also an answer, thickness of the film can be more appropriate and best answer.  

Online Reference:
Mualla F, Aubreville M, Maier A. Microscopy. 2018 Aug 3. In: Maier A, Steidl S, Christlein V, et al., editors. Medical Imaging Systems: An Introductory Guide [Internet]. Cham (CH): Springer; 2018. Chapter 5. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546149/ doi: 10.1007/978-3-319-96520-8_5

questions.text: Which stain is useful for identifying premalignant lesions of the lip?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Toluidine Blue

Toluidine Blue dye is used to identify premalignant lesions of the lip because it being a basic metachromatic dye, stains the excessive nuclear material present in malignant lesions, but not that of normal mucosa and can thus aid in the differentiation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1152.

choices.text: Components of complement can assist in chemotaxis

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding cellular events in acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PECAM/CD31 is responsible for neutrophil activation
 
  • PECAM-1, platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 also called CD31, a cellular adhesion molecule expressed on leukocytes and endothelial cells, mediates the binding events needed for leukocytes to traverse the endothelium(Diapedesis). PECAM is involved in transmigration and not activation. Hence option 1 is incorrect. 
  • The initial rolling interactions are mediated by selectins, of which there are three types: one expressed on leukocytes (L-selectin), one on endothelium (E-selectin), and one in platelets and on endothelium (P-selectin)
  • TNF and IL-1 induce endothelial expression of ligands for integrins, mainly vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 (VCAM-1), the ligand for the β1 integrin VLA-4, and intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1), the ligand for the β2 integrins LFA-1 and MAC-1.






Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 79.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is both morphogenic and mitogenic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Bone morphogenetic protein 
 
  • Bone morphogenetic protein constitutes a group of pivot morphogenetic signals involved in the development of heart, central nervous system, cartilage as well as post-natal bone development. 
  • Bone morphogenic proteins activate MAP kinase and help in mitosis. 
  • Recombinant human BMPs are used in orthopedic applications such as spinal fusions, non-unions and oral surgery. 
Reference: Harrison's Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2856.

choices.text: Mixed population of normal and apoptotic cells

questions.text: The image below shows DNA electrophoresis on an agarose gel using a population of cells as the sample. What is the proper justification for the discovery as shown in the band marked "C"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Predominantly necrotic cells

A “smeared” pattern of DNA fragmentation is thought to be indicative of necrosis, but this may be a late autolytic phenomenon, and typical DNA ladders are sometimes seen in necrotic cells as well.

Pattern A is of Normal cell
Pattern B is of Apoptotic cell

                                  
Online Reference:
Rahbar Saadat Y, Saeidi N, Zununi Vahed S, Barzegari A, Barar J. An update to DNA ladder assay for apoptosis detection. Bioimpacts. 2015;5(1):25-8. doi: 10.15171/bi.2015.01. Epub 2015 Feb 21. PMID: 25901294; PMCID: PMC4401164.

questions.text: Which is the most reactive free radical?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hydroxyl

  • Hydroxyl radical is the most potent Reactive Oxygen Species in vivo. 
  • Hydroxyl radical is particularly unstable and is the most reactive of the free radical molecules.
  • In addition, it is capable of reacting rapidly and non-specifically with most biological molecule.
  • H2O2 + e- → OH + OH- (Hydroxyl radical)
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 83.
Online Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3911811/pdf/JRI-14-158.pdf

questions.text: What factors influence the tensile strength of a 30-year-old woman's wound after a laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
#controversial
Correct Answer is Option 3 - Extensive crosslink of tropocollagen (Controversial question as both option 1 and 3 contribute to tensile strength of wound) 
 
  • The tensile strength of a wound depends on factors such as collagen synthesis and organization and the type of collagen. 
  • Extensive crosslinking of tropocollagen is the main factor for achieving tensile strength and hence is a better answer amongst other options.
Option 1 Replacement of type 3 collagen is associated with wound healing and increases the tensile strength also. 
Option 2 and 4 
Macrophage activity/invasion and granulation tissue formation are important processes in wound healing but are not specifically related to the tensile strength of the wound.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: Which of the following causes apoptosis in a cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Glucocorticoids

Glucocorticoids induce apoptosis in a cell.

* [Extra Edge]: Inducers of apoptosis

  • Growth factor withdrawal
  • Detachment from matrix 
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Cytotoxic drugs
  • Immune cytolysis

Glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis affects the skeletal system, muscular system, circulatory system, nervous system, endocrine system, endocrine system and immune system.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: Olympian brow and rhagades are observed in which disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Congenital syphilis

Olympian Brow is bony prominence of the forehead due to persistent recurrent periostitis and Rhagades refer to Linear scars that extend in a spoke-like pattern from previous mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus and genitalia are late manifestations of Congenital syphilis.

* [Extra Edge]: Congenital Syphilis
 
  • Manifestations of congenital syphilis may appear early (within the first 2 years of life, often at 2–10 weeks of age) or late (after 2 years).
  • In early congenital syphilis, periarticular swelling and immobilization of the involved limbs (Parrot’s pseudo paralysis) complicate osteochondritis of long bones.
  • Clutton’s joint, a late manifestation of congenital syphilis that typically develops between ages 8 and 15 years, is caused by chronic painless synovitis with effusions of large joints, particularly the knees and elbows.
  • Classic stigmata include Hutchinson’s teeth (centrally notched, widely spaced, peg-shaped upper central incisors), “mulberry” molars (sixth-year molars with multiple, poorly developed cusps), saddle nose, and saber shins.
Reference: Harrison's Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1410.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common primary for intraocular metastases:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Breast
 
  • Most common site of primary for intraocular metastasis is from the breast.
  • Next to lung cancer, breast cancer is the tumor that spreads most frequently to the eye. 
  • Breast cancer is currently the most prevalent tumors to metastasize to the eye. Ocular metastasis can constitute the early manifestation of breast carcinoma. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1316.

questions.text: Children with germline retinoblastoma are more likely to acquire other primary cancers later in life. Which of the following cancers can develop in such patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Osteosarcoma of lower limbs

  • Children with germline retinoblastoma are more likely to develop other primary malignancies in their later lifetime.
  • These non-metastatic malignancies which develop in disease free patients are known as second site tumors. The most common among them is osteosarcoma.
  • Other Tumors associated with retinoblastoma include osteosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, Ewing’s sarcoma, epithelial malignant tumors, lymphoma, leukemia, melanoma, brain tumors and pinealoblastomas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 291.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Inflammation

Apoptosis is a process of cells undergoing programmed cell death whereby unwanted cells are removed by the activation of specific genetic pathways.

Characteristic features of apoptosis include all, but it does not involve inflammation. 
 
* Characteristic features of apoptosis include-

  • Condensation of chromatin
  • Fragmentation of DNA,
  • Shrinkage of the Cell membrane (it stays intact)
  • Phagocytic recognition and removal
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 42.

choices.text: Rolling → Stable adhesion →Activation of integrins → Migration via endothelium
Rolling → Activation of integrins → Stable adhesion → Migration via endothelium
Stable adhesion → Rolling → Activation of integrins → Migration via endothelium
Activation of integrins → Migration via endothelium→ Stable adhesion → Rolling

questions.text: Which of the following best describes how cells behave during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rolling → Activation of integrins → Stable adhesion → Migration via endothelium 

The journey of leukocytes from the vessel lumen to the tissue is a multistep process that is mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines.

* This process can be divided into sequential phases- 

1. In the lumen: margination, rolling, and adhesion to endothelium. Vascular endothelium in its normal state does not bind circulating cells or allow their passage. In inflammation the endothelium is activated and can bind leukocytes as a prelude to their exit from blood vessels.
2. Migration across the endothelium and vessel wall.
3. Migration in the tissues toward a chemotactic stimulus.


Fig: The multistep process of leukocyte migration through blood vessels.
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 77.

questions.text: For acidic mucin, which of the following stains is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Alcin Blue

  • The alcian blue stain has the ability to distinguish between sialomucins, sulfomucins, and proteoglycans which are stained blue.
  • Neutral mucins on the other hand, will demonstrate a deep red/magenta staining with the PAS.
  • On a tissue or cellular level, the reaction of both neutral and acidic mucins will display varying shades of purple since they interact differently with the alcian blue and react with the Schiff reagent.
Other options: -
  • MPO stain is used for detecting Myeloperoxidase
  • Masson's trichrome is used for staining collagen
  • PTAH stain is used to identify contraction band necrosis
Online Reference: Kameyama A, Dong W. Succinylation-Alcian blue staining for mucins. 2021 Oct 1 [Updated 2022 Mar 24]. In: Nishihara S, Angata K, Aoki-Kinoshita KF, et al., editors. Glycoscience Protocols (GlycoPODv2) [Internet]. Saitama (JP): Japan Consortium for Glycobiology and Glycotechnology; 2021-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK593966/

questions.text: A 12-year-old youngster suffered a cut on his forearm four days prior. Due to the creation of granulation tissue, the bleeding has now stopped. A portion of the granulation tissue was also included in the material when conducting a skin biopsy. Below is a diagram illustrating granulation tissue's histology. This granulation tissue contains what kind of collagen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Type 3
 
  • In the given image, we can see that the granulation tissue is 4 days old, which means that the matrix is still composed of type III collagen, fibrin, plasma fibronectin and other components.
  • This matrix is in the process of being replaced by a matrix predominantly composed of type I collagen. Eventually, this will convert into a pale, avascular scar, containing spindle-shaped fibroblasts, collagen fragments, and other ECM components.
* Timeline Of Wound Healing by Primary Intention:
 
  • Within 24 hours, neutrophils are seen at the incision margin, migrating toward the fibrin clot.
  • Within 24 to 48 hours, epithelial cells from both edges have begun to migrate and proliferate along the dermis yielding a thin but continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound.
  • By day 3, neutrophils have been largely replaced by macrophages, and granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space.
  • By day 5, neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space.
  • During the second week, there is continued collagen accumulation and fibroblast proliferation.
  • By the end of the first month, the scar comprises a cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells and covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not utilised to identify a particular aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) RT-PCR

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization), QF-PCR (Quantitative Fluorescent Polymerase Chain Reaction), and Microarray are commonly used techniques for identifying specific aneuploidies.
RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a technique primarily used for detecting and quantifying gene expression levels, rather than identifying aneuploidies.
QF-PCR is Quality Fluorescence PCR and Microarray can detect aneuploidy though are mainly used to detect certain genomic defects frequently. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 181.

questions.text: The best method for prenatal haemophilia diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PCR
 
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a commonly used method for detecting genetic mutations, including those associated with hemophilia.
  • Hemophilia: Hemophilia is a genetic bleeding disorder characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of clotting factors, most commonly factor VIII (hemophilia A) or factor IX (hemophilia B).
  • This results in prolonged bleeding and impaired blood clotting.
  • Symptoms can range from mild to severe, with spontaneous bleeding into joints, muscles, or other tissues being common. Diagnosis is made through laboratory tests to measure clotting factor levels.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Cowden syndrome is associated with which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PTEN
 
  • Cowden syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of developing certain cancers.
  • It is caused by mutations in the PTEN (Phosphatase and Tensin Homolog) gene.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 292.

questions.text: Determine an X-linked disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Color blindness
 
  • Color blindness, or more specifically red-green color blindness, is a well-known X-linked recessive disorder.
  • Color blindness, or color vision deficiency, is a condition characterized by the inability to distinguish certain colors or perceive them accurately.
  • The most common type of color blindness is red-green color blindness, where individuals have difficulty differentiating between shades of red and green.
  • Color blindness is typically caused by inherited genetic mutations that affect the photopigments in the cone cells of the retina.

Other options:
  • Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder caused by mutations in the globin genes and is not X-linked.
  • Azoospermia refers to the absence of sperm in semen and can have various causes, including genetic factors, but it is not specifically an X-linked disorder.
  • Retinitis Pigmentosa is a group of inherited disorders affecting the retina and can have different inheritance patterns, including X-linked recessive, but it is not the sole X-linked disease.
* [Extra Edge]: Types of inheritance



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 218.

questions.text: L and H Cells have been observed in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lymphocyte predominance

L and H Cells also known as popcorn cells are seen in NLPHL i.e. Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 613.

questions.text: One can observe a stellate granuloma in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cat scratch disease
 
  • Stellate granulomas are a histological finding characterized by a central area of necrosis surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells in a star-shaped pattern.
  • Cat scratch disease, caused by Bartonella henselae, can present with stellate granulomas in lymph nodes.
Option 1 Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, not stellate granulomas.
Option 3 and 4 Cryptococcosis and histoplasmosis are fungal infections that typically present with granulomas but not specifically stellate granulomas.

* [Extra Edge]: Fungal infection and their characteristics



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 101.

choices.text: Changing one type of epithelium to another

questions.text: What is anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Lack of differentiation
 
  • Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation or dedifferentiation of cells, resulting in a more primitive or undifferentiated appearance.
  • Anaplastic cells typically display features such as pleomorphism, high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, prominent nucleoli, and increased mitotic activity.
*Option 1,2 and 4:
  • Changing one type of epithelium to another refers to metaplasia, not anaplasia.
  • Nuclear chromatin and morphological changes are associated with anaplastic cells but do not fully encompass the concept of anaplasia.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 270.

questions.text: How long does it take for hyperacute graft rejection to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): In minutes
 
  • Hyperacute graft rejection occurs rapidly, within minutes after transplantation.
  • It is an immediate and severe immune response against the transplanted organ due to preexisting recipient antibodies.
  • The antibodies activate the complement cascade, leading to endothelial cell injury, thrombosis, and graft failure.
*[Extra Edge]: Type of Transplant Rejections



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: Caspases are involved in the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): apoptosis
 
  • Caspases are a family of proteases involved in the process of apoptosis (programmed cell death).
  • They play a crucial role in initiating and executing the biochemical changes that lead to cell death during apoptosis.
  • Caspases cleave various cellular proteins, resulting in nuclear condensation, DNA fragmentation, and cell shrinkage.
*[Extra Edge]: irreversible cell injury



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 44.

questions.text: Select the most significant role of Bradykinin in acute inflammation.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Mediation of pain
 
  • Bradykinin, a potent vasoactive peptide, is involved in acute inflammation and plays a significant role in mediating pain.
  • It sensitizes nociceptors (pain receptors) and induces the release of pain mediators, such as prostaglandins and substance P.
  • Bradykinin also promotes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, contributing to the inflammatory response.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 92.

questions.text: Which is most characteristic feature of apoptosis on light microscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Nuclear compaction
 
  • The most characteristic feature of apoptosis on light microscopy is nuclear compaction or pyknosis.
  • Pyknosis refers to the shrinkage and condensation of the nucleus, resulting in a dense, darkly stained appearance.
  • Other features of apoptosis include cell shrinkage, chromatin fragmentation, membrane blebbing, and formation of apoptotic bodies are seen in electron microscopy. 
*[Extra Edge]: Irreversible cell injury



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: The following is not a feature of apoptosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Cellular swelling
 
  • Cellular swelling is not a feature of apoptosis but rather a characteristic of necrosis.
  • Apoptosis is characterized by nuclear condensation, intact cell membrane, cytoplasmic eosinophilia, and the absence of cellular swelling.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: Where are Reed Sternberg cells found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hodkin's Disease
 
  • Reed-Sternberg cells are considered Pathognomic/typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • They are distinct neoplastic giant cells (30-60 um in size) with abundant cytoplasm, 2 large nuclei, and 2 large inclusion like nucleoli giving an Owl Eye appearance that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers.
  • Reed Sternberg cells in a background of inflammatory cells infiltrate are diagnostic of Hodgkin's Lymphoma. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: What does the term "patho" in greek refer to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Suffering
 
  • Pathology is derived from the Greek root word " PATHOS " which means Suffering, misfortune.
  • Pathology derives from the Greek pathos "suffering" and ology "study of"––to give us "the study of disease" but often pathology means the disease's behavior.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1.

choices.text: Extended excision is the treatment of choice
It do not extend beyond the wound

questions.text: Regarding Keloid, the following statement is accurate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) It contain growth factor
 
  • Keloid is an abnormal overgrowth of scar tissue that forms at the site of a wound or injury.
  • It is characterized by excessive collagen deposition and an imbalance in collagen synthesis and degradation.
  • One accurate statement about keloids is that they contain growth factors. These growth factors, such as transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), and fibroblast growth factor (FGF), play a crucial role in promoting the growth and persistence of keloid scars.
  • The overexpression of these growth factors leads to abnormal fibroblast proliferation and collagen synthesis, contributing to the raised and hypertrophic appearance of keloids. Location of keloid commonly found on chest, shoulders and earlobes. Location of hypertrophic scar can occur anywhere on the body.
  • Excision can lead to recurrence of keloid. Intralesional Triamcinolone is the treatment of choice. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: Development of RET proto-oncogene is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Medullary carcinoma thyroid
 
  • The development of the RET proto-oncogene is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid.
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid is a rare form of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland.
  • Mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, inherited or acquired, are strongly associated with the development of medullary carcinoma thyroid.
* [Extra Edge]: MEN syndromes



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1087.

questions.text: A patient had a tibia fracture and was being treated 48 hours later and now has a spO2 of 60%. Was started on oxygen supoort and while maintaining 100% saturation using an NRBM, the patient still appears to be confused. He also has a petechial rash. The chest is clear. Which diagnosis is more likely
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fat embolism syndrome
 
  • Tibial fracture followed by hypoxemia and respiratory distress along with confusion and petechial rash all point towards Fat embolism syndrome.
  • Fat embolism syndrome is caused by fragments of bone marrow, fat, or platelet clumps entering the bloodstream and getting lodged in the lungs.
  • Symptoms of this condition range from confusion, headaches, hypoxia, fever, and in some cases petechial hemorrhage.
  • Treatment includes the administration of oxygen and pulmonary supportive therapy.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 131.

questions.text: The image below shows cellular changes which happened to a patient who is 45 years old, chain smoker with control being normal epithelium and CS being post smoking. This image represents which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Metaplasia

  • Metaplasia is a condition in which a mature adult tissue type is replaced by a different kind of tissue.
  • The picture depicts a typical example of metaplasia where columnar epithelium (left) is replaced by squamous epithelium (right).
  • This metaplasia is usually caused by chronic exposure to a number of factors such as smoking or chronic bronchitis, presence of stones in biliary tract, salivary duct or pancreatic duct. It is also seen in conditions like Barrett’s esophagus and Myositis ossificans.
  • The pathogenesis of metaplasia is thought to be due to a reprogramming of stem cells in the tissue and can be reversed, although it can lead to malignant transformation of the metaplastic epithelium.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 61.

questions.text: ATRA is a tumour healing treatment is associated with which one amongst the given options:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PML RARA
 
  • AML (acute myeloid leukemia) is a type of blood cancer that originates in the bone marrow (the soft inner part of bones where new blood cells are made) and affects white blood cells known as myeloid cells.
  • It is the most common form of acute leukemia in adults and recurrent genetic abnormalities, such as a translocation of the chromosomes 8 and 21 (t [8;21]), t [15;17] and inv (16), can be present in the leukemic cells. AML is also seen before the age of one year old.
  • Treatment of AML can involve chemotherapy, radiation therapy, stem cell transplantation and targeted therapies, such as reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and arsenic trioxide.
  • Certain AML subtypes, such as AML with t (15;17) (PML/RARA), are sensitive to an additional treatment with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA).
  • ATRA therapy induces the terminal differentiation of the leukemic promyelocytes and can cause a unique side effect called the differentiation syndrome.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 317.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Endothelial damage
 
  • Endothelial injury plays a major role in initiating thrombus formation by exposing the underlying subendothelial collagen layer of the artery wall, providing a substrate for platelet adhesion, activation, and thrombus growth.
  • With the damage to the endothelial cell surface, the collagen layer becomes exposed and initiates platelet aggregation which serves as a nucleus for the formation of a thrombus.
  • Additionally, the endothelial injury releases factors that promote thrombosis such as thromboxane A2, platelet activating factor, VWF, and TF (tissue factor). These factors, in conjunction with the platelet aggregation, lead to further platelet adhesion and activation, further promoting the growth and stability of the thrombus.

Fig: The Virchow triad in Thrombosis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 76.

questions.text: Choose which of the given options can be found in biopsy of a post MI reperfusion surgery patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Endothelial contraction band
 
  • Microscopically, after reperfusion, irreversibly damaged myocytes develop contraction band necrosis.
  • In this pathological process, intense eosinophilic band of hypercontracted sarcomeres are created by an influx of calcium across plasma membrane that heightens actin - myosin interactions.
* Pathological mechanisms:
  • Oxidative stress- new damage may be initiated during reoxygenation by increased generation of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species.
  • Intracellular calcium overload- it is exacerbated during reperfusion due to influx of calcium resulting from cell membrane damage and ROS-mediated injury to sarcoplasmic reticulum. Calcium overload favors opening of the mitochondrial permeability transition pore with resultant ATP depletion.
  • Inflammation- The importance of neutrophil influx in reperfusion injury has been demonstrated experimentally by the salutary effects of treatment with antibodies that block cytokines or adhesion molecules and thereby reduce neutrophil extravasation.
  • Activation of the complement system may contribute to ischemia-reperfusion injury. 

For exam purpose remember 2 words related to Reperfusion Injury - Hemmorhagic Myocardium and Contraction Band Necrosis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 549.

questions.text: A child with 15 days of cough, examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Lymph node biopsy shows Langhans giant cells. What's the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Tuberculosis
 
  • The presence of cough for more than 2 weeks and cervical lymphadenopathy showing Langhans giant cells point towards a diagnosis of TB.
  • Langhans giant cells are giant cells found in granulomatous conditions.
  • They are formed by the fusion of epithelioid cells (macrophages) and contain nuclei arranged in a horseshoe-shaped pattern in the cell periphery. They are typically associated with TB.

Fig: Granulomatous Inflammation

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 100.

choices.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

questions.text: Choose the aetiology of Werner syndrome with premature ageing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

  • Telomeres are repeating sequences of DNA at the end of each chromosome which are essential for maintaining the stability and integrity of the genetic information contained within.
  • In Werner Syndrome (also known as Adult Progeria or WS), telomeres are abnormally short, resulting in a wide range of associated premature aging features, including a risk of metabolic disorders, cataracts, diabetes, thinning hair, and insulin resistance.
  • By shortening faster than usual, telomeres also cause the chromosomes themselves to become unstable, which can create further genetic damage, potentially leading to further accelerated aging.
  • Over time, these shorter telomeres can lead to cellular senescence, or aging, leading to such phenotypic features often seen in those affected with Werner Syndrome.
  • Increased glycation end products is seen in diabetes. 

Please try not to confuse it with Wermer syndrome which is basically MEN 1 syndrome

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 67.

questions.text: A 30 year old female having retroperitoneal swelling supported by biopsy seen, t(12:16) diagnosed. Find the suggestive Dx
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Myxoid Liposarcoma

The three distinct subtypes of liposarcoma, well-differentiated, myxoid, and pleomorphic, have different genetic aberrations.
  1. Well-differentiated liposarcomas harbor amplifications of chromosome region 12q13–q15, which includes the p53 inhibitor MDM2.
  2. In myxoid liposarcoma, a fusion gene generated by a t(12;16) translocation arrests adipocyte differentiation, leading to unregulated proliferation of primitive cells.
  3. Pleomorphic liposarcomas have complex karyotypes without reproducible genetic abnormalities.

* [Extra Edge]: Diagnostic features of myxoid Liposarcoma 
  • Gross Features: Myxoid liposarcoma has a characteristic gross appearance that can help in diagnosis. It is generally found as an encapsulated mass within the soft tissue of the extremities. The external surface is typically smooth, with a relatively soft and yellow-white cut surface. On cut sections, numerous cystic spaces, are usually present.
  • Histologic Features: Microscopic examination reveals a lipogenic lesion composed of myxoid stroma and atypical lipoblasts. Perivascular and peri adnexal localizations of tumor cells may also be observed. Additionally, the presence of pleomorphic spindle cells and unfamiliar round cells, along with intracellular mucin, is suggestive of a malignant liposarcoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1209.

questions.text: Which amino acid is Nitric oxide (NO) derived from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) L-arginine
 
  • In humans, NO is synthesized from the amino acid arginine with the aid of several different enzymes, including the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
  • NOS catalyzes the formation of NO from arginine and oxygen by transferring a terminal guanidino nitrogen to form L-citrulline. This reaction is coupled to the hydrolysis of NADPH and the overall reaction involves five steps known as the nitric oxide synthase (NOS) pathway.
  • First, arginine is converted to N-hydroxy arginine, followed by a series of electron transfer reactions within the NOS enzyme. Then, the N-hydroxyarginine is converted to citrulline, and nitric oxide is released. Finally, the citrulline is converted back to arginine, completing the cycle. Together, these steps form the nitric oxide synthesizing reaction from arginine in humans.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 83.

questions.text: What forms the genetic basis of synthesis of Apolipoprotein B48?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) RNA editing
 

  • Apolipoprotein B-48 (apoB-48) is a remnant of RNA editing, which is a post-transcriptional process of altering the primary sequence of an RNA molecule after it is transcribed from a gene in the genome.
  • RNA editing can involve the addition, removal, or substitution of specific nucleotides in an RNA molecule. This process helps to diversify the proteins encoded by different genes and has been identified in a variety of organisms, including humans.
  • ApoB-48 is a truncated form of ApoB-100, the primary apolipoprotein found in chylomicrons, which are particles produced by the small intestine and involved in the absorption of dietary fats and cholesterol.
  • ApoB-48 is produced through a process of somatic (or “adult”) RNA editing and is found in blood plasma and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein) particles. It has been shown to play a role in the metabolism of cholesterol, chylomicron remnant uptake, and bile acid homeostasis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 698.

questions.text: Where is intrinsic and extrinsic pathway seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Apoptosis

Apoptosis can occur via an intrinsic or extrinsic pathway.
  1. The intrinsic pathway involves the release of cytochrome C from the inner surface of the mitochondria and release of SMAC/DIABLO from mitochondria.
  2. The extrinsic pathway is activated by TRAIL and Fas Ligand (which binds to CD95-Fas). The initiator caspase in the mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway is caspase 9 while in extrinsic pathway is caspase 8 and 10.
Option 3 Necroptosis- this form of cell death is a hybrid that shares aspects of both necrosis and apoptosis. Morphologically, and to some extent biochemically, it resembles necrosis, as both are characterized by loss of ATP, swelling of the cell and organelles, generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately rupture of the plasma membrane.
Option 4 Pyroptosis- this is a form of apoptosis that is accompanied by the release of the fever-inducing cytokine IL-1.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 45.

choices.text: a, b, c and d are correct

questions.text:
Proto-oncogene to Oncogene transformation occurs by:
a. Point mutation
b. Promoter initiation
c. Amplification
d. Enhancer insertion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) a, b, c and d are correct

* Oncogenes can develop from proto-oncogenes through the following mechanisms:
  • Proto-oncogene point mutations, deletions, or insertions that result in increased transcription.
  • Gene amplification processes that result in extra proto-oncogene chromosomal copies.
  • Chromosomal translocations that result in the fusion of a proto-oncogene with a different gene to create a fusion protein with cancer-causing properties.
  • Insertion mutagenesis: Both the promoter and enhancer regions result in an increase in gene function. C-Myc amplification by oncogenic viruses is the best example.
               
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 324.

questions.text: Arrange the following inflammatory cellular activities in the correct order: i. Rolling ii. Tissue migration iii. Endothelial adhesion iv. Margination
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) iv - i - iii- ii

The multistep process by which leukocytes travel from the vessel lumen to the tissue is mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines known as chemokines.
1. Margination, rolling, and endothelium adhesion in the lumen.
2. Migration along the vessel wall and endothelium.
3. Tissue migration in response to a chemotactic stimulation.


Fig: Inflammatory cellular activities

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 77.

choices.text: Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area viable and grey area necrosed.
Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area necrosed and grey area viable.

questions.text: The sliced liver of a patient who passed away from heart failure is depicted in the following image. Which of the following statements is true based on the specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area necrosed and grey area viable.
 
  • The given image in the question shows the nutmeg appearance of liver typically seen in chronic venous congestion of liver.
  • It is seen during right heart failure resulting in congestion of blood in the systemic organs. Because of chronic venous congestion, there is back pressure on the hepatic veins (central veins) resulting in necrosis of the central region which appears dark in color (centrilobular necrosis and periportal fibrosis). The periportal region remains viable and is grey in color.

Fig: Chronic Venous Congestion microscopic examination (nutmeg liver)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 517.

choices.text: can be used during sentinel lymph node biopsy
helps to check for negative tumor margins

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about frozen sections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) provides definitive diagnosis in all cancers

*[Extra Edge]: Frozen section in Diagnostic Pathology

  • It is a pathological laboratory procedure done to perform rapid microscopic analysis of a specimen. Mainly used in oncological surgery. 
  • It can be used for diagnosis in many cases, but quality of slides produced is lower compared to formalin fixed paraffin embedded tissue processing (gives more accurate diagnosis).
  • Intraoperative assessment of resected specimens to check whether resection margins are clear of the tumor.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy to check for presence of tumor in dissected lymph nodes, to check for suspected metastasis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 275.

questions.text: What is the most common retroperitoneal tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Liposarcoma

Most common retroperitoneal tumor is Liposarcoma. It is commonly seen in 5th to 7th decade of life with no specific gender predilection. 
 

They are classified histologically into five types-

  • well differentiated liposarcoma

    • also known as atypical lipomatous tumor

    • most common (~50%) 

    • has the highest amount of fat content

  • myxoid liposarcoma / round cell

    • second most common

    • intermediate grade (myxoid) or high grade (round cell)

    • balanced chromosomal translocation t(12,16)

  • dedifferentiated liposarcoma

    • high grade, aggressive with frequent metastases

  • pleomorphic liposarcoma

    • least common

    • high grade, aggressive with frequent metastases

  • myxoid pleomorphic

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1213.

questions.text: In HPE, which fixation technique is used for fat?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option ) Frozen section

A frozen section is done for the fixation of fats. This ensures that the tissue need not to go through routine processing, which can remove lipids.

When tissue sample goes through rapid freezing, it becomes firmer. the ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned.

The goal of fixation is to create the matrix of cross-links to immobilize proteins that make up the tissue.As our body is made up of all kinds of proteins and lipids, carbohydrates, etc., creating a matrix of cross-links is incredibly important. Once we do that, we stop autolysis which is the self-destruction of the tissue. Stopping autolysis prevents the tissue from acting upon itself as well as breaks down those intracellular proteins that will also prevent decomposition.



Reference: Wintrobe's Clinical hematology, 13 th edition, Page no. 43

Online Reference: Rachel C Hart, Darian T Carroll, Maria Vinogradova, Evan S Krystofiak, A Guide to Fixation and Staining of Biological Samples for Electron Microscopy, Microscopy Today, Volume 32, Issue 2, March 2024, Pages 37–40, https://doi.org/10.1093/mictod/qaae009

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient has a PAP Smear with hyperchromatic nuclei and poor maturation index pleomorphism that affects nearly all thickness. What is the name of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dysplasia
 
  1. Metaplasia: Metaplasia is a reversible process in which one type of adult cell is replaced by another type of adult cell that is not typical for that tissue. This adaptive change occurs in response to chronic irritation or inflammation and is meant to protect the underlying tissues from the adverse environment. For example, in the respiratory tract of smokers, the normal ciliated columnar epithelial cells may be replaced by stratified squamous epithelial cells.
  2. Hyperplasia: Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue, resulting in its enlargement. In epithelium it may be seen as increased thickness.
  3. Carcinoma: Dysplasia with basement membrane invasion
  4. Dysplasia: It is a loss in the uniformity of individual cells and in their architectural orientation. Dysplastic cells exhibit considerable pleomorphism and often possess hyperchromatic nuclei that are abnormally large for the size of the cell. Mitotic figures are more abundant than usual and frequently appear in abnormal locations within the epithelium.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 7.

choices.text: Total number of times a cell can divide in their lifetime
Total number of times a cell can divide in a year
Total number of times a cell can divide in a month
Total number of times a cell can divide in a day

questions.text: Define Hayflick limit:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Total number of times a cell can divide in their lifetime

Hayflick limit is total number of times a cell can divide in their lifetime.
Abolition of telomerase activity results in telomere shortening, a process that eventually destabilizes the ends of chromosomes, leading to genomic instability and cell growth arrest or death.
Therefore, telomere shortening leads to the attainment of the Hayflick limit.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3734.

questions.text: Apoptosome component with cytochrome C and APAF 1 is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Procaspase 9

Components of apoptosome with cytochrome C and APAF 1 is procaspase 9.
In the intrinsic pathway, caspase activation requires the formation of an activating complex called an apoptosome.
This complex is made up of four components, including
  • cytochrome c
  • apoptosis-activating factor 1 (Apaf-1)
  • adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and
  • procaspase-9
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 45.

questions.text: Which of the following outcomes occurs in acute inflammation caused by the retraction of endothelial cell cytoskeleton?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Early transient increase in permeability
 
  • Contraction of endothelial cells resulting in opening of inter-endothelial gaps is the most common mechanism of vascular leakage. It is elicited by histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienes, and other chemical mediators. It is called the immediate transient response because it occurs rapidly after exposure to the mediator and is usually short-lived (15 to 30 minutes).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 76.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman has been receiving hemodialysis for the past 8 years and has renal failure. She experienced Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.
Which of the following amyloid types will be linked to it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Beta-2 microglobulin
 
  • Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure develop amyloidosis as a result of deposition of beta-microglobulin deposition.
  • Amyloidosis is a pathological proteinaceous substance deposited between cells in various tissues and organs of the body.
  • Common Biopsy sites in Amyloidosis: Subcutaneous abdominal at aspirate, Rectum, Skin.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 264.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers is least likely to spread lymphatically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Basal cell carcinoma
 
  • Basal cell carcinoma is a distinctive locally aggressive cutaneous tumor that is associated with mutations that activate the Hedgehog signaling pathway.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a type of skin cancer that is not associated with lymphatic spread because it is a slow growing, relatively non-aggressive form of skin cancer.
  • It typically only affects the skin, staying within its layers and not spreading through the lymph nodes or elsewhere in the body. Because of this, BCC is often curable and rarely deadly.
  • The vast majority are recognized at an early stage and cured by local excision. However, a small number of tumors (<0.5%) are locally aggressive and potentially disfiguring, and on rare occasions metastasis to distant sites is seen.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1147.

questions.text: CD 95 is a marker of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Extrinsic pathway of apoptosis
 
  • CD-95 is a marker of extrinsic pathway of apoptosis
  • Fas receptor (FasR) also called CD95 is a member of TNF-R death receptor subfamily localized on the surface of various cells and triggers a signal transduction pathway leading to apoptosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 45.

questions.text: A patient of more than 70 years, presented with generalized lymphadenopathy, WBC count was 20,000/mm3 and blood film showed >70% mature looking lymphocytes. Next investigation that should be done:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Peripheral Immunophenotyping
 
  • The above clinical features are suggestive of CLL (Chronic lymphocytic leukemia).
  • Immunophenotyping will eliminate the other T-cell disorders and can often help sort other B-cell malignancies.
  • CLL/SLL has a distinctive immunophenotype- The tumor cells express the pan B-cell markers CD19 and CD20, as well as CD23 and CD5, the latter a marker that is found on a small subset of normal B cells. Low-level expression of surface Ig (usually IgM or IgM and IgD) is also typical, as is high-level expression of BCL2.
  • If Flow cytometry was in the option it would have been a better answer 
Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia- Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 597.

questions.text: What is the most popular fixative for electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glutaraldehyde

Most common fixative used in electron microscopy is glutaraldehyde.
Glutaraldehyde is good for electron microscopy as it fixes quickly.

Online Reference: Wisse E, Braet F, Duimel H, Vreuls C, Koek G, Olde Damink SW, van den Broek MA, De Geest B, Dejong CH, Tateno C, Frederik P. Fixation methods for electron microscopy of human and other liver. World J Gastroenterol. 2010 Jun 21;16(23):2851-66. doi: 10.3748/wjg.v16.i23.2851. PMID: 20556830; PMCID: PMC2887580.

questions.text: Which staining is done for sebaceous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Oil Red O
 
  • Stain used for staining sebaceous cell carcinoma is oil red 'O'
  • If a frozen section of sebaceous cell carcinoma is stained with oil red 'O' or Sudan black stain the vacuolated cells shows abundant lipid.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 787.

questions.text: Which is the main collagen type in a completely healed scar mark?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (1): Type 1 Collagen
 

The main collagen type in a completely healed scar mark is 1. Type 1 collagen.

During the healing process, type 3 collagen is initially laid down in the wound, but as the scar matures, it is gradually replaced by type 1 collagen, which provides greater tensile strength and structural integrity to the healed tissue.

Type of Collagen 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 23.

questions.text: The following aneuploidy is due to an defective mitosis leading to cells with different chromosome numbers within the same individual.:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Mosaicism
 
  • Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes in a cell.
  • Errors during cell division can lead to aneuploidy.
  • Mosaicism is a type of aneuploidy that occurs due to errors in mitosis, leading to cells with different chromosome numbers within the same individual.
Other options:
  • Uniparental disomy refers to the inheritance of both chromosomes of a homologous pair from a single parent.
  • Monosomy is the presence of only one copy of a particular chromosome.
  • Trisomy is the presence of an additional copy of a particular chromosome.
* [Extra Edge]: Chromosomal Abnormality



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: Dystrophy calcification can be observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Tuberculoma
 
  • Dystrophic calcification refers to the deposition of calcium in areas of tissue damage or necrosis.
  • It occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium levels and is not caused by systemic calcium imbalances.
  • Tuberculoma is a granulomatous lesion caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • In chronic tuberculosis infection, caseous necrosis and subsequent calcification can occur, leading to dystrophic calcification.
* Other options:
  • Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by increased serum calcium levels and can lead to metastatic calcification in various tissues.
  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that can cause non-caseating granulomas but is not typically associated with dystrophic calcification.
*[Extra Edge]: Dystrophic Calcification Vs Metastatic Calcification



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 65.

questions.text: The following is a cause of systemic amyloidosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Lymphoma
 
  • Amyloidosis is a group of disorders characterized by the extracellular deposition of abnormal insoluble protein fibrils called amyloid.
  • Systemic amyloidosis refers to the involvement of multiple organs/systems
  • In Lymphoma, an abnormal protein called serum amyloid A (SAA) is produced secondary to chronic inflammation, which can lead to systemic amyloidosis.
* Other options:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma /Alzheimer's disease and Type 2 diabetes mellitus are associated with localized Amyloidosis. 

* [Extra Edge]: Types of Amyloidosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 262.

questions.text: What is an example of Acute Pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Fat Necrosis
 
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammatory condition of the pancreas characterized by autodigestion of pancreatic tissue.
  • Fat necrosis is a characteristic feature of acute pancreatitis, where pancreatic enzymes cause damage to adipose tissue, leading to the release of fatty acids and formation of calcium soaps( saponification). 
* Other options:
  • Liquefactive necrosis is a type of necrosis characterized by the formation of a liquid, viscous mass in the affected tissue, commonly seen in conditions such as abscesses or brain infarction.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is a type of necrosis associated with immune-mediated reactions and is typically observed in blood vessels in conditions such as vasculitis.
  • In Coagulative necrosis, the architectural structure of the tissue is preserved, but the cells undergo irreversible injury and denaturation.
* [Extra Edge]: Type of Necrosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 41.

questions.text: What are the secondary morphogenetic errors that result from the destruction of an organ that was formerly developing normally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Disruption
 
  • Secondary morphogenetic errors are abnormalities that occur during organ development due to external factors disrupting normal developmental processes.
  • Disruption refers to the destruction or damage of a previously developing organ or structure, leading to the formation of secondary abnormalities.
* Other options:
  • Malformation refers to primary errors in organ development that occur during embryogenesis and result in structural abnormalities.
  • Deformation refers to abnormalities in organ shape or structure due to mechanical forces acting on a developing organ.
  • Association refers to a non-random occurrence of multiple anomalies that are not causally related but often coexist in the same individual.
* [Extra Edge]: General pathology terms with definitions



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about irreversible cell injury is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Cytoplasmic vacuolization
 
  • Irreversible cell injury refers to cellular damage that is beyond the point of recovery and leads to cell death.
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolization is a characteristic feature of reversible cell injury, not irreversible cell injury.
  • Clumping of nuclear chromatin, lysosomal rupture, and degradation of membrane phospholipids are all features of irreversible cell injury.
  • During irreversible cell injury, the cells undergo extensive damage to various cellular components, leading to loss of cell membrane integrity, organelle dysfunction, and ultimately cell death.
* [Extra Edge]: Reversible Vs Irreversible Cell Injury



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding apoptosis are true except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Cellular swelling
 
  • Apoptosis is a programmed cell death process that plays a crucial role in maintaining tissue homeostasis and eliminating damaged or unwanted cells.
  • Cellular swelling is not a characteristic feature of apoptosis. It is more commonly observed in reversible cell injury or necrosis.
  • Nuclear compaction, intact cell membrane, and cytoplasmic eosinophilia are all features of apoptosis.
  • Apoptotic cells typically show nuclear condensation, membrane blebbing, and fragmentation into membrane-bound apoptotic bodies.
Apoptosis Vs Necrosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: Apple Green birefringence in Amyloid is observed on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Polarized light
 
  • The histologic diagnosis of amyloid is based almost entirely on its staining characteristics.
  • The most common staining technique uses the dye Congo red, which under ordinary light imparts a pink or red color to amyloid deposits. Under polarized light, the Congo red–stained amyloid shows so-called apple-green birefringence. 
  • This reaction is shared by all forms of amyloid and is caused by the cross-β-pleated configuration of amyloid fibrils.


Fig: Polarizing microscope image of amyloidosis
