Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 260.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about red infarcts is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): End-Arterial occlusion
 
  • Red infarcts occur in organs with dual blood supply or in tissues with significant collateral circulation.
  • They are characterized by hemorrhage into the infarcted area, giving a red appearance.
  • Red infarcts can occur due to venous occlusion or reperfusion injury.
  • In end-arterial occlusion, such as in the heart or kidney, the infarcted area lacks collateral circulation and typically shows pale or white appearance (pale infarcts), not red.
  • Ill-defined margins are a characteristic feature of red infarcts.
* [Extra Edge]: Infarct Type




Fig: Red and white infarcts

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 133.

questions.text: All of the following are trinucleotide repeating disorders which occur in the non coding / intron regions except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (4): Huntington Disease 
 
  • Fragile X Syndrome, Friedrich Ataxia, and Myotonic Dystrophy are all genetic disorders caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions in non-coding regions of the respective genes.
  • However, Huntington Disease is characterized by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CAG repeat) in the coding region of the huntingtin (HTT) gene.
  • This repeat expansion leads to the production of an abnormal huntington protein, which causes neuronal degeneration and the clinical manifestations of Huntington Disease.

Trinucleotide Repeat Disorder



Mnemonic:  All trinucleotide repeat diroders occur in non coding regions except SHEK- Spinocerebellar ataxia,Huntington which are Exon and K(C)oding

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1285.

questions.text: Reversible polarity loss accompanied by pleomorphism is observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Dysplasia
 
  • Dysplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by reversible polarity loss, cellular pleomorphism (variations in size, shape, and staining characteristics), and abnormal cellular organization.
  • Dysplastic cells exhibit loss of uniformity, altered nuclear size and shape, increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and disordered cellular arrangement.
* Other options:
  • Metaplasia refers to the reversible change in which one adult cell type is replaced by another adult cell type
  • Anaplasia is the loss of cellular differentiation and reversion to a more primitive, undifferentiated state.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 272.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hypertrophic scars is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Disorganized collagen
 
  • Hypertrophic scars are characterized by excessive deposition of collagen in the dermis, resulting in raised, thickened scars.
  • They are confined to the wound margins and do not extend beyond the boundaries of the original injury.
  • Hypertrophic scars are generally not associated with disorganized collagen, as the collagen fibers are densely packed and oriented parallel to the epidermis.
The other options, including being confined to wound margins, regressing spontaneously, and having infrequent recurrence, are true statements about hypertrophic scars.

* [Extra Edge]: Keloid Vs Hypertrophic Scars


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: Which statement regarding both MPO deficiency and Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Hypochlorite is absent
 
  • Myeloperoxidase (MPO) deficiency and Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) are both disorders affecting neutrophil function.
  • In MPO deficiency, the enzyme MPO, which is responsible for generating hypochlorite (a potent antimicrobial agent), is absent or deficient.
  • In CGD, the defect lies in the NADPH oxidase system, which leads to impaired respiratory burst and reduced production of reactive oxygen species (including hypochlorite).
  • Therefore, the correct statement is that hypochlorite is absent in both MPO deficiency and CGD.
  • The other options, including the absence of NADPH oxidase and abnormal NBT (nitro blue tetrazolium) test, are specific to CGD.

* [Extra Edge]: Immunodeficiency Disorder



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 241.

questions.text: What is the name of non-neoplastic organised salivary gland tissue in the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Choristoma
 
  • Choristoma refers to the presence of normal tissue in an abnormal location.
  • In the middle ear, the presence of non-neoplastic organized salivary gland tissue is known as a choristoma.
  • It is believed to occur due to abnormal embryological development or displacement of tissue during embryogenesis.
  • Choristomas can occur in various locations throughout the body and can consist of different types of tissues.
  • In the context of the middle ear, the presence of salivary gland tissue is an example of a choristoma.
Memorizing trick:- 
Choristoma- Chori (Theft)- Normal tissue is stolen and kept in abnormal location- normal tissue abnormal location 
Hamartoma- Hamara( Ours)- Abnormal tissue at normal location 

* [Extra Edge]:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 270.

questions.text: Which of the following cutaneous cancers does not metastasize through the lymphatics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Basal cell carcinoma
 
  • Basal cell carcinoma is a common type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells in the epidermis.
  • Unlike squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma, and Kaposi's sarcoma, basal cell carcinoma tends to grow locally and rarely metastasizes.
  • It typically remains confined to the site of origin and does not spread through the lymphatic system to distant sites in the body.
* [Extra Edge]: Types of skin cancer


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1147.

questions.text: Except for________, all of the following leukotrienes are vasoconstrictors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Leukotriene B4
 
  • Leukotrienes are bioactive lipid mediators derived from arachidonic acid metabolism.
  • Leukotriene B4 (LTB4) is the only leukotriene that does not exhibit vasoconstrictor activity.
  • In contrast, leukotriene C4 (LTC4), leukotriene D4 (LTD4), and leukotriene E4 (LTE4) are potent vasoconstrictors that can cause constriction of blood vessels and contribute to inflammatory processes.
* [Extra Edge]: Functions of Leukotrienes


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 680.

questions.text: Which cytokine that causes macrophages to become activated and transform into giant cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): IFN gamma
 
  • Interferon-gamma (IFN gamma) is a cytokine primarily produced by activated T cells and natural killer (NK) cells.
  • It plays a crucial role in immune responses, including the activation of macrophages.
  • IFN gamma stimulates macrophages to become activated and exhibit enhanced phagocytic and antigen-presenting capabilities.
  • In certain pathological conditions, such as granulomatous inflammation, activated macrophages may fuse together to form multinucleated giant cells under the influence of IFN gamma.
* [Extra Edge]: Cytokines involved in granuloma formation


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 98.

questions.text: What is the best way to define the deletion of one alpha globin gene on one chromosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Alpha Thalassemia silent carrier 
 
  • The deletion of one alpha globin gene on one chromosome is best defined as alpha thalassemia silent carrier.
  • It refers to a carrier state where an individual has one deleted alpha globin gene on one chromosome but maintains normal hemoglobin production.
  • The term "silent" indicates that individuals with this condition are usually asymptomatic and do not exhibit any clinical manifestations of alpha thalassemia.
  • In contrast, alpha thalassemia trait and alpha thalassemia major involve more severe deletions or mutations in the alpha globin genes and can result in clinical symptoms and abnormal hemoglobin production.

* [Extra Edge]: Thalassemia Types


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

questions.text: Large platelets and Dohle bodies in neutrophils are seen in which of the following autosomal dominant condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): May-Hegglin Anomaly
 
  • Large platelets and Dohle bodies in neutrophils are seen in the May-Hegglin Anomaly.
  • The May-Hegglin Anomaly is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by abnormal platelets and leukocytes.
  • The May-Hegglin Anomaly is caused by mutations in the MYH9 gene, which encodes for the non-muscle myosin heavy chain IIA.
  • Large platelets are a characteristic feature of this condition and can be observed on a blood smear.
  • Dohle bodies are basophilic inclusions found in the cytoplasm of neutrophils and are associated with abnormal RNA synthesis.
Option A- Alder Reilly Anomaly
  • Rare autosomal recessive disorder with large, dark-staining cytoplasmic granules in leukocytes and other cells.
  • Associated with defects in lysosomal enzymes and can cause skeletal abnormalities and intellectual disability.

Option B- Pelger-Huet Anomaly
  • Autosomal dominant disorder with abnormal nuclear segmentation in neutrophils.
  • Neutrophils have hypo segmented nuclei, but the condition is typically benign and does not cause significant health problems.

Option D- Chediak-Higashi Syndrome
  • Rare autosomal recessive disorder with impaired lysosomal trafficking and fusion in cells.
  • Characterized by recurrent infections, partial albinism, and peripheral neuropathy. Neutrophils show giant granules and defective phagocytosis.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 907.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for generating 'oxygen burst' within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): NADPH Oxidase  
 
  • NADPH oxidase is the enzyme responsible for generating the 'oxygen burst' within neutrophils.
  • This burst involves the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide anion (O2-) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which are crucial for killing intracellular bacteria.
  • NADPH oxidase transfers electrons from NADPH to molecular oxygen, generating superoxide anion in the process.
  • Deficiencies in NADPH oxidase activity lead to impaired bacterial killing and are seen in disorders such as Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).
* [Extra Edge]: Immunodeficiency Disorder



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 82.

questions.text: Out of the following organelles which play a pivotal role in Apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Mitochondria
 
  • Mitochondria play a pivotal role in apoptosis, the process of programmed cell death.
  • Mitochondria release cytochrome c, which activates the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway of apoptosis.
  • Cytochrome c interacts with apoptotic protease-activating factor 1 (Apaf-1) and procaspase-9, forming the apoptosome complex that initiates the caspase cascade.
  • This cascade ultimately leads to cell death by activating executioner caspases and initiating the breakdown of cellular components.
* [Extra Edge]: Apoptosis Vs Necrosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 45.

questions.text: All of the following enzymes may contribute in generating free oxygen/free radicals within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (4) Glutathione Peroxidase 

Glutathione peroxidase is not involved in generating free oxygen radicals within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria. Glutathione peroxidase plays a role in reducing hydrogen peroxide and lipid peroxides, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage. 







Other options
  • Myeloperoxidase combines H202 with Cl- resulting in geneatin of Hypochlorite (HOCl) ion which is a potent bactericidal and kills bacteria. 
  • Fenton's reaction involves the reaction between hydrogen peroxide and ferrous ions to generate hydroxyl radicals (OH·).
  • NADPH oxidase generates superoxide anion (O2-) as part of the respiratory burst in neutrophils.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 82.

questions.text: Most characteristic feature of acute inflammation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vasodilatation and Increased vascular permeability 
 
  • Vasodilatation and increased vascular permeability are the most characteristic features of acute inflammation.
  • Vasodilatation leads to increased blood flow to the affected area, resulting in redness and heat.
  • Increased vascular permeability allows the passage of fluid, proteins, and leukocytes from the blood vessels into the surrounding tissues, leading to swelling and edema.
  • These vascular changes are essential for the recruitment of inflammatory cells and the delivery of plasma proteins and immune mediators to the site of injury or infection.
* [Extra Edge]: Acute Inflammation Vs Chronic Inflammation


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 75.

questions.text: All of the following statements about Xanthogranulomatous inflammation are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Associated with Tuberculosis
 
  • Xanthogranulomatous inflammation is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by the presence of foam cells, yellow nodules, and multinucleated giant cells.
  • The condition is associated with chronic infections, most commonly involving the urinary tract, such as pyelonephritis or cholecystitis.
  • Xanthogranulomatous inflammation is not specifically associated with tuberculosis. It can occur due to various other bacterial infections.
  • Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis occurs when chronic urinary obstruction (often by staghorn calculi), together with chronic infection, leads to suppurative destruction of renal tissue.
  • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis, the gallbladder has a massively thickened wall and is shrunken, nodular, and chronically inflamed with foci of necrosis and hemorrhage.
     
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 876.

questions.text: In order to confirm systemic amyloidosis, which of the following initial biopsy sites is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Abdominal fat 
 
  • The deposition of amyloid can occur in various organs in systemic amyloidosis.
  • The abdominal fat pad biopsy is preferred for the following reasons (Other sites - kidney or rectal mucosa, can also be used but abdominal fat is the most preferred initial site).
  1. Abdominal fat is easily accessible and has a high yield for detecting amyloid deposits.
  2. Congo red staining of the abdominal fat pad can reveal the characteristic apple-green birefringence under polarized light, confirming the presence of amyloid.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 264.

questions.text: Which of the following would indicate a mixed connective tissue disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): UI-RNP antibody
 
  • Mixed connective tissue disorder (MCTD) is a rheumatic autoimmune condition that shares features of several connective tissue diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.
  • MCTD is characterized by the presence of high titers of antibodies against U1 ribonucleoprotein (UI-RNP antibody).
  • The UI-RNP antibody is specific to MCTD and distinguishes it from other connective tissue diseases.
  • Clinical features of MCTD include joint pain, Raynaud's phenomenon, muscle weakness, and a high prevalence of pulmonary hypertension.
  • MCTD typically has a good response to treatment with immunosuppressive agents.
* [Extra Edge]: Various Autoantibodies associated conditions



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 234.

questions.text: Which is an exception to seeing Psammoma bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid 
 
  • Psammoma bodies are concentrically laminated calcific structures that can be seen within the stroma of certain tumors.
  • They are most commonly associated with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, serous papillary cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, and meningioma.
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is an exception to seeing Psammoma bodies.
  • Follicular carcinoma is characterized by the presence of follicular structures and invasion into blood vessels or thyroid capsule but typically does not exhibit the formation of Psammoma bodies.

Fig: Psammoma Bodies 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 950.

questions.text: In diagnostic pathology which of the following is the most commonly used 'fixative'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Formaldehyde
 
  • Formaldehyde, in the form of formalin, is a widely used fixative for preserving tissue samples for histological examination.
  • It works by cross-linking proteins and nucleic acids, thereby stabilizing cellular structures and preventing tissue degradation.
  • Formaldehyde fixation allows for the preservation of tissue architecture and cellular morphology, enabling accurate microscopic evaluation.
  • It is compatible with various staining techniques and is the standard fixative for routine histopathology.
Online Reference: Rachel C Hart, Darian T Carroll, Maria Vinogradova, Evan S Krystofiak, A Guide to Fixation and Staining of Biological Samples for Electron Microscopy, Microscopy Today, Volume 32, Issue 2, March 2024, Pages 37–40, https://doi.org/10.1093/mictod/qaae009

questions.text: Identify the one which is not a feature of exudate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Proteins < 3 gm
 
  • Exudate is a type of fluid that accumulates in tissues or body cavities as a result of inflammation or injury.
  • It is characterized by a high protein content (> 3 gm/dL) compared to transudate.
  • Other features of exudate include:
    • Cells > 1000/mm³, predominantly neutrophils.
    • Cloudy appearance due to the presence of inflammatory cells and debris.
    • Elevated levels of inflammatory markers, such as cytokines and acute-phase reactants.
* [Extra Edge]: Exudate Vs Transudate


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text: A 40 years old white raced male presented with a slow growing small nodule on the nose medial to inner canthus of eye. Later on, it ulcerated. Biopsy of the lesion was done and the histopathological image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a slow growing nodule on face and histopathological image showing peripheral palisading makes the diagnosis go in favor of basal cell carcinoma. 

Basal cell carcinoma does not show any distant metastasis as the tumor tends to destroy its own lymphatic supply. 

Management is by Moh's microscopic surgery. 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 651.

questions.text: What is the route of metastasis of carcinoma prostate to lumbar vertebra:
questions.solution:
Carcinoma of prostate commonly spreads to lumbar vertebra through prostatic veous plexus which in turn into prevertebral venous plexus of Batson. 

It commonly gives rise to osteoblastic metastasis. 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1468-1473.

questions.text: A young female developed a slow growing mass in the middle anterior part of the neck. After few months, she had enlargement of cervical lymph nodes on both the sides. She was subjected to biopsy and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is NOT the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with histopathological finding of Orphan Annie Eye nuclei goes in favor of papillary cancer of thyroid. 

Option A- Papillary Ca of thyroid shows a characteristic appearance of nucleus known as Orphan Annie Eye due to preinucleolar clearing. 

Option B- It carries an excellent prognosis among the thyroid cancers.

Option C- It can be diagnosed on FNAC unlike follicular carcinoma. It can be diagnosed on FNAC just on the basis of its nuclear features. 

Option D- It commonly spreads via lymphatics. Lungs are the most common site for distant metastasis for papillary Ca of thyroid. 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 817-819.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1087-1089.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
MEN 2B syndrome also known as MEN 3 occurs due to mutation of RET proto oncogene on chromosome 10. 

The associated conditions are-

Medullary Ca of thyroid, Pheochromocytoma, Mucosal neuromas, Marfanoid habitus, Medullated corneal nerve fibers and megacolon 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2983, 2988-2990.

questions.text: Match the following - Method of collecting the sample
questions.solution:
• Marjolin ulcer on the foot (3x2 cm) can be diagnosed by a wedge biopsy, which involves removing a small wedge-shaped piece of tissue for examination. Wedge biopsy is usually performed for lesions where not only length and breadth but also depth of specimen is important like Marjolin ulcer/subcutaneous mycosis etc.
 
  • Sarcoma on the thigh (8x4 cm) can be diagnosed by using a core needle biopsy, which involves inserting a larger needle into the nodule to collect a sample of tissue. A small and superficial tumor(<2 cm) could be diagnosed with an excision biopsy but for large tumors - A core needle is preferred. 
 
  • A single cervical lymph node (1.5x 2 cm) can be diagnosed by excisional biopsy. It is the appropriate method for collecting a sample in this case, as it involves removing the entire node and the entire nodal architecture can be seen for an appropriate diagnosis. 
 
  • Solitary nodules on the thyroid can be diagnosed by using a fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) guided by ultrasound.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 235, 741, 809, 862.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true? 
(i) GIST : KIT 
(ii) Lung carcinoma : K-Ras-amplification 
(iii) Breast carcinoma : ERBB 
(iv) Astrocytoma : PDGFR-beta
questions.solution:
• Astrocytoma is associated with overexpression of PDGF-beta, NOT PDGFR-beta.
  • PDGFR-beta amplification is associated with Glioma and Leukemia.
 

  1. GIST : KIT (i)
    True. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are commonly associated with mutations in the KIT gene, which encodes for the CD117 (c-KIT) receptor tyrosine kinase.

  2. Lung carcinoma : K-Ras amplification (ii)
    Partially true. While K-Ras mutations are frequently observed in lung adenocarcinoma, amplification of K-Ras is also seen in 30% of cases of Adenocarcinoma.

  3. Breast carcinoma : ERBB (iii)
    True. ERBB2 (HER2), a member of the EGFR family, is frequently amplified in certain subtypes of breast carcinoma, driving tumor growth and progression.




Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 285, 287, 717, 779, 813, 814, 1046.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about sirtuins are true? 
(i) \(\uparrow\) insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism 
(ii) Promote genes that increase longevity 
(iii) 7 types 
(iv) It's a type of histone deacetylase
questions.solution:
• Sirtuins are a family of signaling proteins involved in metabolic regulation.
  • All the above statements regarding sirtuins are true.


Functions of Sirtuins:
 
  1. Regulation of aging and longevity
  2. Metabolic regulation
  3. Stress resistance
  4. Regulation of inflammation
  5. Epigenetic regulation
  6. Mitochondrial function and biogenesis
  7. Regulation of apoptosis
  8. Cancer suppression and tumor progression
  9. Cardiovascular health
  10. Neuroprotection


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: Which among the following is an X linked dominant disorder?
questions.solution:

  • It affects mainly females, with a prevalence of 1 in 10,000.
  • The clinical features of Rett syndrome include regression of acquired skills, repetitive hand movements, breathing abnormalities, seizures, and intellectual disability.
  • It follows an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern. 

Inheritance patterns and defective genes of other disorders mentioned in the options

questions.text: Cell in cell appearance is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Entosis is a phenomenon where one cell invades and takes up residence inside another cell. This process is known as "cell-in-cell" formation and can occur in various physiological and pathological conditions. Entosis has been observed in many types of cells, including epithelial cells, immune cells, and cancer cells.
  • During entosis, a cell actively engulfs another cell, forming a structure called an entotic vacuole. The engulfed cell can survive for a period of time within the entotic vacuole, but eventually, it undergoes cell death or is extruded from the host cell. The mechanism underlying entosis is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve changes in adhesion molecules, actin cytoskeleton, and apoptotic pathways.

   

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 39,40,42,44,46,47 .

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of surgery presents with the following finding at the scar site. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
The patient with the previous history of surgery has inspection findings of a large area of scar tissue which has failed to regress within a year and expands beyond the boundaries of the original wound margins, suggestive of a keloid.
If the scar tissue grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress, it is called a keloid. Keloid formation seems to be an individual predisposition, and for unknown reasons it is somewhat more common in African Americans.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 110.

questions.text: 55y old elderly Gentleman came with history of fever with productive cough. FOB guided biopsy was done which is given below. Which of the following chemical mediators is involved in this process?
questions.solution:
Interferon Gamma is a pro inflammatory cytokine that involved in the process of granuloma formation.
It activates Macrophages to differentiate into Epitheloid and Giant cells which constitute Granulomas. IFN Gamma is produced in response to stimuli such as infections, foreign body and allergens.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1362.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in repair of DNA following double stranded breaks?
questions.solution:
MSH2 is involved in mismatch repair, usually involved in correction of single mismatch base repair. It is not involved in double stranded breaks repair.
Double Stranded breaks in DNA pose a significant concern. Genetic recombination events can give rise to chromosomal translocation, chromosomal breakage and ultimately cellular demise. 2 potential repair to undergo: Homologous recombination and non- homologous end joining.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 413.

questions.text: The Protease of Vibrio Cholera disrupts the extracellular part of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Protease of V. Cholera disrupts the Extra cellular part of Occludin.
Occludin prevents leakage of fluids and molecules across the epithelium.
Protease of Vibrio cleaves the occludin thus causing profuse diarrhoea.


Fig: Mechanism of Action of Cholera Toxin.

questions.text: 55y old female was diagnosed to have Breast cancer. Biopsy Showed HER2 positivity. Which of the following chromogen is responsible for imparting brown color after staining?
questions.solution:
Diaminobenzidine is chromogen used in IHC , produces brown color when exposed to hydrogen peroxide and horse radish peroxidase.
* Extra Edge: 
Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is an important auxiliary method for pathologists as it specifically visualizes distribution and amount of a certain molecule in the tissue using specific antigen-antibody reaction. The applications of IHC have recently been expanded explosively as more and more molecules involved in pathogenesis, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases are discovered. The unique feature that makes IHC stand out among many other laboratory tests is that it is performed without destruction of histologic architecture, and thus the assessment of an expression pattern of the molecule is possible in the context of microenvironment.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 831.

questions.text: Identify the test given below.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of Fluorescent In Situ Hybridsation used for detection of specific DNA sequences in cells and tissues. It is used to detect aneuploidy, microdeletion and rearrangements, complex translocations and gene amplifications.

questions.text: What is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
Cell radiosensitivity varies during the cell cycle:

  • Most radiosensitive: M phase (mitosis) and G2 phase

  • Moderately sensitive: G1 phase

  • Most radioresistant: S phase (DNA synthesis)

Reason:

  • During the S phase, DNA is actively being replicated and cells have abundant repair mechanisms for DNA damage, making them less susceptible to ionizing radiation.

  • In contrast, during M and G2, cells are actively dividing, and DNA damage cannot be efficiently repaired, making them highly radiosensitive.

Hence, the S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

questions.text: What do apoptotic bodies consist of?
questions.solution:
Apoptotic bodies are membrane-bound vesicles formed during apoptosis (programmed cell death).

Key points:

  • They contain fragments of the entire cell, including:

    • Nucleus (condensed chromatin or nuclear fragments)

    • Cytoplasm

    • Organelles (mitochondria, ER, etc.)

  • Formed after cell shrinkage, membrane blebbing, and fragmentation.

  • Phagocytosed by macrophages or neighboring cells, preventing inflammation, unlike necrosis.

questions.text: Name the marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor among the following
questions.solution:
• DOG1 and CD117 are the most sensitive markers for GIST.
  • GIST also expresses CD34, SDH,PDGF receptor A.
  • S100 is a marker for melanoma.
  • CA15-3 is a marker for breast cancer.
  • NRG-1 highly expressed in papillary carcinoma thyroid

questions.text: Identify the histological type of carcinoma lung
questions.solution:
• Presence of keratin pearls in the given image is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma lung.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
  • SCC is more strongly associated with smoking than any other type of NSCLC.
  • Squamous cell lung tumors often occur in the central part of the lung or the primary airway, such as the left or right bronchus


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 718-720.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with uterine rupture
questions.solution:
• Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a genetic disorder affecting collagen formation and function. manifests clinically with skin hyperelasticity, hypermobility of joints, atrophic scarring, and fragility of blood vessels.
  • EDS is classified into 6 types (classical, vascular, hypermobile, arthrochalasis, kyphoscoliotic, and dermatosparaxis)
  • Vascular EDS is an autosomal dominant disease with a prevalence of 1–9/100 000. It is most often associated with a mutation in COL3A1 oR, COL1A1, which respectively code for type-III and type-I procollagen chains.
  • Type-III collagen is found in the skin, vessel walls and viscera, where it provides structural robustness.
  • Vascular EDS is one of the most severe disease subgroups because its complications are potentially life-threatening.

The major clinical diagnostic criteria for vascular EDS include the occurrence of spontaneous colon perforation, uterine rupture during pregnancy, in the absence of a previous caesarean section, and/or severe peripartum perineal tears, arterial rupture before the age of 40 years and the formation of a carotid cavernous sinus fistula in the absence of trauma

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 149,507.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be detected by FISH?
questions.solution:
• Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is a method of molecular analysis of genetic lesions involving large deletions, duplications, or more complex rearrangements that are not detectable by PCR.
  • It is not useful for identifying point mutation.
  • Point mutations are identified by other means like sequencing studies and restriction fragment length polymorphism.
  • FISH uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. To perform FISH, large fragments of cloned genomic DNA spanning up to 200 kb are labeled with fluorescent dyes and applied to metaphase chromosome preparations or interphase nuclei.
  • The probe hybridizes to its homologous genomic sequence and thus labels a specific chromosomal region that can be visualized under a fluorescent microscope.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 182-183.

questions.text: Give below is an image of an excision biopsy performed on a neck swelling, what is the possible diagnosis?

The given image is a cross-section of a lymph node, showing caseating granuloma with Langerhan's giant cells. Th response is responsible for the formation of a granuloma and caseous necrosis.

Other options provided do not typically show caseous necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not diffferentiate between necrosis and Apoptosis?

questions.text: Which among the following is a growth-promoting oncogene?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart shows an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.
Autosomal dominant conditions are manifested in the heterozygous state, hence at least one parent of an index case is usually affected. In this mode of inheritance, both males and females are affected and both can transmit the condition. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, every child has one in two chance of having the disease.
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 144 .

questions.text:
Match the following disorders with their genetic abnormalities.

Genetic abnormalities		 Disorders
1 Trinucleotide repeat a Patau syndrome
2 Trisomy 18 b Huntington chorea
3 Trisomy 13 c Sickle cell anemia
4 Hb beta chain d Edward syndrome (Glu to val)
questions.solution:
Huntington's disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant, progressive brain disorder characterized by involuntary movements, emotional disturbances, and cognitive decline. It is caused by the degeneration of neurons and gliosis in the caudate lobe, putamen, and globuspallidus. This condition arises due to an abnormal expansion of the CAG trinucleotide in the Huntington gene on chromosome 4.

Edward's syndrome, or Trisomy 18, results from the inheritance of an extra copy of chromosome 18, usually due to meiotic nondisjunction. Clinical manifestations include micrognathia, low-set ears, a prominent occiput, and rocker-bottom feet. Patients often exhibit marked hypertonia, such as clenched hands with overlapping fingers. Common complications include cardiac defects (ventricular septal defects, patent ductus arteriosus) and gastrointestinal anomalies (Meckel's diverticulum, malrotation). Prenatal ultrasound typically reveals fetal growth restriction.
Trisomy 13 leads to Patau syndrome, characterized by midline facial clefts (such as cleft lip or palate) and musculoskeletal abnormalities like polydactyly. Other phenotypic features include microcephaly, low-set ears, hypertelorism, and a broad nasal bridge.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a point mutation in the ?-globin gene, leading to the substitution of valine for glutamate. This mutation results in the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS). Factors that contribute to sickling include infection, dehydration, and acidosis. Clinically, the disease manifests with moderately severe hemolyticanemia, jaundice, and painful bone crises. Aplastic crises occur when parvovirus B19 infects red cell progenitors, temporarily halting erythropoiesis and causing a sudden worsening of anemia.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3375,3404,757-759 .

questions.text: A patient on long-term hemodialysis due to renal failure is likely to develop which type of amyloidosis?
questions.solution:
Patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis due to the deposition of beta-2 microglobulin. Beta-2 microglobulin is a component of the MHC class I molecule and a normal serum protein. In the past, patients with chronic kidney disease retained this protein in their circulation because it could not be filtered through older dialysis membranes. This led to its deposition in the joints, muscles, tendons, and ligaments. One potential complication of this deposition is carpal tunnel syndrome. However, with the introduction of newer dialysis filters, this complication has become rare.


 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 260,262 .

questions.text:
The BRCA1 gene is associated with:
A. Repair of double-strand DNA breaks
B. Risk of development of ovarian cancer
C. Tumor suppressor gene
D. Mutation is seen in the subset of Fanconianemia
questions.solution:
The BRCA1 gene is associated with:

Repair of double-strand DNA breaks

Increased risk of ovarian cancer

Tumor suppression


Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes. Mutations in these genes are linked to a higher risk of breast cancer in women. They are crucial for repairing double-stranded DNA breaks. Women with BRCA1 mutations are also at an elevated risk for developing epithelial ovarian cancer, while men with BRCA1 mutations have a slightly increased risk of prostate cancer.

BRCA2 mutations are connected to a range of cancers, including those of the ovary, prostate, pancreas, bile ducts, stomach, melanocytes, and B lymphocytes. Additionally, some germline BRCA2 mutations can lead to Fanconianemia. Both BRCA proteins and Fanconianemia proteins work together within a DNA damage response network associated with homologous recombination repair. Deficiencies in this pathway may trigger nonhomologous end-joining mechanisms, potentially leading to telomere shortening.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 124,292,281 .

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image
questions.solution:
The histopathological slide presented uses Congo red staining, which is employed to identify amyloid deposits.

Amyloidosis is characterized by the extracellular accumulation of fibrillar proteins. These abnormal fibrils result from the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind various proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, such as heparansulfate and dermatan sulfate, as well as plasma proteins like serum amyloid P component (SAP). Under a microscope, amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline extracellular substance.

Amyloidosis can be classified into systemic, localized, and hereditary types. Microscopically, all forms of amyloid deposits consist of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A distinctive cross-?-pleated sheet conformation is detectable using X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.

Congo red staining is used to visualize amyloid deposits, which appear pink to red under ordinary light and exhibit apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

The image displays a Congo-red stained biopsy specimen showing:

(A) Focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material

(B) Apple-green birefringence under polarized light

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 259,260,547,768,848,849,993 .

questions.text: The most common genetic cause of hypercoagulability is:
questions.solution:
The Factor V Leiden mutation is the most prevalent genetic cause of hypercoagulability. Inherited hypercoagulability is commonly due to mutations in the factor V and prothrombin genes. Among these, the Factor V Leiden mutation is the most frequent, followed by the prothrombin G20210A mutation.

The Leiden mutation is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It causes factor V to become resistant to cleavage and inactivation by protein C, disrupting an essential antithrombotic pathway.

Deficiencies in Protein C, Protein S, and antithrombin III are less common causes of primary hypercoagulability.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 126,127 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not essential in the workup of a mosaic Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Anti-nuclear antibodies are not essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome.
 
  • Turner syndrome is characterized by the presence of a deletion or non-functional X chromosome in females.
  • About 50% of individuals with Turner syndrome have monosomy X (45, XO), which means they only have one X chromosome.
  • The remaining 50% exhibit mosaicism (45, X with mosaicism), where the body contains a mix of cells—some with the usual two sex chromosomes and others with only one X chromosome.
  • This mosaic Turner syndrome arises from random events during early fetal development and is not inherited.



Reference: Shankar Kikkeri N, Nagalli S. Turner Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Aug 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554621/

questions.text:
Which of the following are the features of necrosis?
A. Disrupted cell membrane
B. Induces inflammation
C. Swelling of the cell
D. Physiological
questions.solution:
The features of necrosis include:

Disrupted cell membrane

Induces inflammation

Swelling of the cell


Necrosis is characterized by the denaturation of cellular proteins, leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, and enzymatic digestion. It can result from loss of oxygen supply, exposure to microbial toxins, burns, and other forms of chemical or physical injury.

When the cell membrane is damaged, lysosomal enzymes enter the cytoplasm and digest the cell. The leaked cellular contents move into the extracellular space, causing inflammation.

Morphological changes in necrosis include:

Cell size: Increased

Cytoplasmic changes:

Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens

Moth-eaten appearance due to vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles from enzymatic degradation

Glassy and homogeneous cytoplasm from loss of glycogen


Nuclear changes:

Pyknosis: The nucleus shrinks and becomes more condensed

Karyorrhexis: Fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus

Karyolysis: The nucleus fades away, leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells


 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th edition, Page no 42 .

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic factor?
questions.solution:
MCL1 is an anti-apoptotic factor among the options provided. Anti-apoptotic factors, such as BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1, are located in the outer mitochondrial membrane, cytosol, and endoplasmic reticulum membranes. They work by maintaining the impermeability of the mitochondrial outer membrane, thereby preventing the release of cytochrome c and other death-promoting proteins into the cytosol.

In contrast, pro-apoptotic factors like BAX and BAK, upon activation, form oligomers in the outer mitochondrial membrane, increasing its permeability. This leads to the leakage of death-promoting proteins into the cytosol.

Additionally, regulated apoptosis initiators include BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa. These factors become active during cellular stress or damage and trigger the apoptosis process.

 

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th edition, Page no 44,45 .

questions.text:
Which of the following are the true statements about amyloidosis?
A. It is an extracellular protein.
B. It is called amyloid because of starch deposition.
C. Beta-pleated sheets are seen on X-ray crystallography
D. AL is a secondary type of amyloidosis.
questions.solution:
Amyloidosis is characterized by the extracellular deposition of fibrillar proteins. These abnormal fibrils result from the aggregation of misfolded proteins and bind to a variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, such as heparansulfate and dermatan sulfate, as well as plasma proteins, notably the serum amyloid P component (SAP). Under a microscope, amyloid deposits appear as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance.

The term "amyloid" is derived from the deposits' resemblance to starch due to their staining characteristics, as they contain abundant charged sugar groups. This resemblance was the basis for the name "amyloid."

Amyloidosis can be classified into systemic, localized, or hereditary types. All types of amyloid deposits are composed of continuous, nonbranching fibrils with a characteristic ?-pleated sheet conformation, which can be visualized using X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.

To identify amyloid deposits, the Congo red stain is used. This stain imparts a pink to red color under ordinary light and shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

The AL type of amyloidosis, also known as immunoglobulin light chain amyloidosis, is associated with primary amyloidosis and is often observed in multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell proliferations.

The biopsy specimen described in the image demonstrates Congo red staining with focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material and apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 259,260,574,768,848,849,993 .

questions.text: Which of the following is a sensitive and specific marker of intestinal inflammation?
questions.solution:
Why Fecal lactoferrin?

 

  • Source: Released from activated neutrophils infiltrating intestinal mucosa.

  • Stable in feces → Good for outpatient stool testing.

  • Differentiates:

    • IBD (↑ fecal lactoferrin)

    • IBS (normal levels)

questions.text: A family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
The provided pedigree chart indicates autosomal dominant inheritance. This type of inheritance is characterized by a vertical pattern in pedigree charts, where individuals in each generation are affected, including both parents and their children.

In autosomal dominant conditions, males and females are equally affected, and each affected individual has a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to their offspring.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical condition is a dodecanucleotide repeat disorder?
questions.solution:
Disease repeat expansion disorder seen
Fragile X syndrome Trinucleotide repeat expansion disorder - CGG
Myotonic dystrophy Trinucleotide repeat expansion disorder - CTG
Huntington's disease Trinucleotide repeat expansion disorder - CAG
EPM1 myoclonic epilepsy Dodecamer repeat expansion disorder
CCC-CGC-CCC-GCG
Frontotemporal dementia Hexanucleotide repeat expansion disorder

Progressive myoclonic epilepsy is an example of an unstable dodecamer repeat disorder. Ref - Kaplan textbook of Psychiatry 10th edition page 3126-3128

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Metastatic calcification with increased serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum calcium level

questions.text: A 40 year old lady presented with a neck swelling since one month associated with fever, weight loss and night sweats. Biopsy revealed caseous necrosis in the lymph node. Which of the following statements is true
questions.solution: The given history is suggestive of tuberculous lymphadenitis with biopsy showing caseous necrosis. Hence this site is prone for dystrophic calcification. Dystrophic calcification occur in dead and dying tissues such as coagulative, caseous, liquefactive necrosi or necrosis of fat and usually have normal serum calcium levels . Ref -Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition • Page no 36-37

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with cough fever and weight loss since the past one month. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological slide of cervical lymph node shows features of caseous necrosis and with the given history of fever weight loss and cough for 1 month the diagnosis is suggestive of tuberculosis.
Once mycobacterium tuberculosis is engulfed by the macrophages it inhibits phagolysosome formation by recruiting a host protein coronin that inhibits fusion of phagosome and lysosome causing unchecked replication of M. Tuberculosis. The Antigen presenting cells present mycobacterial antigens to T cells in the lymph node which releases IL-12 and IL-18 causing differentiation of T cells into Th1 cells. Th1 cells produce IFN-y which activate macrophages causing phagolysosome maturation. The Th1 response leads to the formation of a granuloma and caseous necrosis and the Macrophages that are activated by the action of IFN-y differentiate into epithelioid histiocytes. Ref-Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e • Page no. 374, 375

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back along with history of foul smelling pale, large volume, loose stools. What is the condition he is suffering from and what type of necrosis is seen here?
questions.solution:
Type of necrosis Example
Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast trauma
Caseous necrosis  tuberculosis
Fibronoid necrosis Vasculitis, Malignant hypertension
Liquefactive necrosis Brain infarct

The given clinical scenario points towards chronic pancreatitis. Chronic pancreatitis causes releases activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification). On Histologic examination foci of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic calcium deposits are seen.
Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e • Page no 40 - 41

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of irreversible injury?
questions.solution:
• Blebbing of the plasma membrane is an early and reversible change seen in cell injury. The cell can recover if the stress is removed.

Signs of irreversible injury (cell death) include:

  1. Karyolysis – dissolution of the nucleus due to enzymatic degradation of DNA.

  2. Karyorrhexis – fragmentation of the nucleus.

  3. Nuclear pyknosis – condensation of chromatin in the nucleus.

Remarks on other options:

  • Karyolysis, karyorrhexis, and pyknosis are all nuclear changes of irreversible injury.


Reference:

1. Robbins Basic Pathology, 9th edition, pages 41 and 42.

questions.text: Which among the following is a mediator of chronic inflammation?
questions.solution:
• Chronic inflammation is characterized by fibrosis, angiogenesis, and persistent immune activation.

  • TGF-β (Transforming Growth Factor-beta) is a key mediator of chronic inflammation, promoting fibroblast proliferation, collagen deposition, and scar formation.

  • TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6 are predominantly mediators of acute inflammation (fever, neutrophil recruitment, systemic effects).


Reference
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e - Page 97,98,99,

questions.text: A girl with intellectual disability presents to the OPD with the following finding (image below). Cardiac evaluation shows a congenital endocardial cushion defect. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a single transverse palmar crease (simian crease), which is a classic physical finding in Down’s syndrome (trisomy 21).

  • Other supporting features:

    • Intellectual disability

    • Congenital heart defect, particularly atrioventricular (endocardial cushion) defect

Other options:

  • Turner syndrome (45,X): Short stature, webbed neck, shield chest; no simian crease or endocardial cushion defect.

  • Patau syndrome (trisomy 13): Severe intellectual disability, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly; heart defects usually ventricular septal defect.

  • Edward syndrome (trisomy 18): Severe intellectual disability, rocker-bottom feet, clenched fists; heart defects include VSD, PDA, but simian crease uncommon.


Reference :
1.Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition - Page nos: 611-613, 2192
2.Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page no: 660

questions.text: Thermogenin protein is mainly found in
questions.solution:
Thermogenin, also known as Uncoupling Protein 1 (UCP1), is a mitochondrial protein that plays a critical role in non-shivering thermogenesis, especially in brown adipose tissue.

Key Features of Thermogenin (UCP1):

  • Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane.

  • Function:

    • It uncouples oxidative phosphorylation by allowing protons (H) to re-enter the mitochondrial matrix without ATP production.

    • This dissipates the proton gradient as heat, which is vital for temperature regulation, especially in newborns.

  • Found mainly in:

    • Brown fat (brown adipose tissue) in neonates and hibernating animals.


Other options: 

  • Nucleus is primarily responsible for storing genetic material and regulating gene expression. It does not play a role in thermogenesis or energy dissipation, so it is not the site for thermogenin.

  • Golgi complex is involved in modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids. It is not associated with thermogenic activity or uncoupling proteins.

  • Endoplasmic reticulum is responsible for protein and lipid synthesis and calcium storage. It does not contribute to heat generation via uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation.


Reference: Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 14

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks back, now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The key points in the question are:

  • Surgery for a lipoma was done 5 weeks ago

  • A scar has formed at the incision site

  • The scar is limited to the boundaries of the original wound.

    Differentiation:

Feature Hypertrophic Scar Keloid
Growth Limited to original wound Extends beyond original wound
Onset Within weeks after injury Often later
Regression May regress with time Rarely regresses
Time since surgery 5 weeks – consistent with hypertrophic Too early for classic keloid growth



Other options: 

  • Exuberant granulation: Overgrowth of granulation tissue that prevents epithelialization, appears as red, moist tissue—not a scar.

  • Keloid: Extends beyond the wound borders, unlikely here as the lesion is confined.

  • Granulation tissue: Seen during earlier wound healing stages, not a mature scar.



Reference: Robin's basic pathology 10e page no 111

questions.text: During wound healing, the cells that appear first due to chemotaxis , at the site of the wound is___
questions.solution:
In the early phase of wound healing (inflammatory phase), neutrophils are the first cells to arrive at the wound site. This is due to chemotaxis — the migration of immune cells in response to chemical signals released by damaged tissue.

Timeline of cellular infiltration:

  • Neutrophils: First 24–48 hours; remove debris and bacteria.

  • Monocytes: Arrive after neutrophils; differentiate into macrophages.

  • Macrophages: Key in transitioning to the proliferative phase.

  • Lymphocytes: Appear later; involved in immune regulation and repair.

So, neutrophils are the first responders due to chemotaxis.


Reference: Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 106-107

questions.text: Which amongst the following molecules helps in the adhesion of the leucocyte to the endothelium during inflammation?
questions.solution:
During inflammation, leukocyte adhesion to endothelium is a key step in their migration from blood vessels to tissues (this process is called as extravasation). 
P-selectin is expressed on activated endothelial cells and mediates rolling and weak adhesion of leukocytes.


Other options: 

  • Option 1 - NAPDH Oxidase - involved in respiratory burst, not in adhesion and extravasation
  • Option 2  Complement - Involved in opsonization, chemotaxis, and cell lysis — not direct adhesion to endothelium.
  • Option 4-  Platelet-activating factor (PAF) - A lipid mediator involved in increasing vascular permeability and leukocyte activation, but not directly adhesion.

Reference: Robbin's and Cotran Pathological Basis of disease 9e page no 74

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 ?
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome (also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome) is a developmental disorder resulting from a deletion on chromosome 22 at the q11.2 region.

Key Features of DiGeorge Syndrome:

Feature Explanation
Hypocalcemia Due to parathyroid hypoplasia
Thymic hypoplasia Causes T-cell immunodeficiency
Cardiac abnormalities Especially conotruncal defects like Tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus
Chromosomal deletion 22q11.2 deletion
Facial dysmorphism Low-set ears, small jaw, upslanting palpebral fissures
Mnemonic CATCH-22: Cardiac, Abnormal facies, Thymic hypoplasia, Cleft palate, Hypocalcemia + 22q11.2 deletion

Other options:

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome: Deletion on chromosome 5p; characterized by cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability—not associated with thymic or cardiac defects.

  • Pitt syndrome: Likely referring to Pitt-Hopkins syndrome; involves intellectual disability, seizures, and breathing abnormalities—not deletion of 22q11.2.

  • Williams syndrome: Caused by deletion on 7q11.23; associated with elfin facies, hypercalcemia, and supravalvular aortic stenosis—not hypocalcemia or thymic hypoplasia.


Reference:Robin's basic pathology 10th edition page no 164,533

questions.text: A child who was fed only on rice water presents with a swollen belly and dull face. His appearance is of a 'fat sugar baby' and is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents with classic features of Kwashiorkor, a form of severe protein-energy malnutrition, commonly seen in children who are:

  • Weaned off breast milk early

  • Fed high-carbohydrate but low-protein diets (like rice water)

    Key Features of Kwashiorkor:

Feature Description
Diet Low protein, adequate calories (mainly carbohydrates)
Edema Pitting edema, especially on the legs, face (swollen belly)
Skin changes Flaky paint dermatosis, hypopigmentation
Hair changes Easily pluckable, flag sign (alternating bands)
Mental changes Apathy, irritability
Serum proteins Low total protein & albumin
Typical appearance “Fat sugar baby” – due to edema despite malnutrition

Differentiation from Marasmus:
Feature Kwashiorkor Marasmus
Protein intake Very low Low
Edema Present Absent
Weight loss Less prominent (edema masks it) Severe wasting
Appearance "Fat sugar baby" "Skin and bones" appearance


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 337

choices.text: Transduce the signal to T-cell following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

questions.text: What does Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC)-1 and -2 do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

The main function of the MHC molecule is to bind peptide fragments of foreign protein for presentation to appropriate antigen-specific T cells.
  • Class I MHC molecules display peptides that are derived from cytoplasmic proteins, including normal proteins and virus- and tumor-specific antigens, which are all recognized bound to class I MHC molecules by CD8+ T cells.
  • Class II MHC molecules present antigens derived from extracellular microbes and proteins following their internalization into endosomes or lysosomes.
  • MHC molecules play several key roles in regulating T cell–mediated immune responses.
  1. First, because different antigenic peptides bind to different MHC molecules, it follows that an individual mounts an immune response against a protein antigen only if he or she inherits an MHC variant that can bind peptides derived from the antigen and present it to T cells.
  2. Second, by segregating cytoplasmic and internalized antigens, MHC molecules ensure that the correct immune response is mounted against different microbes—CTL-mediated killing of cells harboring cytoplasmic microbes and tumor antigens, and helper T cell–mediated antibody production and macrophage activation to combat extracellular and phagocytosed microbes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 195.

questions.text: What kind of DNA repair is defective in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Non-homologous end-joining repair

Non-homologous end joining repair is defective in severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID).
Other examples of human disease of DNA damage repair:
  1.  Defective Non homologous end joining repair
    1. SCID
  2. Defective homologous repair
    1. ATLD
    2. NBS
    3. Bloom syndrome
  3. Defective DNA nucleotide, excision repair
    1. Xeroderma pigmentosum
    2. TTD
  4. Defective DNA mismatch repair
    1. HNPCc
                  
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: The characteristic anomaly noticed in Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Birbeck granules
 

  • The Penta laminar tubules known as Birbeck granules, which contain the protein langerin are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

  • These Birbeck granules frequently have a dilated terminal end that gives them the appearance of a tennis racket.
* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell Histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: Which gene in the thymus is responsible for self-antigen recognition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): AIRE
 
  • The gene responsible for self-antigen recognition in the thymus is AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator).
  • AIRE gene plays a crucial role in central tolerance by promoting the expression of a diverse array of tissue-specific antigens (TSAs) within thymic epithelial cells.
  • This allows developing T cells to encounter and recognize self-antigens, leading to the deletion of autoreactive T cells and the development of self-tolerance.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 216.

questions.text: Where are MHC Class II proteins expressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B-cells, dendritic cells and macrophages

  • Class II MHC molecules present antigens derived from extracellular microbes and proteins following their internalization into endosomes or lysosomes. Here, the internalized proteins are proteolytically digested, producing peptides that then associate with class II heterodimers in the vesicles, from which they are transported to the cell surface as stable peptide-MHC complexes.
  • In contrast to class I molecules, class II molecules are mainly expressed on cells that present ingested antigens and respond to T-cell help (macrophages, B lymphocytes, and DCs).
  • Platelets and all nucleated cells have MHC I. 

* Audio Explanation:
 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 198.

questions.text: patient came in with an intermittent fever, no weight loss, and no anorexia, but a retroperitoneal tumor. Results from the peripheral smear were normal. The mass is shown in both gross and microscopical form. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Castleman’s disease


*Clinical Features:

  1. B symptoms: fever, weight loss, night sweats, fatigue 

  2. Splenomegaly or Hepatomegaly

  3. Fluid accumulation (edema, anasarca, pleural effusion)

* [Extra Edge]: Castleman disease

  1. Castleman disease (CD) is a rare, nonclonal lymphoproliferative disorder having distinct subtypes depending on its etiology, pathology, and clinical presentation. It can affect lymph nodes of any body region, imitating both benign and malignant malformations, including the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

  2. The hyaline vascular type has an increased number of lymphoid follicles with a broad mantle zone and hypoplastic germinal center. Centrally placed germinal center is surrounded with small lymphocytes arranged in concentric circles, forming an "onion skin-like" structure. The center of these follicles is penetrated by hyalinized capillaries resembling a "lollipop" (also known as the lollipop sign).

  • Histopathologic screening of lymph nodes is done to assess a single node involvement (suggestive of UCD) or a multimode involvement (suggesting MCD) after excluding other infectious, malignant, and autoimmune disorders that exhibit their characteristic features in the lymph nodes. In addition, their characteristic lymph node features are also noted.

  • The lymph node size must be enlarged.

  • IL-6 has proven to be a specific biomarker for this disease, contributing to its pathogenesis, symptomatology, and histopathology. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 257.
Online Reference: Ehsan N, Zahra F. Castleman Disease. [Updated 2023 Apr 27]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK576394/

questions.text: Without a positive ANA, which of the following conditions is highly unlikely to be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Drug-induced lupus
 
  • Without a positive ANA, drug-induced lupus cannot be diagnosed.
  • An ANA positive syndrome known as drug-induced lupus is characterized by symptoms including fever, malaise, severe arthralgias/myalgias, serositis, and/or rash.
  • Drug-induced lupus is classically marked by antinuclear and anti-histone antibodies and, in some cases, anti­ double-stranded DNA or perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA) antibodies.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: Dendritic cells possess:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Both HLA1 and HLA 2
 
  • Class 1 HLA antigens are found on all nucleated cells of the body and platelets as well as platelets.
  • Class 2 HLA antigens are present on the surface of antigen presenting cells. 
Since, dendritic cell is a nucleated as well as an antigen presenting cell, it will have both the classes of HLA antigen. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 196.

questions.text: Where are MHC antigens absent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Erythrocyte

MHC antigens are absent on erythrocytes. 

  • HLA class I antigens (A, B and C) are found on the surface of virtually all nucleated cells and platelets. They are the principal antigens involved in graft rejection and cell-mediated cytolysis.
  • HLA class II antigens are more restricted in distribution, being found only on cells of the immune system- macrophages, dendritic cells, activated T cells, and particularly on B cell
*Audio Explanation:
 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 198.

choices.text: Transduce the signal to T cells following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors

questions.text: What are the functions of Major Histocompatibility Complex-1 and -2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors
 
  • Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC)-1 molecules present antigens derived from intracellular pathogens to CD8+ T cells.
  • MHC-2 molecules present antigens derived from extracellular pathogens to CD4+ T cells.
  • Transducing the signal to T cells following antigen recognition and enhancing the secretion of cytokines are functions associated with T cell receptors and co-stimulatory molecules, not MHC molecules.
* [Extra Edge]: MHC I Vs MHC II


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 198.

questions.text: Which of the given options is the immunological marker of Langerhans cell histiocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) CD1a

Amongst the given options, CD1a is the immunological marker of LCH (Langerhans cell histiocytosis).
Option 2 CD20 is present on B-Cells.
Option 3 and 4 CD16 and CD56 are present on NK-cells. 

* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell Histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: What course of treatment is recommended for intractable Sydenham’s Chorea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Valproate
 
  • Intractable Sydenham's Chorea is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements.
  • It is typically associated with rheumatic fever. When symptoms are severe and do not respond to other treatments, Valproate is recommended.
  • Valproate is an antiepileptic medication, works by increasing the levels of GABA, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate neuronal activity.
The Modified Jones Criteria is used for the diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever,
          
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2768.

questions.text: Which drug is best for resistant rheumatic chorea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Valproate
 
  • Intractable Sydenham's Chorea is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements.
  • It is typically associated with rheumatic fever. When symptoms are severe and do not respond to other treatments, Valproate is recommended.
  • Valproate is an antiepileptic medication, works by increasing the levels of GABA, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate neuronal activity.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2768.

questions.text: Where are Bence Jones proteins derived from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Gamma Globulins
 
  • Bence Jones proteins are derived from gamma globulins.
  • Bence Jones proteins are abnormal proteins produced by certain plasma cells in individuals with multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer.
  • They are light chain proteins that can be detected in the urine and are indicative of the presence of multiple myeloma.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 872.

questions.text: Which of these is a condition depicted in flow cytometry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyper IgM syndrome
 
  • The given flow cytometric findings are suggestive of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • This is because B cells are positive for CD-19 on X-axis and negative for CD-40 on Y-axis when compared to normal individual.
  • Lack of CD-40 on the surface of B cells is the cause of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • In this disorder, affected patients have IgM antibodies but are deficient in IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies.
  • Mature B cells are present, but they are incapable of Ig class switching and affinity maturation, because of a defect in CD4+ helper T cells or an intrinsic B-cell defect.
  • Approximately 70% of individuals with hyper-IgM syndrome have the X-linked form of the disease, caused by mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26 that interfere with CD4+ helper T cell function.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: The options are genes involved in SCID . Identify the exception.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) BTK

BTK (Bruton tyrosine kinase) mutation is seen in Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

* [Extra Edge]: SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency)
Both humoral and cell-mediated immunity are defective in SCID
  • X LINKED SCID
Most common and results from a mutation in the gamma chain subunit of cytokine receptors.
This protein is a signal-transducing component of the receptors for IL2, IL4, IL7, IL9, IL11, IL15, and IL 21
  • AUTOSOMAL RECESSIVE SCID
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is the primary cause of AR SCID.
  • Other Causes
  • Recombinase activating gene mutation (RAG)
  • JAK3 intracellular kinase mutation: Important for signal transmission via the cytokine receptor gamma chain.
Remember IL7 Receptor is most commonly mutated in SCID if nothing else is mentioned in the question, it is NOT ADA Defciency, it comes next after IL7R.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: Identical twins with following graft:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Isograft
 
  • Graft exchanged between identical twin is isograft
  • Graft exchanged between individuals of same species is allograft
  • graft from one species to another is xenograft
  • Autograft is tissue from patient's own body

Online Reference: Oli AN, Babajide Rowaiye A, Adejumo SA, Anazodo FI, Ahmad R, Sinha S, Haque M, Adnan N. Classic and Current Opinions in Human Organ and Tissue Transplantation. Cureus. 2022 Nov 1;14(11):e30982. doi: 10.7759/cureus.30982. PMID: 36337306; PMCID: PMC9624478.

questions.text: 6 years old child presented to OPD with eczematous rash. On evaluation was found to have fever, platelet= 80,000. On enquiring there is h/o multiple hospitalization for recurrent infection. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome  
 
  • The presentation of eczematous rash, fever, and thrombocytopenia along with a history of recurrent infections suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder.
  • Among the options given, the most likely diagnosis in this case is Wiskott Aldrich syndrome (WAS).
  • WAS is an X-linked disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections. It results from mutations in the WAS gene, which plays a role in the function of immune cells. Patients with WAS have defective T and B lymphocyte function, which leads to increased susceptibility to infections.
Option 1 and 2 Chediak Higashi Syndrome and Bruton's agammaglobulinemia may present with recurrent infections, but thrombocytopenia and eczematous rash are not typical features of these disorders.

Option 4 Severe combined immunodeficiency can also present with recurrent infections, but it is usually associated with severe T and B lymphocyte dysfunction leading to severe combined immunodeficiency.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 246.

questions.text: Which of the following induces the production of IgE by B cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) IL-4

The cytokine that induces the production of IgE by B cells is IL-4. 

  • IL-4 is produced by activated T cells and plays a critical role in the regulation of immune responses, especially in the context of allergic reactions. It is a key cytokine in the differentiation of Th2 cells, which are involved in the production of IgE and the development of allergic responses.
  • IL-4 also induces the expression of CD23, which is the receptor for IgE on B cells, and promotes the survival, proliferation, and differentiation of B cells into IgE-producing plasma cells.
     

Option 1 IL-2 is a cytokine that is mainly involved in the proliferation and differentiation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells.

Option 3 IL-1 is a proinflammatory cytokine that is involved in the regulation of immune responses, including the activation of T cells and the production of other cytokines.

Option 4 IL-6 is a pleiotropic cytokine that is involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including the regulation of immune responses, hematopoiesis, and inflammation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 200.

questions.text: Pick the diagnosis in the kid of A 5 years old child presented to the clinic with h/o of recurrent infections. O/e the child had rashes as shown below. Routine blood investigations revealed the patient had low platelets.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

  • Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the WAS Protein Gene.
  • The syndrome is characterized by recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
     
  • Patients are also at risk for autoimmunity, allergies, and malignancy. WAS is usually diagnosed in infancy, but it can be diagnosed in later life in rare cases.
  • The diagnosis is made with the use of laboratory tests, physical exams, and examining family histories.
  • Treatment typically involves managing infection risk with antibiotics, managing eczema with topical steroids and other treatments, and managing thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions and/or immunomodulatory medications. Bone marrow transplantation may also be an option for some patients.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 246.

choices.text: Type IV hypersensitivity - epitheloid cells, giant cells, macrophages
