questions.text: A patient who arrives at the hospital has had a cough and low-grade fever for the past two weeks. An X-ray of the chest revealed caseous necrosis in the lung's apex. What is the disease's underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Type IV hypersensitivity - epithelioid cells, giant cells, macrophages 
 

  • The given clinical history (low grade fever, cough for 2 weeks) is suggestive of TB infection of lung, caused due to inhalation of Mycobacterium Tuberculosis.
  • The inhaled organism activate cell mediated immunity (type 4 hypersensitivity) resulting in the formation of an epithelioid granuloma with central caseous necrosis.
  • Granuloma is composed of slipper shaped cells called epithelioid cells; multinucleated giant cells called Langhan’s Giant cell with a central area of necrosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 212.

questions.text: After being stung by a bee, a patient develops anaphylaxis. Identify the antibody that is causing this reaction.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) IgE

  • The given history is suggestive of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction to a bee sting. It is mediated by Ig E antibody.
  • Type I hypersensitivity involves immunoglobulin E (IgE) mediated release of antibodies against the soluble antigen.
  • This results in mast cell degranulation and release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.
  • Most immediate hypersensitivity (Type I) disorders are caused by excessive Th2 responses, and these cells play a central role by stimulating IgE production and promoting inflammation.
  • When a mast cell armed with IgE antibodies previously produced in response to an antigen is exposed to the same antigen, the cell is activated, leading to the release of an arsenal of powerful mediators that are responsible for immediate hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (e.g., the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g., peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g., those in bee venom).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 205.

choices.text: Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases the antigen toxicity
PD-1 and PD-1L activation leading to tumor suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about immune surveillance is correct
 1. Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
 2. Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases the antigen toxicity
 3. PD-1 and PD-1L activation leading to tumor suppression
 4. Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
 
  • Anti CTLA-4 antibody is a new modality, used in treatment of cancers, particularly in advanced stages.
  • Mutation of tumor suppressor gene will increase the antigen toxicity.
  • PD-1 and PD-1L inhibition leads to tumor suppression Binding of CD-28 leads to inhibition of immune tolerance.
  • Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance: CD28 binding provides costimulatory signals that promote T cell activation, not tolerance.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: What causes affinity maturation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Somatic hypermutation

Affinity maturation is due to somatic hypermutation.
Helper T cells also stimulate the production of antibodies with high affinities for the antigen. This process, called affinity maturation, improves the quality of the humoral immune response.

* [Extra Edge]: Affinity development
i. The process by which B cells create antibodies with higher antigen specificities during an immune response.
ii. Compared to an initial reaction, a secondary response has the potential to produce antibodies with higher affinity.
iii. Takes place in secondary lymphoid organs' germinal centers.
iv. Takes place in 2 interconnected processes:
  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM), which causes mutations in the immunoglobulin genes variable regions.
  • Clonal Selection in which somatically hypermutated B cells struggle for scarce growth resources, including the presence of antigen.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 203.

questions.text: What causes a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cell-mediated

Type IV hypersensitivity is also known as cell-mediated hypersensitivity because it is the result of the interaction of T lymphocytes and the specific antigen to which they have been sensitized.

Other options: -
  • Antibodies mediated is Type II HSN reaction 
  • Immune complex mediated is Type III HSN reaction 

* [Extra Edge]: Mechanisms of T cell mediated cytotoxicity
 
  • Cytokine-mediated inflammation: CD4+ T cells are activated by exposure to a protein antigen and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 effector cells. Subsequent exposure to the antigen results in the secretion of cytokines. IFN-γ activates macrophages to produce substances that cause tissue damage and promote fibrosis, and IL-17 and other cytokines recruit leukocytes, thus promoting inflammation. The classical T cell–mediated inflammatory reaction is DTH.
  • T cell–mediated cytotoxicity: CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) specific for an antigen recognize cells expressing the target antigen and kill these cells. CD8+ T cells also secrete IFN-γ.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 212.

questions.text: Which is the very first chemical barrier that microorganisms encounter for a commonly exposed body surface?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Acidic pH
 
  • First chemical barrier encountered by microorganism for common exposed surfaces of the body is acidic pH.
  • All surfaces of the body, which come in contact with the external environment, are equipped with mechanical and chemical barriers to prevent penetration by microorganisms.
  • Secretions of sebaceous glands contain both saturated and unsaturated fatty acids that kill bacteria and fungi.
  • The sebaceous secretions also have a low pH that inhibits bacterial growth.
Online Reference: Janeway CA Jr, Travers P, Walport M, et al. Immunobiology: The Immune System in Health and Disease. 5th edition. New York: Garland Science; 2001. The front line of host defense. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK27105/

questions.text: What causes hyperacute rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Preformed antibodies
 
  • Hyperacute rejection is mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells.
  • The preformed antibodies may be natural IgM antibodies specific for blood group antigens or may be antibodies specific for allogeneic MHC molecules that were induced by prior exposure of the organ recipient to allogeneic cells through blood transfusions, pregnancy, or transplantation of another organ.
        
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has swollen tonsils, a sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The following image depicts the removed tonsil's histological features. What is the responsible organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) EBV
 
  • The histological features of swollen tonsils, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The image provided shows characteristic histological findings of infectious mononucleosis, including hyperplastic germinal centers, infiltrating lymphocytes, and reactive lymphoid follicles.
  • EBV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is transmitted through saliva, making it a common cause of infectious mononucleosis.
  • The virus infects B cells, leading to their proliferation and subsequent immune response, resulting in the clinical presentation observed in the patient.
* [Extra Edge]: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

  • EBV is a ubiquitous herpesvirus implicated in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphomas, B-cell lymphomas in patients with T-cell immunosuppression (HIV infection, transplant recipients), and several other cancers.
  • The EBV genome harbors several genes encoding proteins that trigger B-cell signaling pathways; in concert, these signals are potent inducers of B-cell growth and transformation.
  • In the absence of T-cell immunity, EBV-infected B cells can rapidly “grow out” as aggressive B-cell tumors.
  • In the presence of normal T-cell immunity, a small fraction of infected patients develops EBV-positive B-cell tumors (Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma) or carcinomas (e.g., nasopharyngeal carcinoma).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 357.

questions.text: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies can be seen in the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Malakoplakia
 
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are intracellular basophilic inclusion bodies that can be observed in the cytoplasm of certain cells in specific conditions.
  • The presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is most commonly associated with malakoplakia, a rare chronic inflammatory condition typically affecting the genitourinary tract.
  • Malakoplakia is characterized by the accumulation of macrophages with defective bacterial killing mechanisms, leading to the formation of basophilic inclusion bodies called Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. These bodies consist of undigested bacteria and calcium salts.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies can also be seen in other conditions such as chronic granulomatous disease and Crohn's disease.
Other options: - 
  • Xanthogranulomatous cystitis- foam cells found
  • LCH- Birbeck granules are found
  • Tuberculosis- Caseous granuloma seen 


Fig: Malakoplakia

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 956.

questions.text: The presence of_____characterises Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Linear grooves in the nuclei 
 
  • LCH is typically positive for CD1a, S100, and CD207(Langerin). 
  • It's characterized by cells having vacuolated abundant pale eosinophilic cytoplasm containing linear groves on the nucleus and the presence of Birbeck granules. 
  • CD15 positivity is seen in Hodgkin's Lymphoma. 
* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell Histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: Which is the most common/frequently seen antibodies in Antiphospholipid Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibody 
 
  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL) and a predisposition to thrombotic events.
  • The most commonly detected antibodies in APS are anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies.
  • Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies target beta 2 glycoprotein I, a protein that binds to phospholipids on cell surfaces, including those on platelets and endothelial cells.
  • Other commonly seen antibodies in APS include anticardiolipin antibodies and lupus anticoagulant.
  • APS is an autoimmune disorder characterized by:

    1. Presence of one or more antiphospholipid (aPL) autoantibodies
    2. Venous or arterial thromboses, or pregnancy complications such as recurrent miscarriages, unexplained fetal death, and premature birth.
     

* [Extra Edge]: Autoantibodies 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 128.

questions.text: Which is an exception to an autoimmune disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sickle Cell Disease
 
  • Sickle cell disease is not an autoimmune disease, but a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin (hemoglobin S) within red blood cells, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
  • Autoimmune diseases result from an abnormal immune response directed against self-antigens, leading to tissue damage and inflammation.
  • In contrast, sickle cell disease is caused by a mutation in the beta-globin gene, leading to the production of abnormal hemoglobin and the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells.
* [Extra Edge]: Autoimmune Disease


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: Necrotizing lymphadenitis is characteristically seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kikuchi disease 
 
  • Necrotizing lymphadenitis, also known as Kikuchi disease or histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis, is a rare benign condition that primarily affects young adults.
  • It is characterized by tender, enlarged lymph nodes, most commonly in the cervical region.
  • Histologically, Kikuchi disease is characterized by necrotizing lymphadenitis with karyorrhexis (fragmentation of the cell nucleus) and abundant histiocytes.
  • The exact etiology of Kikuchi disease is unknown, but it is believed to involve a dysregulated immune response, possibly triggered by viral infections.
  • Kikuchi disease is usually self-limiting, and treatment is supportive.
Option 1 Kimura disease: A rare chronic inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the lymph nodes and soft tissues. It is characterized by painless subcutaneous nodules, lymphadenopathy (especially in the head and neck region), and increased eosinophil levels in the blood.

Option 3 Hodgkin's disease (Hodgkin lymphoma): A type of lymphoma characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells in the lymph nodes. It typically presents as painless, rubbery lymph node enlargement, commonly in the neck, armpits, or groin. Other symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, and generalized itching.

Option 4 Castleman disease (also known as angio follicular lymph node hyperplasia): A rare lymphoproliferative disorder that affects the lymph nodes. It can manifest as unicentric or multicentric disease. Unicentric Castleman disease involves a single lymph node region, while multicentric Castleman disease involves multiple lymph node regions and can be associated with systemic symptoms like fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1364.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Neutrophil Extracellular Trap EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Neutrophil Extracellular trap is extrusion of nuclear DNA ( not mitochondrial ) as a last resort against sepsis. 

The trap provides a scaffolding on which the anti-bacterial substances get deposited along with entrapment of organisms. This helps in elimination of organisms from the bloodstream. 

It is derived from amino acid arginine. 
          


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 83, 84.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines are not released by Th1?
questions.solution:
Th1 cells primarily produce cytokines involved in cell-mediated immunity and the activation of macrophages, such as:

  • IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma): A key cytokine released by Th1 cells to activate macrophages and enhance the killing of intracellular pathogens.
  • IL-2: Promotes the proliferation of T cells.
  • TGF-β (Transforming Growth Factor-beta): Can be involved in immunoregulation but is not uniquely characteristic of Th1 cells.
  • IL-12: Not directly released by Th1 cells but promotes the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells.
T Helper cells are of 3 types - TH1 , TH2 and TH3 
1. Th1 takes part in cell mediated immunity - involves IL2, IL12 and INF gamma
2. Th2 takes part in Type 1 hypersensitivity - involves IL4, IL5 and IL 13 involved in activation of mast cells, eosinophils.
3. Th3 - IL 17 mediated

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 99.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy presented with a two-day history of fever and abscess over the neck. The mother reveals that the child had similar recurrent infections in the past the dihydrorhodamine test (DHR) was found to be positive what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 7-month-old with recurrent infections, abscess formation, and a positive dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test strongly suggests Chronic Granulomatous Disease.

Key points:

  • CGD is caused by a defect in NADPH oxidase, leading to impaired respiratory burst in phagocytes.

  • As a result, neutrophils cannot effectively kill catalase-positive bacteria and fungi, causing recurrent abscesses (skin, lymph nodes, liver).

  • DHR test is used to detect oxidative burst activity; a positive test (abnormal DHR fluorescence) confirms the diagnosis.

  • Common pathogens: Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus.

Other options:

  • Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): Presents with severe infections early in life, but usually viral, bacterial, and fungal, not just abscesses. DHR is normal.

  • Tuberculosis: Usually chronic; rare in infants and doesn’t cause positive DHR.

  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome: Features partial albinism, giant granules in neutrophils, and recurrent infections; DHR is normal.

Hence, the most likely diagnosis is Chronic Granulomatous Disease.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture-
questions.solution:
In the picture above, Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are observed, which are a pathognomonic feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed-Sternberg cells are characterized by their large size and may be multinucleated or possess a bilobed nucleus, giving them an "owl's eye" appearance. They feature prominent eosinophilic, inclusion-like nucleoli. These cells are clonal in origin and arise from germinal center B cells but typically exhibit reduced B-cell gene expression and function.

While Reed-Sternberg cells are most commonly associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma, they are not exclusive to this condition. They can also be found in various other conditions, including:

Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (particularly in the immunoblastic type)
Infectious mononucleosis
Sarcomas


Fig: Reed-Sternberg cell. Reed-Sternberg cells are large, abnormal lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) that may contain more than one nucleus. These cells are found in people with Hodgkin lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cells are also called Hodgkin and Reed-Sternberg cells.

Reference: Küppers R, Hansmann ML. The Hodgkin and Reed/Sternberg cell. Int J Biochem Cell Biol. 2005 Mar;37(3):511-7. doi: 10.1016/j.biocel.2003.10.025. PMID: 15618006.

questions.text: During pregnancy, ABO incompatibility does not occur due to which antibody?
questions.solution:
ABO incompatibility between mother and fetus is less severe than Rh incompatibility primarily because the naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B antibodies in adults are mostly IgM:

  • IgM antibodies:

    • Large pentameric molecules

    • Cannot cross the placenta

    • Hence, maternal IgM does not affect the fetus

  • IgG antibodies:

    • Can cross the placenta

    • Responsible for Rh incompatibility hemolytic disease

Other immunoglobulins:

  • IgD: Mainly a B-cell receptor; minimal role in hemolysis

  • IgA: Found in secretions; does not cross the placenta significantly

Thus, ABO incompatibility is usually mild in newborns because maternal antibodies are predominantly IgM, which cannot cross the placenta.

questions.text: Reiter syndrome is associated with?
questions.solution:
Reiter syndrome (also called reactive arthritis) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy characterized by the classic triad:

  • Arthritis (usually asymmetric, lower limb)

  • Urethritis

  • Conjunctivitis

Key points:

  • Strong genetic association with HLA-B27.

  • Often triggered by bacterial infections like Chlamydia trachomatis, Salmonella, Shigella, or Yersinia.

  • Extra-articular manifestations: keratoderma blennorrhagicum, mucocutaneous lesions.

Other HLA associations for context:

  • HLA-DR3: Type 1 diabetes, Graves’ disease

  • HLA-DR4: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • HLA-DQ8: Type 1 diabetes

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the autosomal recessive type of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) is a group of genetic disorders characterized by severe impairment of both T and B lymphocyte function.

Key points:

  • Autosomal recessive SCID is most commonly caused by adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency.

  • ADA deficiency leads to:

    • Accumulation of deoxyadenosine and deoxy-ATP

    • Toxic to lymphocytes, causing profound immunodeficiency

  • Clinical features:

    • Recurrent infections (bacterial, viral, fungal)

    • Failure to thrive

    • Chronic diarrhea

  • Other enzyme options:

    • Ornithine transcarbamylase: Urea cycle disorder

    • Phosphomannose isomerase: Congenital disorder of glycosylation

    • HGPRT (Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase): Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

questions.text: The histological section of a skin lesion is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows keratin pearls, which are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).


Key Features of Squamous Cell Carcinoma:
Histological Characteristics: SCC is marked by the proliferation of atypical squamous cells, including the presence of "horn pearls" or keratin pearls.
Macroscopic Appearance: SCC can present in various forms, including:
Nodular
Verrucous
Papillomatous
Ulcerating lesions
Immunohistochemistry: SCC typically stains positive for cytokeratins 1 and 10.
Grading: SCC can be histologically graded using Broder's histological grading system.

choices.text: Decrease in IgG and increase in IgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning the immunological abnormality observed with the absence of CD40 in B cells?
questions.solution:
The absence of CD40 in B cells leads to Hyper IgM syndrome, characterized by a decrease in IgG and an increase in IgM. This condition often arises from loss-of-function mutations in either CD40 or activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), a DNA-editing enzyme essential for immunoglobulin class switching and affinity maturation in B cells.

CD40 deficiency disrupts class switching and the production of memory cells, while the B-cell response to antigens remains unaffected, resulting in elevated levels of IgM antibodies. Therefore, the syndrome is termed Hyper IgM syndrome.

Patients typically have normal or elevated IgM levels but lack IgA and IgE, with extremely low levels of IgG. Clinically, they experience recurrent pyogenic infections due to the insufficient opsonizing IgG antibodies and are particularly susceptible to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 244,245 .

questions.text: Thymus is designed to recognize the MHC molecules presented to it and distinguish the cells as self and foreign. Which gene is responsible for this?MHC :Major histocompatibility complex
questions.solution:
Central tolerance is a crucial process for eliminating self-reactive T and B lymphocytes during their development in central lymphoid organs—the thymus for T cells and the bone marrow for B cells. This process ensures that these self-reactive clones are either destroyed or rendered inactive.

In the thymus, self-reactive T lymphocytes are removed through a process known as negative selection or deletion, which requires the AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) protein. Mutations in the AIRE gene can lead to autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

For B cells, receptor editing is employed. When developing B cells encounter self-antigens, they undergo changes to alter their receptor so it no longer recognizes the self-antigen. Additionally, self-reactive B cells may be eliminated through apoptosis.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 216,285,607,324 .

questions.text: What type of cell is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
In the image above, Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are present, which are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed-Sternberg Cells:
Appearance: RS cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus, resembling an "owl's eye" due to their prominent eosinophilic nucleoli.
Origin: These cells are clonal in nature and arise from germinal center B cells, though they have lost most B-cell gene expression and function.

Note:
While RS cells are a hallmark of Hodgkin's lymphoma, they are not exclusive to it and can be seen in some other conditions as well.

Both RS cells and CMV inclusion bodies have Owl's eye appearance. However, they can be differentiated on the fact that RS cells have eosinophilic nucleoli (eye), whereas the inclusion bodies (eye) in CMV are basophilic in nature.

Other Options:

Option A: Mott cells are plasma cells (mature B cells) that contain multiple Russell bodies—large, eosinophilic, globular inclusions made up of accumulated immunoglobulins (Ig) in the cytoplasm. They are characterized by eccentric nucleus and clock face chromatin. They are seen in plasma cell dyscrasias, such as Multiple Myeloma.


Option B: Sezary-Leutner cells, also known as cerebriform cells are found in cutaneous T cell lymphomas. They are called so because their nucleus appears like brain tissue.


Option D: Faggot cells are seen in Acute Promyelocytic Leulemia (APML OR AML-M3). Their cytoplasm contains bundles of Auer rods which looks similar to a "stack of sticks", hence the term "faggot cell" (archaic term for a bundle of sticks).

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disorder that primarily targets the joints, leading to nonsuppurative, proliferative, and inflammatory synovitis. As the inflammation advances, it results in the destruction of articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints.

In RA, the synovium exhibits germinal centers with secondary follicles and a high concentration of plasma cells, which produce antibodies, including autoantibodies. Many of these autoantibodies generated in the lymphoid tissues are directed against citrullinated peptides (CCPs). Approximately 80% of patients have serum IgM or IgA autoantibodies that bind to the Fc regions of their own IgG. These autoantibodies, known as rheumatoid factor, may also accumulate in the joints as immune complexes.

The distinctive histological features of RA comprise:
  • Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation.
  • Dense inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis.
  • Fibrinopurulent exudate on the synovial and joint surfaces.
  • Osteoclastic activity in the underlying bone.
  • Subcutaneous nodules consisting of necrotizing granulomas, characterized by a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by activated macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells.
Collectively, these changes result in a swollen mass of synovium known as pannus, which extends over the articular cartilage and contributes to its erosion.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a cauliflower-like growth in the left eye along with leukocoria and an absent red reflex. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which is the causative gene in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histological findings suggest retinoblastoma, a malignancy caused by a mutation in the Rb gene on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular cancer in children, and leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) is the most frequent presenting symptom. Other signs include strabismus (usually convergent) and, less commonly, nystagmus and defective vision.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

Usually presents within the first two years of life.
Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex).
Strabismus (misalignment of the eyes).
Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma.
Orbital inflammation that can mimic cellulitis.
In neglected cases, orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth.
Metastasis to regional lymph nodes or the brain is rare before ocular involvement is detected.

Other options:

  • FBN1 → Marfan syndrome

  • ATP7B → Wilson disease

  • Rhodopsin gene → Retinitis pigmentosa

questions.text: A young person with recurrent seasonal conjunctivitis presents with itchiness and watering in the eyes. What is the most likely cell involved in the immediate phase of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described suggest Type 1 hypersensitivity, which is mediated by IgE binding to mast cells.

Key Features of Type 1 Hypersensitivity (Immediate Hypersensitivity):
1. Mechanism:
This is a rapid immune response, also known as an allergic reaction, triggered when an antigen binds to an IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells.
2. Phases:
Early Phase:
Occurs immediately after exposure to the allergen.
Mast cells release histamine, leukotrienes, and other mediators, causing intense reactions like edema, mucus secretion, and smooth muscle spasm.
Other early-phase mediators include:
Enzymes: Neutral proteases (e.g., chymase, tryptase) and acid hydrolases.
Proteoglycans: Heparin and chondroitin sulfate.
Lipid mediators: Platelet-activating factor (PAF).
Late Phase:
Begins hours after the early phase and is characterized by leukocyte recruitment, leading to sustained inflammation.
Key mediators in the late phase include:
Cytokines: TNF, IL-1, IL-4, IL-5, and chemokines like eotaxin.
Leukocytes: Especially eosinophils, which play a major role.
Eosinophil products: Major Basic Protein (MBP) and Eosinophil Cationic Protein, contributing to tissue damage.
Together, these mediators drive the classic symptoms of allergic reactions, such as swelling, redness, and itching, as well as prolonged inflammation seen in the late phase.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male comes with complaints of hip pain. An X-ray of the hip shows lytic lesions and serum calcium levels are elevated. Bone marrow plasma cells are 42% and the cells seen are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In an elderly male patient, the combination of hypercalcemia, lytic bone lesions, more than 10% plasma cells in the bone marrow, and the presence of characteristic Mott cells, as seen in the image, indicates a diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder characterized by the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. This condition is associated with increased osteoclast activity and suppressed osteoblast activity, leading to punched-out lytic lesions in the bones and hypercalcemia. The incidence of multiple myeloma rises with age and is more prevalent in males than in females.

questions.text: The viral marker positivity of a 25-year-old male presented with fever is given below. What ts the most likely diagnosis? HBsAg : Positive IgM anti HBc antibody : Positive
questions.solution:
An acute case of hepatitis is indicated by positive HBsAg and positive IgM anti-HBc antibody.

Only when a patient has a chronic carrier status or an acute infection is HbsAg positive. During an acute infection, anti-HBc antibodies develop and remain.

Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page NO 2350, 2360.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the autosomal recessive type of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) is a group of disorders characterized by:

  • Profound defects in both T and B lymphocyte function, leading to severe immunodeficiency.

    Adenosine Deaminase (ADA) Deficiency:

  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive.

  • Mechanism:

    • ADA is crucial for the breakdown of adenosine and deoxyadenosine.

    • Its deficiency leads to accumulation of deoxyadenosine, which is toxic to lymphocytes, particularly T-cells.

    • This results in lymphopenia and severe immunodeficiency.

      Other options:

Option Disease/Defect Notes
Phosphomannose isomerase Congenital disorder of glycosylation type Ib Rare metabolic disease, not related to SCID.
Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) Lesch-Nyhan syndrome X-linked recessive; associated with hyperuricemia and neuro symptoms.
Ornithine transcarbamylase OTC deficiency (urea cycle disorder) X-linked; causes hyperammonemia, not immunodeficiency.

Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 239-240

questions.text: A person was bought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin? IgA-Immunoglobulin A IgE-Immunoglobulin E IgM-Immunoglobulin M IgG-Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
The symptoms described — facial swelling, itching, and hypotension — following a bee sting are characteristic of an anaphylactic reaction, which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

  • IgE is the key immunoglobulin involved in type I hypersensitivity.

  • Upon re-exposure to the allergen (e.g., bee venom), IgE bound to mast cells and basophils triggers the release of histamine and other mediators, leading to:

    • Vasodilation → hypotension

    • Increased vascular permeability → facial swelling

    • Histamine effect on sensory nerves → itching

Other immunoglobulins:

  • IgM: Involved in early humoral response, not allergy.

  • IgA: Found in mucosal immunity.

  • IgG: Involved in opsonization, complement activation, and type II/III hypersensitivity.


Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 10e page no 205-208

questions.text: A Rh-negative mother delivered an Rh-positive baby and Coomb's test was positive for the baby. What is the mechanism of hypersensitivity seen in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes hemolytic disease of the newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis) due to Rh incompatibility. It is a classic example of:

Type II hypersensitivity reaction — antibody-mediated cytotoxicity.

Mechanism:

  • Rh-negative mother is exposed to Rh-positive fetal RBCs during first delivery (or miscarriage, trauma, etc.).

  • Mother forms IgG antibodies against Rh (D) antigen.

  • In subsequent pregnancies, maternal anti-Rh IgG crosses the placenta.

  • These antibodies bind fetal Rh-positive RBCs → cause complement activation and destruction of fetal RBCs by macrophages and NK cells.

  • This is antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).
     

    Types of Hypersensitivity Reactions with their mechanisms and classic examples:

    Type Name Mechanism Key Immune Components Examples
    I Immediate (Anaphylactic) IgE-mediated mast cell and basophil degranulation on re-exposure to antigen IgE, Mast cells, Basophils Anaphylaxis, Asthma, Allergic rhinitis, Urticaria, Bee sting
    II Antibody-mediated Cytotoxic IgG/IgM bind to antigen on cell → Complement activation or ADCC IgG, IgM, Complement, NK cells Hemolytic anemia, Rh incompatibility, Goodpasture’s, Myasthenia gravis
    III Immune Complex-mediated Antigen–antibody complexes deposit in tissues → Complement activation IgG, IgM, Immune complexes, Neutrophils SLE, Serum sickness, Arthus reaction, Post-streptococcal GN
    IV Delayed-type (Cell-mediated) Sensitized T-cells release cytokines → Macrophage activation or cytotoxicity CD4+ T-cells (TH1), CD8+ T-cells TB skin test, Contact dermatitis, Type 1 DM, Multiple sclerosis


Reference: Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 10e page no 205-213,922

questions.text: A 6-year-old Afro-American boy was seen with chronic hemolysis, abdominal pain, and an irregular RBC shape on a peripheral smear. The cause of this disease is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Point Mutation

  • The clinical presentation points towards Sickle Cell Anemia.
  • It mostly affects people of African origin.
  • It's caused by a point mutation in beta-globin's 6th codon (GAG-->GTG), which results in the substitution of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.
  • In sickle cell anemia, the peripheral blood demonstrates variable numbers of irreversibly sickled cells, reticulocytosis, and target cells, which result from red cell dehydration.
  • Howell-Jolly bodies (small nuclear remnants) also are present in red cells due to asplenia (see later). The bone marrow is hyperplastic as a result of a compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was diagnosed with an abdominal mass. The para-aortic lymph nodes appear significantly enlarged on imaging. A starry sky pattern was noted during the biopsy. What is the underlying abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Translocation involving Myc gene
 
  • A biopsy finding of a starry eye pattern strongly suggests Burkitt lymphoma. The c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 is linked with all forms of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • Burkitt's lymphoma has a very high mitotic index resulting in generation of many apoptotic and necrotic cells due to outgrowing of their blood supply.
  • The nuclear remnants of these cells are phagocytosed by the macrophages.
  • These phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm resembling the stars while the small round blue tumor cells represent the sky, giving rise to starry sky pattern. 
  • Most common presentation of endemic Burkitt's is a mass involving the mandible whereas sporadic burkitt's appears as a mass involving peritoneum and ileocecum. 
  • Other options - p53 mutation - Li fraumeni syndrome, Rb - Retinoblastoma, BCR - ABL - CML
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 601.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man who had acute, uncontrollable diarrhea presented. His kidney and bone marrow were sampled, as can be seen in the images below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Multiple myeloma 
 
  • The image shows: Cast Nephropathy in multiple myeloma. In the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts, casts are often present, characterized by their irregular, angulated, and geometric shapes with fracture planes, sometimes forming a jigsaw puzzle-like arrangement.
  • Occasionally, these casts exhibit a lamellated or crystalline appearance. They stain strongly eosinophilic on H&E, pale or weakly positive on PAS, and red-violet (metachromatic) on trichrome, reflecting their varying compositions of light chains and Tamm-Horsfall proteins. Casts are frequently lined with reactive tubular epithelium and can be associated with polymorphonuclear cells, syncytial giant cells, or granulomatous reactions. Some casts are congophilic, showing amyloidogenic activity, posing a risk for systemic amyloidosis. Additionally, proximal convoluted tubules may exhibit acute tubular injury.
  • Multiple myeloma is the most likely diagnosis. The images show plasma cells infiltrating the bone marrow and forming characteristic sheets or aggregates.
  • Multiple myeloma is a hematological malignancy characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow.
  • The presence of these abnormal plasma cells, along with the clinical symptoms of acute diarrhea and renal damage, supports the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.
  • Further tests, such as serum and urine protein electrophoresis, can help confirm the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulins.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient who previously experienced tonsillitis and a high-grade fever two months ago now has cervical lymphadenopathy. a peripheral smear with a WBC value of 22 109 /L demonstrates lymphocytosis. The mono spot test came back empty. After a tonsillectomy, big cells intermingled with lymphocytes were discovered. The cells had CD20, EBV-LMP1, MUM1, and CD79a positivity. CD3-positive background cells were present. The cells do not express CD15. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) EBV-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

The image shows a malignant proliferation of cells. CD20/CD79a positivity points towards the B-cell origin of the neoplasm and EBV LMP1 positivity points towards an EBV-driven neoplasm.
Since CD 15 is negative - Classical Hodgkins Lymphoma is ruled out and negative mono-spot test rules out Infectious mononucleosis.
The likely diagnosis hence in this particular scenario is EBV-positive diffuse large B cell lymphoma. 
 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: Which novel mantle cell lymphoma marker is most helpful in cases where Cyclin D1 is not present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) SOX11
 
  • SOX11 is the most helpful marker in cases where Cyclin D1 is not present. Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the overexpression of Cyclin D1.
  • However, in rare cases where Cyclin D1 is not present or is not detected by immunohistochemistry, SOX11 can serve as a valuable marker.
  • SOX11 is a transcription factor that is highly expressed in mantle cell lymphoma cells and can aid in the diagnosis and classification of this type of lymphoma.
* [Extra Edge]: Types of Non-Hodgkin lymphomas:


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 849.

questions.text: Which of the following describes a tumor that is anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Inflammatory Myo fibroblastic tumor
 
  • Inflammatory Myo fibroblastic tumors (IMTs) are rare neoplasms that often exhibit ALK gene rearrangements, leading to overexpression of the ALK protein.
  • This genetic characteristic is not commonly found in synovial sarcoma, fibromatosis, or Ewing sarcoma.
  • Immunoreactivity for ALK is detectable in 50-60% cases, correlate with presence of ALK gene rearrangement.

Option 1 Synovial sarcoma - Ck 7,14,19, Cd 99
Option 2 Fibromatosis - variable positivity for SMA, b- catenin (70-98%)
Option 3 Ewing sarcoma- CD 99

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 724.

questions.text: Which of the following markers are not expressed on the surface of T-cells at some stage of development
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PAX5
 
  • PAX5 is not expressed on the surface of T-cells at any stage of development.
  • PAX5 is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in B-cell development and is primarily expressed in B-cells. It is involved in regulating the expression of B-cell-specific genes and is not typically expressed in T-cells.
  • T-cells undergo a distinct developmental pathway characterized by the expression of markers such as CD1a, CD34, and Tdt.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 596.

questions.text: A 20-year-old kid who had been experiencing cervical lymphadenopathy for a year presented with the condition. The lymph node's histopathology reveals Reed-Sternberg cells with focal nodules and a backdrop of T reactive lymphocytes. The cells were EBV negative and positive for CD20, LCA, and EMA, but negative for CD15 and CD30. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma
 
  • The presence of Reed Sternberg cells in the histopathology sections points toward a diagnosis of Hodgkin's Lymphoma.
  • However, since these cells are EBV Negative, CD15/30 negative but positive for CD20 - the likely diagnosis is Non-classical Hodgkin's Lymphoma i.e.  Nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma (NLPHL). 
 
* [Extra Edge]: Various Histological Subtypes of Hodgkin's Lymphoma



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: What is represented by the red cell distribution width?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Anisocytosis
 

The red cell distribution width (RDW) represents anisocytosis, which refers to the variation in the size of red blood cells (RBCs).

  • RDW is a measure of the variation in RBC size and is often included in a complete blood count (CBC) report.
  • An increased RDW value indicates a greater variation in RBC size, suggesting the presence of different-sized RBCs, which can be seen in various types of anemias and other hematological disorders.
* [Extra Edge]: RBC Parameters

* [Extra Edge]: Types of RBCs


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 635.

questions.text:
Which of the following tubes contains sodium fluoride as an anticoagulant?
1. 
2. 
3.
4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Gray vacutainer

Gray vacutainer contains sodium fluoride and is used for glucose estimation because sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis.

* [Extra Edge]: Color Coding of Vacutainers


Online Reference: Gupta S, Kaur H. Inhibition of Glycolysis for Glucose Estimation in Plasma: Recent Guidelines and their Implications. Indian J Clin Biochem. 2014 Apr;29(2):262-4. doi: 10.1007/s12291-013-0405-1. Epub 2013 Nov 22. PMID: 24757316; PMCID: PMC3990791.

questions.text: In a patient with multiple clotting factor deficiency and active bleeding, the following blood product is recommended:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fresh frozen plasma
 
  • The best blood product to be given to a patient with multiple clotting factor deficiency with active bleeding is fresh frozen plasma.
  • Fresh frozen plasma is also indicated for a planned surgery or invasive procedure in the presence of abnormal coagulation tests, the reversal of warfarin in the presence of active bleeding, or a planned procedure when vitamin K is inadequate to reverse the warfarin effect, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, and congenital or acquired factor deficiency with no alternative therapy.
  • Fresh frozen plasma contains all coagulation factors except platelets.
  • Fresh frozen plasma contains fibrinogen (400 to 900 mg/unit), albumin, protein C, protein S, antithrombin, and tissue factor pathway inhibitors. It is free of erythrocytes and leukocytes. 
  • Fresh frozen plasma corrects coagulopathy by replacing or supplying plasma proteins in patients deficient in or defective plasma proteins.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2630.
Online Reference: Khawar H, Kelley W, Stevens JB, et al. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) [Updated 2022 Sep 19]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513347/

choices.text: Hodgkin’s lymphoma; Epstein Barr Virus and Reed Sternberg cells
Hodgkin’s lymphoma; Epstein Barr Virus and Embryo cell
Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma; HIV and Giant B cell

questions.text:
For the past two years, a 12-year-old kid has had enlargement of bilateral cervical lymph nodes. A lymph node biopsy displays the image below.
Which of the following diagnoses, etiologies, and cells are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Epstein Barr Virus and Reed Sternberg cells

The histopathology displayed shows Reed-Sternberg cells typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
They are distinct neoplastic giant cells that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers.

* [Extra Edge]


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most significant prognostic factor in ALL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Response to steroids

Amongst the given options, Response to steroids is considered (i.e. response to therapy) the most important prognostic factor in ALL. 

* [Extra Edge]: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) prognostic factors



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 828.

questions.text: Which of the following blood preservatives can be used for  35-day blood storage period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) CPDA-1

CPDA-I is a common anticoagulant-preservative and allows storage of BC concentrates for 35 days.

*Additives for increasing shelf life of blood include:
  • Acid citrate dextrose: 21 days
  • Citrate phosphate dextrose: 21 days
  • Citrate phosphate dextrose with adenine: 35 days
  • Sodium adenine glucose mannitol: 42 days
Blood storage: -
  • PRBC- SAGM- 42 days- 2-6 degree Celsius 
  • Platelet- 5 days- 20-24 degree Celsius (room temperature)
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma- 1 year- -30 degree Celsius 
  • Cryoprecipitate- 2 years- less than -30 degree Celsius 
Online Reference: Moore GL. Additive solutions for better blood preservation. Crit Rev Clin Lab Sci. 1987;25(3):211-29. doi: 10.3109/10408368709105883. PMID: 3315464.

questions.text: Which anticoagulant from the list below is used to estimate electrolytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lithium Heparin 
 
  • Lithium heparin is the anticoagulant used for electrolyte estimation- it's the anticoagulant in a green-colored vacutainer.
  • Because EDTA causes in vitro hemolysis (which might lead to spurious electrolyte values), lithium-heparin is the preferred anticoagulant for electrolyte measurement. 
* [Extra Edge]:


Online Reference: Bayot ML, Tadi P. Laboratory Tube Collection. [Updated 2023 Aug 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555991/

questions.text: What will a five-year-old patient with HbA2 3% and HbF 97% have on their peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 1, 2 and 3
 
  • Presence of 3% of HbA2 and 97% of HbF in a child is highly suggestive of thalassemia major.
  • In thalassemia major, nucleated RBCs with target cells, Howell-Jolly bodies and teardrop cells (Dacrocytes) are seen, which implies 1,2 and 3 as the correct option.
  • Blood smears show severe red cell abnormalities, including marked variation in size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis), microcytosis, and hypochromia.
  • Target cells (so called because hemoglobin collects in the center of the cell), basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common.
  • Inclusions of aggregated α chains are efficiently removed by the spleen and not easily seen.
  • The reticulocyte count is elevated but is lower than expected for the severity of anemia because of ineffective erythropoiesis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 645.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Transthyretin
 
  • The liver produces transthyretin, a normal serum protein that transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein. Transthyretin does not participate in iron metabolism.
  • Transthyretin (TTR) is a normal serum protein that binds and transports thyroxine and retinol.
  • Several distinct mutant forms of TTR (and its fragments) form amyloid in a group of genetically determined disorders referred to as familial amyloid polyneuropathies.
  • Unmutated TTR may also deposit as amyloid in the heart of aged individuals (senile systemic amyloidosis).
* Proteins involved in Fe metabolism include:
  • Ceruloplasmin
  • DMT1
  • Ferrireductase
  • Ferritin
  • Ferroprotein
  • Hepcidin
  • Hephaestion
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 260.

questions.text: Which of the following is not reduced in iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) TIBC

Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) is increased in iron deficiency anemia.
In case of iron deficiency anemia since the relative free transferrin concentration is high; it is potentially able to bind to more amounts of iron, hence TIBC increases.

* Trick- Two 'Ts' increase in iron deficiency anemia- TIBC and soluble transferrin receptors. Remaining parameters of iron metabolism decrease. 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 751.

questions.text: Where is the origin of CLL and SLL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Post germinal center B cell
 
  • Cell of origin for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) is naive B-cells in inter-follicular zones.
  • The expression of CD5 and CD23 in CL cells is antigen-experienced, indicating that these cells have undergone secondary modifications, possibly signifying cell activation or nonspecific changes brought on by the malignancy.
  • Consequently, the memory B-lymphocyte may be the CLL cell's original cell.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 594.

questions.text: Which investigation will help in the diagnosis of chloroma in a child with bilateral proptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Peripheral smear
 
  • Chloroma is a presentation of AML most commonly AML M2 >M5>M4 , most commonly manifesting as proptosis.
  • As soon as you suspect chloroma, we should do a peripheral blood smear to check for blasts.
  • Peripheral smear must be done for diagnosis of chloroma.
  • If the peripheral smear is inconclusive we can go for a bone marrow study.
  • Despite the fact that biopsies of chloroma lesions may point to the diagnosis, the results may mimic a number of inflammatory or neoplastic disorders.
  • In order to confirm the diagnosis, immunophenotyping, inspection of peripheral blood smears, and bone marrow aspirates are frequently needed.
  • Hb concentration and platelet count are not helpful in determining the diagnosis of chloroma. Since extramedullary blast growth is the source of chloroma, the leucocyte count may not increase in this condition.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 620.

questions.text: A male patient from a hilly area presented with fever and splenomegaly. TLC was 21000, and the differential revealed metamyelocytes and myelocytes (approximately 40%). Hb was 16, lymphocytes were normal. Patient has Thrombocytopenia. What will be the next investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) FISH
 
  • Hemoglobin in normal as per guidelines for adult male. However, the patient has thrombocytopenia and has myeloid bulge (40% myelocytes metamyelocytes).
  • Therefore, the patient has to be investigated for Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia. The most common cause for which is Philadelphia chromosome.
  • CML is distinguished from other myeloproliferative neoplasms by the presence of a chimeric BCR-ABL gene derived from portions of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 and the ABL gene on chromosome 9.
  • BCR-ABL directs the synthesis of a constitutively active BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase, which in CML is usually 210 kDa in size. In more than 90% of cases, BCR-ABL is created by a reciprocal (9;22) (q34; q11) translocation (the so-called Philadelphia chromosome [Ph]).
* Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia - Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 622.

choices.text: Lack of A; B and H antigens on RBCB.
Lack of A; B and H antigens in Saliva
Presence of Anti-A; Anti-B; and Anti-H antibodies in blood

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about the Bombay Blood Group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lack of other Blood Group Antigens

The Bombay blood group is a rare blood group, phenotypes of this group lack H antigen on the red cell membrane and have anti-H in the serum.
It fails to express any A, B or H antigen on their red cells or other tissues. However, other blood group systems such as Kelly, Duffy, Lewis are present. 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 884.

questions.text: Anemia and jaundice for two years are present in a 23-year-old female patient. She also complains of oral ulcers. Spherocytes are visible on the peripheral smears. Which investigation is should be conducted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Coomb’s Test
 
  • In a 23-year-old female with pallor/oral ulcers and spherocytes in the peripheral blood, this is a likely a case of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). AIHA occurs when the body's immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys red blood cells, leading to anemia. Jaundice is occurring due to hemolysis leading to increased indirect bilirubin. 
  • The diagnostic test for AIHA is the antiglobulin test (also called the Coombs' test). This test checks for antibody or complement proteins attached to the outside of red blood cells, indicating that the patient's own antibodies have attacked the blood cells.
Remember- The most common cause of visualization of spherocytes on peripheral blood smear is autoimmune hemolytic anemia and not hereditary spherocytosis. 

Hereditary Spherocytosis would have family history( aurosomal dominant nature) and onset from early childhood. (not in the 20's)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 649.

choices.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman reported having arthralgia, cyanosis of the nose, blue lips, and persistent weariness throughout the month of December. The image below depicts a peripheral blood smear. What is the most plausible reason for the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
 
  • The most likely cause is clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anaemia.
  • Spherocytes, which are only present in hereditary spherocytosis and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, are clearly visible in the peripheral smear seen above.
  • The described history of wintertime cell lysis is typical of cold antibody type autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

*Mnemonic trick: -
IgG- G for garam(hot)- Warm agglutination
So, remaining cold agglutination is IgM mediated.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 649.

questions.text: Identify the cell which is raised markedly in worm infestations in the given Leishman’s stained blood smear.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) C
 
  • In cases of worm infestations, particularly helminthic infections, eosinophils are known to increase significantly in the blood smear.
  • Eosinophilia is a characteristic feature of parasitic infections and is often observed in response to the presence of worms or their larvae in the body.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 398.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman had pallor, 9.5 mg/dL hemoglobin, MCV 100, and a 2 million/mm3 RBC count. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Folic acid deficiency

  • A high MCV here is suggestive of macrocytic anemia, as seen in a deficiency of folic acid.
  • The marrow is usually markedly hypercellular as a result of increased numbers of hematopoietic precursors. Megaloblastic changes are detected at all stages of erythroid development.
  • The most primitive cells (pro megaloblasts) are large, with a deeply basophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and a distinctive, fine nuclear chromatin pattern.
  • Defects in nuclear maturation, as seen in megaloblastic anemias due to folate or B12 deficiency, result in large oval erythrocytes (macro ovalocytes) with a normal hemoglobin content. The MCV and MCH are increased, while the MCHC remains normal. There is anisocytosis, and RDW is often increased.


*Audio Explanation: 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 654.

questions.text: All of the following statements about the condition of the patient with splenomegaly, anaemia, and jaundice are true, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Low reticulocyte count
 
  • In cases of hemolytic anemia, increased reticulocytes are seen in the circulation.
  • This happens as a response to the increased lysis of erythrocytes; i.e. immature RBCs are released into the circulation from bone marrow.
  • Increased hemolysis lead to increased LDH and bilirubin formation, bilirubin is broken down to water soluble urobilinogen . Hemoglobin released binds to haptoglobin leading to decreased haptoglobin levels. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 637.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is admitted with episodes of weakness/difficulty breathing and bleeding. He had a platelet count of 50 x 109 cells/L and a leukocyte count of 48 x 109 cells/L. A differential count revealed 76% neutrophils, 8% blast cells, 12% myelocytes and metamyelocytes, and 4% other cells, indicating neutrophil dysplasia. 14% of blasts were found in the bone marrow analysis. Cytogenetics revealed that the patient has t(8:21). Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acute myeloid leukemia

With the given features the diagnosis can be concluded to that of AML.
  • Acute leukemias are characterized by an abrupt onset and clinical signs and symptoms related to suppressed marrow function, such as fatigue, fever, bleeding, bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly. Central nervous system manifestations such as headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies can also occur, particularly in children and in ALL.
  • Remember in patients with AML with t (8;21), inv 16, and t (15:17) - even if blasts are less than 20% in Bone Marrow- a diagnosis of AML can be made. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 617.

questions.text: In which of these is the Direct Coombs test not positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Aplastic anemia

  • Direct coomb’s test is positive in all of these conditions except Aplastic anaemia.
  • The direct Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that are stuck to the surface of red blood cells. It is used for the diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia.


Fig: Direct Coombs Test

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 671.

questions.text: Which of these is not an Epstein-Barr virus-associated lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma

EBV is not associated with NLPHL (Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma) - Non-classical Hodgkins Lymphoma.
All the others are types of NHL -Non-Hodgkin lymphoma and are associated with EBV.

* [Extra Edge]: Histological subtypes Of Hodkins lymphoma


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 358.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Positive ANA
 
  • ANA positivity is seen in multiple Rheumatological disorders like SLE, Systemic sclerosis but is not characteristic of Multiple Myeloma.
  • Major criteria for diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma: Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy Bone marrow plasmacytosis with >30% plasma cells Monoclonal globulin spike on serum electrophoresis exceeding 3.5 gm/dl for IgG or 2 gm/dL for IgA,21 gm/24 of K or λ light-chain excretion on urine electrophoresis in the presence of amyloidosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of megaloblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Increased reticulocyte count
 
  • Megaloblastic anemia refers to deficiency in B12 and Folate leading to anemia.
  • Both B12 and folate are crucial for generation of nuclear material for a new cell. their deficiency leads to inability of the cells to decide and mature, the cells hence remain nucleated and large in size, increased destruction of cells causes jaundice and splenomegaly.
  • Reticulocyte count remains low.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with painless supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. A biopsy revealed binucleated acidophilic owl eyed cells with floating lymphocytes in empty space that were CD15 and CD30 positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the described case is 2. Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma.

The presence of binucleated Reed-Sternberg cells (often described as "owl-eyed" cells), along with the floating lymphocytes in an empty space, and the positivity for CD15 and CD30 are characteristic features of Hodgkin lymphoma.
Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma and is typically associated with the clinical presentation of painless lymphadenopathy, particularly in the supraclavicular region.

RS cells are of different types in different types of classical Hodgkins Lymphoma - 
  1. Mixed cellularity - Mononuclear RS cell
  2. Nodular sclerosis - Lacunar cell
  3. Lymphocyte rich - Classical RS cell
  4. Lymphocyte depleted - Pleomorphic/Reticular cell
In non classical Hodgkins - Lymphocyte predominant NHL - Popcorn or LH cells are seen.

Lymphocyte rich variant is the best answer but it's not in the option. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: What is the most typical Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma subtype in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

The most common subtype of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in India is diffuse large B cell lymphoma.
* [Extra Edge]: NHL types
B-Cell
1. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: MC subtype (34%)
2. Follicular Centre-cell lymphomas: 12.6%
3. B-cell small lymphocytic lymphoma: 5.7%
4. Mantle-cell lymphoma: 3.4%
5. Marginal zone B-cell lymphomas (including MALT lymphomas): 8.2%
T-Cell
1. T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma: 6%
2. Anaplastic large-cell lymphomas of T/null-cell type
3. Other nodal peripheral T-cell lymphomas: 2.9%

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in the orbit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B cell
 
  • Orbital lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that originates in the conjunctiva, lacrimal gland, soft tissues of the eyelid, or extraocular muscles. It is most commonly extraconal in location.
  • The majority of non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas of the orbit are extra nodal marginal-zone B-cell lymphomas of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue type.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: Which laboratory test is the best among the following to detect bleeding in disseminated intravascular coagulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Increased FDPs
 
  • In the case of acute DIC, there is a swift activation of coagulation leading to bleeding, with low platelet count, prolonged PT and APTT, low fibrinogen and elevated FDP and D-dimer levels.
  • On the other hand, in chronic DIC, the activation of coagulation is slow, and although there may be a normal platelet count, usual PT and APTT, elevated FDP and D-dimer levels are still present.
  • Therefore, if the DIC is acute, all options are valid, but if it is chronic, increased FDP would be the correct answer.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 669.

choices.text: Should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from blood bank
Should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from blood bank
Wait till the patient is stable then transfuse, irrespective of any timing
Should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from blood bank

questions.text: Which of the following statements about packed RBC blood transfusions is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from blood bank 
 
  • RBCs are to be transfused within four hours of issue from the blood bank because of the risk of hemolysis. When RBCs sit at room temperature, the temperature can rise and cause the cells to burst, leading to potentially life-threatening consequences. To prevent this, RBCs should be transfused within four hours.
  • Additionally, red blood cells (RBCs) are fragile cells. When RBCs are transfused, it is important to use a needle that is thin enough to minimize trauma to the cells but still large enough to provide an adequate transfusion rate. A 18-20 G needle is the optimal size for delivering red blood cells. 
  • Opened bags must be used within 6 h. Following transfusion, the transfusion set has to be closed in sterile fashion and retained, together with the empty bag, for 24 h at a temperature of + 1°C to + 10°C.
Online Reference: Müller MM, Geisen C, Zacharowski K, Tonn T, Seifried E. Transfusion of Packed Red Cells: Indications, Triggers and Adverse Events. Dtsch Arztebl Int. 2015 Jul 20;112(29-30):507-17; quiz 518. doi: 10.3238/arztebl.2015.0507. PMID: 26249256; PMCID: PMC4555065.

questions.text: The following are detected using toluidine blue staining:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Mast cell
 
  • Toluidine blue is a stain that can differentiate basophils and mast cells based upon its chemical reaction with acid mucopolysaccharides present in the cell granules.
  • This form of staining, however, may not be effective when the level of acid mucopolysaccharides are low - as seen in malignant mast cells or basophils. To identify this type of cell more definitively, immunohistochemical markers, such as staining for mast cell tryptase, can be used in replacement of toluidine blue staining.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 206.

questions.text: RBCs, platelets, and fresh frozen plasma (FEP) are stored at the following temperatures:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) RBC 2-6°C, Platelet 20-22°C, FFP-30°C

* Storage temperature of:
  1. RBC 2-6°C,
  2. Platelet 20-22°C,
  3. FFP-30°C.
Blood storage: -
  • PRBC- SAGM- 42 days- 2-6 degree Celsius 
  • Platelet- 5 days- 20-24 degree Celsius (room temperature)
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma- 1 year- -30 degree Celsius 
  • Cryoprecipitate- 2 years- less than -30 degree Celsius 

Under these conditions, there is minimal loss of activity of the labile coagulation factors V and VIII.
One milliliter of FFP contains approximately one unit of coagulation factor activity. After thawing, FFP may be stored in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours before use.

Online Reference: Basu D, Kulkarni R. Overview of blood components and their preparation. Indian J Anaesth. 2014 Sep;58(5):529-37. doi: 10.4103/0019-5049.144647. PMID: 25535413; PMCID: PMC4260297.

questions.text: Which of the following, according to the WHO's 2016 categorization of acute leukemia, is not a temporary entity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) AML with hyper diploidy
 
  • In response to the WHO 2016 classification, AML with hyper ploidy is not a provisional entity because it is simply a subtype of AML, and not a distinct entity in and of itself.
  • Hyper ploidy refers to an increase in the number of chromosomal copies in each cell, which can occur in both myelodysplastic syndromes and certain types of AML.
  • The WHO 2016 classification recognizes the importance of this finding but does not consider it to be a separate entity, since it is not distinct from the underlying disease of AML.
WHO 2022 Classification of AML


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 810.

questions.text: Which disease is the CD59 marker for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PNH
 
  • CD59 is a marker for PNH, a rare, acquired disorder characterized by complement-mediated hemolysis due to a deficiency of proteins involved in the protection of red blood cells from complement attack.
* [Extra Edge]: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
 
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare, acquired disorder of the blood characterized by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis) and the presence of dark urine in the morning.
  • It is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells.
  • This results in increased sensitivity to complement-mediated destruction. PNH can lead to anemia, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to infections and blood clots.
  • Diagnosis is made through flow cytometry to detect the absence of GPI-anchored proteins.
  • Treatment options include supportive care, blood transfusions, and targeted therapies such as eculizumab.
Other options:
  • PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene associated with Cowden syndrome, not related to CD59.
  • BRR and Cowden’s syndrome are not associated with CD59.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 648.

questions.text: Bernard-Soulier syndrome results from a lack of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2)Gp 1b
 
  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome (BSS) is a rare bleeding disorder characterized by platelet dysfunction, giant platelets, and prolonged bleeding.
  • It is caused by mutations in the genes encoding the GPIb-IX-V complex, leading to impaired platelet adhesion and aggregation.
  • BSS patients exhibit a higher risk of spontaneous bleeding, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries.
  • Diagnosis is made through blood tests and examination of giant platelets.
  • Management involves supportive care and treatment of bleeding episodes as needed.
* Other options:
  • Gp 2b/3a is the receptor involved in platelet aggregation, not associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome. It is involved in Glanzman Thrombesthenia. 
  • vWf (von Willebrand factor) is a protein that plays a role in platelet adhesion, but its deficiency is associated with von Willebrand disease, not Bernard-Soulier syndrome.
  • TNF (Tumor Necrosis Factor) is a cytokine involved in inflammation and is not related to Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

To remember Bernard Soulier and Glansmanz Thrombasthenia, B comes first alphabetically so Gp1 is associated, then comes G so G2b 3a is associated

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 666.

questions.text: Within many hours after a transfusion does TRALI occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 6hrs

TRALI typically tends to occur within 6 hours from transfusion. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 672.

questions.text: Heterozygous sickle cell anemia helps to protect against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Malaria

Heterozygous sickle cell anemia (carrier state) provides some protection against malaria. The presence of sickle hemoglobin in red blood cells makes them less suitable for the growth and survival of the malaria parasite. As a result, individuals with sickle cell trait have a reduced risk of developing severe forms of malaria.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: What is Burkitt's Lymphoma associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) t(8:14)
 
  • Burkitt's Lymphoma involves translocation of the c-myc gene present on chromosome 8 with either Immunoglobin heavy chain(IgH) on chromosome 14 or with immunoglobulin light chain (Kappa on chromosome 2 and lambda on chromosome 22). 
  • t(11:14) is associated with Mantle cell Lymphoma, t(14:18) is associated with Folicular Lymphoma and (15:17) is associated with APML. 
Memorizing trick: -
Half of 8 looks like B- Burkitt's- t(8;14), t(2;8),t(8;22)


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 601.

questions.text: What is Translocation t(2:8)(p12:q24) associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Burkitt's Lymphoma

Translocation t (2:8) (p12: q24) is associated with Burkitt's Lymphoma. 
Memorizing trick: -
Half of 8 looks like B- Burkitt's- t(8;14), t(2;8),t(8;22)
Option (1)
CML is associated with t (9;22) (q34; q11.2)
Option (2)
AML is a heterogenous disease as far as the genetic basis is concerned but common translocations include t(8;21), inv16, t(15;17)
Option (3)
ALL is also a heterogenous disease as far as the genetic basis is concerned but common translocations/genetic aberrations include t(12;21), trisomies (4/7/10), t(9;22), etc. 


Common lymphoid Neoplasm and their characteristic chromosomal translocation 
 
Lymphoma Chromosomal Translocation
Burkitt's Lymphoma t(8;14), t(2:8) , t(8:22)
MALToma t(11:18)
Follicular Lymphoma t (14:18)
Mantle cell Lymphoma t(11;14)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 316.

questions.text: PNH is linked to deficiencies in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) All of the above
 
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is associated with deficiencies in multiple proteins that are anchored to the cell membrane by glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI).
  • Deficiencies of DAF (decay accelerating factor), MIRL (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis), and other GPI-anchored proteins contribute to the pathogenesis of PNH.
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare, acquired disorder of the blood characterized by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis) and the presence of dark urine in the morning. It is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells. This results in increased sensitivity to complement-mediated destruction.
  • PNH can lead to anemia, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to infections and blood clots. Diagnosis is made through flow cytometry to detect the absence of GPI-anchored proteins.
  • Treatment options include supportive care, blood transfusions, and targeted therapies such as eculizumab.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

choices.text: GPI Anchored Protein (Glycosyl phosphatidyl inositol anchored proteins)

questions.text: PNH is associated with deficiency of:
questions.solution:
