Correct Answer is (Option 3) GPI Anchored Protein (Glycosyl phosphatidyl inositol anchored proteins)
 
  • PNH is primarily associated with a deficiency of GPI-anchored proteins on the surface of red blood cells, leukocytes, and platelets. The most notable GPI-anchored protein deficiency in PNH is CD55 (decay accelerating factor, DAF) and CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, MIRL).
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare, acquired disorder of the blood characterized by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis) and the presence of dark urine in the morning. It is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells. This results in increased sensitivity to complement-mediated destruction.
  • PNH can lead to anemia, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to infections and blood clots. Diagnosis is made through flow cytometry to detect the absence of GPI-anchored proteins.
  • Treatment options include supportive care, blood transfusions, and targeted therapies such as eculizumab.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

questions.text: Plasmacytoid lymphomas is linked to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) IgM

Plasmacytoid lymphomas are typically associated with the production of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulins.
IgM is a pentameric immunoglobulin involved in the primary immune response and is commonly observed in B-cell lymphomas such as Waldenström macroglobulinemia.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 610.

questions.text: Which of the following has a mutational deficit and leads to Leiden thrombophilia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Factor V
 
  • Factor V has a mutational deficit and leads to Leiden thrombophilia.
  • Leiden thrombophilia is a genetic disorder characterized by an increased risk of blood clot formation.
  • The mutation in the Factor V gene, known as Factor V Leiden mutation, makes individuals more susceptible to abnormal clotting.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 127.

choices.text: Serum levels of factor VIII are decreased.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate about hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Serum levels of factor VIII are decreased.
 
  • Serum levels of factor VIII are decreased in hemophilia A.
  • Hemophilia A is a hereditary bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of clotting factor VIII.
  • Decreased levels of factor VIII result in impaired blood clotting, leading to prolonged bleeding episodes and easy bruising.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Massive blood transfusion results in -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Metabolic Acidosis
This can be controversial as both metabolic acidosis and alkalosis is possible with massive blood transfusion.
Defined as transfusion of equal blood volume of patient within in 24 hours (5L/24h) or half the blood volume within 3 hours.(2.5L/3h) 
Sodium citrate and citric acid can result in metabolic acidosis and hypocalcemia when added to blood products during storage to prevent coagulation. 

* [Extra Edge]: Complications of Massive blood transfusion
  • Hypocalcemia: ionized calcium is bound by citrate anticoagulant
  • Hyperkalemia: due to RBC breakdown
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypothermia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Initially Metabolic acidosis: due to  sodium citrate >>>Later Metabolic alkalosis due to formation of NaHCO3 from citrate, When you have to choose one choose Acidosis.
Online Reference: Jennings LK, Watson S. Massive Transfusion. [Updated 2023 Oct 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499929/

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of fatigue and abdominal pain after playing football. USG abdomen shows a large spleen. Which of the following is the most likely cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sickle cell anemia
 
  • Sickle cell anemia is an inherited disorder caused by a mutation in the gene responsible for making hemoglobin, which carries oxygen in red blood cells.
  • Symptoms of sickle cell anemia include anemia, pain, fatigue, jaundice, and infections. People with this disorder have red blood cells that are curved and look like sickles.
  • These cells cannot deliver enough oxygen to parts of the body because they don't last as long as normal red blood cells. Other features of sickle cell anemia include a risk of stroke, organ damage, an increased risk for blood clots, and an increased risk for infections due to a weakened immune system.
  • Sickle cell crisis- bone pains, abdominal colic occur during low oxygen tension like exercise as given in the question stem
  • In the early stages of the disease splenomegaly is present and later due to vascular crises autosplenectomy occurs. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

choices.text: Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 stores aggravating symptoms

questions.text: A 30 years old patient complaints of easy fatigability, exertional dyspnoea and weight loss. She also complaints of frequent fall. There is B/L decrease in vibration sense. Her Hb levels were low. She was treated with folate. Her anemia improved but neurological symptoms worsened. Which of the following is most probable reason of her condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 stores aggravating symptoms

  • B12 deficiency causes neurological features, folate deficiency doesnt directly cause neurological features.
  • Folate therapy is the process of taking folic acid (a B vitamin) to treat symptoms of pernicious anemia. When folate therapy is administered, the body’s folate stores (which are already present in red blood cells) are rapidly depleted.
  • This in turn can cause the body to use its stores of vitamin B12 to remain operational; but, as vitamin B12 serves to aid in the metabolism of folate, this depletion can further aggravate the anemia symptoms and lead to an overall slower metabolism. This is known as Folate trap. 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 655.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient from Punjab presented with h/o of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, Hb =7gm%, MCV = 102 FL. PS shows macrocytic RBCs. What is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Alcoholism

* [Extra Edge]: Signs and Symptoms of Chronic Alcoholism

  1. Physical Changes: Chronic heavy drinking can lead to physical changes in the body, such as cirrhosis of the liver and a condition called macrocytosis. Macrocytosis is an abnormally large red blood cell size, resulting from a deficiency in vitamin B-12. It can cause fatigue, anemia, loss of appetite, dizziness, and irritability.
  2. Cognitive Changes: Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to problems with focus and cognition, such as difficulty concentrating, impaired judgement, and memory problems. As alcohol consumption increases, so does the risk of cognitive changes.
  3. Behavioral Changes: Drinking alcohol heavily on a regular basis can lead to behaviors that would not normally be exhibited in someone who isn’t drinking. This can include changes in attitude, social behavior, and relationships.
  4. Psychological Changes: Chronic alcoholism can heavily affect the mental health of a person and can lead to feelings of depression, anxiety, and restlessness. It can also limit the individual’s ability to cope with stress and can lead to increased risks of suicide or self-harm. 
  5. Nutrition Deficiencies: Chronic alcohol consumption can result in numerous nutritional deficiencies due to an inadequate intake of nutrients or alcohol interfering with the absorption of vitamins or minerals in food. Nutritional deficiencies can lead to a weakened immune system and symptom of anemia.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 420.

questions.text: Mention the deficiency when a 45-year-old has paresthesia and Hb=6.8g/dL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and neutrophils with hypersegmented nuclei. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vit. B12 deficiency

  • Pernicious anemia (PA) is an autoimmune macrocytic anemia caused by a vitamin B12 deficiency due to a lack of intrinsic factor which is an important factor for the absorption of B12 in the small intestine.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms such as paresthesia, and a decreased Hemoglobin (Hb) value of 6gm% is a sign of anemia.
  • Characteristic features seen on a peripheral smear that occurs due to megaloblastic anemia can include macrocytes, and neutrophils with hyper segmented nuclei.
  • Endoscopy findings can reveal atrophy of gastric mucosa, which can result in decreased absorption of vitamin B12 due to a lack of intrinsic factor, and therefore lead to its deficiency.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 652.

questions.text: Choose the lab parameters of IDA from the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 


Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA) is characterized by:

  • Increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) – Due to low iron levels, the liver produces more transferrin to enhance iron transport.
  • Decreased transferrin saturation – Less iron is available to bind to transferrin, leading to reduced saturation.
  • Decreased ferritin – Ferritin is the storage form of iron, and its levels drop in IDA due to depleted iron stores.

 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 655.

questions.text: Deficiency of what led to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vit. B12 deficiency
 
  • Pernicious anemia (PA) is an autoimmune macrocytic anemia caused by a vitamin B12 deficiency due to a lack of intrinsic factor which is an important factor for the absorption of B12 in the small intestine.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms such as paresthesia, and a decreased Hemoglobin (Hb) value of 6gm% is a sign of anemia.
  • Characteristic features seen on a peripheral smear that occurs due to megaloblastic anemia can include macrocytes, and neutrophils with hyper segmented nuclei.
  • Endoscopy findings can reveal atrophy of gastric mucosa, which can result in decreased absorption of vitamin B12 due to a lack of intrinsic factor, and therefore lead to its deficiency.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 652.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability, pallor, hyperpigmented knuckles, and white nails. The findings from her hand are displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B 12 deficiency

In the given scenario, the likely diagnosis is vitamin B12 deficiency. It is characterized by- 
1. Fatigability
2. Pallor
3. White nails
4. Hyper-pigmented knuckles

The first three signs describe an anemic picture, while the fourth one is specific for B12 deficiency.
Hyperpigmented knuckles are either due to increased levels of melanin or decreased levels of reduced glutathione which activates tyrosinase and thus leads to increased transfer to melanosomes. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 652.

choices.text: It has a Complete response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor in all cases

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the accelerated phase of CML
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 1) It has a Complete response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor in all cases

According to 5th edition of WHO classification of hematolymphoid tumors, accelerated phase of CML is removed.
Criteria for blastic phase includes-
1. Presence of >20% myeloid blasts in blood or bone marrow
2. Presence of extramedullary proliferation of blasts.
3. Presence of increased lymphoblasts in peripheral blood or bone marrow

The presence of more than or equal to 1 of the following cytogenetic/hematological criteria or provisional criteria for response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) therapy defines CML-AP.
Hematological/Cytogenetic Criteria:
A persistent or increasing high WBC count that is therapy-unresponsive (>10 x 10^9/L).
Splenomegaly that persists or worsens and is unresponsive to treatment.
Unresponsive to therapy, persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 x 10^9/L) Persistent (<100 x 10^9/L) thrombocytopenia unrelated to treatment. >20% basophils in the PBS 10-19% blasts in PBS Philadelphia (Ph) chromosome.

Patients in accelerated or blastic phase may receive therapy with TKIs, preferably second- or third-generation TKIs (dasatinib, nilotinib, bosutinib, ponatinib), alone or in combination with chemotherapy, to reduce the CML burden, before undergoing allogeneic SCT. Response rates (major hematologic) with single-agent TKIs range from 30 to 50% in accelerated phase and from 20 to 30% in blastic phase.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 826.

questions.text:
A patient arrived with a history of renal failure, nodular lesions with cavitations in the lungs, ulcerative lesions in the
nasopharynx, and recurrent sinusitis.
Which of the following investigations is the most crucial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) ANCA for vasculitis

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly known as Wegener’s Granulomatosis, is the most likely diagnosis based on the history provided in the question. 

GPA is a necrotizing vasculitis characterized by a triad of:
  • i. acute necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract (ear, nose, sinuses, throat) or the lower respiratory tract (lung) or both
  • ii. necrotizing or granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, most prominent in the lungs and upper airways but also affecting other sites
  • iii. focal necrotizing, frequently crescentic glomerulonephritis.
The immunofluorescence patterns produced by ANCA antibodies are perinuclear and cytoplasmic, respectively
ANCA antibodies were previously grouped as c-ANCA (cytoplasmic) and p- ANCA (perinuclear). Now
1. Antilroteinase-3(PR3-ANCA, previously c-ANCA)
2. Anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO- ANCA, previously p-ANCA)

ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Leukemia
 
  • PNH is a condition brought on by acquired mutations in the PIGA gene, an enzyme required for the production of a few complement regulatory proteins linked with membranes.
  • Clinical Signs and Symptoms In adults, nocturnal and morning hemoglobinuria is a common finding: More frequently, hemolysis is chronic. Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia are frequently seen. episodes of back pain and headaches that come and go frequently.
  • The diagnosis of PNH may be preceded or followed by hypoplastic or aplastic pancytopenia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

questions.text: Which of the following describes a hallmark of Langerhans cell histiocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Birbeck granules 

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare multisystem disorder characterized by the clonal proliferation of Langerhans Cells.
  • (Antigen presenting cell)
  • The Penta laminar tubules known as Birbeck granules, which contain the protein langerin are hallmarks of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • These Birbeck granules frequently have a dilated terminal end that gives them the appearance of a tennis racket.
* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: Which of the following does not feature splenomegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Aplastic anemia
 
  • Aplastic Anemia is a condition in which there is complete absence of both intra and extramedullary hemopoiesis. Hence there is no splenomegaly in this case.
  • Lymphoma and leukemia present with splenomegaly Due to splenic involvement by malignant cells. 
  • Hairy cell leukemia has bone marrow infiltration resulting in extramedullary hemopoiesis presenting as splenomegaly.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 659.

questions.text: A patient's peripheral blood analysis revealed lymphocytosis with smudge cells. Which of the following investigations is most likely to yield a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flow cytometry

The given clinical history is suggestive of Chronic Lymphocytic Lymphoma.
Clinically presents with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, anaemia (autoimmune haemolytic anemia).
Flow cytometry helps us arrive at a definitive diagnosis and rule out important differential diagnosis.

Flow cytometry—

CD19+, CD20+, CD5+ CD23+.

Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia - Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 336.

questions.text: A child with proptosis and little extraocular movement presents to the OPD. Chloroma is tentatively diagnosed. Which of the following investigations is the best suitable for evaluation?
questions.solution:
In the context of a child with proptosis and limited extraocular movement where chloroma (a myeloid sarcoma) is tentatively diagnosed, the best suitable investigation for evaluation would be 2. Peripheral smear.

A peripheral smear can help identify the presence of abnormal cells, such as blasts that are indicative of myeloid leukemia or chloroma. This investigation would provide immediate information about the type of cells in circulation, which is crucial for diagnosing hematological conditions. Other options like platelet count, leukocyte count, and hemoglobin estimation are useful but would not directly provide the necessary diagnostic information for chloroma as effectively as a peripheral smear would.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 620.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy arrives at the emergency department complaining of neck swelling. Cervical lymphadenopathy was discovered during the examination. Following a lymph node biopsy, HPE revealed the image below. Identify the cancer and the characteristic feature.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hodgkin’s with R-S cells; EBV infection

  • The given image shows Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) which are considered pathognomic/typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • They are distinct neoplastic giant cells (30-60 um in size) with abundant cytoplasm, 2 large nuclei, and 2 large inclusion like nucleoli giving an Owl Eye appearance that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers. Reed Sternberg cells in a background of inflammatory cells infiltrate are diagnostic of Hodgkin's Lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin's Lymphoma is typically associated with EBV infection.  


* [Extra Edge]: Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells)



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: A boy who has a history of fever, night sweats, and neck swellings visits the OPD. A biopsy of the swellings revealed a starry sky look. Identify the likely gene mutation responsible for the given ailment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) C-myc

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of Burkitt’s Lymphoma.
  • It is the most common type of NHL in children < 15 years.
  • It is also commonly associated with EBV infection. Lymph Node Biopsy: Starry Sky appearance
  • It is a cancer of B lymphocytes present in germinal center.
  • It can arise from genetic defects: t (8:14), t (2:8), t (8:22). t (8:14) - Resulting in increased expression of c - myc (oncogene) causing increased cell proliferation.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 289.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about NLPHL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Poor prognosis compared to classical HL
 
  • NLPHL has the best prognosis among various subtypes of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) is a slow-growing CD20 positive form of Hodgkin lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system's B cells.
  • The five year survival rate of NLPHL is more than 90% making it one of the most survivable cancers present.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: A baby who was 14 months old and whose Hb level was 6.3 gm% received repeated blood transfusions during the previous nine months. Which of the following will be the best investigation for this patient's final diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Globin gene sequencing

Decreased hemoglobin levels, multiple target cells on peripheral smear and history of multiple blood transfusions point towards thalassemia.
In cases of thalassemia definitive diagnosis is done though Globin gene sequencing.

Investigations for hemoglobin disorders include:
  • Screening by hemoglobin electrophoresis.
  • Investigation of choice is HPLC.
  • Definitive diagnosis though globin gene sequencing.
* [Extra Edge]:

  • HbH disease, which is usually due to compound heterozygosity for one chromosome with both α-globin genes deleted and one chromosome with only a single α-globin gene, is defined by the hematologic findings along with varying levels of reticulocytosis.
  • At birth, when hemoglobin is separated by HPLC, 20–30% Hb Bart’s is present; in adults, traces to 40% HbH are present along with residual Hb Bart’s in some cases.
  • HbH inclusions can be induced in some red cells after incubation and staining with brilliant cresyl blue.
  • Hemoglobin composition in Hb Bart’s hydrops fetalis is predominantly Hb Bart’s with some Hb Portland if the deletion removing α-globin genes preserves the ζ-globin gene.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 645.

questions.text:
Which of the following will show up on a flow cytometry test if the lymphoma cell is positive for t( 11;14 ) translocation? 
 (A) SOX 11
 (B) Cyclin D1
 (C) CD 10
 (D) CD 200
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) A and B only

T (11, 14) containing lymphoma has SOX 11 and Cyclin D1.

Mantle cell lymphoma:
  • Involves 11:14, translocation.
  • Leads to over expression of cyclin D1.
  • SOX 11 is the new marker for cyclin D1 (-) mantle cell lymphoma. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 602.

questions.text: What is the least likely cause of bone marrow showing dry tap?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Follicular lymphoma

The least likely cause of Bone marrow showing dry tap amongst the given options is Follicular lymphoma. Dry tap means no cells in Bone Marrow aspiration, then the next line investigation becomes Bone Marrow Biopsy. 
  
* [Extra Edge]:

A nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions:
(1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small, cleaved cells), 
(2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts


A dry tap on bone marrow is seen usually due to bone marrow fibrosis or in cases of aplastic anemia.

+ Amongst the given options:
- Hairy cell leukemia: dry tap is seen due to perisinusoidal fibrosis, and it shows pancytopenia
- AML M7: Megakaryoblasts release Platelet-derived Growth factor and TGF-Beta which results in none marrow fibrosis
- MDS:  Abnormal dysplastic cells release fibrogenic cytokines which results in bone marrow fibrosis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text:
What is the most common cause of JAK2 mutation?
 1. Essential thrombocytosis
 2. Polycythemia Vera
 3. PMF
 4. CLL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Polycythemia Vera

JAK 2 mutation is most commonly associated with Polycythemia Vera.

JAK 2 mutation is associated with various myeloproliferative disorders, as follows-  
  • i. Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • ii. Polycythemia Vera
  • iii. Essential thrombocythemia
  • iv. Primary myelofibrosis
  • v. Systemic mastocytosis
  • vi. Chronic eosinophilic leukemia

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 625.

questions.text:
Which is the most likely diagnosis for the given peripheral smear

 1. B 12 deficiency
 2. IDA
 3. HS
 4. MDS
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B 12 deficiency
 
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are seen in both Megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency and in Myelodysplastic syndrome. But since vitamin deficiency is much more common it is the better answer.
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils refers to neutrophils with more than 5 nuclear lobules.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 654.

questions.text:
Which of the following will have pancytopenia, as revealed by a blood test?
A. Megaloblastic anemia
B. Hairy cell leukemia
C. MDS with hypocellular BM
D. APML
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) A, B, C
 
  • Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia doesn’t show pancytopenia. Rather it shows hypercellularity in peripheral smear.
  • Pancytopenia is present in megaloblastic anemia with hypocellular BM as a result of inefficient hematopoiesis.
  • Hairy cell leukemia with hypocellular BM exhibits splenomegaly and pancytopenia from perisinusoidal fibrosis.
  • Pancytopenia and hypocellular BM occur in MDS.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 618.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in the center of target cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Haemoglobin
 
  • Codocytes, also known as target cells, are red blood cells that have the appearance of a shooting target with a bullseye.
  • In optical microscopy these cells appear to have a dark center (a central, hemoglobinized area) surrounded by a white ring (an area of relative pallor), followed by dark outer (peripheral) second ring containing a band of hemoglobin.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 647.

questions.text:
A Patient presented with generalised fatigue, tiredness. Primary clinical examination was normal . Normal TLC and DLC.No immature cells were seen on PS. Superficial discrete lymph nodes were enlarged. On biopsy, it showed an effaced architecture,  atypical cells containing indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus. CD 10 and BCL 2 were Positive.
What’s the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Follicular lymphoma
 
  • By performing a biopsy, which involves removing all or part of an enlarged lymph node and studying the cells under a microscope, the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma is confirmed.
  • In FL instances, CD10 expression is present. Follicles showed a significant positive trend. One CD10-positive instance of FL displayed ambiguous BCL2 staining, while the other did not.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 599.

questions.text:
Red cell aplasia was diagnosed in a patient with a substernal mass who was not responding to blood transfusion. Hb is low; TLC is normal.
What is the most probable cause of aplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 3) Thymic neoplasia
 
  • Thymic neoplasia is the most probable cause.
  • Pure Red Cells Aplasia is believed to be an autoimmune condition that may be brought on by a thymus gland tumor, some medications, or a viral infection. It belongs to a class of disorders that cause bone marrow failure.
  • Pure Red Cells Aplasia is also seen in Parvo virus B19 infection and Diamond-Blackfan syndrome. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 633.

questions.text:
A patient who arrived with exhaustion, weight loss, and illness has a 20-year history of exposure to benzene.
Systematic analysis is typical. Which cancer is the most likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Blood
 
  • Blood cancer will be suspected in the given patient.
  • Anemia may result from benzene's damaging effects on the bone marrow and possible reduction in red blood cell production. Moreover, it can weaken the immune system and produce excessive bleeding, which increases the risk of infection.
Remember Benzene - AML vs Benzidene - Bladder Cancer
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 659.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman working in IT visited the OPD complaining of light weariness. She explains that she has a history of spending 12 to 14 hours every day in front of a computer. She typically orders non-vegetarian food with less fruits and vegetables from a restaurant. A blood test revealed Hb was 9g% and MCV was 120. What is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Folic Acid deficiency
 
  • The 30-year-old woman working in IT complains of light weariness, and her blood test reveals low hemoglobin (9g%) and an elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 120.
  • The most likely cause of her condition is folic acid deficiency.
  • Folic acid is essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell production.
  • Prolonged computer use and a diet lacking in fruits and vegetables contribute to folic acid deficiency.
  • The deficiency leads to impaired DNA synthesis, resulting in ineffective red blood cell maturation and macrocytic anemia.
* [Extra Edge]: Vitamins



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 653.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy shows up with bleeding gums and is easily bruised. He had  Hb 3g/dL, TLC 15,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 15000/mm3 after a month of fever. Upon examination, there was pallor and a petechial rash all over the body. No spleen. No immature cells are visible in the peripheral smear. No Macrocytes, no megakaryocytes, and depleted bone marrow is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic anemia
 
  • The 20-year-old boy presents with bleeding gums, easy bruising, severe anemia (Hb 3g/dL), low platelet count (15,000/mm3), pallor, and a petechial rash. The most likely diagnosis is idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.
  • This condition is characterized by bone marrow failure, resulting in pancytopenia (low red blood cells, low white blood cells, and low platelets).
  • The absence of immature cells, macrocytes, and megakaryocytes in the peripheral smear, as well as depleted bone marrow, further support this diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 660.

questions.text: Except for__________,  all rise with iron deficiency anaemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Transferrin Saturation
 
  • Transferrin saturation is decreased in IDA.
  • Low transferrin saturation and high iron binding capacity are indicators of an iron deficit (even in the presence of a normal or elevated ferritin).
  • Tissue iron shortage causes an increase in soluble transferrin receptors.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 655.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the RBC of a G6PD patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with G6PD (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency, the correct description of the red blood cells (RBCs) is 4. Hemolyses in hypotonic saline.

G6PD deficiency leads to reduced production of NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining the integrity of the red blood cell membrane. As a result, these RBCs are more susceptible to oxidative stress and can undergo hemolysis more readily, especially in hypotonic saline. This means they would swell and burst in a dilute solution due to their compromised membrane stability.

The other options do not accurately describe the RBCs in G6PD deficiency:

  • 1. Mutated spectrin: This is more characteristic of conditions like hereditary spherocytosis.
  • 2. Spherical in shape: G6PD-deficient RBCs can be more prone to shape changes due to oxidative stress, but they are not specifically described as spherical.
  • 3. Resist hemolysis in saline: G6PD-deficient RBCs are actually more likely to hemolyze under oxidative stress conditions, including in hypotonic solutions.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 640.

questions.text:
Previously, two blood transfusions were necessary for a 6-year-old child who is pallorous now. Fever and petechial haemorrhages have also appeared in him.
His Hb is 9 gm/dL, platelet count is 20,000/mm3 and 60,000/mm3, respectively.
The results of flow cytometry show that CD-10 +ve, CD-19 +ve, CD-33 - ve, CD-117 +ve, MPO +ve and CD-3 -ve.
The diagnosis that is most likely is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Mixed phenotypic acute leukemia
 
  • The most likely diagnosis is mixed phenotypic acute leukemia.
  • Mixed-phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) is a rare but difficult-to-treat hematologic malignancy with immunophenotypic co-expression of at least two cell lineages, or with only rare cases involving all three lineages, e.g. myeloid with B- or T-lymphoid or all three of myeloid, B- and T-lymphoid altogether
  • In the given case scenario -CD10 and CD19 are B-lymphoid markers whereas CD117 and myeloperoxidase are myeloid lineage markers and hence, the child likely has MPAL (Mixed Phenotypic Acute leukemia) 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 809.

questions.text: A female patient, aged 22, describes having chronic joint discomfort and joint in the past. She is now noticing multiple ecchymotic patches. Most likely, she has what?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Acquired factor VIII inhibitors
 
  • The clinical presentation in a young female with recurrent joint pains with ecchymotic hemorrhage is suggestive of an autoimmune disease.
  • Options '1', '2', and '3' would present with mucosal bleeding episodes (epistaxis/petechia/gum bleeds and not ecchymosis) and they would also be present since birth.
  • A female patient is unlike to have hemophilia, as it is an X-linked disorder. However, she can have autoantibodies against factor VIII - which then can cause ecchymotic patches.
  • Joint pain given in the clinical stem can also be due to hemarthrosis which is common with factor VIII deficiency. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to treat sideroblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pyridoxine
 
Supplemental pyridoxine may be effective in treating the severe anemia. (The activity of ALA-synthase depends on this cofactor.) 
  • The frequency of transfusions may be decreased or eliminated with cofactor supplementation.
  • Those who are unresponsive can need blood transfusions and need chelation therapy.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3230.
Online Reference: Abu-Zeinah G, DeSancho MT. Understanding Sideroblastic Anemia: An Overview of Genetics, Epidemiology, Pathophysiology and Current Therapeutic Options. J Blood Med. 2020 Sep 25;11:305-318. doi: 10.2147/JBM.S232644. PMID: 33061728; PMCID: PMC7524202.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in preleukemic conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria
 
  • Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a pre-leukemic condition.
  • Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH) is a benign self-limiting autoimmune hemolytic anemia. PCH does not undergo leukemic transformation and is hence not considered a pre-leukemic condition.
  • Recovery is the rule in Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria.
  • PNH may terminate in Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Other options mentioned are also believed to be preleukaemic conditions.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 650.

questions.text: On what does flow cytometry take place?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lymphocytes
 
  • Flow cytometry is done on lymphocytes
  • Numerous individual cell properties, including membrane antigens and the DNA content of tumor cells, can be quickly and precisely measured by flow cytometry.
  • The identification and classification of malignancies originating from T and B lymphocytes as well as from mononuclear phagocytic cells have both been aided by flow cytometry.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 332.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign that megaloblastic anaemia is not present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Increased reticulocyte count

Increased reticulocyte count does not indicate megaloblastic anemia.

* Characteristics of megaloblastic anemia
    • hypercellular bone marrow with abnormally large, nucleated RBC
    • raised unconjugated bilirubin and
    • mild splenomegaly

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: Myelofibrosis leading to a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is seen with which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Acute megakaryocytic leukemia
 
  • Myelofibrosis leading to a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is seen with acute megakaryocytic leukemia.
  • In acute megakaryocytic leukemia, its challenging to aspirate the bone marrow, and ~60% of patients have considerable fibrosis due to the production of fibrogenic cytokines.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 626.

questions.text: Which one below is a Lymphoma Marker?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Leukocyte common antigen

Lymphoma marker is leukocyte common antigen (CD 45).
Normal lymphocytes as well as the majority of lymphoproliferative disorders express LCA (leukocyte common antigen) or CD45 strongly.

Other options: - 
  • S-100 and HMB-45 are markers of melanocytes 
  • Cytokeratin is a marker of epithelial neoplasm

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 593.

questions.text: The following cause of hemolytic anemia involves IgM in the Pathogenesis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Mycoplasma infection
 
  • Mycoplasma infection is associated with hemolytic anemia involving IgM antibodies.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae, a bacteria-like organism, can cause atypical pneumonia and is known to induce the production of cold agglutinins, which are IgM antibodies that bind to red blood cells at low temperatures.
  • The binding of IgM antibodies to red blood cells leads to their destruction and hemolysis, resulting in hemolytic anemia.
  • Other causes of hemolytic anemia involving IgM include infectious mononucleosis (caused by EBV) and certain lymphomas.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 650.

questions.text: The following diad is true regarding the given image and the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bite cells: G6PD deficiency 
 
  • Bite cells and helmet cells are characteristic of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is an inherited enzymatic disorder that leads to red blood cell membrane damage and the formation of Heinz bodies.
  • Bite cells are formed when macrophages in the spleen remove the Heinz bodies from the red blood cells, leaving characteristic "bites" or notches.
  • Therefore, the correct match is Bite cells - G6PD deficiency.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: A patient has Pancytopenia and back pain. The accompanying image displays a bone marrow aspirate. The conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Multiple myeloma
 
  • Pancytopenia (reduction in red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) along with back pain suggests a possible bone marrow disorder.
  • Bone marrow aspirate in multiple myeloma typically shows:
    • Increased plasma cells (abnormal, cancerous plasma cells).
    • Replacement of normal bone marrow elements by these abnormal plasma cells.
    • Rouleax formation (RBCs being stacked up).
  • Multiple myeloma is a malignant neoplasm of plasma cells, which can infiltrate the bone marrow and cause pancytopenia
  • Inclusions in Myeloma are - 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 608.

questions.text: There is an increase in PT and aPTT in-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Liver diseases
 
  • PT (Prothrombin Time) and aPTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) are tests used to evaluate the clotting function of the blood.
  • In liver diseases, the liver's synthetic function is impaired, leading to a deficiency in clotting factors.
  • Decreased levels of clotting factors in the blood result in prolonged PT and aPTT.

* Other options:
 
  • Hemophilia A is a congenital disorder characterized by a deficiency in factor VIII, leading to prolonged aPTT.
  • Hemophilia C is a rare congenital disorder characterized by a deficiency in factor XI, leading to prolonged aPTT.
  • von Willebrand disease (VWD) is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, resulting in prolonged bleeding time and sometimes aPTT.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 455.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following is associated with a favourable/good prognosis in AML?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (3) Translocation (15:17)
 
  • Prognosis in AML is influenced by various factors, including age/TLC/FAB subtype and genetic abnormalities.
  • Translocation (15:17) refers to the fusion of the promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene on chromosome 15 and the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARα) gene on chromosome 17- resulting in PML-RARA fusion gene formation. 
  • This translocation results in subtype of AML called acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) - also M3 subtype in the FAB classification
  • APML has a excellent prognosis, with high response rates to treatment (~ 90-95% overall survival) which includes all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and As2O3 (Arsenic trioxide) given as differentiating agents. 

Other options
  • Age <1 year i.e infantile AML is associated with a bad prognosis. Infantile Leukaemia typically tends to have t(4;11) involving MLL gene translocation which confers chemotherapy resistance and poor prognosis. 
  • Total leukocyte count >1 Lac/mm3 (100,000/mm3) is a high leukocyte count and can be associated with a higher risk of complications; hence associated with a poor prognosis
  • Deletion 5q is a chromosomal abnormality found in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) which can then transform into secondary AML.  Secondary AML has poor prognosis.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 811.

questions.text: Which of the following bleeding conditions shows an elevated aPTT with a normal PT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hemophilia A
 
  • The activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and prothrombin time (PT) are tests used to evaluate the clotting function of blood.
  • Hemophilia A is a congenital bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of clotting factor VIII.
  • Hemophilia A is characterized by an elevated aPTT (indicating a defect in the intrinsic pathway) and a normal PT (indicating an intact extrinsic pathway).

Other options:
 
  • Liver diseases, such as cirrhosis, can lead to abnormalities in both aPTT and PT due to impaired synthesis of clotting factors.
  • Parahemophilia is a rare bleeding disorder characterized by a deficiency of clotting factor V can lead to abnormality in both aPTT and PT. 
  • Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by low platelet counts and can affect both aPTT and PT.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Identify the synonyms of the correctly matched cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Target Cells or Codocytes
 
  • Target cells, also known as codocytes, are red blood cells with a central area of hemoglobin surrounded by a ring of pallor and a thickened rim of hemoglobin.
  • They appear as a target or bullseye-shaped cell under the microscope.

* [Extra Edge]: Types of RBCs


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 428.

questions.text: What does a direct anti-globulin (Coombs) test that is positive mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hemolytic disease
 
  • A positive direct anti-globulin (Coombs) test indicates the presence of antibodies or complement proteins bound to the surface of red blood cells.
  • This finding suggests immune-mediated hemolysis, where the immune system targets and destroys red blood cells.
  • Hemolytic disease refers to a condition characterized by increased destruction of red blood cells.
  • The positive Coombs test helps confirm the diagnosis of immune-mediated hemolytic diseases such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia and hemolytic disease of the newborn.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 462.

questions.text: Heavy chain disease with immunoglobin fragments in urine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
 
  • Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a syndrome in which high levels of IgM lead to symptoms related to hyper viscosity of the blood like stroke, amarausis fugax,etc. 
  • It occurs in older adults, most commonly in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: What is the process by which CLL/SLL becomes DLBCL known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Richter syndrome
 
  • The process by which Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL) transforms into Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) is known as Richter Syndrome.
  • Richter Syndrome is a rare complication characterized by the development of an aggressive lymphoma, usually DLBCL, in patients with preexisting CLL/SLL.
  • This transformation is associated with a poor prognosis, as DLBCL is more aggressive and less responsive to treatment compared to CLL/SLL.
* [Extra Edge]: Types of Non-Hodgkin lymphomas


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 599.

questions.text: HbH is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Deletion of 3 alpha genes 
 
  • HbH (hemoglobin H) disease is caused by the deletion of three alpha genes, resulting in a deficiency of alpha-globin chains.
  • The remaining alpha genes are unable to produce enough alpha-globin chains, leading to the formation of abnormal hemoglobin H (composed of four beta chains) in red blood cells.
  • HbH disease results in chronic hemolytic anemia and can manifest with splenomegaly, jaundice, and bone changes.
  • The deletion of four alpha genes would result in the more severe form, alpha-thalassemia major (also known as hydrops fetalis).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

choices.text: Normal Platelet count with prolonged bleeding time
Normal Platelet count with normal bleeding time

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Platelet function defects is true:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Normal Platelet count with prolonged bleeding time
 
  • Platelet function defects are disorders characterized by abnormalities in platelet function, leading to impaired clot formation and prolonged bleeding time.
  • Platelet function defect is known as Thrombesthania. 
  • The platelet count in platelet function defects is typically normal, as these disorders primarily affect the function rather than the number of platelets.
  • Prolonged bleeding time, which measures the time it takes for bleeding to stop after a standardized skin incision, is a characteristic finding in platelet function defects.
  • Other laboratory tests, such as platelet aggregation studies, can also be performed to evaluate platelet function. It is important to distinguish platelet function defects from other causes of bleeding disorders, such as platelet count disorders or coagulation factor deficiencies.
  • Platelet function defects refer to conditions in which platelets do not function properly, leading to a prolonged bleeding time. Thrombocytopenia is a condition in which there is a low platelet count, which can also lead to a prolonged bleeding time.
  • Thrombocytosis, on the other hand, is a condition in which there is an excessive number of platelets, but this does not necessarily affect platelet function.
  • Therefore, a normal platelet count with a prolonged bleeding time is indicative of platelet function defects.
  • This can be caused by a number of conditions, including von Willebrand disease, Glanzmann's thrombasthenia, and Bernard-Soulier syndrome, among others.
  • Diagnosis is typically made through a combination of clinical evaluation, bleeding time tests, platelet function assays, and genetic testing.
* [Extra Edge]: Platelet Disorder


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 666.

choices.text: Aggregation with collagen and ADP is normal
Due to GP Ib IX receptor defect

questions.text: Which is not true regarding Bernard soulier syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ristocetin aggregation is normal
 
  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare congenital bleeding disorder characterized by a defect in platelet function and decreased platelet adhesion.
  • Ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation is specifically impaired in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.
  • Ristocetin is a medication that induces platelet aggregation by causing the binding of von Willebrand factor (vWF) to platelet surface receptors.
  • In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the affected platelets lack the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, which is the receptor for vWF, resulting in abnormal platelet-vWF interactions and impaired aggregation.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 120.

questions.text: What is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Flow cytometry 
 
  • Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria is a rare, acquired disorder characterized by the deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the cell surface.
  • Flow cytometry is used to detect and quantify the absence or reduced expression of GPI-anchored proteins, such as CD55 and CD59, on red blood cells, granulocytes, and monocytes.
  • This test is essential for confirming the diagnosis of PNH and assessing the extent of GPI-anchored protein deficiency.
  • Other tests, such as sucrose hemolysis and Ham test, can also provide supportive evidence for PNH diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 649.

questions.text: Which one of the following anemias has a raised MCV and normal MCHC?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency
 
  • Anemia refers to a decrease in the number of red blood cells or a decrease in hemoglobin levels, leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) is a measure of the average size of red blood cells.
  • Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency anemias are macrocytic anemias, characterized by an increased MCV (> 100 fL).
  • In these anemias, the red blood cells are larger than normal, but the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) remains within the normal range.
  • Other causes of macrocytic anemia, such as alcoholism and certain medications, can also be associated with an increased MCV.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: Which of the following anemias causes is linked to hypoplastic marrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fanconi's anemia
 
  • Fanconi's anemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by bone marrow failure, congenital abnormalities, and an increased risk of developing malignancies.
  • It is caused by mutations in genes involved in DNA repair mechanisms, leading to genomic instability.
  • The bone marrow in Fanconi's anemia patients may show hypoplasia or aplasia, meaning a decrease or absence of normal cellularity.
  • This bone marrow failure results in reduced production of all blood cell lineages, leading to pancytopenia.
  • Other features of Fanconi's anemia include physical abnormalities, such as skeletal malformations and characteristic facial features.
  • Other options - Primary Myelofibrosis has a proliferative and fibrotic phase, so hypercellular marrow is possible
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 314.

questions.text: Which of the following myeloproliferative illnesses is least likely to be linked to massive splenomegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ET
 
  • Essential Thrombocythemia is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an elevated platelet count in the absence of secondary causes.
  • While splenomegaly can occur in ET, it is typically modest and not massive compared to other myeloproliferative disorders.
  • Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), PV and Primary Myelofibrosis (PMF) are myeloproliferative disorders that commonly present with massive splenomegaly.
  • In ET, the predominant feature is thrombocytosis, which can lead to an increased risk of thrombotic and hemorrhagic complications.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 625.

questions.text: Except for______,  all of the following are linked to secondary hemochromatosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
 
  • Secondary hemochromatosis refers to iron overload resulting from chronic transfusions or increased iron absorption.
  • Thalassemia Major, Sideroblastic Anemia, and Hereditary Spherocytosis can lead to secondary hemochromatosis due to chronic ineffective erythropoiesis, which causes increased iron absorption from the gut and subsequent iron overload.
  • In contrast, Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is not directly associated with secondary hemochromatosis as it is primarily characterized by complement-mediated hemolysis rather than chronic erythropoiesis and iron overload. Moreover, blood transfusion is not required in PNH so it has less chances of developing secondary hemochromatosis. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 848.

questions.text: A 55 years old male presented with complaints of weakness, pallor, weight loss and a dragging sensation in the abdomen. Per abdomen examination revealed massive splenomegaly. Blood pictures showed marked leucoytosis and raised platelet count. Peripheral smear showed myelocytes and metamyelocytes. The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following translocation would be seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
The findings of massive splenomegaly with peripheral smear findings of leucocytosis, increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils go in favor of chronic myeloid leukemia. 

It is characterized by a reciprocal balanced translocation between t(9;22) causing the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene which codes for a 210 kDalton constitutively active tyrosine kinase. 

Option (1)- 8;14 translocation is seen in Burkitt Lymphoma. 

Option (2)- 8;21 translocation is seen in AML M2

Option (4)- 15;17 translocation is seen in AML M3 (APML)



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 601, 602, 617-624.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 826.

questions.text: A patient presented with hemoglobinuria, hemosiderinuria, elevated unconjugated bilirubin and elevated LDH levels. Peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is related to such a condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of hemoglobinuria, hemosiderinuria, elevated unconjugated bilirubin, and LDH with peripheral smear showing schistocytes are suggestive of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). 

Amongst the given options, prosthetic cardiac valves will produce and can cause MAHA. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 647, 650.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 785, 786.

questions.text: An adult male with history of long-standing hemorrhoids developed weakness and lethargy. Blood tests revealed a hemoglobin of 7.5 g/dl. Peripheral blood smear is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of Hb ~ 7.5 g/dl in a patient of long standing hemorrhoids ( which results in blood loss ) with peripheral blood smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia with anisopoikilocytosis is diagnostic of iron deficiency anemia. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 641-644.

questions.text: Which molecule helps in movement of leucocytes across endothelial cells?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis or transmigration of leucocytes is mediated by PECAM/CD31.
 

PECAM-1 (CD31) is the key molecule involved in the transmigration (diapedesis) of leukocytes across endothelial cells. It is expressed on both leukocytes and endothelial cells, facilitating the movement of leukocytes through the endothelial barrier into tissues during inflammation.


Other options:

  • E-Selectin (Option 2):  Facilitates the rolling of leukocytes on the endothelial surface, an early step in the leukocyte extravasation process.
 
  • CD11a (Option 3): Part of the LFA-1 integrin, involved in firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium.
 
  • VLA-4 (Option 4): An integrin involved in leukocyte adhesion to endothelial cells and migration, particularly in certain tissues, but not directly responsible for transmigration.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 12, 78, 79.

choices.text: 8g/dl, MCV=56, MCH =22, RBC count=5.5 million cumm

questions.text:
A 10 year old boy with Hb-9.8g/dl, MCV=56, MCH =22, RBC count=5.5 million cumm
Ferritin =150 [(N)-130-160],
TLC=7600; Lymphocyte = 65%, Neutrophil -30% 
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the iron profile is suggestive of diagnosis of thalassemia.

 
  • The first difference in thalassemia and iron deficiency anemia is in the red blood cell count.
  • In iron deficiency, this value is low because the bone marrow is unable to manufacture red blood cells. In thalassemia trait, RBC is normal to elevated.
 
  • Mentzer index= MCV/RBC count
  • Here, Mentzer index= 9.8, which is less than 13, s/o Thalassemia trait
Mentzer index:
<13: Thalassemia trait/minor
>13: IDA



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 644-649.

questions.text: Maximum amplitude in thromboelastography is due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Platelets 

Thromboelastography provides information on the kinetics and strength of clot formation, which is represented by several parameters including maximum amplitude (MA).
 
  • The extrinsic pathway is responsible for initiating the clotting cascade in response to tissue injury.
  • The extrinsic pathway plays a crucial role in the initiation of clot formation, and therefore, it is responsible for the maximum amplitude in thromboelastography. 
  • Maximum Amplitude represents the maximal clot strength, which is primarily influenced by the platelet function and count.
  • LY30 represents the percentage decrease in amplitude at 30 min after MA was reached, and reflects fibrinolysis.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1161.

Shaydakov ME, Sigmon DF, Blebea J. Thromboelastography. [Updated 2023 Apr 10]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537061/

questions.text: Which of the following markers will be positive in Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
• Reed-Sternberg cells are large, abnormal lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) that may contain more than one nucleus. These cells are found in people with Hodgkin lymphoma
 
  • They are CD15 and CD30 positive.





Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th edition, Page no 611-616.

questions.text: Absent graft versus host reaction in a patient with Bare lymphocyte disease is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Mutation in transcription factor that regulates the expression of class II MHC genes leads to absent graft vs host reaction.
 

Bare lymphocyte syndrome (BLS) is a rare immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the absence or reduced expression of MHC molecules on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • In MHC class II deficiency, there is an inability to present antigens to CD4+ T cells, leading to impaired activation of these cells. This results in a lack of a graft-versus-host (GVH) reaction because CD4+ T cells play a central role in initiating GVH responses.

  • MHC I deficiency, on the other hand, would primarily affect the activation of CD8+ T cells and is associated with different immune defects.


Other options:

  1. CD4 T-cells: While their activation is impaired due to MHC II deficiency, the root cause in BLS is the lack of MHC II, not the absence of CD4 T-cells.
  2. Complement: Complement deficiencies affect innate immunity and are unrelated to GVH reactions or MHC expression.
  3. MHC I: Deficiency of MHC I primarily impacts CD8+ T cells and cytotoxic immune responses, not CD4-mediated processes.


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 244.

questions.text: In a patient with megaloblastic anaemia, which of the following sites is least likely to be associated with malabsorption/dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option (2)

Megalobloastic anemia occurs due to either Vit B12 or folate deficiency. Duodenum(option 2) is not involved in the absorption of vitamin B12 or folic acid. Folate is absorbed in the jejunum while B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Stomach secretes intrinsic factor involved in B12 Absorption and hence stomach dysfunction/involvement by a systemic illness can also result in B12 deficiency. 

Duodenum is involved in the absorption of iron, not B12/Folic acid and duodenal pathology can cause IDA (Iron deficiency anemia) but not megaloblastic anaemia. 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 651-654.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis and muscle hematoma are the features associated with Hemophilia A.
 

Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder caused by Factor VIII deficiency and has the following characteristics:

  1. Factor 8 deficiency (True): Hemophilia A is due to a deficiency or dysfunction of Factor VIII, a key clotting factor in the intrinsic pathway.
  2. XLR inheritance (True): It is inherited in an X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern, primarily affecting males, while females are typically carriers.
  3. More common in males (True): Due to its X-linked inheritance, it predominantly occurs in males.
  4. Mucosal bleeding seen frequently (False): Mucosal bleeding is more characteristic of platelet disorders (e.g., von Willebrand disease or thrombocytopenia). In hemophilia A, the bleeding tends to involve joints (hemarthrosis), muscles, and soft tissues, rather than mucosal surfaces.

  • Hemophilia A typically presents with deep bleeding (e.g., joint and muscle hematomas), not superficial or mucosal bleeding.
  • Mucosal bleeding is more commonly associated with primary hemostasis disorders, like von Willebrand disease.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 668, 669.

choices.text: At least 26 percent cases have family history
GB stones develop by 4 to 5 years age
Splenetomy doesn't protect against developing GB stones

questions.text: Which of the following is true in Hereditary Spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
People usually inherit hereditary spherocytosis from their parents. Usually, 1 parent has the disorder and there is a 50% chance of passing it on in each pregnancy
 

  1. At least 26 percent cases have family history (True):
    Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an autosomal dominant disorder in most cases, though autosomal recessive forms exist. A significant proportion of cases (Almost 75% cases) have a positive family history.

  2. High MCH pathognomonic (False):
    High mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) may be seen in HS due to cellular dehydration but is not specific or pathognomonic. It can occur in other conditions like dehydration or other hemolytic anemias.

  3. GB stones develop by 4 to 5 years age (False):
    Gallstones in HS result from chronic hemolysis and the subsequent increase in bilirubin levels. They typically develop later in childhood or adolescence, not as early as 4–5 years of age.

  4. Splenectomy doesn't protect against developing GB stones (False):
    Splenectomy reduces hemolysis, lowering bilirubin production, and thus reduces the risk of gallstone formation. However, it does not entirely eliminate the risk if gallstones have already formed.


    Hereditary Spherocytosis:

  • Pathophysiology: Defects in red cell membrane proteins (e.g., ankyrin, spectrin) lead to spherocyte formation, which are less deformable and prone to hemolysis.
  • Clinical Features: Hemolytic anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and risk of gallstones (pigment stones).
  • Diagnostic Tests: Increased osmotic fragility, high MCHC, and presence of spherocytes on peripheral smear.
  • Treatment: Folate supplementation, splenectomy for severe cases, and cholecystectomy if gallstones are symptomatic.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 638-640.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21dt edition, Page no 778-780.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below
questions.solution:
Image shown is of Klima's needle.
  • The needles most commonly used for obtaining bone marrow aspirates from the sternum are the Salah and Klima needles.
Mnemonic:
S for Side screw, which is present in Salah's needle

Klima's needle do not have side screw.


Bone marrow biopsy needles:













Reference: Dacie and Lewis Practical Hematology, 12th edition, Page no 15, 120-122.

questions.text: A patient has WBC count of 4,50,000/cumm with eosinophilia and Basophilia. Neutrophil count showed a left shift. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings strongly suggest Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):

  1. WBC count of 4,50,000/cumm: This significantly elevated WBC count is a hallmark feature of CML.
  2. Eosinophilia and Basophilia: CML often shows an increase in eosinophils and basophils, which is less common in other leukemias.
  3. Neutrophil left shift: Indicates the presence of immature neutrophils (e.g., myelocytes, promyelocytes) in peripheral blood, a characteristic feature of CML.

Other options:
 
  • CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia):
    • Typically presents with lymphocytosis, not marked neutrophilia, eosinophilia, or basophilia.
  • AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia):
    • Associated with blasts in peripheral blood, not a high WBC count with left shift, eosinophilia, or basophilia.
  • ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia):
    • Involves lymphoblasts and typically occurs in younger individuals.

Diagnosis:
 
  • Peripheral blood smear: Reveals mature granulocytes with a left shift, eosinophilia, and basophilia.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Hypercellular marrow with myeloid hyperplasia.
  • Cytogenetics or Molecular Studies: Detection of the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) or BCR-ABL fusion gene confirms the diagnosis.

Treatment:
 
  • First-line therapy includes tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib) targeting the BCR-ABL fusion protein.


 
Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 588, 594, 596, 597. 618, 619.

questions.text: 45-year-old woman presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, she was found to be pale and her Hb was 6 gm%. Which of the following feature is most likely to be seen in the peripheral smear of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Based on the given information, the most likely feature to be seen in the peripheral smear of this patient is "Microcytic hypochromic RBCs."
  • Microcytic hypochromic RBCs are seen in conditions such as Iron deficiency anemia, which is the most common cause of anemia worldwide.
  • Iron is an essential component for the production of hemoglobin, and its deficiency leads to small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) RBCs.
  • Other causes of microcytic hypochromic anemia include thalassemia and anemia of chronic disease.
 

Reference : Robbins and Crotan Pathological Basis of Disease , 10th Edition Page no 655,657,658,816 .

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Anemia of Chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Anemia of Chronic disease has 'high' levels of Ferritin, not low. 

Anemia of Chronic Disease
 
  • Anemia of chronic disease (ACD) is a type of anemia that occurs in individuals with chronic inflammatory or infectious diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, and chronic kidney disease.
  • In ACD, increase in the levels of hepcidin reduces the release of iron from stores, leading to a decrease in the amount of iron available for the production of red blood cells, and hence, anemia.
  • In ACD, the levels of ferritin in the blood are typically elevated due to increased iron storage in the RES system, such as the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. The elevation of ferritin in ACD can be useful in distinguishing it from iron-deficiency anemia, where ferritin levels are usually low.


 

Reference : Robbins and Crotan Pathological Basis of Disease , 10th Edition Page no 658,659,848 .

questions.text: In India Pretransfusion routine blood screening is done for all except?
questions.solution:
In India, pretransfusion routine blood screening is done for all except dengue (option 4)

The following blood-borne infections are screened for in India:

1. HIV
2. Hepatitis B
3. Hepatitis C
4. Syphilis
5. Malaria
 

Dengue is not routinely screened for in India.

 

Reference : Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 672.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy presents with recurrent watery stools and diarrhea, atopic dermatitis, petechia and a platelet count of 20,000/mm3. Which among the following is the confirmatory step for a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical stem describes the classical triad of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome in an 11 month old boy. 
  • Atopic dermatitis
  • Thrombocytopenia (petechia and platelet count of 20,000)
  •  Immunodeficiency (repeated watery stools and diarrhea)
Hence, the confirmatory step for diagnosis would be option(1) - WASP gene testing(present on chromosome X )
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 246 .

questions.text: A patient presents with retroperitoneal bleed with a history of pain and swelling in both knees. Which factors deficiency can lead to the given picture?
questions.solution:
Answer: (2) Factors 8, 9

The patient presents with a history of bleeding and we suspect a bleeding disorder. 


 
  • The clinical presentation of a retroperitoneal bleed with pain suggests a deep tissue bleed.
  • The pain and swelling in both knees (hemarthrosis), is also a deep tissue bleed. Thus, we suspect clot-factor deficiency/ disorders. 
  • The most likely factor deficiencies leading to such a presentation are factors 8 and 9, which are both involved in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.
Recall bias: Some examinees also mentioned other demographic history details of the patient being mentioned in the question - such as the age of the patient (young/ 10-20 years), and sex of the patient (male) - which further supports the diagnosis of hemophilia A and B due to its X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 669.

questions.text:
A child has a mass in the jaw. The child is noted to have t(8;14), and a biopsy of the lesion is shown below. Identify the disease in this child?

1. Burkitt Lymphoma
2. AML
3. B-ALL
4. Follicular Lymphoma
questions.solution:
Answer:(1) Burkitt Lymphoma

The findings of a jaw mass with translocation (8:14) and biopsy revealing monomorphic, medium-sized cells with round nuclei, multiple dark nucleoli, basophilic cytoplasm and prominent cytoplasmic lipid vacuoles towards one pole of the cell are highly suggestive of Burkitt Lymphoma.

The Most probable diagnosis Based on Histopathology " Starry Sky" pattern is Burkitt Lymphoma.
The tumor cells express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10 and BCL6 a phenotype consistent with a germinal center B-cell origin.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 602.

questions.text:
A 10-year old child presents with anemia and jaundice and Splenomegaly. Platelet count is 2.5 lakh and TLC is 7500. There is a history of similar complaints in the elder brother. Peripheral smear findings are as shown. What is the probable diagnosis and investigation required to confirm it?

1. Hereditary spherocytosis, Osmotic fragility test
2. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, Coombs test
3. PNH, Flow cytometry
4. HUS, Stool culture
questions.solution:
A child presenting with anemia and jaundice indicates that the etiology of the anemia is likely due to hemolytic jaundice.

The peripheral smear findings in the given case show spherocytes, which are small, dense, and lack central pallor; they can be seen in hereditary spherocytosis, hemolytic anemias of other causes such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AHA), and clostridial sepsis.
  • Only confusion here is between HS & AIHA.
  • HS will have family history, splenomegaly & early presentation.
  • AIHA does not present with a family history.
  • HS is caused by diverse mutations that lead to an insufficiency of membrane skeletal components. As a result of these alterations, the life span of affected red cells is decreased on average to 10 to 20 days from the normal 120 days. The pathogenic mutations most commonly affect ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2, the proteins involved in one of the two tethering interactions.
  • Laboratory Investigations that are done to confirm the diagnosis:
  • Osmotic Fragility test
  • Acid glycerol Lysis test
  • Eosin-5'-maleimide(EMA)- Binding test.
  • SDS- gel electrophoresis test



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 639.

questions.text:
A 64-year old male went for a routine medical and was accidently found to have WBC counts - 95000/ mm3. The peripheral smear is examined. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
1. Bone Marrow Biopsy
2. Flow cytometry
3. BCR-ABL analysis
4. Chemotherapy
questions.solution:
• The elderly patient with raised WBC counts showing marked lymphocytosis (damaged lymphocytes -"smudge cells") are present. This is characterstic of CLL.
  • Immunophenotyping using flow cytometry is the investigation done to arrive at the diagnosis. CD-19+, CD20+, CD23+, CD5+.
  • Expectant Management  is treatment of choice for asymptomatic patient of CLL. The gold standard combination of CLL is Fludarabine, cyclophosphamide and Rituximab.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 598.

choices.text: Hemolytic transfusion reaction due to ABO incompatibility

questions.text: A patient presented with severe pallor and weakness. Hb was found to be 4.6. The patient was transfused 4 units of blood over 6 hours. The patient developed breathlessness and crepitus. There was bilateral prominence of fissures on CXR. JVP was elevated. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
• The transfusion of multiple units of blood in this patient over a short span is likely to cause fluid overload leading to the signs & symptoms described. This is termed as TACO(transfusion-associated circulatory overload). 
  • TACO results in dyspnea, hypoxia, bilateral and predominantly alveolar infiltrates on chest Xray, frequent systolic hypertension, elevated brain natriuretic peptide.
  • Treatment requires stopping the transfusion and administrating oxygen and diuretics.




Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 895.

questions.text:
A biopsy of the bone marrow of a patient with leukocytosis is shown. The bleeding parameters include increased PT and aPTT. The disease is most commonly due to which mutation?

1. t(15;17)
2. t(8;21)
3. t(9;22)
4. ETV6 mutation
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear shows numerous Auer rods (marked with arrows) in the cytoplasm of cells in this bone marrow biopsy.

  • These cells likely represent promyelocytes, which are characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). They are particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) (acute promyelocytic leukemia - FAB M3 subtype)
  • The bleeding parameters reveal raised PT and aPTT both indicating that both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are activated, likely leading to a generalized deficiency of coagulation factors - this represents DIC.
  • Auer Rods are mostly seen in APML, which is a subtype of AML, asso. with t(15:17), which results in the formation of fusion gene called PML-RARA. Treatment includes administration of all-trans retinoic acid. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 619.

choices.text: High mechanical fragility and low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Sickle cells have ?
questions.solution:
Sickle cells have high mechanical fragility hence being more rigid and less deformable when subjected to mechanical stress.
