  • The higher conc of Hb in sickle cells and the Hbs protein makes them resistant to swelling in hypotonic solution, thus having low osmotic fragility.
  • In sickle cell anemia, the peripheral blood demonstrates variable numbers of irreversibly sickled cells, reticulocytosis, and target cells, which result from red cell dehydration. Howell-Jolly bodies (small nuclear remnants) also are present in red cells due to asplenia (see later).
  • The bone marrow is hyperplastic as a result of a compensatory erythroid hyperplasia. Marked expansion of the marrow leads to bone resorption and secondary new bone formation, producing prominent cheekbones and changes in the skull that resemble a “crewcut” on radiographic studies. Extramedullary hematopoiesis may also appear.
The increased breakdown of hemoglobin may cause hyperbilirubinemia and formation of pigment gallstones.



Fig:  PBS of Sickle cell anemia.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 643.

questions.text: All of the following conditions have increased transferrin saturation, except?
questions.solution:
Iron deficiency anemia has- reduced Iron, reduced Ferritin, Increased TIBC, Reduced MCV, reduced RBC count, Reduced transferrin saturation, Increased Transferrin.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page. No- 658.

questions.text: What is the anti coagulant present in the following vacutainer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Sodium citrate as Anticoagulant.




Reference: Bayot ML, Tadi P. Laboratory Tube Collection. [Updated 2023 Aug 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555991/

questions.text: 25y old female vegetarian came with hyperpigmentation of knuckles with generalised fatigue. On evaluation he had Hb 9.5g/dl MCV- 116fl . What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vegetarian diet + Knuckle Hyperpigmentation with anemia and High MCV - Megaloblastic anemia.
Causes - Liver disease, Metformin, Alcoholism, Hypothyroidism, Inflammatory bowel disease.

* Extra Edge: 
Certain peripheral blood findings are common to all forms of megaloblastic anemia. The presence of red cells that are macrocytic and oval (macro-ovalocytes) is highly characteristic. Because they are larger than normal and contain ample hemoglobin, most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear “hyperchromic,” but the mean cell hemoglobin content is not elevated. There is marked variation in red cell size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis). The reticulocyte count is low. Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe. Neutrophils are also larger than normal and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 651.

questions.text: 30y old female with menorrhagia presents to ER, she also says that her Father and Sister have bleeding disorders but is not able to recall more details. Which of the following is an Autosomal Dominant Disorder?
questions.solution:
Patient history and family history is suggestive of Von Willebrand Disease.
It is due to deficiency of Von Willebrand factor.
BRE- Increased BT, Normal Platelet, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT.
It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.
There are three types -Type I and 3 are quantitative defects. Type II Qualitative defect.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 909.

questions.text:
A 20 -year-old female complained of fatigue for the past 1 year . Examination revealed massive splenomegaly and her Hb level was noted to be 8gm/dL. Immature cells were seen in the peripheral smear.



Her blood work up show the total leukocyte count of 1,50,000/ microL, platelet count of 6,00,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of symptoms for 1 year points towards a chronic cause (rather than acute ).
Peripheral smear shows marked leucocytosis with shift towards left and presence of myelocytes/metamyelocytes and immature cells. CBC shows anaemia (Hb is 8g/dL) and thrombocytosis, and physical examination shows Massive splenomegaly. All these features point towards a myeloproliferative disorder like CML (Chronic myeloid leukaemia)

Other options 
Option 1,2 - Acute leukemias(ALL or AML) will have shorter presentation(<3 months) and PS will shows Blasts(myeloid or lymphoid). While splenomegaly can be seen - massive splenomegaly is rare in both AML/ALL. They will also have thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis.  
Option 4-  CLL will have lymphocytosis( Lymphocyte >5000/mm3 ) and seen only in individuals above 50 years -therefore is ruled out as a cause.

CML
  • CML is a myeloproliferative disorder that typically peaks in incidence during the fifth to sixth decades of life.
  • It is characterized by the presence of the chimeric BCR-ABL gene, which is formed by a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 9 and 22 (9;22)(q34;q11), known as the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • This BCR-ABL fusion gene can be identified using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with pallor and fatigue. Investigations revealed the following: Hb 5gm%, MCH 24, Low MCV, Leukocytes 11,000/uL and Platelets 5 lakhs. The iron profile showed low ferritin and high TIBC. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation and lab findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia (IDA):

Key findings:

  • Clinical: Pallor, fatigue

  • CBC:

    • Low Hb (5 g/dL) → severe anemia

    • Low MCV → microcytic

    • Low MCH → hypochromic

    • Leukocytes normal or mildly elevated

    • Platelets elevated (thrombocytosis) → often reactive in IDA

  • Iron studies:

    • Low ferritin → depleted iron stores

    • High TIBC → increased iron-binding capacity

Differentiation from other anemias:

  • Megaloblastic anemia: Macrocytic anemia (high MCV), hypersegmented neutrophils

  • Anemia of chronic disease: Low iron, low/normal TIBC, normal/high ferritin

  • Sideroblastic anemia: Microcytic or normocytic, iron overload, ring sideroblasts

questions.text: A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show Hb: 8.5, Platelet count: 12,000 and Total leucocyte count: 52,000 with 83% blasts as seen below. The blasts are CD33+. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The morphology of the blasts, characterized by abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules, and the presence of Auer rods, along with delicate nuclear chromatin and 1-4 prominent nucleoli, suggests a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), particularly with CD33 positivity.



According to the 2016 WHO classification of AML, the categories include:

AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities
AML with myelodysplasia-related changes
Therapy-related myeloid neoplasms
AML not otherwise specified
Myeloid sarcoma
Myeloid proliferations associated with Down syndrome

AML arises from hematopoietic progenitors due to acquired oncogenic mutations that hinder differentiation, leading to an accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the bone marrow. While it can occur at any age, its incidence increases with age, peaking after 60 years. In some cases, blasts may be completely absent from the bloodstream, a condition known as aleukemic leukemia. Therefore, a bone marrow examination is crucial to rule out acute leukemia in patients presenting with pancytopenia.

questions.text: Which mutation is linked to the Philadelphia chromosome?
questions.solution:
The BCR-ABL fusion gene is created by a reciprocal translocation (9;22), resulting in the Philadelphia chromosome.



This genetic alteration is commonly detected using cytogenetics, fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and is associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). The peak incidence of CML typically occurs in the fifth to sixth decade of life.

Clinical Features:
Symptoms: Patients may experience anemia, weight loss, and anorexia.
Splenomegaly is also common.
Peripheral Blood Findings:
Leukocytosis: White blood cell counts may exceed 100,000 cells/mm3, predominantly consisting of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
Blasts: Typically make up less than 5% of circulating cells.
Bone Marrow Findings:
The bone marrow is markedly hypercellular, showing an abundance of maturing granulocytic precursors, with an increased proportion of eosinophils and basophils.
A low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is noted.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department complaining of severe pain in her right index finger back and legs along with fatigue. she says that the pain began suddenly about six hours ago. On examination the patient appears pale and is grimacing in pain. A peripheral smear confirms the presence of sickle-shaped red blood cells. The biochemical analysis revealed high levels of indirect bilirubin. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant and there is diffuse tenderness in the joints. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with:

  • Acute onset pain in back, limbs, and joints → classic painful vaso-occlusive crisis

  • Pallor and fatigue → hemolytic anemia

  • Peripheral smear: Sickle-shaped RBCs → diagnostic of sickle cell disease

  • Biochemical findings: High indirect bilirubin → due to hemolysis

  • Abdominal tenderness (RUQ) → may indicate hepatic involvement or gallstones from chronic hemolysis

Key points about sickle cell crisis:

  • Triggered by hypoxia, dehydration, infection, or stress

  • Types of crises: Painful (most common), aplastic, sequestration, hemolytic

  • Management: Pain control, hydration, oxygenation, treat underlying trigger

Other options:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: Would show spherocytes, positive Coombs test, less commonly painful crises.

  • Anemia of chronic disease: Usually mild, normocytic anemia, not acute pain.

  • Thalassemia: Chronic hemolysis and anemia, but no acute painful crises.

choices.text: Prolonged PT and factor VIII as treatment
Prolonged aPTT and factor VIII as treatment

questions.text: What are the hematological abnormalities seen haemophilia B and what is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Blood product contents present indication
Fresh frozen plasma all coagulation factors, plasma proteins, protein C &S, Antithrombin bleeding disorders in which the missing clotting factor is unknown or when the specific clotting factor is not available
Cryoprecipitate fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, and von Willebrand factor haemophilia A, von willebrand disease, DIC
Cryodepleted plasma supernatant plasma left after the removal of cryoprecipitate from fresh frozen plasma
contains most clotting factors in similar amounts to FFP but is deficient in factor VIII, fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, factor XIII and fibronectin.		  used as an alternative to FFP for the treatment of coagulopathy where there is no significant reduction in Factor VIII, fibrinogen, Factor XIII or VWF such as Hemophilla - A
for rapid temporary warfarin reversal in patients requiring emergency surgery and in warfarin overdose with life-threatening bleeding
 
  • Hemophilia B, also known as Christmas Disease, occurs due to a deficiency of Factor IX, also called Christmas Factor. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)contains all coagulation factors, including factor IX, and can be used to treat Hemophilia B, and cryo poor plasma is the plasma remaining after the cryoprecipitate has been removed, and it still contains factor IX, making it useful for treating Hemophilia B.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 669.

choices.text: Waldeyer's ring is the most common site of Hodgkin's Lymphoma
Mixed cellularity is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma
Reed sternberg cells are positive for CD30 and PAX5

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
• Most common sites to be involved in Hodgkin's lymphoma are cervical and clavicular lymph nodes.
  • Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma with good prognosis and presents as a mediastinal mass in young patients.
  • Reed sternberg cells are of B cell origin and are positive for CD 30 and PAX5 markers.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 611-616.

choices.text: Cola colored urine in the first two hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in delayed haemolytic transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
• Cola-colored urine in the first 2 hours is a feature of acute haemolytic transfusion reaction.
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions (DHTR) occur days to weeks after a blood transfusion. delayed immune response is often due to the formation of alloantibodies against minor antigens on the donor red blood cells.
  • Clinically, DHTR presents with symptoms such as a failure of rise in hemoglobin levels despite transfusion, increased levels of indirect bilirubin, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, indicative of ongoing hemolysis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 671-672.

questions.text: Which of the following blood group can be given to a patient who came to the ER with Severe bleeding and unable to get matching group from the blood bank?
questions.solution:
• O negative is universal donor for all patients because it lacks A B and Rh Antigens on surface of RBC thus minimising adverse reactions.
  • Both O positive and Negative can be used for immediate transfusion with specific considerations. O neg is universal Donor because it lacks A , B and Rh antigens.
  • O pos can be used in emergencies but preferred for transfusing Rh positive patients.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 671, 672.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong with regards to G6PD deficency?
questions.solution:
• G6PD deficency does not have an equal incidence in males and females.
  • It is an X Linked Reccessive disorder hence its is more commonly seen in males.
  • Triggers for hemolysis- Fava beans, infections,drugs like anti malarials, sulphonamides, dapsone.
  • There is usually episodic hemolysis both in the intra and extravascular compartment causing Hemolytic anemia and hemoglobinuria.
  • PS- Heinz Bodies and Bite cells.
Reference: Richardson SR, O'Malley GF. Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency. [Updated 2022 Sep 26]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470315/

choices.text: Therapy related MDS is not dependent on age
Patients with MDS are at high risk for developing acute lymphoid leukaemia

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Myelodysplastic syndrome is more commonly seen in males.
  • It is a heterogeneous group of hematologic disorders characterized by both cytopenias due to bone marrow failure and a high risk of development of acute myeloid leukemia.
  • MDS is mainly seen in elderly mean age of onset being 70years.
  • Secondary or therapy related MDS is not age related.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 799.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly patient presenting with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy, along with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). The diagnosis is confirmed through immunophenotyping via flow cytometry. The characteristic immunophenotype of CLL includes CD19+, CD20+, CD23+, and CD5+ markers.

CLL is a peripheral B-cell neoplasm typically seen in adults, especially men. Most patients are asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis. When symptoms do occur, they are often nonspecific, such as easy fatigue, weight loss, and anorexia. Symptomatic patients frequently exhibit generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly.

The chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL include:

Deletion of 13q (most common, associated with a good prognosis)

Deletion of 11q

Trisomy 12q

Deletion of 17p (linked to poor prognosis)


In a peripheral blood smear, CLL is characterized by small, round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm. Smudge cells are formed when some of these cells rupture during smear preparation. An absolute lymphocyte count greater than 5000/ml is needed for diagnosis. Hypogammaglobulinemia is often observed, increasing susceptibility to infections. Some patients may also develop hemolyticanemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies produced by non-neoplastic B cells.

A lymph node biopsy in CLL typically shows small lymphocytes mixed with larger, activated lymphocytes. The larger cells are mitotically active and form loose aggregates known as proliferation centers, which are pathognomonic for CLL.

For asymptomatic patients, expectant management is the preferred approach. The gold standard treatment involves a combination of fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab.

A serious complication of CLL is Richter‘s syndrome, where the disease transforms into an aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 597-599 .

choices.text: cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°c with a shelf life of 6 mont
Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°c with a self life of 5 days
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products?
questions.solution:
Platelets can be stored at temperatures between 20°C and 24°C, with a shelf life of 5 days. These platelet concentrates are used to treat conditions like thrombocytopenia, platelet function defects, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and to prevent dilutional thrombocytopenia during massive blood transfusions or in cases of bone marrow failure. Agitation during storage is crucial for maintaining the viability and function of platelets, as they continue to metabolize glucose and produce lactate at room temperature. Agitation ensures even distribution, prevents clumping, and facilitates gas exchange.

Fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate are typically stored at –30°C. Before use, they are thawed at temperatures between 30°C and 37°C in the blood bank, then transported at ambient temperature to the ward. They must be used immediately after thawing and should not be refrozen.

Whole blood and packed red cells are stored between 2°C and 6°C, and transported between 2°C and 10°C. Packed red cells stored with SAGM (sodium, adenine, glucose, and mannitol) have a shelf life of up to 42 days.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 886,890 .

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presenting with 36 weeks of gestation, underwent a C-Section for placenta accreta spectrum. During the procedure, there was profuse bleeding and she was transfused blood according to the massive blood transfusion protocol. Which of the following is not seen after a massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia can occur following a massive blood transfusion, which is defined as transfusing 50% of a patient‘s total blood volume within 3 hours or more than 5-10 units of RBCs. The associated complications include:

1. Citrate toxicity


2. Hypothermia (due to rapid transfusion of blood stored at 4°C)


3. Hypocalcemia, presenting as circumoralparesthesia


4. Hyperkalemia (caused by RBC potassium leakage during prolonged storage or irradiation, which increases potassium levels)


5. Dilutional coagulopathy



To prevent these issues, it is recommended to use washed or plasma-reduced RBCs, limit storage to less than 7-10 days, and avoid using RBCs stored for more than 24 hours after irradiation. Treatment options include administering insulin, glucose, calcium gluconate, and furosemide.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 895 .

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy image of a cell. Identify the cell.
questions.solution:
Hairy cell leukemia derives its name from the appearance of the leukemic cells, which exhibit fine, hair-like projections that are most easily identified under a phase-contrast microscope. This is a distinct B-cell neoplasm that primarily affects middle-aged men. The cells in hairy cell leukemia express standard B-cell markers such as CD-19 and CD-20, as well as specific markers like CD11c, CD25, CD103, and annexin A1.

In a peripheral blood smear, hairy cells typically show round or kidney-shaped (reniform) nuclei and a moderate amount of pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like or bleb-like extensions. In the bone marrow, these cells are often trapped within a network of reticulinfibers, making it difficult to aspirate, a condition known as a “dry tap.”

Patients often present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration by leukemic cells. Pancytopenia, due to bone marrow involvement, is also common. Additionally, patients may have atypical monocytopenia, which increases their risk of atypical mycobacterial infections. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF inhibitors, and the prognosis is excellent.


Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition, Page no 595,603,604.605,641-643 .

questions.text: A phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for several tests. Which of the following blood collection sequences will avoid contaminating the samples due to the additives in the tubes?
questions.solution:
• The correct color sequence of the blood collection tube is light blue-> red-> lavender-> grey.
  • And/or arterial blood samples in a single patient.
 
  • The Clinical & Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has recommended a color sequence for multiple collections of venous
 
  • Yellow, pink, and blue -> light Blue-> red- > green lavender -> grey.



Reference: WHO guidelines on Drawing blood: Best practices in Phlebotomy. URL: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241599221

questions.text: Which one of the following is a feature of hemolytic anemia?
questions.solution:
Serum haptoglobin levels are diminished in cases of hemolytic anemias. During intravascular hemolysis, free hemoglobin released from lysed red blood cells is quickly bound by haptoglobin, forming a complex that is rapidly cleared by mononuclear phagocytes. In extravascular hemolysis, some hemoglobin escapes from phagocytes, leading to variable reductions in plasma haptoglobin levels.

Hemolytic anemias are characterized by a shortened red blood cell lifespan of less than the normal 120 days. This results in elevated erythropoietin levels and a compensatory increase in erythropoiesis, which is reflected as prominent reticulocytosis (Option C) in the peripheral blood. Additionally, there is an accumulation of hemoglobin degradation products resulting from hemolysis.

Other options:

  • Reticulocytopenia → False. Hemolytic anemia shows reticulocytosis (bone marrow response to RBC destruction), unless marrow failure coexists.

  • Neutropenia → False. Hemolytic anemia does not typically cause neutropenia.


    Laboratory Features of Hemolytic Anemia

  • Anemia (low Hb, low RBC count)

  • Reticulocytosis (↑ reticulocyte count due to marrow compensation)

  • Increased LDH (from RBC breakdown)

  • Indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia (due to heme catabolism → jaundice)

  • Decreased haptoglobin (binds free hemoglobin; gets consumed in hemolysis)

  • Peripheral smear abnormalities (depending on cause → spherocytes, schistocytes, sickle cells, etc.)

  • Positive Coombs test (in autoimmune hemolysis only)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a throbbing unilateral headache and nodular thickening along the temporal artery. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of giant cells and granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario presented strongly indicates giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell arteritis, also known as temporal arteritis, is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting large to small-sized arteries, with a particular focus on the temporal arteries. It predominantly occurs in individuals over 50 years of age. Common symptoms include facial pain or headaches along the path of the superficial temporal artery.

Patients may also experience scalp pain, jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Approximately 50% of individuals show abnormalities in the temporal artery, such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and diminished pulse, which can be unilateral or bilateral. Applying gentle pressure to the scalp may trigger focal or generalized tenderness.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
• Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene (chromosome 11).

  • At the 6th position of the β-globin chain:

    • Normal: Glutamic acid (hydrophilic)

    • Mutant: Valine (hydrophobic)

  • This change causes HbS formation → polymerizes under low oxygen tension → sickling of RBCs.

Other options:

  • Valine by glutamate → reversed substitution (not correct).

  • At 5th position → wrong site, the mutation is at 6th position.

So, the mutation is Glutamate → Valine at 6th position of β-chain.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor participates in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation?
questions.solution:
• Factor VII is a key component of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
• The prothrombin time (PT) assay evaluates the function of the proteins involved in the extrinsic pathway, which includes Factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.
• Factors VIII, IX, and XI are involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.
• Factor VIII, in particular, plays a critical role in the intrinsic pathway, and its function is assessed through the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.
These assays are crucial for evaluating different parts of the clotting cascade to diagnose and manage coagulation disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Gaisböck syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients with Gaisböck syndrome present with hypertension, not hypotension.

Gaisböck syndrome is characterized as a stress polycythemia, where patients are typically hypertensive, obese, and anxious. They exhibit a high hematocrit, low plasma volume, and normal leukocyte counts. Unlike polycythemia vera, patients with Gaisböck syndrome do not have splenomegaly.

Plasma volume measurement helps differentiate relative polycythemia, where there is a reduction in plasma volume, from absolute polycythemia, which involves an actual increase in red cell mass.

Polycythemia refers to an abnormally high red blood cell count and is typically accompanied by elevated hemoglobin levels (>16 ± 2 g/dL).

Polycythemia is classified into two main types:

1. Relative polycythemia (due to reduced plasma volume):

Dehydration from water deprivation, prolonged vomiting, diarrhea, or excessive diuretic use
Gaisböck syndrome
2. Absolute polycythemia (due to an actual increase in red cell mass):

Primary causes (intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors):

Polycythemia vera
Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations
Secondary causes (increased levels of erythropoietin):

Compensatory mechanisms due to cyanotic heart or lung disease or high altitude
Paraneoplastic erythropoietin-secreting tumors

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with hemarthroses of the knee joint and prolonged bleeding following tooth extractions. His platelet count and bleeding time are normal. PT is within normal limits and aPTT is prolonged. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The boy presents with:

  • Hemarthroses (typical of coagulation factor deficiency, not platelet disorder).

  • Normal platelet count and bleeding time → excludes platelet disorders like ITP or Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

  • Normal PT but prolonged aPTT → points to an intrinsic pathway defect (factors VIII, IX, XI, XII).

  • In children with hemarthroses, the commonest causes are Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency) and Hemophilia B (factor IX deficiency).

Other options:

  • Functional platelet disorders: Would show prolonged bleeding time, not normal.

  • ITP: Characterized by low platelet count, not normal platelets.

  • Vitamin K deficiency: Affects factors II, VII, IX, X → prolongs PT first, not isolated aPTT.


Reference
1.Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e - Page no: 662, 663
2.Dacie and Lewis Practical Haematology 11th Edition - Page no: 420

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of fatigue. On examination, there is pallor. Blood investigations showed a hemoglobin of 10g/dl, RBC count of 3 million cells/mm cube, MCV = 70 fL, MCH = 22 pg. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with fatigue and pallor, and her blood investigations show:

  • Hemoglobin 10 g/dL → mild anemia

  • RBC count 3 million/mm³ → low

  • MCV 70 fL → microcytic anemia

  • MCH 22 pg → hypochromic anemia

These features are classic for microcytic hypochromic anemia, the most common cause of which is iron deficiency anemia. Common causes include blood loss (menstrual or GI), poor dietary intake, or increased demand.

Other options:

  • Anemia of chronic disease: Usually normocytic or mildly microcytic, and iron studies show low serum iron but normal/high ferritin.

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Causes macrocytic anemia (high MCV), not microcytic.

  • Sideroblastic anemia: Can be microcytic or normocytic but is rarer and associated with ringed sideroblasts in bone marrow.


Reference
1.Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page - 697
2.Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e - 652

questions.text: A 30-year-old male complained of fatigue for the past 1 year. Examination revealed massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? * Anemia * Total leucocyte count - 1,50,000/microL * Peripheral blood smear - * 60% neutrophils-6% * basophils-4% * eosinophils * myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes * Myeloid to erythroid ratio18:1
questions.solution:
This patient's profile is highly characteristic of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia:

  • Fatigue → common symptom of anemia or chronic illness.

  • Massive splenomegaly → hallmark of CML due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

  • Very high TLC (1,50,000/μL) → suggests leukemoid proliferation.

  • Peripheral smear:

    • Predominantly neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils → reflects granulocytic series proliferation.

    • Presence of myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes → spectrum of myeloid precursors → seen in CML.

    • Basophilia is particularly characteristic of CML.

  • Myeloid: Erythroid ratio of 18:1 → markedly elevated → supports myeloid hyperplasia.

    Differentiation:

  • ALL: More lymphoblasts, common in children/young adults, not massive splenomegaly with basophilia.

  • AML: Increased blasts (usually >20%), more acute presentation, not chronic fatigue.

  • CLL: Common in elderly, with absolute lymphocytosis and smudge cells.

Thus, the presentation is classic for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).


Reference: Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of diseases 9e page no 617-618

choices.text: 5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis? Hb-Hemoglobin TLC-Total leucocyte count

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level 3 gm/dl, TLC1500/muL, platelet count15000/uL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis? Hb-Hemoglobin TLC-Total leucocyte count
questions.solution:
This patient presents with:

  • Pancytopenia:

    • Hb = 3 g/dL (very low)

    • TLC = 1500/μL (severe leukopenia)

    • Platelets = 15,000/μL (severe thrombocytopenia)

  • Reticulocyte count = 0.5% → indicates hypoproliferative marrow

  • Peripheral smear: Macrocytes (often seen in aplasia)

  • Bone marrow: Fatty replacement, absence of megakaryocytes, and no immature cells or blasts → rules out leukemia or MDS

    Diagnosis:

This is classic for Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia, characterized by:

  • Hypocellular marrow replaced by fat

  • Absence of abnormal cells (blasts)

  • Pancytopenia

  • Young age (typical presentation in teens or young adults)

Other options: 

  1. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria – Can cause pancytopenia, but often has hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and flow cytometry is diagnostic (CD55/CD59 deficiency).

  2. Myelodysplastic syndrome – Usually shows dysplastic changes and hypercellular marrow with blasts or abnormal precursors.

  3. Tuberculosis – Can rarely cause pancytopenia (via infiltration or hypersplenism), but not with hypocellular marrow and typically would have systemic or constitutional symptoms and organ involvement.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 720-721

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Duke's Criteria for Infectious Endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Splenomegaly
 
Splenomegaly is not included in Duke's Criteria for Infectious Endocarditis.

* [Extra Edge]: Modified Duke Criteria



• Definitive diagnosis: Two major criteria or one major and three minor criteria or five minor criteria.
• Possible diagnosis: One major and one minor criterion or three minor criteria.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: Which one of the following does not exhibit hyperdynamic circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cor pulmonale
 
  • Hyperdynamic circulation is seen in anemia, beriberi & AV fistula, but not in Cor pulmonale.
  • Cor pulmonale has a depressed ejection fraction (<40%). 
* [Extra Edge]: 
  • In acute cor pulmonale there is marked dilation of the right ventricle without hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle chamber is transformed to a dilated ovoid.
  • In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens, sometimes up to 1.0 cm or more. More subtle right ventricular hypertrophy may take the form of thickening of the muscle bundles in the outflow tract, immediately below the pulmonary valve, or thickening of the moderator band, the muscle bundle that connects the ventricular septum to the anterior right ventricular papillary muscle. Sometimes, the hypertrophied right ventricle compresses the left ventricular chamber or leads to regurgitation and fibrous thickening of the tricuspid valve.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 556.

questions.text: During a football game, a 29-year-old male athlete passed away after abruptly collapsing. The following discovery was made during a gross inspection at the autopsy. His family had already had two deaths that were comparable. What is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

The above clinical scenario is typical of HCM. The autopsy heart also shows hypertrophied myocardium

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)
  • 60-70% - familial
  • Autosomal dominant (most commonly-  alpha-myosin heavy-chain mutation)
  • May cause sudden death in athletes due to ventricular arrhythmia
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complained of severe dyspnea. There was mitral stenosis with LA hypertrophy. Plants on the mitral valve, which was removed.
What does the image of HPE show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Aschoff nodule

The presented image displays a confined nodule of mixed mononuclear inflammatory cells with accompanying necrosis.
Large active macrophages inside the inflammation exhibit conspicuous nucleoli and chromatin that has been compressed into long, wavy ribbons (caterpillar cells). The results imply the existence of Aschoff's body.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: The heart of a patient whose death was presumed to be from a myocardial infarction was stained with triphenyl tetrazolium tetrachloride dye at autopsy. What shade will the myocardium be that is still viable?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Red

  • It is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride.
  • This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, Non infarcted myocardium with preserved lactate dehydrogenase activity.
  • This is Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.
* Audio Explanation:
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 548.

questions.text: The heart of a patient after a myocardial infarction is shown below, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. What can you say regarding the infarction's age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 6 hours.

  • The myocardial biopsy is showing some coagulative necrosis along with wavy fibers with widened spaces between the dead fibers, which contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.
  • No dense neutrophilic infiltrate is seen. These are typical early changes after MI, seen within 6 hours of infarction.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 547.

questions.text: In a patient, commissures fuse together and there are vegetations on the mitral valve along the lines of closure. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Rheumatic endocarditis

The image is showing small vegetations in a row along the lines of closure of valves and commissural fusion can be seen. This is typically seen in Rheumatic Endocarditis.


Fig: Acute rheumatic mitral valvulitis


Fig: Various Types of vegetations

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is diagnosed with a strawberry tongue, widespread erythematous rash, cervical lymphadenopathy( 2cm), and fever over the past five days. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kawasaki disease
 
  • Strawberry tongue, rash, fever are common for both scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease. Only distinguishing feature is adenopathy more than 1.5 cm is more characteristic of Kawasaki disease.
  • This clinical picture can resemble TSS and scarlet fever, but clues to the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease are cervical lymphadenopathy, cheilitis, and thrombocytosis.

Fig: Strawberry Tongue and Cheilitis

*Table: Warm CREAM and FEBRILE Mnemonics for KD Criteria
 

Warm = Fever for > 5 days

  • C = Conjunctivitis without exudate
  • R = Rash
  • E = Edema or erythema of hands or feet, followed by desquamation and nail changes
  • A = Adenopathy, often unilateral, cervical node > 1.5 cm 
  • M = Mucosal erythema, fissures or crusting of lips or strawberry tongue
  • F = Fever for > 5 days
  • E = Enanthem of mucosal membranes
  • B = Bulbar conjunctivitis
  • R = Rash, erythematous, polymorphous
  • I = Internal organ involvement: coronary, abdominal, pneumonitis, hepatitis, orchitis
  • E = Extremity changes, initial edema, and erythema, desquamation, nail changes

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: Regular evaluation of a 17- year-old child with no symptoms reveals a short PR interval and a delta wave on the ECG. The boy would benefit the least from which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Beta blocker
Short  PR/Delta waves point to WPW syndrome (characterised by a presence of Presence of an accessory conduction pathway)
Digitalis, beta blockers, and calcium channel blockers are effective in inhibiting conduction through the AV node; however, they do not impede conduction over most accessory pathways.
Drugs like Beta Blockers may actually reduce the refractory period of an accessory pathway which could lead to a faster ventricular rate (and a risk of ventricular fibrillation and hemodynamic collapse) if administered to individuals suffering from WPW syndrome.
Hence, Beta blockers are NOT Given to individuals with WPW Syndrome

WPW(Wolff–Parkinson–White) syndrome
  • Presence of an accessory conduction pathway (usually in left atrium/free wall of left ventricle)
  • Impulse conduction through the accessory pathway leads to earlier pre-excitation of ventricles since there is no AV nodal delay and ventricular contraction.
ECG Changes
  1. Decreased PR interval -because of earlier ventricular depolarisation and excitation.
  2. Prolonged QRS - since conduction is via accesory pathyway - not AV node. 
  3. DELTA WAVE - initial slurred upstroke of QRS (arrow)




Reference: Chhabra L, Goyal A, Benham MD. Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Aug 7]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554437/

questions.text: How do kidneys react to shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increases afferent arteriole resistance
 
  • During shock, the kidneys undergo compensatory mechanisms to maintain perfusion.
  • One of the mechanisms is vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles, which increases resistance and helps maintain blood flow to the vital organs so glomerular filtration rate (GFR) decreases if shock is severe in nature.

*Other options:
  • Decreases renal blood flow would be a consequence of shock rather than a reaction of the kidneys. GFR may decrease as a result of decreased renal blood flow and afferent arteriole vasoconstriction.
  • Decreased perfusion of the kidney is seen in shock.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 135.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the "Flipping effect"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) LDH 1 > LDH 2
 
  • The "Flipping effect" refers to the phenomenon observed in the electrophoresis of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzymes, where the LDH 1 band becomes more prominent than the LDH 2 band.
  • LDH 1 represents the LDH isoenzyme with the highest electrophoretic mobility, while LDH 2 has lower mobility.
  • In certain conditions, such as myocardial infarction, LDH 1 can increase relative to LDH 2, resulting in the flipping effect.


Online Reference: Weinberger I, Rotenberg Z, Sagie A, Fuchs J, Sperling O, Agmon J. "Flipped" lactic dehydrogenase pattern in acute coronary insufficiency. Clin Cardiol. 1986 Dec;9(12):597-9. doi: 10.1002/clc.4960091202. PMID: 3780075.

questions.text: Which of the following have most friable vegetation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Infective endocarditis
 
  • amongst the given options, Infective endocarditis is the most appropriate answer.
  • Infective endocarditis is characterized by the formation of friable vegetations composed of fibrin, platelets, and microorganisms on the heart valves. These vegetations can embolize and lead to systemic complications.
  • Libman Sacks endocarditis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is characterized by small, sterile vegetations.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 563.

choices.text: Fibrous endocardial thickening of right ventricle, tricuspid valve & pulmonary valve
Endometrial thickening of tricuspid valve with severe tricuspid stenosis
Collagen rich, elastic deposits in endocardium of right ventricle and pulmonary valve

questions.text: A notable pathological revelation in carcinoid heart disease is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fibrous endocardial thickening of right ventricle, tricuspid valve & pulmonary valve
 
  • Carcinoid heart disease is associated with fibrous endocardial thickening primarily involving the right side of the heart, including the right ventricle, tricuspid valve, and pulmonary valve.
  • It is caused by the release of vasoactive substances (serotonin) from carcinoid tumors, leading to fibrosis and valve dysfunction.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 565.

questions.text: Granulomatous pathology is linked to all of the following conditions, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Polyarteritis Nodosa (Classic PAN)
 
  • Granulomatous pathology is not typically associated with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).
  • PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis that primarily affects medium-sized arteries and does not involve small vessels.
  • It is characterized by transmural inflammation, fibrinoid necrosis, and aneurysmal formation in affected arteries.
  • Wegener's granulomatosis, Takayasu arteritis, and giant cell arteritis are examples of vasculitides that can exhibit granulomatous inflammation.
  • In Wegener's granulomatosis, necrotizing granulomas involving the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels are typically seen.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: Which of the following is the paraganglioma's most distinctive ultrastructural feature as seen under an electron microscope?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dense core neuroendocrine granules
 
  • Paragangliomas, which are neuroendocrine tumors arising from extra-adrenal paraganglia, exhibit dense core neuroendocrine granules when examined under an electron microscope.
  • These dense core granules contain various hormones and neuropeptides that are characteristic of neuroendocrine cells.
  • The presence of dense core granules is one of the distinguishing features of neuroendocrine tumors and can aid in their identification on electron microscopy.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of abdominal Aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atherosclerosis 
 
  • Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
  • AAA is the dilation and weakening of the abdominal aorta, the main blood vessel supplying blood to the abdomen and lower extremities.
  • Atherosclerosis, a condition characterized by the buildup of plaque in the arterial walls, increases the risk of AAA formation.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 506.

questions.text: Scattered, large friable plant growth on the valves.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 2) Infective Endocarditis

  • Infective endocarditis is an infection of the lining of the heart, typically caused by bacterial or fungal species, which results in the formation of vegetations (clumps of bacteria or fungi along with coagulated blood).
  • These vegetations can break away and cause embolization.
  • Acute infective endocarditis is caused by highly virulent organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus and the HACEK group (Haemophiles species, Actinobacillus species, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella species) and is typically found in intravenous drug abusers.
  • Subacute endocarditis is caused by lower virulent organisms such as viridians streptococci. Prosthetic valve endocarditis is typically caused by coagulase negative Staphylococci (e.g., Staphylococcus epidermidis). The hallmark of endocarditis is friable, bulky, destructive vegetations, which can be seen on echocardiography.
  • The diagnosis of endocarditis is based on the duke's criteria and may have associated complications, such as palms or soles (Janeway lesions), subcutaneous nodules in the pulp of the digits (Osier nodes), and retinal hemorrhages in the eyes (Roth spots).
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis, or marantic endocarditis, is a form of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, which is characterized by small, 1-4 mm in diameter, single or multiple, sterile, pink verrucous/warty vegetations.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 563.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who had been experiencing exertional dyspnea for the previous month presented to the OPD. He had experienced significant mitral stenosis. A prosthetic valve was used to replace his sick valve. A biopsy was taken from the removed valve. Determine the disease implicated and the typical biopsy finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff nodules, Rheumatic Heart disease

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of rheumatic heart disease.
  • It is an immunologically mediated multi - system disease. It is caused due to type 2 hypersensitivity reaction which usually occurs 2-3 weeks after a Beta haemolytic Streptococcal infection. This is due to molecular mimicry of Streptococcal Antigen with glycoprotein in heart and joints. In chronic rheumatic fever, patient develops mitral stenosis. Diagnosis is by Revised Jones Criteria.
  • Aschoff Bodies (Pathognomic for RHD) consists of lymphocytes, plasma cells, giant cells, fibrinoid necrosis, collagen and cells with wavy, slender, ribbon - like nucleus (Caterpillar cells/Antischkow Cells)


Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text:
Shortness of breath, bilateral pedal edoema, and right upper abdominal pain are the symptoms a 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with. His JVP was discovered to be raised upon examination, and his liver is palpable 8 cm below the right costal edge.
Which heart chamber is not functioning properly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Right ventricle

  • The given signs and symptoms (pedal edema, tender hepatomegaly, raised JVP) is suggestive of right sided heart failure which is due to the inability of right ventricle to pump blood efficiently.
  • Shortness of Breath occurs due to decreased capacity of right ventricle to pump enough blood for oxygenation resulting in accumulation of blood in veins, causing dyspnea

* [Extra Edge]: Signs of right sided heart failure

—Raised JVP.

—Kussmaul sign (Rise in JVP on inspiration) 

—Tender hepatomegaly. 

—B/L pitting oedema. 

—Abdomino - Jugular reflux present.

Right sided heart failure is often caused by pulmonary heart disease (Cor Pulmonale).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 556.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who had migrating arthritis of the lower big joints and tachycardia appeared. Murmur is Pansystolic. Mitral regurgitation is seen on an echo. What does the biopsy reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff body
 
  • Upon performing a cardiac catheterization, an endomyocardial biopsy revealed the presence of an Aschoff's body in the endocardium, confirming a clinical suspicion of active carditis.
  • Aschoff bodies are nodules that are discovered in the hearts of rheumatic fever patients. They are a defining feature of rheumatic heart disease and are caused by inflammation in the heart muscle.

Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text:
While running, one athlete fell and passed away instantly. The heart's autopsy region is shown.
Which of the following statements about the condition is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
 
  • This is a case of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The most common cause of death is ventricular arrythmia.
  • Major clinical problems in HCM are atrial fibrillation, mural thrombus formation leading to embolization and possible stroke, intractable cardiac failure, ventricular arrhythmias, and, not infrequently, sudden death, especially with certain mutations.
  • Indeed, HCM is one of the most common causes of sudden, otherwise unexplained death in young athletes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: Which of these is characteristic of serum-ascites albumin gradient-high ascites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) CHF
 
  • The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is a measure used to differentiate the causes of ascites (fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity).
  • A high SAAG (>1.1 g/dL) is typically associated with portal hypertension.
  • Conditions associated with a high SAAG include liver cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis, and congestive heart failure (CHF).
  • CHF leads to elevated venous pressure, which can cause fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity (ascites).


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 323.

questions.text: Among the following, which has the most friable vegetation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Infective endocarditis
 
  • Friable vegetation refers to fragile and easily breakable growths on heart valves, commonly observed in infective endocarditis.
  • Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the endocardium, typically caused by bacteria.
  • The vegetations in infective endocarditis consist of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells, and they can become large and friable.
* [Extra Edge]: Other options
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a nonbacterial form of endocarditis associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), but the vegetations are usually small and non-friable.
  • Rheumatic heart disease is a consequence of rheumatic fever and can lead to valvular damage, but the vegetations are typically firm rather than friable.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 562.

questions.text: What exactly does C-ANCA positivity refer to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Wegener's Granulomatosis
 
  • C-ANCA (cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody) positivity refers to the presence of specific antibodies targeting neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.
  • It is most commonly associated with Wegener's granulomatosis, a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of blood vessels in multiple organs.
  • C-ANCA antibodies primarily target proteinase 3 (PR3), an enzyme found in neutrophil granules.
  • The detection of C-ANCA antibodies in a patient's blood is an important diagnostic marker for Wegener's granulomatosis.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 






Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: What does the needle-shaped void on the histopathology slide of an atheromatous plaque signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cholesterol Cleft
 
  • The needle-shaped void on the histopathology slide of an atheromatous plaque signifies a cholesterol cleft.
  • Cholesterol clefts are characteristic histological findings in atherosclerotic plaques.
  • Cholesterol clefts result from the deposition of cholesterol crystals in the necrotic core of the plaque.
  • These crystals are derived from the hydrolysis of cholesterol esters by enzymes such as cholesterol esterase.

Fig: Cholesterol Clefts

Online Reference: Shah N, Nagalli S. Cholesterol Emboli. [Updated 2024 Jan 23]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556091/

questions.text: Except for______, each of the following statements concerning Anitschkow cells is accurate.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pathognomonic of Rheumatic Heart Disease 
 
  • Anitschkow cells, also known as Aschoff cells, are modified cardiac histiocytes and are characteristic of rheumatic heart disease.
  • Anitschkow cells are large cells with a central, wavy, or rod-like nucleus (caterpillar appearance) when observed in longitudinal section.
  • In transverse sections, they show a characteristic "owl's eye" appearance due to the folding and condensation of the nucleus.
  • While Anitschkow cells are strongly associated with rheumatic heart disease, they are not pathognomonic and can also be seen in other inflammatory conditions.

Fig: Aschoff Body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: What is Bilateral upper limb pulseless disease is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Takayasu Arteritis
 
  • Takayasu Arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects large vessels, including the aorta and its major branches.
  • It commonly affects young females and leads to stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysmal dilation of affected vessels.
  • The involvement of the subclavian arteries can cause upper limb pulselessness, known as "pulseless disease."
  • Other features of Takayasu Arteritis include systemic symptoms, such as fever and fatigue, hand claudications, and symptoms related to the affected organs or regions.
VASCULITIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 512.

questions.text: What among the following is a "Small Vessel Vasculitis"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Microscopic polyangiitis
 
  • Microscopic Polyangiitis is a systemic vasculitis affecting small blood vessels, including arterioles, capillaries, and venules.
  • It is characterized by necrotizing inflammation of vessel walls, without granulomatous inflammation.
  • The term "microscopic" refers to the involvement of small vessels, which can be visualized microscopically.
  • Other forms of small vessel vasculitis include Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) and Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), which involve granulomatous inflammation.
Vasculitis Memorizing Trick: -
Large vessel- GT road is the largest road- Giant cell arteritis and Takayasu arteritis
Medium Vessel- PK- PAN and Kawasaki 
Rest are small vessel vasculitis

VASCULITIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text:
A 5-year old child has fever, dyspnea and cough. He started having chest pain. Further evaluation revealed left ventricular dysfunction. Biopsy findings are as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?

1. Acute rheumatic fever
2. Lymphocytic myocarditis
3. Chagas disease
4. Eosinophilic myocarditis
questions.solution:
• The given clinical vignette has a 5-year-old child presenting with fever and chest pain associated with dyspnea/cough and the echocardiogram reveals left ventricular dysfunction.
  • This clinical scenario is suggestive of myocarditis(likely viral).
  • The given image shows massive infiltration with mononuclear cells and occasional eosinophils associated with clear myocyte damage. This is diagnostic of lymphocytic myocarditis.(seen in viral myocarditis)
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 576.

questions.text: The following biopsy is of 80y old female diagnosed to have heart failure. What is the likely cause of it?
questions.solution:
The given biopsy is suggestive of hyaline eosinophilic deposits which is suggestive of Cardiac Amyloidosis which causes Restrictive Cardiomyopathy > Dilated Cardiomyopathy.
ECG in Cardiac Amyloidosis shows low voltage complex with ECHO showing thickened Ventricular walls due to infiltrative process. It Can be detected on Gadolinium enhanced MRI.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 574.

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) stain is useful for identifying infarcts in the heart.

Myocardial infarctions that are less than 12 hours old may not be visible during gross examination. However, for infarcts that occurred 2 to 3 hours before death, tissue slices can be immersed in TTC solution to reveal areas of necrosis. This stain highlights intact myocardium, where lactate dehydrogenase activity is preserved, by turning it a brick-red color. Since damaged cells lose dehydrogenases through compromised membranes, the infarcted area appears as a pale, unstained zone.

Other Options:

Option A and D: Sudan Black B and Oil Red O are used for staining fats. 

Option B: Masson Trichome stain is used for staining collagen.

questions.text: A young girl presented with dyspnea fatigue and on evaluation had loud S1 and a mid diastolic murmur. On echocardiography had a vegetation involving the mitral valve. Histopathological findings of the vegetation were as follows identify the finding
questions.solution:
The given image shows Aschoff bodies seen in rheumatic heart disease.
Aschoff bodies are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.Ref- Robbins basic Pathology 9th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and edema. On examination, JVP was elevated. Gross examination finding of the tissue biopsy is shown. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Congestive hepatopathy is suggested by the clinical manifestation of ascites and edema as well as a raised jugular venous pressure (JVP). The accompanying image shows a "nutmeg liver," which is a sign of persistent passive hepatic congestion, usually caused by congestive heart failure.

Pathophysiology:

Long-standing cardiac conditions, especially those affecting the right heart, including right-sided heart failure, are frequently associated with chronic passive hepatic congestion. Blood can back up in the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins as a result of this disorder.

Engorgement of the venous circulation results from an increase in pressure within the hepatic veins' sublobular branches.

When heart failure causes persistent passive hepatic congestion, the liver's centrilobular regions become visible.



Reference
1. Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e - Page no 116
2. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page NO: 1936, 1937, 2021, 2022, 277

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg. Ultrasound examination revealed a ruptured spleen. Arterial blood gas analysis was suggestive of metabolic acidosis. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A 24-year-old male with:

  • Severe trauma (motorcycle accident)

  • Hypotension (BP 80/60 mm Hg)

  • Ruptured spleen on ultrasound

  • Metabolic acidosis on ABG

These findings are classic for hypovolemic shock, particularly hemorrhagic shock due to intra-abdominal bleeding from a ruptured spleen.

       Why the other options are less likely:

  • Septic shock: Caused by infection; not supported by the acute trauma and splenic rupture history.

  • Cardiogenic shock: Due to pump failure (e.g., MI, arrhythmia); unlikely in a young trauma patient with no cardiac history.

  • Neurogenic shock: Seen in spinal cord injuries; typically presents with hypotension and bradycardia due to loss of sympathetic tone. No evidence of spinal injury or bradycardia is given.

    Why hypovolemic shock fits best:

  • Etiology: Blood loss from ruptured spleen

  • Pathophysiology: ↓ Preload → ↓ Cardiac output → ↓ BP → ↑ peripheral resistance (compensation)

  • Metabolic acidosis: Due to lactic acid buildup from tissue hypoperfusion



Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 10e page no 134-135

questions.text: 70-year-old man spent 10–15 years working in an asbestos factory. A tumour was discovered in the right lung's apical area during a routine X-ray. The mass was subjected to a biopsy. Which of the following can be viewed under an electron microscope
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Numerous long, slender microvilli
 
  • Most common lung cancer associated with above mentioned history is Mesothelioma.
  • In H&E examination of mesothelioma we can see long slender microvilli

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 727.

choices.text: Small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined borders and hyperchromatic nuclei with nuclear moulding
Derivatives of all three germ layers are seen
Tall columnar cells with cytoplasmic and intra-alveolar mucin
Palisading or rosette-like arrangement of cells separated by abundant fibrovascular stroma

questions.text: The central lung mass of a 65-year-old chronic smoker with distal bronchiectasis and recurrent pneumonia is observed and a grayish-white tumor is resected. Which histopathological finding from the list below is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined borders and hyperchromatic nuclei with nuclear Moulding
 
  • The most common lung cancer associated with chronic smoking is small cell carcinoma of lung. So, the histopathological finding will be small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined border and hyperchromatic nuclei.
  • Small cell carcinoma is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.
  • The cells are round, oval, or spindle shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent. There is no absolute size for the tumor cells, but in general they are smaller than three times the diameter of a small resting lymphocyte (a size of about 25 µm).
  • The mitotic count is high. The cells grow in clusters that exhibit neither glandular nor squamous organization.
  • Necrosis is common and often extensive. Basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells (Azzopardi effect) is frequently present.


Fig: Small cell carcinoma showing islands of small, deeply basophilic cells and areas of necrosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 718.

questions.text: Which of the following does not usually cause a reduction in the diffusion lung capacity of carbon monoxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asthma
 
  • During an episode of acute asthma, luminal narrowing due to smooth muscle constriction, inflammation, and thickening within the small- and medium-sized bronchi raise frictional resistance and reduce airflow. "Scooping" of the flow-volume loop is caused by a reduction of airflow, especially at lower lung volumes. 
  • DLCO decreases in diseases that i) thicken or destroy alveolar membranes (e.g. pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema); ii) curtail the pulmonary vasculature (e.g. pulmonary hypertension) or reduce alveolar capillary hemoglobin (eg. anemia). 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 684.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does the given graph most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Interstitial lung disease
 
  • The compliance curve is shown by the pressure-volume loop above, and its decreased slope suggests decreased compliance.
  • Interstitial lung disease is a common example of a restrictive lung disease in which this is commonly observed. Increased compliance is a symptom of obstructive lung disease like emphysema.
   
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 688.

questions.text: Which of the following is not performed prior to ABG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Flexion of wrist
 
  • While taking ABG, wrist is generally kept in hyperextension. This is to make the vessel straight and to fix the position (because of tension in hyperextension).
  • Flexion will make the vessel loose and the vessel will slip easily while poking.
  • Other steps are performed while doing ABG.
ABG steps:- 
  • Heparin rinse of syringe
  • Modified Allen's test performed 
  • Wrist extension 
  • Needle pierced at 45 degrees angle 
Online Reference: Castro D, Patil SM, Zubair M, et al. Arterial Blood Gas. [Updated 2024 Jan 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK536919/

questions.text: The following causes death from smoke inhalation:
questions.solution:
he correct answer is 4. All of the above.

Death from smoke inhalation can occur due to multiple mechanisms, including:

  1. Hypoxemia: Reduced oxygen availability in the blood due to the presence of smoke and toxic gases.
  2. Anemic hypoxia: Carbon monoxide in smoke can bind to hemoglobin more effectively than oxygen, reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.
  3. Ischemic hypoxia: Inflammation and damage to lung tissue can impair blood flow and oxygen delivery to tissues.

All of these factors can contribute to the lethal effects of smoke inhalation.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 699.

questions.text:
A patient who was depressed and had a history of the rapid onset of dyspnea arrived. An X-ray of the chest reveals bilateral diffuse infiltrates, with the right middle
and lower lobes being more heavily affected. Despite treatment, he was not able to be saved, and an autopsy revealed that his lungs looked grossly normal.
The following was revealed through histopathology: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia
 
  • The given histological slides depict a granuloma with multinucleated giant cells reacting to acellular debris that could be foreign matter that has been inhaled, similar to what is seen in vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia.
  • Depressed patient, history of rapid start of dyspnea, and chest X-ray revealing bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominance of involvement of the middle and lower lobes suggest the diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 711.

questions.text: 85-year-old man was involved in a car accident and visited the hospital. He sustained multiple lower-limb fractures, rib fractures, and lung contusions. He eventually passed away from his wounds. An autopsy lung biopsy revealed the following characteristics. What is the most probable reason for his demise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fat embolism

  • Fat embolism is the most probable reason for his demise.
  • The patient has a history of a traffic accident with a lower limb fracture, which results in fat embolism since lengthy bone fractures cause microscopic fat globules to leak.
  • The small pulmonary artery branch in this region of the lung has distinct, circular holes (fat globules) that are typical of a fat embolism.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 131.

questions.text: What is the cause of ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is Option (4) Damage to Endothelial cells > Option(2) - Answer confirmed by consulting with SRs/Assistant Professor at AIIMS, Delhi. 

ARDS is a progressive condition that includes three stages:
1. Exudative
2. Proliferative
3. Fibrotic.

The exudative stage involves injury to the alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type II pneumocytes(endothelial-epithelial barrier damage) While the initial insult damages both endothelial cells and type II pneumocytes - the primary inciting event is the damage to endothelial cells which results in the secretion of multiple inflammatory cytokines(TNF-alpha/IL-1/IL-8) that cause Neutrophil activation and migration - causing further endothelial-epithelial damage - causes fluid accumulation leading to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema which is characteristic of ARDS. 

The endothelial injury also leads to microthrombi and results in ischemic injury too.

The proliferative stage involves the proliferation of type II pneumocytes and the synthesis of new pulmonary surfactant. (Hence, option 1 is incorrect - there is proliferation of type 2 pneumocytes)

In the fibrotic phase, the alveolar edema and inflammatory exudates are converted to extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis, necessitating long-term support with mechanical ventilation and/or supplemental oxygen.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: The largest difference in alveolar-arterial oxygen is observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Pulmonary embolism

  • In Pulmonary embolism gradient increases to very high level.
  • The Alveolar-arterial gradient is a measure of the difference between the alveolar concentration and the arterial concentration of oxygen.
  • It helps to assess the integrity of alveolar capillary unit. In states of ventilation-perfusion mismatch, such as pulmonary embolism or right-to-left shunt, oxygen is not effectively transferred from the alveoli to the blood which results in elevated gradient.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: A patient presented with a 4 months’ history of cough with diarrheal episodes. Bronchoscopy revealed an intrabronchial polyp. Biopsy from the polyp showed atypical cells with microscopic necrosis and 5 mitotic figures per 10 high-power fields as shown below. Chromogranin staining was positive. What is the diagnosis and grade of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Atypical carcinoid grade 2

  • The patient has carcinoid syndrome, according to this clinical situation.
  • Chromogranin positivity supports the tumor's neuroendocrine origin. The difference between typical and atypical carcinoids is that typical carcinoids have less than two mitoses per ten high-power fields and do not exhibit necrosis, whereas atypical carcinoids have between two and ten mitoses per ten high-power fields and/or necrotic foci.
  • These have been categorized as grade 2 carcinoids.
  • As a result, the patient has a Grade 2 Atypical Carcinoid. Atypical carcinoids also show increased pleomorphism, have more prominent nucleoli, and are more likely to grow in a disorganized fashion and invade lymphatics.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 723.

questions.text: What does indoor air pollution not result in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Impaired neurological development

Indoor air pollution does not lead to Impaired neurological development.

* Indoor air pollution

  • Chronic lung disease (1.7x increased risk as compared to unexposed) 
  • Adverse pregnancy outcome
  • Pneumonia in children (2x increased risk as compared to unexposed).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 410.

questions.text: In a 70 years old man who was working in asbestos factory for 10-15 years. On routine X-ray, a mass was seen in right apical region of the lung. Biopsy was taken from the mass. Which of the following is seen on electron microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Numerous long slender microvilli
 
  • Most likely diagnosis on the basis of description is malignant mesothelioma.
  • Numerous long, slender microvilli will be seen on electron microscopy in malignant mesothelioma.
  • Contrast this with short stubby microvilli seen in Adeno carcinoma. Mesotheliomas are the most specific neoplasms associated with asbestosis. They can develop 1-2 years after exposure, but the incidence is highest 20-35 years after exposure.
  • Displays a strong male preference (3:1) The presence of long microvilli and abundant tonofilaments on electron microscopy, but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies, favors the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 726.

choices.text: Enlarged breasts, increased hair all over the body

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who smoked 5 packs a day for 11 years has been diagnosed with lung cancer. The tumor was shown to have tiny, highly mitotic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei through histologic analysis. Which of the following clinical manifestations could the patient experience while they are ill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thin limbs and obese trunks
 
  • The biopsy of the patient, who is a 60-year-old male with a history of 55 pack years and presented with chronic cough, revealed small hyperchromatic nuclei and highly mitotic cells–findings which are suggestive of Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC).
  • Small cell carcinoma is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli (see Fig. 15.43C). The cells are round, oval, or spindle shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell cancer lungs- SIADH, Cushing's syndrome(given in the question), Lambert-Eaton syndrome, anemia, etc. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 721.

questions.text: A middle-aged immunocompromised man arrived with a fever and shortness of breath. A middle lobe lesion with infiltration was seen on HRCT. The image displays a lung biopsy taken from the lesion. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) CMV pneumonia 
 
  • This diagnosis was suggested due to a middle-aged immunocompromised male presenting with a history of fever and breathlessness, and HRCT showing a middle lobe lesion with infiltration.
