  • Analysis of the lung biopsy image revealed many cells with intranuclear inclusions, suggesting CMV pneumonia as the likely diagnosis.
  • In immunosuppressed individuals, such as transplant recipients and HIV-infected individuals, CMV infection can lead to severe, life-threatening problems, particularly of the lungs and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Pneumonia caused by CMV is characterized by an interstitial mononuclear infiltrate with foci of necrosis along with enlarged cells with intranuclear inclusions. This can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • The intestinal infection can lead to intestinal necrosis and ulceration which can cause pseudo membranes and debilitating diarrhea.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1139.

questions.text: A worker who had spent the previous 20 years working in a manufacturing suddenly had pleural thickening and fibrosis. The graphic below depicts the lesion's histopathology. Most likely medical condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Asbestosis 

The diagnosis of asbestosis is suggested due to the presence of pleural thickening, fibrosis, and asbestos bodies found on the image.
  • Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center which are formed when macrophages phagocytize asbestos fibers, and the iron is derived from phagocyte ferritin.
  • In addition, other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes which are known as ferruginous bodies. This diagnosis is further supported by the history of working in an asbestos factory for 20 years.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lobar Pneumonia
 
  • The image shows uniform involvement of whole lobe and therefore it is a case of lobar pneumonia.
  • Patchy consolidation of the lung is the dominant characteristic of bronchopneumonia, while consolidation of a large portion of a lobe or of an entire lobe defines lobar pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 708.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Miliary tuberculosis
 
  • The picture represents miliary tuberculosis, which is characterized by widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis throughout the body.
  • Miliary tuberculosis appears as numerous small, millet seed-like granulomas in various organs, including the lungs.
  • These granulomas consist of central caseous necrosis surrounded by epithelioid macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and lymphocytes.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 373.

questions.text: A female recounts a history of escalating shortness of breath. Histology reveals a patchy heterogeneous fibrosis with a number of fibroblastic foci. The following is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Usual interstitial pneumonia
 
  • The described histological findings of patchy heterogeneous fibrosis with fibroblastic foci are consistent with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).
  • UIP is the histological pattern seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a chronic progressive lung disease characterized by fibrosis and architectural distortion of the lung parenchyma.
  • In UIP, there is a combination of areas of normal lung, fibrosis with honeycomb changes, and fibroblastic foci representing sites of active fibroblast proliferation.
  • Fibroblastic foci are aggregates of activated fibroblasts associated with myofibroblasts that contribute to the ongoing fibrotic process in UIP.
Other patterns of interstitial lung disease, such as non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP), have distinct histological features and clinical associations.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2190.

questions.text: Cavitary lesions in lungs can be observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Staphylococcal pneumonia
 
  • Cavitary lesions in the lungs can be observed in Staphylococcal pneumonia.
  • Cavitary lesions refer to hollow spaces or cavities within the lung tissue.
  • Staphylococcal pneumonia is a type of bacterial pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus bacteria, which can lead to the formation of cavitary lesions in the lungs. 
  • In x-ray Soap Bubble appearance is seen. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 270.

questions.text: A 30 years old woman with dyspnea, cough, sputum production and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was a non-smoker and alcoholic. The lung autopsy is portrayed. Which of the following conditions was most likely associated with the woman's death
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)   \(\alpha~\)-1 antitrypsin deficiency
 
  • The Gross specimen suggest emphysematous lungs, it is a chronic lung disease that results in damage to alveoli, the small air sacs in the lungs- pan acinar emphysema.
  • When damaged, alveoli lose their flexibility and cannot feed enough oxygen into the bloodstream.
  • Emphysema is typically caused by long-term exposure to cigarette smoke, as well as environmental pollutants like car exhaust. Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a protein produced in the liver that helps protect the lungs from damage caused by inflammation.
  • Individuals with emphysema are often low on AAT, leaving their lungs and alveoli vulnerable to the effects of smoking, air pollutants, and other irritants. Though is can be present without active smoking also.
  • Without the protection of AAT, the lung tissue gradually becomes damaged and scarred, leading to difficulty breathing, coughing, and a decreased quality of life.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 679.

questions.text: The electron microscopic image of alveoli is given below. Which among the following marked structure is inflamed and swollen in COVID-19 ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Endothelium
 
  • The endothelium of the alveoli is inflamed and swollen in COVID-19 ARDS.
  • Histopathological findings include diffuse alveolar damage, hyaline membrane formation, and inflammatory infiltrates.
  • The endothelial cells show signs of inflammation, such as cytoplasmic swelling and vacuolation.
  • The presence of viral particles within the endothelial cells and vascular endothelial damage contribute to vascular leakage and edema.
  • These histopathological changes lead to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure in severe cases of COVID-19 ARDS.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2270.

questions.text: A 50-year-old industrial worker arrives at the OPD with a cough and dyspnea. Upon examination, it was discovered that he had lung fibrosis and pleural thickening. The lung biopsy resulted in the following discovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asbestosis

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of Asbestosis. It is an occupational lung disease especially seen in shipping industry. Occurs because of chronic exposure to Asbestos. Patient complaints of cough, dyspnea.
  • It usually affects the lower lobes of lung and presents as —Pleural plaque (Most Common Lesion), Lung Cancer or malignant mesothelioma (Most specific finding of asbestosis, needs about 25 years of exposure). H&E demonstrates asbestos/ferruginous bodies (dumbbell shaped bodies)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct options.
Column A Column B
A. Silicosis 1. Crazy paving pattern
B. Mesothelioma 2. Malignant Plural effusion without mediastinal shift 
C. Caplan Syndrome 3. Initially demonstrated in coal workers
D. Asbestosis 4. Basal lobes involved
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4
 
  • In silicosis, crazy paving pattern is seen on HRCT chest which represents ground glass opacity with septal thickening.
  • Malignant plural effusion can be with or without mediastinal shift. In cases of Mesothelioma, shift is absent.
  • Caplan syndrome was first demonstrated in coal workers.
  • Asbestosis, which is a type of pneumoconiosis is due to the deposition of asbestos bodies, usually involving the basal lobes of the lung. It's an exception since majority of pneumoconiosis have predilection for upper lobes of the lung.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 692.

questions.text:
What is the most common lung damage finding in COVID 19 infection?
 1. Pulmonary infarction
 2. Diffuse alveolar damage
 3. Endothelial injury
 4. Fibrin clots
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diffuse alveolar damage
 
  • Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common finding of lung injury in COVID-19 due to ARDS.
  • It is characterized by formation of a hyaline membrane (pink in color) which fully encloses the alveoli.
  • There is associated widespread inflammation and mononuclear cell-dominated alveolar damage.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1509.

questions.text:
Which of the following is an ILD caused by smoking?
a. Respiratory bronchiolitis
b. Idiopathic Pulmonary fibrosis
c. Pulmonary Langerhans histiocytosis
d. Desquamative Interstitial pneumonitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) a,c,d are correct

Smoking-related ILD includes:
  • i. Respiratory Bronchiolitis with interstitial lung disease (RB-ILD)
  • ii. Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia (DIP)
  • iii. Pulmonary Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (PLCH)
These diseases are due to active or prior smoking exposure.
DIP has also been linked to Familial Pulmonary Fibrosis in children (FPF).
The cause of IPF is unknown but it has been linked to smoking

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2194.

questions.text:
A patient is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. During the pulmonectomy, there was a 1 cm blackish hilar lymph node.
Identify the cause of pigmentation.
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2) Anthracotic pigment.
 
  • The patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung had a 1 cm blackish hilar lymph node observed during pulmonectomy. The cause of pigmentation in this case is anthracotic pigment.
  • Anthracotic pigment refers to the accumulation of carbonaceous particles in the tissues, typically derived from inhaled environmental pollutants or cigarette smoke.
  • Chronic exposure to these particles can lead to their deposition in the lymph nodes, resulting in pigmentation.
  • In the context of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, the pigmentation is most likely due to the accumulation of carbon particles from inhaled smoke or other environmental sources in the regional lymph nodes.
* [Extra Edge]: PNEUMOCONIOSIS


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 694.

questions.text: The following causes acute respiratory distress syndrome [ARDS] by causing indirect lung injury:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Sepsis

Sepsis is an indirect cause of ARDS, while Fat embolism/Aspiration of gastric contents and Pneumonia are direct causes of lung injury causing ARDS. 



   

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2225.

questions.text: The following is not true regarding lung carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Scar carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma
 
  • Scar carcinoma is type of adenocarcinoma. Scar carcinoma is a type of lung cancer that originates around peripheral scars in the lung. Scarring in the lung can result from a variety of infections, injuries, and lung diseases. 
  • Therefore, option 4 is not true and is the correct answer.
  • Option 1 is correct because adenocarcinoma is actually the most common type of lung carcinoma, accounting for approximately 40% of cases.
  • Option 2 is true because squamous cell carcinoma is typically centrally located and can cause obstruction of the bronchi, leading to symptoms such as coughing and shortness of breath.
  • Option 3 is also true because small cell carcinoma is a highly malignant type of lung cancer that tends to grow and spread rapidly, making it difficult to treat.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 717.

questions.text: With the exception of, asbestosis exhibits all of the traits listed below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Emphysema
 
  • Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers.
  • It is characterized by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and fibrous pleural thickening.
  • Calcific pleural plaques are also commonly seen in individuals with asbestosis.
  • However, emphysema is not typically associated with asbestosis.
  • Emphysema is a separate lung condition characterized by destruction of the alveolar walls, leading to abnormal enlargement of air spaces.
  • While both asbestosis and emphysema can occur concurrently in individuals with a history of asbestos exposure, they are distinct entities.
PNEUMOCONIOSIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about atypical pneumonia is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alveolar exudates
 
  • Atypical pneumonia refers to pneumonia caused by organisms such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydophila pneumoniae, and Legionella pneumophila.
  • Unlike typical bacterial pneumonia, atypical pneumonia is characterized by a more insidious onset and a milder clinical course.
  • Lymphocytic infiltrate is a characteristic finding in atypical pneumonia.
  • Dry cough is also commonly observed in patients with atypical pneumonia.
  • Interstitial pattern on X-ray is another feature associated with atypical pneumonia.
  • The presence of alveolar exudates is not a characteristic feature of atypical pneumonia, but rather seen in typical bacterial pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 710.

questions.text: Which one of the following describes shock lung?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Diffuse alveolar damage
 
  • Shock lung, also known as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is a severe form of respiratory failure characterized by diffuse lung injury.
  • The histological hallmark of shock lung is diffuse alveolar damage, which includes two distinct phases:
    • Acute exudative phase: Characterized by the presence of hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls, diffuse alveolar edema, and infiltration of inflammatory cells.
    • Subacute proliferative phase: Characterized by fibroblast proliferation and organizing pneumonia.
  • Diffuse alveolar damage results in severe hypoxemia, respiratory distress, and bilateral infiltrates on chest imaging.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 138.

choices.text: Presence of giant cell in vessel wall

questions.text: What histological finding characterises chronic radiation pneumonitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Foam cells in the vessel wall
 
  • Chronic radiation pneumonitis is a late complication of radiation therapy to the chest, typically occurring months to years after treatment.
  • Histologically, chronic radiation pneumonitis is characterized by various findings, including:
    • Fibrosis and thickening of the alveolar septa.
    • Chronic inflammatory infiltrates composed of lymphocytes and macrophages.
    • Foam cells in the vessel wall, which are lipid-laden macrophages that accumulate within the walls of pulmonary arteries.
  • Foam cells in the vessel wall are a characteristic feature of chronic radiation pneumonitis and can lead to vascular occlusion and fibrosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 696.

questions.text: Lupus Pernio is found in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sarcoidosis
 
  • Lupus pernio is a distinct skin manifestation of sarcoidosis, a multisystem granulomatous disorder.
  • It presents as violaceous, indurated, and raised plaques on the face, particularly involving the nose, cheeks, and ears.
  • Lupus pernio lesions are typically chronic and resistant to treatment.
  • The presence of lupus pernio is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis, although it is not specific.
  • Sarcoidosis can involve various organs, including the lungs, lymph nodes, skin, eyes, and liver.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 696.

questions.text: A young person dies of COVID-19 infection. A lung autopsy, what is the significant findings?
questions.solution:
The characteristic finding on lung autopsy in a patient with COVID-19 is a thick layer of fibrin or waxy hyaline membrane lining the alveolar wall. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1508, 1509, 2225-2227.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: IHC for P40 positive with HPE slide as given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The IHC marker and the given image showing Keratin pearls are suggestive of Squamous cell carcinoma of lungs.

Different types of Lung carcinoma:





Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 329, 718.

questions.text: A chronic smoker with a history of consuming 24 packs in a month presents with breathlessness and chest pain. On investigation, the lung tumor is found to stain positive for chromogranin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Positivity for chromogranin points toward a diagnosis of Small cell carcinoma. Small cell carcinoma also has the strongest association with smoking (given in clinical stem)
 
Small cell carcinoma (SCLC) is strongly associated with heavy smoking and frequently presents with symptoms like breathlessness, chest pain, and other systemic manifestations. The staining for chromogranin indicates a neuroendocrine tumor, a hallmark feature of small cell carcinoma.

Features:
 
  1. Smoking History: SCLC has a strong association with chronic smoking.
  2. Neuroendocrine Markers: SCLC stains positive for markers like:
    • Chromogranin
    • Synaptophysin
    • CD56
  3. Clinical Presentation:
    • Rapidly growing central lung tumor.
    • Associated with symptoms due to bronchial obstruction or paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., SIADH, ACTH secretion).

Other options:
 
  1. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Typically stains positive for p63 and p40, not chromogranin.
  2. Adenocarcinoma: Commonly stains positive for TTF-1 and Napsin A, not chromogranin.
  3. Large Cell Carcinoma: Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma can stain for chromogranin, but it is rare and less strongly associated with smoking compared to SCLC.

Thus, the clinical history and chromogranin positivity strongly indicate Small Cell Carcinoma.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 329, 716-722.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with cough. Lab investigations reveal hypercalcemia. Histopathology reveals large atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a chronic smoker presenting with cough and hypercalcemia. Lung carcinoma is being suspected and lung biopsy has been taken to identify the histological subset of lung cancer. 

  • While Cushing syndrome and SIADH are commonly associated with small cell carcinoma, hypercalcemia due to PTHrP is characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Adenocarcinoma may have hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (clubbing) while large cell carcinoma may produce hCG leading to gynaecomastia.
  • Thus, a smoker presenting with cough, hypercalcemia and large atypical cells on biopsy is most likely to have squamous cell carcinoma.

Fig: Keratin Pearls seen in Squamous Type of Lung Malignancy.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 718,719.

questions.text: A Chronic Smoker who worked in a cement factory for the past 20 years developed mesothelioma. Among the following options, exposure to which of the following can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
• Mesothelioma is most specific association of asbestosis.
  • Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis, which is distinguished from diffuse interstitial fibrosis resulting from other causes only by the presence of asbestos bodies. Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center that consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material.
  • Chest x-ray studies reveal irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. With advancement of the pneumoconiosis, a honeycomb pattern develops.
  • The disease may remain static or progress to respiratory failure, cor pulmonale, and death. Pleural plaques are usually asymptomatic and are detected on radiographs as circumscribed densities.
  • Asbestosis complicated by lung or pleural cancer is associated with a particularly grim prognosis.
  • Asbestos bodies are found in increased numbers in the lungs of patients with mesothelioma. Another marker of asbestos exposure, the asbestos plaque, has been previously discussed
     

Fig: High-power detail of an asbestos body, revealing the typical beading and knobbed ends


Fig: Asbestos Related Pleural plaques.

* Extra Edge :


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 726.

questions.text: 70y old smoker is detected to have Lung Carcinoma. . His lung biopsy revealed Keratin Pearls and islands of large polygonal malignant cells. Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific marker for this tumour?
questions.solution:
Keratin pearls on Biopsy is suggestive of Squamous cell carcinoma of lungs. P40 is the most sensitive and specific marker for Squamous cell Carcinoma of lungs.
P63 is also positive but not the most sensitive.
TTF 1 and Napsin A- Adenocarcinoma
Chromogranin,  Synaptophysin ,CD 56 -Small cell Cancer.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No: 271.

questions.text: Which of the following organs as the highest incidence of graft rejection?
questions.solution:
Among all solid organ transplants, the small intestine has the highest incidence of graft rejection.

This is because the intestinal mucosa contains the largest amount of lymphoid tissue (gut-associated lymphoid tissue, GALT), which makes it highly immunogenic. The abundant immune cells and constant exposure to gut flora trigger a stronger host immune response against the graft.

In contrast:

  • Kidney transplants have comparatively low rejection rates due to advances in immunosuppression.

  • Heart and lung transplants have moderate rates of rejection, with lungs being more immunogenic than heart due to direct environmental exposure and colonization by microorganisms.

  • Intestine remains the most challenging due to high antigenicity and bacterial contamination risk.

Hence, intestine > lung > heart > kidney in order of rejection risk.

questions.text: The traid of Situs inversus totalis, chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis indicates the diagnosis of
questions.solution:
The classic triad of situs inversus totalis, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis is characteristic of Kartagener syndrome, a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).

Key points:

  • Pathophysiology: Defective motile cilia → impaired mucociliary clearance → chronic respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and infertility.

  • Situs inversus: Occurs in ~50% of PCD patients due to defective ciliary function during embryogenesis.

  • Other features: Chronic otitis media, male infertility (due to immotile sperm), nasal polyps.

Other options:

  • Cystic fibrosis: Causes thick mucus, chronic respiratory infections, and pancreatic insufficiency, but situs inversus is not typical.

  • Young syndrome: Male infertility with bronchiectasis, but situs inversus is absent.

  • Churg-Strauss syndrome (EGPA): Small-vessel vasculitis with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, unrelated to situs inversus.

Hence, the triad strongly suggests Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Sl no Disease Characteristics
1 Silicosis a- Basal lobes are involved
2 Mesothelioma b- Malignant pleural effusion without mediastinal shift
3 Caplan syndrome c- Initially demonstrated in coal workers
4 Asbestosis d- Crazy paving pattern
questions.solution:
• Silicosis : Crazy paving pattern
  • Mesothelioma: Malignant pleural effusion without mediastinal shift
  • Caplan syndrome: Initially demonstrated in coal workers
  • Asbestosis: Basal lobes are involved


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page no 539,2530 .

questions.text: Asbestos exposure may be associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is primarily associated with mesotheliomas, which are cancers arising from the mesothelial lining of the lungs and other organs.

Asbestos-related diseases include:

Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
Pleural effusion
Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
Lung carcinoma
Mesotheliomas
Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

Mesothelioma features: 

  • Cancer of the pleura, peritoneum, or pericardium

  • Latency: 20–40 years post-exposure

  • Classic histopathology: psammoma bodies, asbestos bodies

  • Often resistant to treatment and poor prognosis

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of fever with hemoptysis and hematuria. Investigations reveal the presence of antibodies against the glomerular basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Goodpasture's Syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against type IV collagen, primarily affecting the lungs and kidneys. Here are the key points regarding the syndrome:

Pathophysiology:
Autoantibodies: The immune system mistakenly produces antibodies against the basement membrane of the glomeruli in the kidneys and the alveoli in the lungs.
Collagen Type: The target of these antibodies is type IV collagen, which is a major component of the basement membranes.
Clinical Features:
Renal Involvement:

Patients may present with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), leading to acute kidney injury.
Symptoms include hematuria (blood in urine), proteinuria, edema, and hypertension.
Pulmonary Involvement:

Patients may experience pulmonary hemorrhage, which can manifest as hemoptysis (coughing up blood), cough, dyspnea (shortness of breath), and chest pain.

Diagnosis:
Serology: Detection of anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibodies in the serum is a key diagnostic marker.
Kidney Biopsy: A biopsy may show crescentic glomerulonephritis with a characteristic pattern of linear immunofluorescence staining along the GBM.
Chest Imaging: Imaging studies may reveal pulmonary hemorrhage or other lung abnormalities.

Treatment:
Immunosuppressive Therapy: Treatment typically involves the use of corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide).
Plasmapheresis: This procedure may be employed to remove circulating antibodies from the bloodstream, particularly in severe cases.
Supportive Care: Management of renal failure may require dialysis until kidney function is restored.
Prognosis:
The prognosis varies and depends on the severity of kidney involvement and the promptness of treatment. Early diagnosis and treatment can improve outcomes significantly.

choices.text: 031 and a high number of polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which of the following terms best describes the pleural effusion in this case?

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was hospitalized due to bacterial pneumonia accompanied by a pleural effusion. Analysis of the pleural fluid showed a specific gravity of 1.031 and a high number of polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which of the following terms best describes the pleural effusion in this case?
questions.solution:
• Pleural effusions are classified as transudates or exudates depending on their protein content, specific gravity, and cellular content.

  • Transudate: clear, low protein, SG < 1.015, few cells → due to systemic causes (CHF, nephrotic syndrome).

  • Exudate: protein-rich, SG > 1.020, with inflammatory cells.

    • Serous exudate: straw-colored, with lymphocytes.

    • Fibrinous exudate: fibrin deposition, seen in TB/viral infections.

    • Purulent exudate (Empyema): thick, pus-like, rich in neutrophils, seen in bacterial infections (e.g., pneumonia).

In this case:

  • SG = 1.031 → clearly an exudate.

  • High neutrophils → bacterial cause.

  • So, this is a purulent exudate (empyema).


Reference
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e - Page no. 75, 93, 94

questions.text: Which among the following is not an autoimmune disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ulcerative colitis

The most appropriate option after elimination is ulcerative collitis rest all have autoimmune etiology. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 799.

questions.text: What factor best determines the prognosis of esophageal cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) T stage
 
  • Long-term survival following esophagectomy depends on a number of factors such as the number of involved lymph nodes (N), depth of the tumor invasion (T), and the location of the tumor in the esophagus.
  • In esophageal cancer, the prognosis is best determined by the T stage, among the options provided.
* Prognosis is better for tumors of the cervical esophagus and tumors located at the GE junction. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 762.

choices.text: Most common mesenchymal tumour of gastrointestinal tract
ALK gene mutation is seen in most of the cases

questions.text: Select the option that is not true about Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumour (GIST).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) ALK gene mutation is seen in most of the cases
 
  • GIST is not associated with ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase) gene mutations. They are associated with KIT gene mutations. 
  • GISTs typically originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal, which are specialized cells in the gastrointestinal tract involved in regulating gut motility.
  • They are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the gastrointestinal tract, and the prognosis can depend on factors such as tumor size, mitotic rate, and presence of metastasis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 778.

choices.text: Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of liver induced due to OCPs
Nutmeg liver with pale areas of necrosis and dark congested areas of perivenular viable hepatocytes

questions.text: The following findings are revealed by a liver biopsy. What is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
 
  • This iconic image of Nutmeg liver shows the liver with chronic passive venous congestion. Necrotic hepatocytes make up the dark, crowded spots, whereas viable hepatocytes are present in the paler, brownish-looking areas around them.
  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • Microscopically, there is centrilobular congestion and hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis
To remember this, think the blood supply comes via portal vein and Hepatic artery from the portal triad towards the center of the lobule, so when there is stasis the first to be affected is the centrilobular area than the periportal area which is close to the vascularity. It is therefore - Periportal fibrosis and Centrilobular necrosis seen in CVC liver
                                        

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 533.

choices.text: H. pylori infection, Silver stain, Gram-negative coccobacilli

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complains of heartburn. An upper GI endoscopy was done and a biopsy from a suspicious lesion showed the following picture.
What is the significance of this? What particular stains are you going to use for confirmation, and what are you looking for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Barrett’s esophagus, mucin stain, dysplasia
 
  • The histological picture of the esophagus shows intestinal-type epithelium with goblet cells, characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.
  • Mucin stain helps to better define the extent of dysplasia and rule out malignant transformation.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman complained of recurring bloody diarrhea. Multiple geographic ulcers are seen during colonoscopy, as seen in the histological analysis below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crohn’s disease

  • The histology of what appears to be a geographical ulcer is indicating a transmural inflammation, meaning it extends through the lamina propria and the muscle layer.
  • A non-caseating granuloma too is seen. Therefore, Crohn's disease is the most likely diagnosis.
  • In contrast, amoebic colitis yields a flask-shaped ulcer and pseudomembranous colitis have ischemic cryptitis and pseudo membrane on histology.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient was admitted with dysphagia. What is the result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett’s esophagus
 
  • The result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the image is consistent with Barrett's esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus with specialized intestinal-type columnar epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).
  • It is commonly associated with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is a premalignant condition for the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient comes in with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain that lasts for six hours. As seen, an erect abdominal X-ray was taken. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Toxic megacolon
 
  • The most probable diagnosis for the patient with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain seen in the erect abdominal X-ray is toxic megacolon.
  • Toxic megacolon is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and dilation of the colon, usually due to severe infection or inflammatory bowel disease.
  • It can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, fever, diarrhea, and signs of systemic toxicity.

Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis:


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2475.

questions.text: What does a lack of urobilinogen in the urine indicate in a jaundice patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Obstructive jaundice
 
  • In obstructive jaundice, urobilinogen levels are typically decreased or absent in urine.
  • This occurs because the obstruction prevents conjugated bilirubin from entering the intestines, where it would normally be converted to urobilinogen by gut bacteria and then excreted in urine.
           
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2650.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old patient was diagnosed with intussusception, which required surgery and the removal of a section of his intestine that had several polyps.
Pathology was visible using microscopy as follows: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hamartomatous polyps 
 
  • The histology shows a sizable, large, pedunculated polyp with a distinct lobulated shape.
  • Well-developed smooth muscle and an arborizing network of connective tissue are seen to extend into the polyp, and it's surrounded by normal intestinal epithelium rich in goblet cells.
  • This is typical of PJ syndrome (Peutz-Jegher syndrome) which has hamartomatous polyps. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text:
An endoscopic image of an esophageal lesion is shown below.



What is the expected histopathology finding?


1. 



2. 




3. 




4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett's esophagus
 
  • The given endoscopic image is of Barrett's esophagus, the pale region signifies squamous epithelium of esophagus and the reddish region signifies columnar region.
  • The histopathologic image of option 3 shows the squamous to columnar metaplasia seen in Barrett's esophagus.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

choices.text: Inability to induce inflammation to remove the organism
Integration of viral DNA with host DNA

questions.text:
Asymptomatic hepatitis B affects 2–3 percent of the general population, but there is an increased risk of progression to hepatocellular carcinoma.
What could be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Integration of viral DNA with host DNA
 
  • HBV DNA serves as an insertional mutagenesis agent by randomly integrating into the chromosomes of hepatocytes.
  • 90% of HCCs linked to HBV experience integration of HBV DNA into the host genome, which has been proposed as an early occurrence in persistent viral infection.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 326.

questions.text: In Barrett’s Esophagus:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Intestinal Metaplasia
 
  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition where the normal tissue in the esophagus is replaced by abnormal tissue that resembles the lining of the small intestine with goblet cells. 
  • Diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus is made by endoscopic guided biopsy.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: What is the most important risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a virus that can cause an acute or chronic liver infection.
Chronic HBV infection is a major risk factor for the development of liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 326.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl has a viral fever. She later has severe vomiting for five days and is admitted to the hospital. She develops cerebral edema while in the hospital. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in a liver biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Marked micro vesicular steatosis
 
  • Marked Micro vesicular steatosis can be seen in liver biopsy of this child, as the features are suggesting Reye Syndrome which is a genetic disorder that is triggered by a viral infection, such as influenza or varicella, and the use of salicylates.
  • Symptoms can include vomiting, encephalopathy, seizures, coma, and increased intracranial pressure that can lead to death. Liver biopsy typically shows micro vesicular steatosis without liver inflammation or necrosis.
  • Treatment includes screening for fatty-acid oxidation and fatty-acid transport defects as well as supportive care for symptoms.

Fig: Microvesicular Steatosis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 826.

questions.text: Jaundice and increased liver enzymes are seen in a young female patient. She had already experienced two instances that are comparable. Her IgG level was 2400 IU, and her serum ANA was 1:40. Her viral indicators were negative, and her serum copper levels were normal. After a liver biopsy, you administered immunosuppressants based on the pathology report, and the patient's condition got better. What was the pathology report's most probable finding and the recommended course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Autoimmune hepatitis

Autoimmune hepatitis has a variable clinical presentation. Patients may be asymptomatic or present in acute liver failure (rare), or anywhere between. It tends to have a relapsing-remitting course. There is an association with other autoimmune conditions.

* Depending on the phase, the patient may present with;

  • hepatomegaly +/- splenomegaly
  • jaundice
  • elevated aminotransferases (ALT and AST)

* Diagnostic criteria of autoimmune hepatitis include:

  • elevated antinuclear antibodies, anti-smooth muscle antibodies
  • globulin level of more than 20 g/L
  • coexistence of non-hepatic autoimmune diseases, including autoimmune thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus
  • the elimination of other forms of hepatitis such as viral or toxic hepatitis
  • histologic examination findings consistent with AIH
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 839.

choices.text: Germline mutations in the cationic trypsinogen gene

questions.text: Which of the following is not an etiological cause for pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Islet cell hyperplasia 
 
  • Islet cell hyperplasia does not cause pancreatitis.
  • Pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas. The most common cause of pancreatitis is alcohol abuse and chronic usage of certain medications, such as steroids and diuretics.
  • Other potential causes include gallstones, infections, abdominal trauma, auto-immune disorders, genetic disorders, and certain medications. In some cases, the cause of pancreatitis can be unknown.
* [Extra Edge]: Etiologic Factors in Acute Pancreatitis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 882.

questions.text: Which of the following describes a stomach epithelial tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Gastric adenocarcinoma
 
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor that arises from the glandular cells lining the stomach.
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is a type of stomach cancer characterized by tumor invasion into the stomach wall, including the deeper layers. It can be classified into different histological types, such as intestinal and diffuse types, based on the appearance of tumor cells.
  • Pathologists also assess the tumor grade, ranging from well-differentiated to poorly differentiated, to determine the aggressiveness of the cancer.
* Other options:
  • Carcinoid tumors arise from neuroendocrine cells and are more commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Lymphoma refers to malignant tumors of lymphoid tissue and can occur in the stomach but is not specific to epithelial cells. GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor) is a mesenchymal tumor arising from Interstitial cells of Cajal and is not from epithelial cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 774.

questions.text: Pick the marker that is specific for Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CD 117
 
  • DOG1 and CD117 were the most sensitive and specific antibodies used in GIST diagnosis.
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are characterized by the expression of CD 117, also known as c-kit protein.
  • CD 117 is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of GIST. Immunohistochemical staining for CD 117 is commonly used to identify and diagnose GIST, as it is highly specific for this tumor type.

Other markers, such as CD 34 and S-100, may also be expressed in GIST, but CD 117 is considered the most specific and sensitive marker for GIST.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 778.

questions.text: What is the most typical site for a stomach ulcer?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is lesser curvature.

Gastric ulcers most commonly occur along the lesser curvature of the stomach, particularly near the junction of the body and antrum. This region is more susceptible to mucosal injury due to factors like H. pylori infection, NSAID use, and direct acid exposure.

Other options

  • The pyloric antrum is more commonly associated with duodenal ulcers rather than gastric ulcers.
  • The greater curvature is a less frequent site for ulcers, and when present, it raises concern for malignancy.
  • Ulcers in the large intestine are unrelated to stomach ulcers and are usually caused by inflammatory bowel disease, ischemia, or infections.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 767.

questions.text: Which of the following about Crohn's disease is untrue
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Continuous lesion visualized in endoscopy
 
  • The untrue statement is 2. Continuous lesion visualized in endoscopy.
  • Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus.
  • While Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and the colon, it can also affect the rectum. Crohn's disease can affect different segments of the gastrointestinal tract in a patchy manner, with skip lesions.
  • Involvement of the rectum in Crohn's disease can lead to symptoms such as rectal bleeding, mucous discharge, tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete evacuation), and perianal fistulas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: Select the most potential diagnosis used on a 20 year old patient with malabsorption diarrhoea and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient shows crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy and CD8 plus cells in lamina propria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Celiac disease

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the body’s immune system attacks and damages the lining of the small intestine when foods containing gluten are consumed.
  • Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Celiac disease can develop at any age and is thought to affect 1 in 100 people.
  • The damage to the small intestine caused by celiac disease leads to various findings in the body. First, malabsorption of important nutrients and vitamins can occur due to the damaged intestine.
  • This can lead to malnutrition, weight loss, and anemia. Other symptoms can include abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, fatigue, and depression.
  • In addition, skin rashes like dermatitis herpetiformis, easy bruising, delayed growth and development, canker sores, and osteoporosis may also be present.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 784.

questions.text: A child, of age 5 diagnosed with anal polyp. The most Histopathological image is given below. What diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Juvenile Polyp

  • Juvenile polyps are a common type of polyp that occurs mostly in children and adolescents.
  • Diagnosis is usually made after a colonoscopy. During the colonoscopy, the doctor will take a small sample of the polyp and examine it under a microscope to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Other tests can also be used to diagnose juvenile polyps, including imaging tests, such as X-rays or CT scans, to get a better look at the inside of the colon.
  • Finally, a colon biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and to differentiate between benign and malignant polyps. Microscopy reveals dilated glands filled with mucin, inflammatory debris.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who complained of chronic mouth ulcers and congested eyes was seen in the OPD. Inquiries revealed that he had h/o prior hospitalization for venous thrombosis. What illness is he dealing with exactly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Behcet's disease
 
  • The patient is dealing with Behcet's disease.
  • Behcet's disease is a systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and eye inflammation (conjunctivitis/uveitis).
  • In addition, it can cause blood vessel inflammation, leading to thrombosis and other systemic manifestations.

* The international criteria for Behçet disease scoring system

Sign/Symptom Points
Ocular lesions 2
Genital aphthosis 2
Oral aphthosis 2
Skin lesions 1
Neurological manifestations 1
Vascular manifestations 1
Positive pathergy test 1

* Patients with a score of < 3 were considered as not having BD.
* A score of 3 was considered probable BD, and a score of ≥4 indicated a definitive diagnosis of BD. 

Online Reference:
Adil A, Goyal A, Quint JM. Behcet Disease. [Updated 2023 Feb 22]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470257/

choices.text: Failure of migration of Neural crest cells

questions.text: Hirschsprung disease is caused due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Failure of migration of Neural crest cells
 
  • Hirschsprung disease is caused due to failure of migration of neural crest cells during embryonic development.
  • Histopathological findings include the absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon.
  • Accumulation of fecal material above the aganglionic segment leads to distension of the colon.
  • PR examination lead to expulsion of feaces. 
  • Biopsy reveals hypertrophic nerve trunks and increased number of nerve fibers in the aganglionic segment.
  • The transition zone between the aganglionic and normal segments shows a characteristic "cuff" of hypertrophic nerves.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 755.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements applies to a person with advanced liver disease?
(i) Hyperammonemia
(ii) Low ATP production
(iii) Conversion of alpha-keto glutarate to glutamate and then to glutamine is increased
(iv) Alpha-keto glutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) i, ii & iii

  • In case of advanced liver disease / liver failure, conversion of NH3 to Urea (Urea Cycle) doesn’t take place in the liver.
  • As a result, NH3 accumulates in the body, especially in the neurons of brain where they bind all the H+ ions to form NH4+.
  • Because of H+ ion depletion, there is decreased ATP production via the ETC. Alpha ketoglutarate is the scavenger of NH3. It binds to form Glutamate.
  • Glutamate binds with NH3 to form Glutamine (carrier of NH3).

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2549.

questions.text: Which of the following is disrupted by cholera toxin (ZOT) in the intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Zonula occludens

Zonula occludens is disrupted by cholera toxin (ZOT) in the intestinal epithelial cells.
  • Other than the well-known CT and TCP toxins, Vibrio has been extensively investigated with respect to Zot, RTX, and Ace among others. 
  • CT toxin- made up of A and B subunits. B binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors in intestinal mucosal cells. A causes production of Adenyl cyclase, this increases cAMP which activates CFTR causing increased secretion of chloride ions. 
  • Zot toxin- zona occludens toxin, alters the tight junctions. Induces a transitory reduction in transepithelial electrical resistance and an increase in transepithelial flux, increasing the permeability of TJs.
  • ACE toxin - integral membrane protein that affects ion transport, builds up in ligated rabbit ileal loops, and produces moderate diarrhea.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 12.

questions.text: What is the most likely primary site of a female with metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK7-, CK20+, and CDX-1 IHC markers
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Colorectal ca
 
  • CDX-1 + IHC marker for metastatic liver adenocarcinoma means colorectal carcinoma is the possible answer.
  • Transcription factors unique to the gut require genes CDX-1 and 2 which control intestine phenotypic development, differentiation, and maintenance.
  • CK7 and CK 20 are used to identify organ of origin in carcinoma of unknown primary. 
  • Colorectal Adeno Ca is ck 7 negative.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 814.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?
 A. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is most common extra-intestinal manifestation
 B. Arborising pattern 
 C. STK-11 mutation
 D. Autosomal recessive
 E. Multiple GI polyps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) B, C, E are correct

* Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is one of the polyposis syndromes due to mutation in tumor suppressor gene STK11. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and is characterized by:

  • multiple hamartomatous polyps, most commonly involving the small intestine (predominantly the jejunum), but also colon and stomach; mouth and esophagus are spared

  • mucocutaneous melanin pigmentation involving the mouth, fingers and toes

* Peutz-Jeghers polyps are non-neoplastic hamartomas due to the proliferation of all three layers of the mucosa, which have a characteristic feature of a smooth muscle core continuous with muscularis mucosa in a tree-like branching pattern.

* Patients are at increased risk of:

  • Intussusception
  • GI tract adenocarcinoma, although the polyps themselves are not premalignant

* Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is the most common extra-intestinal manifestation of familial adenomatous polyposis coli (FAP) syndrome. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 809.

questions.text: The absence of marked Cells will present with all except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Zollinger Ellison syndrome

The marked structures are Parietal Cells which secrete HCl and Castle's intrinsic factor.

Within the stomach, the most remarkable feature is a marked increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia. Gastrin also induces hyperplasia of mucous neck and endocrine cells within oxyntic mucosa.
In case of Zollinger Ellison syndrome, there is massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

* They are absent in:
  • Vit B12 deficiency
  • Intrinsic factor deficiency
  • Type 1 gastric carcinoid syndrome

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 773.

choices.text: APC, Kras and loss of 10 on nyc

questions.text: A colon cancer diagnosis has been made for a male patient. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely to exist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) APC, Kras, P53

In this patient APC, Kras, P53 gene mutations are likely to be present.

* [Extra Edge]: Adenoma-carcinoma sequence:
Fearon and Vogelstein proposed this classic model for the multistage progression of colorectal cancer.
  • A mutation in the APC tumor suppressor gene is generally considered to be the initiation event.
  • This is followed by the sequential accumulation of other epigenetic and genetic changes that eventually result in the progression from a normal cell to a metastatic tumor.
  • The classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence accounts for up to 80% of sporadic cancers and typically includes mutation of APC early in the neoplastic process.
  • Sequence of genetic mutations is in this order APC -> Kras -> P53
  • With loss of APC function, β-catenin accumulates and translocates to the nucleus, where it forms a complex with the DNA-binding factor TCF and activates the transcription of genes, including MYC and cyclin D1, that promote proliferation.
Memorizing Trick: -
AK53- APC, KRAS, P53

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 814.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with cirrhosis. Eosinophilic material that was cytokeratin-positive during the liver biopsy was CK 8+ and CK 18+. What is it most likely composed of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intermediate
 
  • Patients with chronic alcoholism and purulent destructive pulmonary diseases have been found to have an accumulation of intermediate filaments in their lung macrophages and endotheliocytes.
  • In liver accumulation of cytokeratin 8 and 18 is known as Malory Denk Body. 
  • Cytoskeletal components that build up excessively are an indication of cell dystrophy.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 837.
Online Reference:
Tinca AC, Cocuz IG, incu MC, Niculescu R, Sabu AH, Chiorean DM, Morariu SH, Turdean SG, Cotoi OS. CK 818: the key to differentiating intracutaneous lesions with pagetoid features. Rom J Morphol Embryol. 2021 Jul-Sep;62(3):757-763. doi: 10.47162/RJME.62.3.13. PMID: 35263404; PMCID: PMC9019624.

questions.text: What types of salivary gland tumours are most common?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pleomorphic adenoma
 
* ADENOMA PLEOMORPHIC 
  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor. 
  • It can develop from the submandibular, parotid, or other small salivary glands. It typically comes from the parotid's tail. 
  • Pleomorphic adenomas are slow-growing tumors that might present fairly large. 
  • They occur in females of the third or fourth decade. Because both epithelial and mesenchymal components can be observed in histology, they are known as "mixed tumors."
  • The tumor's stroma can vary in type—it could be mucoid, fibroid, vascular, myxochondroid, or chondroid—and its epithelial proportion may vary.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 748.

choices.text: Improves with complex carbohydrates food like bread, and oats
Most common cause of malabsorption in developing countries

questions.text: The correct statement about celiac disease is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Can cause GI Lymphoma

True about celiac disease is that it can cause GI lymphoma.
  • Enteropathy associated T Cell lymphoma can be caused due to celiac disease.
  • Which is a rare gastrointestinal non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, originating from intraepithelial T-lymphocyte, which is specifically associated with celiac disease.
  • It is diagnosed on biopsy and the disease worsens further on consumption of complex carbohydrates. 
  • It is the most common cause of malabsorption in developed countries. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of intestinal fistula in Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ileosigmoid

Crohn's disease can cause fistula formation between different parts of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Types of intestinal fistulas in Crohn's disease:
    • Enterocutaneous: Fistula between the intestine and the skin.
    • Ileosigmoid: Fistula between the ileum (part of the small intestine) and the sigmoid colon (part of the large intestine).
    • Gastrocolic: Fistula between the stomach and the colon.
    • Rectovaginal: Fistula between the rectum and the vagina.
  • Among these, the ileosigmoid fistula is the most common in Crohn's disease.
  • Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus.
  • It is characterized by inflammation, ulcers, and scarring of the intestinal walls, which can lead to the formation of fistulas.
  • An ileosigmoid fistula is a connection between the ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and the sigmoid colon (the last part of the large intestine). It can develop as a complication of Crohn's disease when inflammation and ulcers erode through the intestinal walls and create a passageway between the two organs. Symptoms of an ileosigmoid fistula may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, bloating, and fever. Treatment typically involves surgery to remove the affected portion of the intestine and repair the fistula. 
* [Extra Edge]: Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: Salivary gland tumor was exclusively seen in parotid gland-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 1) Warthin's tumor

Many other tumors in the body show similar morphology as the salivary gland tumors such Pleomorphic adenoma of skin (chondroid syringoma), Adenoid cystic variant adenocarcinoma of endometrium, Warthin's tumor however is seen only in salivary gland.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 749.

questions.text: Which is the most common part of GIT involved in Hirschsprung disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rectosigmoid 
 
  • Hirschsprung disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal segment of the colon and rectum.
  • Ganglion cells are necessary for the normal peristaltic movement of the intestine.
  • The most common part of the gastrointestinal tract involved in Hirschsprung disease is the rectosigmoid region (junction of the rectum and sigmoid colon).
  • Other parts of the colon, such as the descending colon, transverse colon, or entire colon, can also be affected.
  • The involvement of the small intestine is less common.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 755.

questions.text: The following conditions does not cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rotor syndrome 

Rotor syndrome, also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin.
  • Rotor syndrome does not cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is caused by an increase in the level of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood, which is usually due to either increased production or decreased clearance of bilirubin.
  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, on the other hand, is caused by an increase in the level of conjugated bilirubin in the blood, which is usually due to impaired excretion of bilirubin.
  • Hypothyroidism, hemolysis, and physiological jaundice can all cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • In hypothyroidism, there is decreased clearance of bilirubin due to decreased activity of liver enzymes. In hemolysis, there is increased production of bilirubin due to breakdown of red blood cells.
  • In physiological jaundice, there is increased production of bilirubin due to immature liver function.
  • Rotor syndrome, on the other hand, is a rare genetic disorder that causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is characterized by the accumulation of bilirubin in the liver and blood due to impaired excretion of bilirubin. However, it is important to note that unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia may also be present in some cases of Rotor syndrome, but it is not the predominant feature.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 853.

questions.text: Which is the most common benign tumor of the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Mixed cell parotid neoplasm
  • The most common benign tumor of the salivary gland is a mixed cell tumor, also known as pleomorphic adenoma, because of its dual origin from epithelial and myoepithelial elements. It is the commonest of all salivary gland tumors constituting up to two-thirds of all salivary gland tumors and is most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • This tumor accounts for approximately 60-70% of all salivary gland tumors.
  • It typically arises from the parotid gland, which is the largest salivary gland located in front of the ear.
  • Mixed cell tumors are composed of both epithelial and mesenchymal cells, which give rise to the diverse histologic appearance and varied clinical behavior.
  • They are slow-growing and painless, and usually present as a painless, mobile mass that has been present for months or years.
  • Histologically, mixed cell tumors are characterized by a mixture of ductal epithelial cells, myoepithelial cells, and stromal cells.
  • The epithelial cells form duct-like structures, while the myoepithelial cells are spindle-shaped and surround the epithelial cells.
  • The stromal cells are responsible for the production of the myxoid or chondroid matrix which gives the tumor its characteristic rubbery consistency.
  • Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for mixed cell tumors, and the prognosis is generally favorable with a low rate of recurrence.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text: Which of the following exhibits a predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Common bile duct stone
 
  • Hyperbilirubinemia refers to increased levels of bilirubin in the blood.
  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is characterized by increased levels of conjugated bilirubin.
  • The common bile duct stone can cause obstruction of the bile flow, leading to the accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood.
* Other options:
  • Physiological jaundice is a transient condition in newborns and is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Breast milk jaundice is a condition that occurs in breastfed infants and is also associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Hypothyroidism can lead to impaired bilirubin conjugation but is not associated with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2560.

questions.text: Typically, pseudopolyps are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ulcerative colitis 
 
  • Pseudo polyps are inflammatory polypoid lesions that can be seen in the colon and rectum.
  • They are typically observed in the setting of chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal mucosa.
  • Ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease, is one of the conditions in which pseudo polyps are commonly seen.
  • Pseudo polyps are formed due to the regeneration of the mucosal epithelium in areas of ulceration and destruction.
Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 802.

questions.text: The APC gene is mutated in every single one of the genetic disorders listed below that are linked to colorectal cancer, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lynch Syndrome 
 
  • The APC (adenomatous polyposis coli) gene is a tumor suppressor gene involved in the regulation of cell growth and division.
  • Mutations in the APC gene are associated with various forms of familial colorectal cancer syndromes.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), Gardner's syndrome, and Turcot's syndrome are all linked to mutations in the APC gene.
  • However, Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes and not the APC gene.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 813.

questions.text: Which of the following liver areas is most vulnerable to ischemia damage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Centrilobular
 
  • The centrilobular (zone III) region of the liver is the most vulnerable to ischemic damage.
  • This area is the furthest from the oxygenated blood supply and thus receives the lowest oxygen tension.
  • When blood flow to the liver is compromised, such as in cases of severe hypotension or liver ischemia, the centrilobular zone is the first to be affected.
  • Centrilobular necrosis is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic hepatitis (shock liver) and drug-induced liver injury.
* [Extra Edge]: Nutmeg liver
  • Congestion of the hepatic and portal vessels may produce pathologic changes in the liver, the spleen, and the gastrointestinal tract.
  • The liver is usually increased in size and weight (congestive hepatomegaly) caused by passive congestion, greatest around the central veins Grossly, this is reflected as congested red brown pericentral zones, with relatively normal-colored tan periportal regions, producing the characteristic “nutmeg liver” appearance.
  • In some instances, especially when left-sided heart failure with hypoperfusion is also present, severe centrilobular hypoxia produces centrilobular necrosis. With longstanding severe right-sided heart failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually culminating in cardiac cirrhosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 533.

questions.text: Except for___, all of the following are components of Snover's triad in acute cellular rejection of liver transplantation.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3. Cholangitis.

Snover's triad, which is associated with acute cellular rejection of liver transplantation, includes:

  1. Portal inflammation: Infiltration of inflammatory cells in the portal areas.
  2. Endothelialitis: Inflammation of the endothelial cells in the small bile ducts and portal vessels.
  3. Periportal fibrosis: Fibrosis around the portal tracts.

Cholangitis, on the other hand, is not a component of Snover's triad but is a separate condition that can occur due to bile duct complications or infections. Cholangitis is a component of Charcot's triad. 


Online Reference: 
Górnicka B, Ziarkiewicz-Wróblewska B, Bogdaska M, Odakowska-Jedynak U, Wróblewski T, Morton M, Ziókowski J, Paczek L, Krawczyk M, Wasiutyski A. Pathomorphological features of acute rejection in patients after orthotopic liver transplantation: own experience. Transplant Proc. 2006 Jan-Feb;38(1):221-5. doi: 10.1016/j.transproceed.2006.01.002. PMID: 16504708.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl who had previously experienced protracted fever and discomfort in her abdomen was found to have splenomegaly and leukopenia. She developed an acute abdominal incident throughout the course of the illness and passed away. What is the most likely outcome of the autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Longitudinal ulcers
 
  • The given clinical scenario suggests a case of Typhoid disease
  • Longitudinal ulcers are seen in Typhoid 
  • Ulcer may perforated -> peritonitis and finally may lead to death 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text: Mass in stomach, CD117 positive but cytokeratin (CK), S100 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A mass in the stomach that is CD117 (c-KIT) positive but cytokeratin (CK) and S100 negative strongly suggests a diagnosis of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).

IHC markers:
  • CD117 (c-KIT): A marker characteristic of GISTs, found in the interstitial cells of Cajal or their precursors.
  • Cytokeratin (CK): Typically positive in carcinomas, such as adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma, but negative in GISTs.
  • S100: A marker for melanomas and neural tumors but is not associated with GISTs.

Other options:
 
  • Adenocarcinoma: (Option 2) Typically positive for cytokeratin.1
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma: (Option 3) Usually shows markers like CD15 and CD30, not CD117.
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma: (Option 4)Typically positive for cytokeratin but not CD117.

Thus, the combination of CD117 positivity and CK/S100 negativity is characteristic of GIST.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 778, 779.

questions.text:
A child presented with fatigue easy bruising on examination liver was enlarged and platelet count was 4500/\(\mu l\). HPE showed of bone marrow is as follows:

Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Gaucher cells seen in Gaucher's disease have the appearance of signet rings with 'wrinkled tissue paper' because the nucleus is pushed to the periphery of the cells by the massive accumulation of glucocerebroside in the lysosomal system.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3254-3259.

choices.text: In Crohn's disease there is only mucosal involvement

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding inflammatory Bowel disease?
questions.solution:
The true statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease is: Crohn's disease has skip lesions.

The other statements are incorrect:

  1. While there is a genetic component to inflammatory bowel disease, it is not completely understood, and both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis have a genetic predisposition.
  2. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus, and can involve the entire thickness of the intestinal wall, not just the mucosa.
  3. Ulcerative colitis only affects the colon and rectum and typically involves only the mucosa, not the entire intestinal wall.
 

Reference : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 2469,2474-2476,2482-2484 .

questions.text:
Most common ectopic tissue found in meckel's diverticulum? 
(i) Gastric 
(ii) Colonic 
(iii) Pancreatic 
(iv) Adrenals
questions.solution:
Ectopic gastric tissue and ectopic pancreatic tissue are two of the most common types of abnormal tissue that can develop in Meckel's diverticulum. 



 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1311 .

questions.text: Identify the specimen shown below?
questions.solution:
• "Strawberry gallbladder" is a term that refers to a rare condition called cholesterolosis of the gallbladder.
  • In this condition, deposits of cholesterol and other lipids accumulate within the wall of the gallbladder, causing it to become thickened and appear speckled or dotted with yellowish-green spots, which resemble the surface of a strawberry.
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1207,1209-1211 .

questions.text: Iron is transported by which carrier protein into the enterocytes?
questions.solution:
• Iron is transported by Divalent metal transporter 1 into the enterocytes
  • By Ferroportin(at the basolateral membrane) out of enterocytes into the bloodstream. 



 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 655-657.

questions.text: A child was found to have a rectal polyp. On histopathological examination, colonic epithelium and dilated glands with mucin is seen. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
The presence of a rectal polyp in a child is likely to be a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

  • Hamartomas are benign growths that are composed of a disorganized mixture of different types of tissues.
  • The histopathology findings of dilated glands with mucin, rather than an increased number of epithelial cells further corroborate the diagnosis of hamartoma. 
  • Most juvenile polyps are less than 3 cm in diameter. They are typically pedunculated, smooth-surfaced, reddish lesions with characteristic cystic spaces. Microscopic examination shows these cysts to be dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. The remainder of the polyp is composed of lamina propria expanded by mixed inflammatory infiltrates. The muscularis mucosae may be normal or attenuated.
     


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 810.

questions.text: A patient had fever and hepatomegaly. Owl eye inclusion bodies are seen in histopathology. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• CMV-infected cells exhibit gigantism of both the entire cell and its nucleus, which typically contains a large inclusion surrounded by a clear halo (“owl’s eye”).
  • Infected cells are strikingly enlarged, often to a diameter of 40 µm, and show cellular and nuclear pleomorphism.
  • Prominent intranuclear basophilic inclusions spanning one-half of the nuclear diameter are usually set off from the nuclear membrane by a clear halo.
  • Within the cytoplasm of infected cells, smaller basophilic inclusions can also be seen.
