  • Diagnosis of CMV infection is made by demonstration of characteristic morphologic alterations in tissue sections, viral culture, rising antiviral antibody titer, and PCR-based detection of CMV DNA. Quantitative PCR based assays have revolutionized the approach to monitoring CMV infection in people after transplantation.
     


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 356.

questions.text: Most specific indicator of alcohol-induced liver dysfunction is
questions.solution:
The most specific indicator of alcohol-induced liver dysfunction among the given options is gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT). GGT is frequently used as a marker for excessive alcohol consumption in patients with alcoholic liver disease. Although present in various tissues such as the kidneys, pancreas, and liver, GGT is primarily derived from the liver and is often employed to assess hepatobiliary conditions. Chronic alcohol use induces hepatic microsomal GGT, leading to elevated levels in individuals with alcohol use disorder.

Laboratory findings in alcohol-induced liver dysfunction typically include:

AST (SGOT) and ALT (SGPT) levels not exceeding 400 IU/L.

An AST/ALT ratio greater than 1.5.

Serum bilirubin levels over 3 mg/dL.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2618 .

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies in liver sinusoids?
questions.solution:
Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages, are specialized macrophages located in the liver's sinusoidal walls. They are  responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies in liver sinusoids. 

They play a vital role in the body's immune defense by:

Phagocytosis: Kupffer cells are involved in clearing bacteria, foreign bodies, and cellular debris from the blood that enters the liver via the portal vein.
Antigen Presentation: These cells also present antigens to other immune cells, triggering a more coordinated immune response.





Other Options:

Option A: Sinusoidal Endothelial cells are the cells lining the sinusoidal capillaries, responsible for exchange of toxins and other metabolites between the blood vessels and the hepatocytes.

Option C: Ito cells are Vitamin A storing cells located in the space of Disse. They are the key player in the pathogenesis of cirrhosis as they result in production of fibrosis in case of chronic hepatocyte injury, reulting in liver cirrhosis.

Option D: Hepatocytes are the key functional unit of Liver sinusoids. They are responsible for all the metabolic processes and detoxification of drugs and toxins occuring in the liver.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 854.

questions.text: Which among the following carcinogens is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Aflatoxins (especially Aflatoxin B1) are produced by Aspergillus flavus growing on stored grains and groundnuts.

  • They cause mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene, leading to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

  • This is a well-established carcinogen linked specifically to liver cancer.

Other options:

  • Arsenic: Associated with skin cancer, lung cancer, angiosarcoma of liver, but not hepatocellular carcinoma.

  • Asbestos: Strongly linked to mesothelioma and bronchogenic carcinoma, not HCC.

  • Benzene: Associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and aplastic anemia, not liver cancer.


Risk factors for development of HCC 

References

1. Robbins Basic Pathology, 9th Edition, pages 870-871.

2. Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 713.

3. Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition, page 280.

questions.text: What is the gene mutation seen in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Hereditary hemochromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by excessive intestinal iron absorption and iron overload in various organs like the liver, heart, and pancreas.

      Pathophysiology

  • Mutated HFE protein fails to regulate hepcidin, a key iron regulatory hormone.

  • Decreased hepcidin → increased ferroportin activity → unregulated iron export from enterocytes and macrophages → systemic iron overload.

  • Iron accumulates in liver, heart, pancreas, skin, joints, and endocrine organs.

    Diagnosis

  • Serum ferritin: Increased

  • Transferrin saturation: >45%

  • Serum iron: Increased

  • Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC): Decreased or normal

  • Genetic testing: HFE mutation 

  • Liver biopsy (if diagnosis unclear or concern for cirrhosis): Shows iron-laden hepatocytes with Prussian blue staining

    Other options:

  • MRP2 protein: Mutated in Dubin-Johnson syndrome, a conjugated hyperbilirubinemia disorder.

  • PTEN: Tumor suppressor gene mutated in Cowden syndrome and some cancers.

  • ATP7B gene: Mutated in Wilson's disease, causing copper overload, not iron.


Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 10e page no 848-850,853

questions.text: What is the most typical nephropathy linked to cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Membranous glomerulonephritis

Membranous glomerulonephritis is the most typical nephropathy linked to malignancy.

In 20–30% of cases, MGN is secondary and is associated with a malignancy (solid tumors of the breast, lung, colon), infection (hepatitis B, syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis), rheumatologic disorders such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, IgG4 diseases, or drug exposure.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: An older male patient complained of eyesight blurriness. Cotton wool patches were seen on the retina during a fundus examination, and a systemic test revealed diminished peripheral sensations and decreased urine production. What result did the subsequent kidney biopsy reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion.

Above clinical scenario is Common finding in case of Diabetic Retinopathy with Cotton wool spot with involvement of kidney microvasculature. 

  • In view of Diabetic nephropathy these 3 lesions are encountered: (1) glomerular lesions; (2) renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis; and (3) pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.
  • The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.

* [Extra Edge]: Nodular Glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson Disease

  • In this disease the glomerular lesions take the form of ovoid or spherical, often laminated, PAS-positive nodules of matrix situated in the periphery of the glomerulus.
  • They lie within the mesangial core of the glomerular lobules and may be surrounded by patent peripheral capillary loops or loops that are markedly dilated.
  • The nodules often show features of mesangiolysis, defined by disruption of anchoring interactions between the capillaries and the mesangial stalks. The loss of these support structures may lead to the formation of capillary microaneurysms.
     
* Audio Explanation:
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1111.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man who had been experiencing 4 days of frothy urine arrived with facial puffiness. There may have been an acute renal damage. Direct immunofluorescence and electron microscopy images from a kidney biopsy are presented below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Membranous glomerulopathy
 
  • Membranous glomerulopathy is the most likely diagnosis. The images show immune complex deposits along the glomerular basement membrane, which is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy.
  • Membranous glomerulopathy is an autoimmune kidney disease where the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the glomerular basement membrane.
  • This leads to thickening of the membrane and impaired kidney function.
  • The presence of immune complex deposits can be confirmed through immunofluorescence staining.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text:
The image below shows the immunofluorescence staining pattern from a kidney sample taken from a 35-year-old patient who was experiencing proteinuria.
What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lupus nephritis

The most probable diagnosis is of Lupus nephritis.
 
  • Strong IgA, IgM, and C3 staining may be seen in the picture, although IgG positive staining is lesser.
  • All kinds of glomerulonephritis present in SLE, as well as positive IgA, IgM, C3, and IgG, are frequently observed (lupus nephritis). IgG and C3 positivity is present in PSGN and Goodpasture syndrome; IgM and C3 positivity is seen in FSGS.
  • It is called full house effect. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

choices.text: Glomerular basement membrane is stained with PAS
Glomerular basement membrane acts as filtration barrier
Glomerular basement membrane is involved in charge dependent filtration

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the glomerular basement membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Type III collagen is present

Type IV collagen (not the type III collagen) is the main component of the basement membrane, together with laminin.

The underlying mesenchymal cells and the overlying epithelium both contribute to the synthesis of the basement membrane, resulting in a lamellar "chicken wire" mesh (although labeled as a membrane, it is quite porous).

Therefore, the two main components are laminin and amorphous non fibrillar type IV collagen.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 900.

questions.text: Identify the most consistent feature of rapidly progressing glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crescent formation

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is characterized by a rapid decline in the GFR (GFR) of at least 50% over a short period. The main histopathologic finding is an extensive glomerular crescent formation.

* [Extra Edge]: Cresent Glomerulopathy
  • Depending on the underlying cause, the glomeruli often show focal and segmental necrosis, and variably show diffuse or focal endothelial proliferation, and mesangial proliferation.
  • Segmental glomerular necrosis and distinctive crescents adjacent to glomerular segments uninvolved by inflammatory or proliferative changes is the feature most typical of pauci-immune RPGN.
  • Crescents are formed by proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space.
  • Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. The crescents may obliterate the urinary space and compress the glomerular tuft. Fibrin strands are frequently prominent between the cellular layers in the crescents


Fig: Cresent Glomerulonephritis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 910.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a kidney transplant is suffering with decreased urine production. The microscopic image from a urinalysis is displayed below. Identify the structure that has an arrow on it:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyaline casts

The structure marked in the above diagram is a Hyaline cast.

It appears to be a Waxy cast, but Hyaline cast is the best response because it develops from a hyaline cast.

* [Extra Edge]: Hyaline Casts

  • Normal: Up to 5 casts/low-power field
  • Associations: Normal finding in concentrated urine, fever, exercise, diuretics, pyelonephritis, chronic renal disease
Online Reference:
Queremel Milani DA, Jialal I. Urinalysis. [Updated 2023 May 1]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557685/

questions.text: A kidney specimen stained with FITC for IgG is shown below. What does this hint at?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Goodpasture’s syndrome

The immunofluorescence above is showing Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane seen in  Goodpasture’s syndrome.

  • In Membranous glomerulonephritis , Granular IgG (Against GBM) deposits are seen.
  • In Buerger’s disease there is IgA deposition.
  • SLE may have a picture similar to Membranous Glomerulonephritis i.e. Granular IgG immune complexes deposits, but this is not characteristic.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: A kidney specimen that was removed is displayed below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flea-bitten kidney of malignant hypertension
 
  • The image shows a kidney with multiple small hemorrhages, resembling a "flea-bitten" appearance.
  • This finding is characteristic of malignant hypertension, where severe hypertension causes damage to the renal blood vessels leading to hemorrhages.
* Other options:
 
  • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents with glomerular changes such as glomerular hypercellularity and crescent formation, which are not observed in this image.
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis in the glomeruli, which is not seen in this image.
  • Amyloidosis would show amyloid deposits within the kidney, which are not evident in this image.

* [Extra Edge]: Nephritic syndromes


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2091.

questions.text: Where are c-anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Wegener's Granulomatosis 
 
  • Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are auto antibodies, mainly of the IgG type, which are targeted against antigens in the cytoplasm of neutrophil granulocytes and monocytes and detected through a blood test.
  • They are associated with systemic vasculitis, known as ANCA-associated vasculitis and the antigen specifically targeted is proteinase.
  • A c-ANCA positive test result can indicate Wegener's granulomatosis.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: Edema, oliguria, and foamy urine are symptoms that a 10-year-old child exhibits. He has never before been subject to comparable complaints. Examining his urine revealed that it contained 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs or WBCs, and no casts. He had a blood albumin level of 2.5 g/L and a creatinine level of 0.5 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Minimal change disease
 
  • The symptoms and laboratory findings described in the question are characteristic of minimal change disease (MCD), which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • MCD is characterized by diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy, which leads to increased permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier and proteinuria.

Fig: Minimal Change Disorder

* Other options:
  • IgA nephropathy is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the glomeruli, typically presenting with hematuria.
  • Acute interstitial nephritis is an inflammatory condition involving the renal interstitium and is usually associated with drug hypersensitivity or infections.
  • Membranous nephropathy is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposition.
* [Extra Edge]: Nephritic syndromes



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 914.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in markers of acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Micro RNA-122

  • MicroRNA-122 is not a marker of acute kidney injury.
  • Recent studies have shown that aberrant regulation of miR-122 is a key factor contributing to the development of HCC.

* Markers of Acute kidney injury include:



Online Reference:
Vaidya VS, Ferguson MA, Bonventre JV. Biomarkers of acute kidney injury. Annu Rev Pharmacol Toxicol. 2008;48:463-93. doi: 10.1146/annurev.pharmtox.48.113006.094615. PMID: 17937594; PMCID: PMC2742480.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient initially experiences brief vision occlusion for two to three days before experiencing an abrupt loss of vision. Which of the following tests would be most effective in assessing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Serum creatinine levels

Serum creatinine levels would be the best choice as DM can lead to both retinopathy and nephropathy.

Elevated ACE Levels Indicate Diabetic Nephropathy Progression or Companied Retina Impaired.

It has been widely accepted that ACR is a frequently used laboratory index to diagnose DN and distinguish early-stage (30 mg/g < ACR < 300mg/g) and advanced-stage (ACR > 300 mg/g) DN. Based on ACR levels, DN patients were divided into four subgroups of early-stage DN, early-stage DN combined with DR, advanced-stage DN, and advanced-stage DN patients DR.
New studies shows correlation with s homocysteine and DR.
Online Reference:
Huang K, Liang Y, Wang K, Ma Y, Wu J, Luo H, Yi B. Elevated ACE Levels Indicate Diabetic Nephropathy Progression or Companied Retina Impaired. Front Clin Diabetes Healthc. 2022 May 12;3:831128. doi: 10.3389/fcdhc.2022.831128. PMID: 36992775; PMCID: PMC10012155.

questions.text: Renal cell cancer with a chromophobe form is connected to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Monosomy of 1 and Y (-1, -Y)
 
  • Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is associated with specific chromosomal losses, particularly monosomy of chromosomes 1 and Y (-1, -Y). Monosomy refers to the loss of one copy of a particular chromosome in a cell.
  • These genetic abnormalities are frequently detected in chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and can be helpful in its diagnosis.
  • Other renal cell carcinoma subtypes, such as clear cell carcinoma and papillary carcinoma, have distinct chromosomal alterations.
  • Chromophobe renal carcinoma is made up of pale eosinophilic cells, often with a perinuclear halo, arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.
Other options: -
VHL - Clear cell cancer 
Trisomy 7/17- Papillary cell cancer 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 950.

questions.text: Electron microscopy is used to diagnose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alport's syndrome
 
  • Electron microscopy is used to diagnose Alport's syndrome, a hereditary disorder affecting the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Alport's syndrome is characterized by the presence of thinning, splitting, and lamellation of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) when examined under an electron microscope.
  • These ultrastructural changes in the GBM result from mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen, a major component of the GBM.
  • The characteristic electron microscopy findings help differentiate Alport's syndrome from other forms of glomerulonephritis.
* [Extra Edge]: Electron microscopy of Alport syndrome

Early Alport or carriers of Alport show diffuse thinning of GBMs. In established Alport, there are irregular thin and thickened areas with splintered and irregular multi-laminated appearance of the lamina densa, with short stubs of fibrils at right angles to the GBM, irregular lucent areas interspersed with thickened areas of the lamina densa, resulting in a so-called basket-weave pattern. There are no immune complexes, and foot processes, particularly in sclerosed glomeruli, may show effacement.


Fig: lamellated and basket-weave appearance (electron microscopy)

* Vasculitis Types:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 922.

questions.text: Which of these causes hypercoagulation in nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Loss of Antithrombin III
 
  • Nephrotic syndrome is associated with the loss of antithrombin III, a natural anticoagulant. Antithrombin III inhibits several coagulation factors, including thrombin (factor IIa) and factors IXa, Xa, XIa, and XIIa.
  • The urinary loss of antithrombin III in nephrotic syndrome contributes to a prothrombotic state, increasing the risk of hypercoagulability and thrombotic events.
  • Other changes in the coagulation system, such as decreased levels of protein C and protein S, can also contribute to the hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 911.

choices.text: Defect in thick ascending limb of loop of henle

questions.text: Defect is present in Bartter syndrome in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Defect in thick ascending limb of loop of Henle
 
  • Bartter syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by defects in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidney.
  • The defect in Bartter syndrome leads to impaired reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and potassium, resulting in electrolyte imbalances and a salt-wasting phenotype.
  • This defect is primarily located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which plays a critical role in sodium reabsorption.
  • There are different types of Bartter syndrome, each associated with specific genetic mutations affecting various ion channels and transporters in the thick ascending limb.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2293.

questions.text: Name the disease which is the pathognomonic of effacement of foot processes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Minimal change disease

  • Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is a type of nephrotic syndrome, primarily seen in children aged 2 to 6 years, and is caused by disruptions in podocyte function.
  • It is typically suspected clinically, but diagnosed in an electron microscope, in which diffuse effacement of the foot processes of the podocytes is observed.
  • Light microscopy reveals an apparently normal glomerulus, while immunofluorescence shows no g or complement deposits.
  • MCD responds well to corticosteroids and is also known as Lipoid Nephrosis. In adults, it may be associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma.
* [Extra Edge]: effacement of foot processes
 
  • The principal lesion is in the visceral epithelial cells, which show a uniform and diffuse effacement of foot processes, these being reduced to a rim of cytoplasm with loss of recognizable intervening slit diaphragms.
  • This change, often incorrectly termed “fusion” of foot processes, actually represents simplification of the epithelial cell architecture with flattening, retraction, and swelling of foot processes.
  • Foot process effacement is also present in other proteinuric states (e.g., membranous glomerulopathy, diabetic nephropathy); it is only when effacement is associated with normal glomeruli by light microscopy that the diagnosis of minimal change disease can be made.
  • The visceral epithelial changes are completely reversible after corticosteroid therapy, concomitant with remission of the proteinuria.

Fig: Ultrastructural characteristics of minimal change disease include effacement of foot processes

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 915.

choices.text: Microscopy shows fibrinoid necrosis in large arteries

questions.text: Pick the correct assumption about PAN:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 30% patients are HBSAg positive
 
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries.
  • This causes damage to the walls of those arteries and can lead to decreased blood flow, tissue necrosis, and organ damage.
  • PAN is not typically associated with ANCA (an autoantibody found in other vasculitides such as Wegener's granulomatosis), and approximately 30% of individuals with PAN can have HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen)-HBsAb (hepatitis B surface antibody) complexes.
  • Microscopically, PAN involves transmural inflammation and fibrous thickening, as well as segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation and fibrinoid necrosis. This occurs simultaneously in all stages of the disease.
  • Clinically, PAN is commonly found in individuals between the ages of 20 and 40. It can cause hypertension due to renal artery involvement, peripheral neuritis, abdominal pain, and bloody stools. Notably, PAN can also result in severe skin lesions and palpable nodes.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2810.

questions.text: An unconscious patient with a history of not eating for more than two days is brought to the emergency room. Which of the following tests will be positive for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) only iii
 
  • In the given question, patient presents with history of starvation for more than 2 days which can result in production of ketone bodies.
  • Test for ketone bodies is Rothera’s test.
  • Positive test gives a purple ring. Positive in case of acetone and acetoacetate. Negative in case of Beta hydroxy Butyrate.

1st image - Benedict test - shows glucose in urine, which is absent in starvation, 2ns image - Heat and acetic acid test for proteins. 

Online Reference: Comstock JP, Garber AJ. Ketonuria. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 140. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK247/

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in- 
 A. HIV
 B. SLE
 C. Hepatitis B
 D. CLL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) All of the above

MPGN is seen in all of the given conditions. MPGN is of two types:

Type 1: Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
Type 2: Secondary MPGN arising in cases of:
  • i. SLE
  • ii. Endocarditis
  • iv. Infected ventriculoatrial shunts
  • v. Chronic visceral abscesses
  • vi. HIV, Hep B and C infection
  • vii. Schistosomiasis
  • viii. α1-Antitrypsin deficiency
  • ix. Malignant diseases (lymphoid tumors like CLL)
Note: In HIV, FSGS is more common but even MPGN can occur.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2341.

questions.text: What is depicted in the below image concerning urinary crystals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Struvite

The given image is of Struvite crystals (Coffin Lid shaped)
They are typically seen in UTI caused by urease-producing organisms (E.g. Proteus)

*[Extra Edge]:
  • Struvite stones, also known as infection stones or triple phosphate stones, form only when the upper urinary tract is infected with urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, or Providencia species.
  • Urease produced by these bacteria hydrolyzes urea and may elevate the urine pH to a supraphysiologic level (>8.0). Struvite stones may grow quickly and fill the renal pelvis (staghorn calculi).


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2373.

questions.text: Which urinary crystals are visible in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Calcium oxalate

Calcium oxalate crystals are shown (Envelop Shaped)



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2372.

questions.text: The mother says that her 10-year-old son is leaking frothy urine and has generalized edema. The child has 238 mg/dl of serum cholesterol. On analyzing urine: Protein is 3+. Which medical diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Nephrotic syndrome
 
  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by oedema, low serum albumin levels, and proteinuria in the nephrotic range along with hypercholesteremia (as given in the clinical stem of the question). 
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria is defined as the presence of 2 grams of protein per gram of urine creatinine on a single spot urine collection or the loss of 3 grams or more of protein from the body every day.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 911.

questions.text: In idiopathic steroid resistance nephrotic syndrome (SRNS), what is the most frequent gene deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) NPHS-2
 
  • The most common gene defect in idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) is NPHS-2 (which codes for podocin) Mutations in NPHS2 result in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Affected children usually show pathologic features of FSGS.
  • A distinctive pattern of autosomal recessive FSGS results from mutations in the NPHS2 gene, which maps to chromosome 1q25–q31 and encodes the protein product podocin. Podocin has also been localized to the slit diaphragm. Mutations in NPHS2 result in a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset.
  • Mutations in the gene encoding the podocyte actin-binding protein α-actinin 4 underlie some cases of autosomal dominant FSGS, which can be insidious in onset but has a high rate of progression to renal insufficiency

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 916.

questions.text:
A individual with reflux nephropathy, as determined by radiology, develops proteinuria of the nephritic range. Which of the following would most likely
describe the patient's histology findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
 
  • Most likely histologic findings in the patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy and nephritic range proteinuria is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
  • The cause of nephrotic syndrome is characterized by the presence of focal (only some glomeruli are affected) and segmental (only a part of the glomerulus is affected) sclerosis of the glomeruli.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: Fibrinoid necrosis and an onion peel appearance are both found in a kidney specimen. The most likely pathology will be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis

Most probable pathology in specimen of kidney with fibrinoid necrosis and onion peel appearance is hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.
    • Fibrinoid necrosis and
    • Onion peel appearance is characteristic of hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.


Fig: Hyperplastic arteriolitis (onion-skin lesion)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 938.

questions.text: Mutations in the COL4A5 chain are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Alport's syndrome

Mutation in COL4A5 chain is seen in Alport's syndrome.
* Features seen in Alport's syndrome are due to abnormal

  • alpha4(COL4A4)

  • alpha5(COL4A5)

  • chain of type 4 collagen
  • alpha3(COL4A3)
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 922.

questions.text: The following cannot cause the renal pathology is given in the figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diabetes mellitus
 
  • Flea-bitten appearance of the kidney refers to multiple petechial hemorrhages on the renal surface.
  • Conditions associated with this pathology:
    • Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury due to platelet aggregation and microthrombi formation in renal microvasculature.
    • Malignant hypertension: Severe hypertension leading to arteriolar damage and fibrinoid necrosis in renal arterioles.
    • Infective endocarditis: Infection of heart valves leading to embolic infarctions in the kidney.
  • Diabetes mellitus does not typically cause the flea-bitten appearance of the kidney.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text: The type of urinary cast that is positive in urine in a patient of renal parenchymal disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fine granular cast
 
  • Urinary casts are cylindrical structures formed within the renal tubules and are composed of different materials.
  • In renal parenchymal disease, such as glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis, the casts seen in the urine can provide diagnostic clues.
  • Fine granular casts are composed of finely granular material and can be seen in various conditions, including renal parenchymal disease.
* Other options:
  • Coarse granular casts are formed by the precipitation of cellular debris and are typically seen in renal tubular injury.
  • Hyaline casts are transparent and composed of protein and can be found in both normal and pathological conditions.
  • Epithelial casts contain desquamated renal tubular epithelial cells and can indicate severe tubular injury.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2304.

questions.text: Which of these is least likely associated with Dense deposit renal disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lipodystrophy
 
  • Dense deposit renal disease (also known as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type II) is a rare form of kidney disease characterized by the deposition of abnormal material in the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Dense deposit renal disease is most commonly associated with complement dysregulation.
  • Conditions associated with Dense deposit renal disease:
    • HBV infection: Hepatitis B virus infection can trigger immune complex deposition and complement activation, leading to Dense deposit renal disease.
    • SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus): Autoimmune disease characterized by immune complex formation and glomerular involvement.
    • Cryoglobulinemia: Presence of cryoglobulins (abnormal proteins) in the blood, which can deposit in the kidneys.
  • Lipodystrophy is a disorder characterized by the loss of adipose tissue and is not typically associated with Dense deposit renal disease.
  • Out of the given options, Lipodystrophy is least likely associated with Dense deposit renal disease. Lipodystrophy is a rare disorder that affects the body's ability to produce and store fat. It is not typically associated with kidney disease, including Dense deposit disease. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2341.

choices.text: Obliteration & fusion of foot processes of podocytes

questions.text: Light microscopy finding in membranous glomerulonephritis-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Diffuse capillary wall thickening
 
  • Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN) is a type of glomerular disease characterized by the immune complex deposition in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • On light microscopy, membranous glomerulonephritis is characterized by Uniform thickening of the basement membrane along the peripheral capillary loops is seen by light microscopy on renal biopsy; this thickening needs to be distinguished from that seen in diabetes and amyloidosis.
  • The subepithelial spikes appear as irregular, finger-like projections extending into the capillary lumen when viewed under electron microscopy.
  • These spikes are formed by the accumulation of immune complexes, predominantly IgG and complement C3, along the outer aspect of the GBM.
  • These spikes can cause thickening and distortion of the GBM, leading to impaired filtration and the development of nephrotic syndrome.

Fig: The light microscopic appearance of membranous nephropathy in which the capillary loops are thickened and prominent, but the cellularity is not expected to be increased.

* Other options:
 
  • Obliteration and fusion of foot processes of podocytes are characteristic findings in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).
  • Subepithelial Spikes are seen in MGN but in Electron Microscopy.
  • Subendothelial hump is observed in post-infectious glomerulonephritis (PIGN).


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chronic reflux disease
 
  • Chronic pyelonephritis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the renal parenchyma and renal pelvis, usually caused by recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • The most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis is chronic reflux disease, also known as vesicoureteral reflux.
  • In vesicoureteral reflux, there is abnormal retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and kidneys during micturition.
  • This condition predisposes the kidneys to recurrent UTIs, which can lead to chronic inflammation and scarring of the renal tissue.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: Cystoscopic evaluation of a post-transplant patient revealed multiple soft, yellowish raised plaque in the urinary bladder mucosa. A histopathological examination of the plaque is shown in the image below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow white plaques with histopathology showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia. 

It is an example of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis due to acquired defects in phagocyte function. This results in large foamy macrophages with abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products. This coupled with intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes form laminated basophilic concretions knows as Michaelis Gutmann bodies. 

They are pathognomonic of malakoplakia. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 955-957.

choices.text: It is the least common type of RCC

questions.text: Which of the following is true about clear cell renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option 1-  It is mostly sporadic is the correct answer.

Other options
  • Option(2)Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is commonly associated with genetic alterations, including the deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3 (3p) and the loss of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene.
  • Option (3)Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma, not the least common. 
  • Option (4) Clear cell renal cell carcinoma originates from the cells of the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT) of the kidney, not the distal convoluted tubules (DCT).

    

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 948-951 .

questions.text: 8-year-old child presented with cola-coloured urine for 4 days and facial puffiness for 2 days. Creatinine was initially 1.3. She had a history of pyoderma 2 weeks back. What is the electron microscopic finding in this case?
questions.solution:
This describes a child with a history of recent pyoderma infection which may be caused by Streptococcus.
  • Cola-colored urine or smoky brown urine indicates gross hematuria likely indicating the child has acute glomerulonephritis (GN).
  • A provisional diagnosis of post-streptococcal GN can be made, which is the most common cause of acute GN in India.
  • Subepithelial deposits (humps) are seen on EM in PSGN.
 
LM: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG C3 along the glomerular basement Membrane and mesangium.
EM: primarily subepithelial humps are seen. subendothelial deposits can seen in early disease stages.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 908.

questions.text: An elderly male patient is Hepatitis B positive. On kidney biopsy, a characteristic spike and dome pattern is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient who has chronic Hepatitis B is at risk of developing membranous nephropathy.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed on HPE which reveals the characteristic spike and dome pattern of the disease.
  • In most cases of secondary membranous nephropathy, these autoantibodies are absent, with rare reports of autoantibodies to PLA2R in membranous glomerulopathy associated with hepatitis B, cancer, and sarcoidosis.
  • Circulating deposits and glomerular deposits of these autoantibodies have correlated with the likelihood of a spontaneous remission, severity of IMN, and the response to therapy. Eighty percent of patients with MGN present with nephrotic syndrome and nonselective proteinuria.




Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2343.

choices.text: Hyperacute rejection is mediated by Preformed Antibodies specific for antigens
Acute Rejection is mediated by B cells
Except for Identical twins, Immunosuppresive therapy is indicated in all kidney transplant patients
Chronic rejection is an indolent form of graft damage leading to progressive loss of graft function

questions.text: Which of the statements given below is false?
questions.solution:
• Second statement is wrong statement- Hyperacute rejection is mediatedby T cells and antibodies that are activated by alloantigens in the graft
  • Except for Identical twins, Immunosuppresive therapy is indicated in all kidney transplant patients
  •  Chronic rejection is an indolent form of graft damage leading to progressive loss of graft function
  • In kidney transplant, there is substantial benefit if alll the polymorphic HLA alleles are matched.
  • HLA matching is not done for transplants of liver, heart and lungs.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 235-237.

questions.text: Following urine microscopy and examination, a child is found to have hematuria and RBC casts in the urine. What is the probable cause for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of nephritic syndrome, such as hematuria and red cell casts, observed in this child are most likely indicative of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

PSGN is characterized by a sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency, typically following a throat infection caused by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. It can also develop after a streptococcal skin infection or pyoderma.

Patients usually experience an acute nephritic syndrome within:
1 to 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis
3 to 6 weeks following streptococcal pyoderma

The underlying pathogenesis involves the formation of circulating antibodies in response to streptococcal antigens, which then react with normal glomerular antigens. Additionally, complement activation occurs due to the deposition of streptococcal antigens, resulting in immunologic injury to the glomeruli.

Key points: 
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). 

  • Most common glomerulonephritis in children

  • Follows throat or skin infection with nephritogenic Group A β-hemolytic streptococci

  • Typical presentation:

    • Hematuria ("cola-colored urine")

    • RBC casts

    • Periorbital edema, hypertension

      Incorrect Options 

    • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN)

      • Causes hematuria + proteinuria, sometimes nephrotic-nephritic picture.

      • RBC casts possible but classic pediatric cause with RBC casts is PSGN, not MPGN.

    • Minimal change disease

      • Presents with nephrotic syndrome (massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema).

      • Urine: Fatty casts, not RBC casts.

    • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

      • Also causes nephrotic syndrome (proteinuria >> hematuria).

      • Hematuria may occur, but RBC casts are not typical.

questions.text: Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein, also called Uromodulin, is a key component of the organic matrix of renal casts. It is the most abundant protein in normal urine, produced in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
  • .Uromodulin is secreted at a rate of 20 to 100 mg/day and is not expressed by the macula densa or the downstream distal convoluted tubule (DCT).
  • Plays a role in the formation of renal casts and modulating innate immunity and inflammation during kidney injury.
  • The UMOD gene encodes this protein 
  • UMOD Gene mutations -  Medullary cystic kidney disease (MCKD II) and Familial juvenile hyperuricemic nephropathy(aka autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease)

Other options:

  • Bence-Jones proteins: Light chains of immunoglobulins, seen in multiple myeloma.

  • Curschmann spirals: Mucus plugs in sputum of bronchial asthma.

  • Mural thrombi: Thrombi adherent to the endocardium or large vessels, not related to Tamm-Horsfall protein.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with complaints of hematuria, hypertension, and facial puffiness for 3 days. History reveals he had a throat infection 2 weeks back. Urine examination shows positivity for albumin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child presents with acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) features:

  • Hematuria, hypertension, and facial puffiness (edema)

  • History of sore throat 2 weeks ago (latent period for PSGN after streptococcal pharyngitis)

  • Urine with albumin → mild proteinuria

Causative organism:

  • Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GABHS), which can cause pharyngitis or skin infection (impetigo), and trigger an immune-mediated glomerular injury.

Other options:

  • Group B beta-hemolytic streptococci: Causes neonatal infections, not post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

  • Staphylococcus aureus: Can cause acute bacterial infections, rarely associated with PSGN.

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis: Mostly opportunistic, not linked to PSGN.


Reference

1.Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page no: 2723, 2724
2.Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition - Page no: 908-909
3. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page no: 1178, 1181, 1184,1188, 1195

questions.text:
An adnexal tumour is plaguing a 35-year-old woman. LDH was increased, CA199 was normal, CA125 was just slightly elevated. The gross and microscopic images of the tumour after it was removed are shown below. Which diagnosis is most likely?

1 .Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
2. Dysgerminoma
3. Teratoma
4. Choriocarcinoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dysgerminoma
 
  • LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) is an enzyme that can be elevated in certain tumors, including dysgerminoma.
  • CA-19-9 and CA-125 are tumor markers that are typically elevated in different types of ovarian tumors, but in this case, they are within the normal range or only slightly elevated, making dysgerminoma more likely.
  • Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that commonly occurs in young women and has specific histological features, as shown in the images.
* Tumor Markers:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1024.

questions.text: What is the tumor marker for seminoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PLAP

Tumor marker for seminoma is PLAP

Tumor marker for seminoma is PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase) but beta-HCG is also increased in 5-10% of pure seminoma, as they contain syncytiotrophoblast-like giant cells.

Other tumor markers for testicular tumors are-

  • alpha feto protein-YOLK sac and embryonal carcinoma.
  • LDH-marker for bulk disease
  • GGT (Gamma glutamyl transpeptidase)-seminoma testis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 970.

questions.text: What condition does the picture represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Seminoma

Gross morphology shows pale yellow color enlarged testis with no focal regions of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • The picture shows a histological image of seminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the testis.
  • Pathologically, it is characterized by uniform tumor cells with large round or polygonal shape, clear cytoplasm, and central prominent nucleoli.
* Other options:
  • Germ cell differentiate tumor is a broad term that encompasses various types of testicular tumors, including seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, teratoma, and choriocarcinoma.
  • Non-seminoma refers to testicular tumors that are not pure seminomas, usually comprising a mixture of different germ cell tumor types.
  • Teratoma is a type of germ cell tumor that contains differentiated tissues derived from multiple germ layers.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 970.

questions.text: Where is ovarian clear cell carcinoma seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Epithelial tumor

* Epithelial tumors of ovary—

  • —Serous 
  • —Mucinous
  • —Endometrioid 
  • —Clear cell 
  • —Brenner 
  • —Undifferentiated.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female was diagnosed with a granulosa cell tumour of the ovary. Which of the following biomarkers would be most useful for diagnosis and follow-up with the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inhibin
 
  • Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumors.
  • This biomarker may be useful for identifying granulosa and other sex cord-stromal tumors, and for monitoring patients being treated for these neoplasms.
  • Microscopy: Coffee bean nucleus and Call-Exner bodies.
  • MC symptoms: Menometrorrhagia and post-menopausal bleeding.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1026.

questions.text: Which organ has carcinomas that have the highest serum levels of acid phosphatase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Prostate
 
  • Carcinomas of the prostate have the highest serum levels of acid phosphatase among the listed options.
  • Acid phosphatase is an enzyme that is normally present in various tissues, including the prostate gland.
  • In prostate cancer, cancer cells disrupt the normal architecture of the prostate, leading to the release of elevated levels of acid phosphatase into the bloodstream.
  • Elevated serum levels of acid phosphatase are commonly used as a marker of metastatic prostate cancer and can be used to monitor treatment response.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 977.

questions.text: A young male presented with infertility. Semen analysis showed azoospermia. Testicular biospy was done, the image of which is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy showing presence of only Sertoli cells, thickening of tubular basement with absence of germ cells is characteristic of Sertoli only cell syndrome. 

Option C- Testicular atrophy is characterized by thickening of basement membrane with absence of spermatids and germ cells. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 974.
Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 241, 242.

questions.text:
Match the following 
A. Teratoma (i) Lymphocytic infiltrate
B. Dysgerminoma (ii) Neuroepithelium, hair, cartilage present
C. Yolk sac tumor (iii) Cell Exner bodies
D. Granulosa cell tumor (iv) Schiller duval bodies
questions.solution:
• Cell Exner bodies are characteristic histological findings seen in granulosa cell tumors (GCTs) of the ovary. These bodies are small, eosinophilic, and round structures found within the tumor cells. They are believed to represent accumulations of fluid-filled spaces or secretory material within the tumor.


 
  • Schiller-Duval bodies are small, spherical structures found in the endodermal sinus cells of germ cell tumors(yolk sac tumors). These structures are formed by a central capillary surrounded by layers of tumor cells arranged in a rosette-like pattern. The appearance of these structures is often described as resembling a glomerulus, a small cluster of blood vessels found in the kidney.


 
  • Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. As a result, teratomas exhibit a wide range of histopathological features and can contain different types of tissue, including elements such as skin, hair, teeth, cartilage, muscle, bone, and nervous tissue.


 
  • Dysgerminomas are composed of sheets or nests of large, round cells with well-defined cell borders. The cells have abundant clear or eosinophilic cytoplasm. They often show a prominent lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor tissue. The lymphocytes can surround the tumor cells or infiltrate between them.



 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1024,1025,1026,1028 .

questions.text: Ovarian tumor histopathology is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image depicts Schiller-Duval bodies found in Yolk sac tumors. 
  • Schiller-Duval bodies are small, spherical structures found in the endodermal sinus cells of germ cell tumors such as yolk sac tumors. These structures are formed by a central capillary surrounded by layers of tumor cells arranged in a rosette-like pattern. The appearance of these structures is often described as resembling a glomerulus, a small cluster of blood vessels found in the kidney. 
  • Schiller-Duval bodies are a diagnostic hallmark of yolk sac tumors and are usually identified on histological examination of biopsy specimens. 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1024,1025,1026,1028 .

questions.text:
On investigation for infertility in a couple, the male partner was found to have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following findings are true in this condition? 
(i) Azoospermia/ Severe oligospermia 
(ii) Low LH, Low FSH 
(iii) Low LH, High FSH 
(iv) Low testosterone 
(v) Low prolactin levels
questions.solution:
The correct findings in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism are:
(i) Azoospermia/Severe oligospermia
(ii) Low LH, Low FSH, and 
(iv) Low testosterone.

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is characterized by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) in the blood. These hormones are essential for stimulating the production of testosterone ---> low levels would result in low testosterone and later low sperm count. 

 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 463,381 .

questions.text: The following biopsy is that of male after Orchidectomy. The specimen shows Reinke Crystaloids. Identify the tumour.?
questions.solution:
Reinke Crystals are seen in leydig cells and are seen in Leydig cell tumors.
They are made of Calretinin.
Yolk sac Tumors- Schiller Duval Bodies.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page. No- 974.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common testicular tumor?
questions.solution:
Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour. In about 15% of cases, serum HCG levels are raised as these seminomas contain
syncytiotrophoblasts. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels are also measured to assess tumour burden. They are bulky, homogenous, pale, and well-circumscribed masses that do not show any haemorrhage or necrosis. Ref -Robbins and cotran 10th edition page 970

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman was diagnosed with a large tumor in the right ovary and histopathology shows it has origin from all three germ layers. Which of the following is the most likely tumor she is having?
questions.solution:
The tumor described is of ovarian origin and shows components from all three germ layers:

  • Ectoderm (e.g. skin, hair, brain tissue)

  • Mesoderm (e.g. muscle, fat, bone)

  • Endoderm (e.g. gut, respiratory epithelium)

Such a combination is characteristic of a teratoma, which arises from totipotent germ cells. These tumors can differentiate into a variety of tissues.


        Types of Teratoma:

  • Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst):
    Benign, most common ovarian tumor in women of reproductive age. Usually contains well-differentiated structures like hair, sebaceous material, teeth.

  • Immature teratoma:
    Malignant, occurs in younger patients, and contains immature or embryonal tissue.

    Other options:

  • Thecoma:
    A benign sex cord–stromal tumor that produces estrogen. Occurs in older women. Not composed of all three germ layers.

  • Dysgerminoma:
    A malignant germ cell tumor. Composed of large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm. No formation of differentiated tissue from three germ layers.

  • Theca lutein cyst:
    A functional ovarian cyst caused by elevated hCG levels. Not a neoplasm. Does not show tissues from different germ layers.


Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 266-267

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling. Investigations for testicular tumours revealed that LDH was raised but AFP was within normal limits. Following orchidectomy, the following histological picture was observed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A fried egg appearance on histopathology (as shown in image) is characteristically seen in seminoma. It describes tumor cells with:

  • Clear cytoplasm

  • Prominent central nuclei

  • Arranged in sheets or lobules

  • Infiltrated by lymphocytes

This histological appearance, along with:

  • Raised LDH

  • Normal AFP

  • Scrotal mass in a middle-aged male

strongly supports the diagnosis of seminoma.

Other options: 

  • Yolk Sac Tumor:
    This tumor is most common in children and is characterized by elevated AFP levels and the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies on histology. It does not show a fried egg appearance.

  • Embryonal Carcinoma:
    A highly malignant tumor seen in young adults, it typically shows pleomorphic cells with necrosis and hemorrhage. Both AFP and hCG are usually elevated, and the histology lacks the uniform fried egg appearance.

  • Teratoma:
    This tumor contains a mix of mature or immature tissues from different germ layers (e.g., cartilage, epithelium, neural tissue). Tumor markers are not typically elevated, and histology varies widely depending on the tissues present—it does not show fried egg cells.


Reference:Robin's basic pathology 9th edition page no 976

questions.text: All of the following are components of Meigs syndrome except__.
questions.solution:
Components of Meigs syndrome: 
 
Feature Description
Ovarian fibroma Most commonly associated tumor (benign stromal)
Ascites Peritoneal fluid accumulation
Right-sided hydrothorax Pleural effusion, typically right-sided
 

  • These findings resolve after tumor removal.

  • Occurs typically in postmenopausal women.

  • Meigs syndrome is always associated with benign tumors, especially fibroma.

    Diagnosis

  • Imaging shows solid ovarian mass, ascites, and pleural effusion.

  • Pleural fluid is transudate and cytology is negative for malignant cells.

  • Serum tumor markers (e.g. CA-125) may be mildly elevated, but no evidence of malignancy.

    Management

  • Surgical removal of the tumor leads to complete resolution of ascites and pleural effusion.

  • No need for chemotherapy or radiotherapy as the tumor is benign.

  • Dysgerminoma is a malignant germ cell tumor, not a component of Meigs syndrome.

  • It may present with abdominal mass and elevated LDH, but not with the classic triad of Meigs.


Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 1033

questions.text: The Pap smear of a 45-year-old woman with a left ovarian tumour in her late menstrual phase squamous cells is shown below. What is the tumor's most likely histology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Granulosa cell tumor
 
  • The image shows clusters of cells resembling granulosa cells (Carl Exner body), which are characteristic of a granulosa cell tumor of the ovary.
  • Serous papillary carcinoma typically shows papillary structures and atypical glandular cells. Mucinous adenocarcinoma would show mucin-producing glandular cells.
  • Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that typically occurs in younger women and is not consistent with the histology seen in the image.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1026.

questions.text: A woman aged 35 has lumps in the upper outer quadrant of breast. Histopathology suggests cells in mucin with faint nuclei:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Colloidal carcinoma

  • Colloid carcinoma of the breast is a rare type of breast cancer that typically affects postmenopausal women.
  • On gross examination it presents as a well circumscribed, crepitant, currant jelly-like mass.
  • Microscopically, it is composed of small clusters of tumor cells that appear to be 'floating in a sea of mucin'. These tumor cells form solid/acinous/micropapillary structures, and the mucin is of an acid/neutral type.
  • Immunohistochemistry reveals the presence of MUC2, WT1, and estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR), but c-erbB-2 is negative. It is estimated that 25-50% of cases have an endocrine differentiation.
  • Pure mucinous carcinomas rarely metastasize, occurring in only 2-4% of cases; thus, the diagnosis is based on the presence of more than 50% extracellular mucin.
Online Reference:
Limaiem F, Ahmad F. Mucinous Breast Carcinoma. [Updated 2023 Feb 12]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538334/

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for a BIRADS-V lesion?
questions.solution:
ER positivity is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer.
  • High Ki-67 indicates a poor prognosis. 
  • p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, which on mutation acts as an oncogene. p53 positivity is associated with highly malignant breast cancers and has poor survival. 
  • The mutations in BRCA1 gene account for up to 40% of familial breast cancers. These tumors are high-grade, hormone receptor-negative, and aneuploid and do not have a good prognosis.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 822.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman underwent right hemithyroidectomy due to what appears to be a long-standing nodule in the right lobe measuring 2 cm by 2 cm. Histopathological evidence points to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Papillary carcinoma
 

  • Nuclear clearing causing the Orphan Annie eye appearance in the histopathology image - empty-looking nuclei - this points towards Papillary Carcinoma. 
  • Its called Orphan Annie eye due to its resemblance to the eyes of an American comic character "Orhan Annie"


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1088.

questions.text: Which form of thyroid cancer exhibits lymphatic spread the most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Papillary carcinoma
 
  • Among the given thyroid malignancies Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma is the one the spreads via the lymphatic route.
  • PTC may be multifocal and invade locally within the thyroid gland as well as through the thyroid capsule and into adjacent structures in the neck.
  • It has a propensity to spread via the lymphatic system but can metastasize hematogenous as well, particularly to bone and lung.
  • Because of the relatively slow growth of the tumor, a significant burden of pulmonary metastases may accumulate, sometimes with remarkably few symptoms.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1088.

questions.text: How can a mediastinal mass be distinguished from a thymoma or an ALL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cytokeratin

Cytokeratin is an epithelial cell marker, present in thymoma and absent in lymphoma.
 
  • Since solid tumor cells frequently include intermediate filaments distinctive of their cell of origin, antibodies specific to intermediate filaments have shown to be of great utility in such circumstances.
  • An epithelial origin (carcinoma) is indicated by the presence of cytokeratins, which can be detected by immunohistochemistry, whereas desmin is only present in tumors that have muscle cell origins.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 632.

questions.text: Male patient, age 25, presents with a generalised thyroid enlargement in case. Intense lymphocytic  infiltration and Hurthle cell transformation are visible during a biopsy. TSH is elevated. Diagnosis will be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

  • Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing inflammation and damage to the thyroid cells.
  • This destruction and damage lead to a decrease in the production of thyroid hormones. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas where iodine is not deficient.
  • It is more commonly found in women than in men. It is associated with the presence of autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase, and there is a genetic component linked to the genes CTLA4 and PTPN22.
  • Histologically, the thyroid gland shows a mononuclear infiltrate, atrophic thyroid follicles and Hurtle cells. There is also a potential complication of Hashimoto thyroiditis known as hashitoxicosis which is a transient thyrotoxicosis due to disruption of the thyroid follicles.
  • Other complications associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis include extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma, papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, and goitre in children.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1078.

questions.text: The patient presents with a 2 cm-long midline neck edema. Orphan Annie's ocular nuclei are visible on H.P.E. most likely classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Papillary thyroid ca.
 
  • Papillary Carcinoma Thyroid is the most common type of thyroid malignancy. It is more common in females than males. It is seen in 90% of thyroid malignancies in children. In some cases, the papillary carcinoma may have been caused by radiation exposure or a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  • The size can vary from microscopic to huge and can be either solid or cystic. Microscopically, it has complex, branching true papillae with ground glass (optically clear) nuclei, nuclear pseudoinclusions, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies. Immunohistochemistry shows that it is positive for CK7, negative for CK20, positive for thyroglobulin, and positive for TTF-1.
  • Genetically, there is usually activation of the MAPK pathway, RET/PTC and BRAF rearrangements. Variants of papillary carcinoma include papillary microcarcinoma (1 cm or less in diameter), encapsulated variant, follicular variant, diffuse sclerosing variant, oncocytic (oxyphilic) variant, tall cell and columnar cell carcinoma, cribriform-morular variant, and papillary carcinoma with exuberant nodular fasciitis-like stroma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1086.

questions.text: Male Patient of age 25 years having thyroid swelling, lymphocytic infiltration, Hurthle cell charge shown in biopsy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hashimoto's thyroiditis
 
  • The findings described are characteristic of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland.
  • The histopathological features of Hashimoto's thyroiditis include lymphocytic infiltration, Hurthle cell changes, and the presence of thyroid autoantibodies.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1078.

questions.text: Prognathism and increased length of hands and feet were present in a male patient. Which of the following gene mutations is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PIT-1

Mutation of PIT-1 is the likely cause. PIT-1 refers to Pituitary specific transcription factor -1. Its mutation causes:

(1) Gigantism (children)
(2) Acromegaly (adults)
(3) Galactorrhea & amenorrhea
(4) Sexual dysfunction & infertility
(5) Hyperthyroidism

Its mutation is associated with:
  • Somatotroph pituitary adenoma
  • Lactotroph adenoma
  • Thyrotroph adenoma.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2892.

questions.text: A 24 years old patient with history of neck swelling on Right side of thyroid which moves with deglutition, invading into anterior strap muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Following histological features are suggestive of Papillary CA Thyroid:
  • papillary architecture with fibrovascular cone
  • coffee bean nuclei/ Orphan Annie eye nuclei
  • nuclear pseudo inclusions
  • psammoma bodies



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1088, 1089.

questions.text: Neurosecretory granules are typically seen in all of the given malignancies except?
questions.solution:
• Neurosecretory granules are typically seen in neuroendocrine tumors, which are characterized by the presence of cells with neuroendocrine features.
  • The malignancy that does not typically exhibit neurosecretory granules among the given options is option (4) Adrenal cortical tumor.
Adrenal cortical tumor
  • Adrenal cortical tumors, such as adrenal cortical carcinoma or adenoma, arise from the adrenal cortex and are typically not associated with neurosecretory granules.
  • These tumors primarily involve the production of steroid hormones, such as cortisol or aldosterone, rather than neuroendocrine hormones.
 

On the other hand, the remaining options( Medullary thyroid carcinoma/ Pituatory adenoma and Paraganglioma) are known to be associated with neurosecretory granules.


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1119,1120,1091,1067,1070,746 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma
questions.solution:
• Perineural invasion refers to the infiltration of tumor cells into the nerve fibers.
  • It is more commonly associated with malignant tumors rather than benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign salivary gland tumor characterized by the presence of myoepithelial cells and chondroid differentiation, but it does not typically exhibit perineural invasion.
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 748, 751 .

questions.text: What should be the target HbA1c level in a diabetic patient whose fasting blood glucose levels are 140mg/dL and post-prandial are 200gm/dL?
questions.solution:
For most adult patients with diabetes mellitus, the recommended target HbA1c is <7%, as per ADA and WHO guidelines. This target correlates with:

  • Fasting glucose: 80–130 mg/dL

  • Post-prandial glucose: <180 mg/dL

Rationale:

  • HbA1c reflects average blood glucose over the past 2–3 months.

  • Target <7% reduces the risk of microvascular complications (retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy) without causing excessive hypoglycemia.

  • Individualization: Elderly patients or those with comorbidities may have less stringent targets (<7.5–8%), while young patients with long life expectancy may aim for <6.5%.

Patient context:

  • Fasting 140 mg/dL and post-prandial 200 mg/dL → above optimal levels

  • HbA1c target: <7% to achieve better glycemic control

Reference:

questions.text: 30y old female was evaluated for sudden onset hoarseness of voice and Difficulty in breathing. She was found to have a mass compressing the trachea from the outside. Biopsy of the mass showed Cells arranegd in nests with Amyloid Deposits. What is the origin of these cells?
questions.solution:
• Clinical scenario and with biopsy showing cells arranged in nest with amyloid deposits is suggestive of Medullary Carcinoma Thyroid.
  • MCT arises from the Parafollicular C cells.
  • Diagnosis is by clinical examination and Raised Calcitonin and CEA along with FNAC of the mass.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 870, 871.

questions.text: Most common cause of adrenal incidentaloma is
questions.solution:
The most common cause of an adrenal incidentaloma is a non-functioning adenoma.

Incidentalomas are categorized into the following types:

Non-functional: The most common type.

Functional: May present with conditions such as Cushing‘s syndrome, pheochromocytoma, aldosteronoma, or cortisol-producing adenoma.

Secondary metastasis: Seen in 2% of patients, commonly from the breast, lung, or kidneys.


For patients without a confirmed diagnosis, specific tests are recommended to identify underlying hormonally active tumors. These tests include:

(a) A low-dose (1 mg) overnight dexamethasone suppression test to rule out subclinical Cushing‘s syndrome.

(b) A 24-hour urine collection to measure catecholamines, metanephrines, or vanillylmandelic acid (VMA), or testing plasma metanephrine levels to exclude pheochromocytoma.


(c) In hypertensive patients, assessing serum electrolytes, plasma aldosterone, and plasma renin levels to exclude aldosteronoma.

Management of incidentalomas:

Non-functional tumors:

Tumors smaller than 4 cm are managed conservatively, with MRI surveillance every 3-6 months.

For tumors larger than 4 cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is performed.


Functional tumors:

Hormonal assays are performed in suspected cases or in symptomatic patients. If the results are positive, the tumor is managed accordingly. If left untreated, functional tumors have a higher risk of malignancy, which increases fourfold if the tumor exceeds 4 cm.


Secondary metastasis:

Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy are performed. Before the biopsy, pheochromocytoma must be excluded to prevent precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2976 .

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
In the provided image, Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are observed, which are a hallmark feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed-Sternberg Cells
Characteristics: RS cells are typically large and can be either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus, often described as having an "owl's eye" appearance due to their prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli.
Origin: These cells are clonal in nature, originating from germinal center B cells, but they usually exhibit a loss of most B-cell gene expression and function.


Diagnostic Relevance
While Reed-Sternberg cells are most commonly associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma, they are not exclusive to it and can be found in several other conditions, including:

Hodgkin's lymphoma
Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (particularly in the immunoblastic variant)
Infectious mononucleosis
Sarcomas

questions.text: Which of the following thyroid neoplasia arise from the parafollicular c cells of thyroid?
questions.solution:
Thyroid medullary cancer (MTC) is derived from parafollicular C cells.

Most occurrences of MTC are sporadic, although some are connected to hereditary disorders including MEN2A, MEN2B, and familial MTC, which are all brought on by mutations in the RET gene. With a higher frequency in females, the majority of patients receive their diagnosis between the ages of 50 and 60.


Other options:

  • Papillary carcinoma of thyroid: Most common thyroid cancer, arises from follicular cells, not C cells.

  • Follicular carcinoma of thyroid: Also arises from follicular cells, spreads hematogenously.

  • Anaplastic carcinoma of thyroid: Undifferentiated tumor of follicular cell origin, very aggressive, poor prognosis.



Reference
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e - Page no. 259, 260, 261, 262, 1091, 1092, 1093

choices.text: Most common age group is between 3050 years

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding papillary thyroid cancer?
questions.solution:
Rather than papillary cancer, calcitonin is a marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma.

The most prevalent form of thyroid cancer, papillary thyroid carcinoma, has a somewhat good prognosis. The observation of this condition is more common among women aged between thirty and fifty. Radiation exposure (option c) and a family history of thyroid cancer are common risk factors. Papillary thyroid cancer is also linked to genetic abnormalities in the RET or BRAF genes.

Clinically, it usually manifests as a painless swelling of the thyroid that frequently enlarges the cervical lymph nodes. Symptoms including coughing, dysphagia, hoarseness, or dyspnea may appear in more advanced cases.

An effective method for determining the number and size of nodules as well as the classification of lesions as benign, indeterminate, or malignant is ultrasound.

Reference :

1. Bailey & Loves Short Practice of Surgery - 27th Edition - Page no 820
2.Schwartz s Principles Of Surgery - 10th Edition - Page no 1550, 1542-1544

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension,palpitations and sweating. His catecholamine and aldosterone levels were found to be elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The triad of hypertension, palpitations, and sweating is classic for pheochromocytoma (catecholamine-secreting tumor of adrenal medulla).

  • Elevated catecholamine levels confirm excess sympathetic activity.

  • Sometimes aldosterone levels may also appear elevated due to secondary effects of hypertension and catecholamine surge, though pheochromocytoma itself primarily secretes catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine).

Other options:

  • Cushing’s disease: Due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma; causes central obesity, striae, glucose intolerance, not typically palpitations + sweating with catecholamine excess.

  • Pituitary adenoma: Depends on type, but does not explain catecholamine elevation.

  • Addison’s disease: Characterized by low cortisol, hypotension, hyperpigmentation, not hypertension with catecholamine excess.


References:

1. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, pp. 2739–2745.

2. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, p. 2976.

3. Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition, pp. 1128–1129.

questions.text: Pick the right immunohistochemical marker that can be used for the diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Desmin
 
  • Desmin is a protein that is normally expressed in skeletal muscle cells and can be used to clinically diagnose rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Desmin expression is nearly ubiquitous in normal skeletal muscle cells and helps to maintain their structural integrity. 
  • Immunohistochemistry staining for desmin can therefore be used as a diagnostic tool to identify and distinguish rhabdomyosarcoma from other types of cancers.
