  • Additionally, desmin expression can also be assessed in biopsy samples to determine the extent of tumor spread and monitor treatment response.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1212.

questions.text: A five-year-old boy was diagnosed with proptosis. When the mass was examined under a microscope, a round cell tumour that was immunohistochemically positive for desmin was discovered. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma
 
  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma presents as soft gray infiltrative mass. The tumor cells mimics skeletal muscle at various stages of embryogenesis and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma.
  • A diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma is usually made by looking at the specimen under the microscope and finding evidence of characteristic rhabdomyoblasts.
  • Immunohistochemical staining for muscle-specific proteins such as myosin, actin, desmin, and myoglobin can be used to confirm the diagnosis.
  • There are three types of rhabdomyosarcoma, of which embryonal is the most common, accounting for over two-thirds of cases. Of the two subtypes of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, botryoid and spindle cell, the latter tends to be associated with a more favorable prognosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 995.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy's biopsy of his swollen leg revealed small, spherical, blue tumour cells compatible with the diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma. What test will be most effective for identifying the translocation t(11;22) in this cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) FISH
 
  • FISH is a diagnostic tool to detect chromosomal abnormalities, gene mutations and gene amplification. It can be performed on various samples such as blood, tissue samples and even archived tissue slides.
  • Chromosome painting is an extension of FISH which uses probes to span the entire chromosome. However, the number of chromosomes that can be detected are limited by the availability of fluorescent dyes.
  • Spectral karyotyping (also called multicolor FISH) is a breakthrough technique in which different mixtures of five fluorochromes in specific probes are used to visualize the entire human genome. This technique can truly be called “spectacular karyotyping.”
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1192.

questions.text: Myotonic dystrophy is caused by what chromosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chromosome 19
 
  • Myotonic dystrophy, also known as DM1, is caused by an expansion of CTG repeats in the DMPK (Dystrophia Myotonica Protein Kinase) gene located on chromosome 19.
  • Histological changes in muscle: Muscle biopsies of individuals with Myotonic dystrophy often show characteristic histological changes, including muscle fiber atrophy, fiber size variation, and central nuclear clumping. These changes reflect the underlying muscle degeneration and abnormal regeneration.
  • Chromosomes 20, 21, and 22 are not specifically associated with myotonic dystrophy.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1234.

questions.text: From the given options, which is the most likely diagnosis where X-ray shows a lytic lesion of the lower limb and the biopsy shows fibroblastic proliferation, osteoclast, and inflammatory cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) GCT
 
* Giant cell tumor (GCT)-
  • Another name for it is osteoclastoma.
  • Long bones' epiphyses are affected (MC-Distal femur).
  • The female to male ratio is 1.5 to 1.
  • The average age group is 35 years, and those over 20 years old account for 80% of cases.
  • Egg shell crackling when palpated; Jaffe's criterion is used to determine the Osteoclastoma's histological grade.
  • X-ray diagnosis: Soap bubble lesion.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1193.

questions.text: Which investigation would you order next in a case where a child presented with difficulty in walking and on biopsy of the hip some osteoclasts and grooved nuclei with eosinophil cytoplasm are present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is CD 1a marker 
 
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a possible diagnosis in the described situation.
  • LCH may involve the femur.
  • Langerhans cells contain a single, large nucleus that is distinctively folded or grooved (having a coffee-bean appearance), as well as a few small, unnoticeable nucleoli.
  • CD1a surface marker visualization is now thought to be sufficient to make the diagnosis of LCH.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: The image below shows a gross illustration of a bone tumor at the lower end of a femur in a 10-year-old child. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Osteosarcoma
 
  • Osteosarcoma is the diagnosis based on the clinical picture given.
  • Giant cell tumor only occurs after growth plate fusion, i.e. after 20-40 years.
  • Osteoblastoma is seen in the diaphyseal region.
  • Chondroblastoma is most commonly seen in elderly population.
  • Also, it is greyish/bluish in color.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1188.

questions.text: A child with proptosis. On histopathology shows small cells and are desmin positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rhabdomyosarcoma
 
The majority of cases (90%) of this primary orbital tumor in children occur before the age of 15, males are more likely to develop it than females. 
Three different histopathological subtypes: 
1. Embryonal sarcoma, which is the most prevalent.
2. Alveolar sarcoma
3. Pleomorphic Sarcoma (least common)
 
  • It typically shows up in a child between the ages of 7-8 as a sudden, fast progressing proptosis, mimicking an acute inflammatory process.
  • Superonasal quadrant involvement by the tumour is common. 
  • Desmin is an intermediate filament protein linked to skeletal and smooth muscles. 
  • One of the most sensitive rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) indicators, including the majority of the poorly-differentiated cases, is desmin. 
  • It is not totally specific though. It is unable to discriminate between leiomyosarcoma and RMS.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1212.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman had her hip replaced. She ended up loosening after 9 years, necessitating the removal of the implant. Below is a picture of the lesion's histology. What is the most probable reason for this ailment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Metallosis
 
  • Most likely cause of this condition is metallosis.
  • It happens when metal pieces from hip implants or other joint replacement devices scrape against one another and release small amounts of metal into the surrounding tissues and blood.
  • Histopathology shows the presence of black pigment interspersed within extensive fibrosis.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 224.

questions.text: The skeletal muscle fibres are referred to as "ragged red fibres" in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Mitochondrial myopathy 
 
  • Ragged red fibers are characteristic histological findings in mitochondrial myopathies, a group of disorders caused by defects in mitochondrial function.
  • Ragged red fibers appear as irregularly shaped, enlarged muscle fibers with red-staining granules or aggregates in the subsarcolemmal region.
  • These abnormalities are visualized using modified Gomori trichrome staining.
  • The accumulation of abnormal mitochondria with impaired oxidative phosphorylation leads to the characteristic appearance of ragged red fibers.
  • Mitochondrial myopathies can present with muscle weakness, exercise intolerance, and other systemic manifestations depending on the specific genetic defect involved.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3529.

questions.text: Where is Keratoderma Blennorrhagica frequently found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Reactive Arthritis
 
  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a skin manifestation that can occur in reactive arthritis, a form of arthritis associated with certain infections, such as Chlamydia trachomatis or gastrointestinal infections.
  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica is characterized by the presence of hyperkeratotic plaques and pustules on the palms and soles.
  • The lesions may be erythematous and have a yellowish or grayish appearance.
  • Other common features of reactive arthritis include asymmetric oligoarthritis, enthesitis, and uveitis.
  • The presence of Keratoderma blennorrhagica can help support the diagnosis of reactive arthritis.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1045.

questions.text: The most common mutation in Ewing's sarcoma is reflected by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Translocation 11:22
 
  • Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone and soft tissue tumor primarily affecting children and young adults.
  • It is characterized by a specific chromosomal translocation, t(11;22), involving the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11.
  • This translocation leads to the fusion of EWSR1 and FLI1 genes, resulting in the production of an abnormal fusion protein with oncogenic properties.
  • The translocation t(11;22) is present in approximately 85-90% of Ewing's sarcoma cases.
  • The fusion protein plays a crucial role in the development and progression of Ewing's sarcoma.
     

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1192.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presented with pain in the lower limb. X ray showed a lesson at the tibial diaphysis with reactions visible on the surface of the bone. Histopathology of the lesion showed small round cells, the lesion is positive for MIC2 on immunohistochemistry. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical stem and histopathology/IHC description matches Ewing's sarcoma. (Diaphyseal tumor in an adolescent boy having Small round Blue cell histopathology and MIC2 positivity)

Ewing's Sarcoma 
  • The histopathology of Ewing sarcoma is characterized by the presence of small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. (It's a Small round Blue cell tumor). Necrosis and mitotic figures are commonly seen.
  • The following IHC markers are commonly used for Ewing sarcoma:
  1. CD99(Also known as MIC2): This is the most sensitive marker(but not specific) for Ewing sarcoma. It is positive in more than 90% of cases.
  2. FLI-1
  3. NKX2.2: More specific than CD99 for Ewing's Sarcoma. 
  • The combination of CD99/NKX2.2 is very specific for Ewing sarcoma.


 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1192,1193, 1188,477,478.

questions.text: Tongue fascination is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Tongue fasciculation is a common symptom of spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). Muscle denervation in SMA contributes to the involuntary muscle contractions and twitching seen in fasciculations.

SMA is typically caused by genetic mutations in the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene, which is responsible for producing a protein called survival motor neuron (SMN). Insufficient levels of the SMN protein result in the degeneration and loss of motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy.

Note: Drugs used for the treatment of SMA can be asked in future INI-CET exams (Trial of Spinraza is ongoing at AIIMS, Delhi)



 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3415,3501,3509,3510,3521 .

questions.text: A 45-year old alcoholic male patient presented with pain in the great toe. The synovial aspirate revealed increased WBCs. Serum uric acid levels are found to be normal. There is no history of fever, dysuria or diarrhea. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case is acute gouty arthritis, which is supported by the patient's symptoms and the synovial aspirate showing increased white blood cells.
  • Gout is a type of arthritis that occurs when uric acid crystals accumulate in the joints, leading to inflammation and pain.
  • However, it is worth noting that the normal serum uric acid levels do not completely rule out the possibility of gout, as some individuals with gout may have normal uric acid levels.
  • Although nonpharmacologic measures, such as ice pack application and rest of the involved joints, can be helpful, the mainstay of acute gout care is the administration of anti-inflammatory drugs such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, and glucocorticoids.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2896.

questions.text:
Identify the enzyme deficient in the below condition:

1. Hexosaminidase
2. Glucocerebrosidase
3. Sphingomyelinase
4. Alpha-1,4-glucosidase
questions.solution:
• In image atypical Gaucher cell with vacuolations and typical Gaucher cell with a “wrinkled tissue pattern” or “crumpled tissue paper appearance” are identified on bone marrow aspirate smear.
  • Gaucher disease is due to deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase). 
  • There are three clinical subtypes- type I, type II and type III.
  • Clinical Features include anemia, thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly and neurological features depending on the subtypes. 

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page. No- 251.

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of having Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding on electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy. These granules have a dilated terminal end that gives them a tennis racket-like appearance. They contain the protein langerin (CD207) and are observed on electron microscopy.
Histopathologically, Langerhans cells feature a single large nucleus with a distinctive folded or grooved appearance, often described as a coffee-bean appearance, and small, inconspicuous nucleoli. The cytoplasm contains Birbeck granules. Tumor cells specifically express the markers HLA-DR, S-100, CD1a, and langerin (CD207).
Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is caused by the proliferation of immature dendritic cells known as Langerhans cells, which normally function to present antigens. The most frequent mutation associated with LCH is the BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

LCH is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can affect almost any organ, including the skin (particularly the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, and central nervous system.

LCH can manifest in various clinical forms:

Multifocal multisystem LCH (Letterer-Siwe disease)

Unifocal and multifocal unisystem LCH (eosinophilic granuloma)

The Hand-Schüller-Christian triad, which includes bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos

Pulmonary LCH

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 627,628 .

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. On examination, pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles was noted. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes an 8-year-old boy with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and calf pseudohypertrophy → classical for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).

Explanation of options:

  1. Expansions of CTG triplet repeats → Myotonic dystrophy type 1, not DMD.

  2. Defective fibrillin → Marfan syndrome.

  3. Abnormal collagen → Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta.

  4. Absent dystrophin → Duchenne muscular dystrophy (due to frameshift/nonsense mutation in dystrophin gene on Xp21 → complete absence of dystrophin).
     

DMD presents in boys around 2–5 years, progressive proximal muscle weakness, Gower’s sign, calf pseudohypertrophy, wheelchair dependency by ~12 years, and cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: One can find which of these in Schwannoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Antoni A and Antoni B pattern

* Histology of Schwannoma:

Biphasic: Hypercellular/compact Antoni A areas + hypocellular/myxoid Antoni B areas.

Verocay bodies (Nuclear palisading around the fibrillary process)- seen in cellular area. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Identify the acessory protein indicated in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alpha actinin

The star in image shows Z line. 

Z- line 
The Z line is mostly made up of alpha-actinin homodimers arranged in an antiparallel pattern,
which serves as a framework for the insertion of thin filaments made of actin, titin, and nebulin/nebulette.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1804.

questions.text: The microscopic appearance of schwannoma—a nerve sheath tumour most typically involving the cerebellopontine angle—is seen below. What does the region shown with arrow represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Antony A pattern

The microscopic appearance of schwannoma typically shows a pattern known as Antony A pattern. This pattern consists of spindle cells arranged in a palisading pattern with nuclear alignment.
Therefore, the correct answer is 2. Antony A pattern.

The hypercellular part - Antoni A containing Verouccay bodies
The hypocellular area - Antoni B


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Investigation of a patient with bilateral proptosis determine the diagnosis using the region's biopsy that has been provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Schwannoma
 
  • The given histopathological slide along with clinical features goes in favor of schwannoma. 
  • Schwannomas often abut orbital apertures, and patients present with nonspecific symptoms such as progressive painless proptosis.
  • On histopathological examination, in the Antoni A pattern of growth, elongated cells with cytoplasmic processes are organized in fascicles in regions of moderate to high cellularity and substantial stromal matrix.
  • The "nuclear-free cones" of processes that lie in between the regions of nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.
  • A loose meshwork of cells, microcysts, and myxoid stroma make up the Antoni B pattern of head and neck tumors, which are less densely cellular.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Where can we find Verocay bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Schwannoma 
 
  • Schwannoma (neurilemoma) is typically a solitary tumor, most commonly located on the flexor surfaces of the extremities, neck, mediastinum, retroperitoneum, posterior spinal roots, and cerebellopontine angle.
  • Grossly, larger schwannomas often contain cystic areas.
  • Microscopically, there are two different patterns, designated as type A and type B.
  • In type A, the cells are spindle-shaped and arranged in a palisading or organoid formation aka Verocay bodies.
  • In type B, the cells are separated by edematous fluid that can form cystic spaces. Ancient schwannomas may contain isolated cells with bizarre hyperchromatic nuclei, though these are of no particular significance.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: According to histopathology, rosettes are not present in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Neurocysticercosis 

Out of the given options, Neurocysticercosis do no show rosettes.
a. Retinoblastoma has Flexer-Wintersteiner rosettes.
b. Ewing sarcoma has Homer-Wright rosettes.
c. Ependymoma has round rosettes or elongated canals.
d. Medulloblastoma shows Homer Wright or neuroblastic rosette




Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1120.

choices.text: One in 10 people age 65 and older has Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Alzheimer's disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alzheimer’s disease is curable.
 
  • The incorrect statement is B. Alzheimer's disease is curable.
  • Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that causes memory loss, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes.
  • Currently, there is no cure for Alzheimer's disease, but various treatments and interventions can help manage symptoms and slow down its progression.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3370.

questions.text: Swelling in the wrist joint of a 20 aged patient. Histopathology exhibits spindle cells and verocay bodies most likely to be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Schwannoma

  • Schwannoma is a benign neural tumor made up of Schwann cells, which are cells that are typically located in the peripheral nervous system which are the nerves that run from the central nervous system to the extremities.
  • It can be found in solitary or multiple forms, depending on if it is associated with a type 2 Recklinghausen disease.
  • It usually develops on flexed surfaces of limbs, neck, mediastinum, retroperitoneum, posterior spinal roots, and the cerebellopontine angle. Schwannomas are linked to the NF2 gene located on chromosome 22q12 and codes for merlin.
  • In microscopic examination, these tumors typically have an Antoni A (cellular) and an Antoni B (hypocellular) pattern. They can also have Verocay bodies, which are unique structures.
  • There are other types, like melanotic and cellular schwannomas, as well as psammomatous melanotic schwannomas which are components of the Carney complex. Immunohistochemistry shows S-100 protein, calretinin, and calcineurin present in Schwannomas.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

choices.text: There is loss of function type of mutation
It is a trinucleotide expansion mutation related disorder
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome

questions.text: Select the accurate option for Huntington 's Chorea.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) It is a trinucleotide expansion mutation related disorder
 
  • Huntington Disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant movement disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansions in a gene located on 4p16.3, which encodes the protein huntington.
  • The number of repeats increases with each generation, causing an earlier onset in subsequent generations. Clinically, HD presents with a triad of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms, including involuntary jerky movements, dementia, behavioural changes, and an increased risk of suicide.
  • Pathologically, HD is characterized by atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen as well as the loss of neurons and the accumulation of intranuclear inclusions containing ubiquitin. It is most commonly transmitted from father to child.
Memorizing Trick: -
Hunter- CAGE
Huntington- CAG repeats
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1285.

questions.text: Slow conduction of the motor and sensory pathway in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following reasons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Loss of myelin sheath

  • Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system (CNS) caused by chronic inflammation and resulting in demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring) and neuronal loss.
  • The disease can progress in a relapsing or progressive manner.
  • The myelin sheath, which facilitates nerve conduction, is affected, causing conduction block and hyperpolarization of the nerve axon. To compensate, the sodium channels redistribute, allowing for continuous propagation through the demyelinated section.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1269.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common form of muscular dystrophies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) DMD
 
  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disorder, occurring in an estimated 1 in 3,600 live born infant boys. It is caused by an abnormal gene located at the Xp21.2 locus, which encodes a 427-kDa cytoskeletal protein called dystrophin.
  • The most common molecular defect in DMD is a deletion of the gene, which may be followed by duplication or point mutations. Some female carriers, or affected girls, can experience a mild form of the disorder, due to the Lyon Hypothesis which states that the normal X chromosome becomes silenced, and the one with the gene deletion is active. Girls with Turner Syndrome, a disorder caused by a single X chromosome, have a gene deletion at the Xp21 locus.
  • Characteristic clinical features of DMD includes progressive muscle weakness, intellectual impairment, hypertrophy of the calves, and proliferation of connective tissue in the muscle. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is similar to DMD, but usually has a milder phenotype.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1232.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man arrives at the OPD with a left-sided testicular tumor and ataxia. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Non-Hodgkins lymphoma
 
  • According to the given history the patient is most likely to have Non - Hodgkin’s Lymphoma.
  • Non - Hodgkin’s Lymphoma can involve extra nodal tissues (testes, GIT, brain, etc) and hence it is the most likely answer for this question. Glioblastoma is seen in the brain and it rarely metastasises to the testes.
  • Non - seminomatous Germ Cell Tumour can present with testicular swelling but ataxia is less likely. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma usually presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, it rarely involves extra nodal tissues.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 592.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, four-day fever, and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no previous travel or tick bite history. Increased protein, normal glucose, moderate lymphocytosis and  presence of RBCs were all observed in the CSF. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Enterovirus

Meningitis with CSF parameters of normal glucose, increased protein and lymphocytosis goes in favor of viral meningitis due to enterovirus. 
  • Option A- West Nile virus is endemic in North America but since there is no history of travel, we rule out this option.
  • Option B- Bacterial meningitis will have increased protein and WBC count with predominant neutrophils and decreased CSF glucose levels. Gram staining will show gram positive lanceolate shaped diplococci. 
  • Option C- Meningococcal meningitis will also have increased protein and WBC count with predominant neutrophils and decreased CSF glucose levels. Gram staining will show gram negative diplococci. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 351.

questions.text: Which nerve is obstructed in the following picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nasociliary nerve
 
* Nasociliary nerve block- Close to the ethmoidal foramen, the nasociliary nerve is blocked before it splits into nasal branches of the anterior ethmoidal nerve and the intratracheal nerve. 
  • Epinephrine-free solutions ought to be applied here to reduce the risk of retinal artery spasm. 
  • One centimeter above the medial canthus, halfway between the posterior palpebral fold and the eyebrow, a 15–30 mm, 25–27-gauge intradermal needle is inserted. 
  • After that, it is aimed medially and backward in order to make contact with the orbit's bony roof. 
  • After a negative aspiration test, a maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is slowly injected at a depth of 1.5 cm, at the anterior ethmoidal foramen. The external nasal nerve can be blocked by continuously injecting while removing the needle. 
  • The finger's compression of the inferior angle of the eye helps the solution diffuse into the foramen.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3438.

questions.text: A multiple sclerosis diagnosis is made for a patient. Where is the disease most prevalent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Oligodendrocytes
 
  • In multiple sclerosis (MS), the disease is most prevalent in oligodendrocytes.
  • Oligodendrocytes are responsible for producing myelin, the protective covering around nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
  • In MS, the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the myelin, leading to communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body.
  • Oligodendrocyte damage and loss of myelin are characteristic features of MS lesions.
  • The disease primarily affects the white matter of the brain and spinal cord, where oligodendrocytes are abundant.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1269.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates a poor prognosis for multiple myeloma patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Serum ß2 Microglobulin

Beta 2 microglobulin, the light chain of the HL-A histocompatibility complex, is a low molecular weight protein that is present on the surface of all nucleated cells.
Patients with multiple myeloma who have higher serum beta 2 microglobulin levels have a worse prognosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an alpha synucleinopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Alzheimer

Alzheimer is not alpha synnucleopathy.
α-Synucleinopathies are neurodegenerative diseases characterized by the abnormal accumulation of α-synuclein aggregates in neurons, nerve fibers or glial cells.
It’s examples are:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with levy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
Alzheimer's disease on the other hand is an example of Taupathy. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

choices.text: Number of senile plaques correlates with age
Number of neurofibrillary tangles is associated with the severity of dementia
Extracellular inclusions can be found in the absence of intracellular inclusions

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Extracellular inclusions can be found in the absence of intracellular inclusions

Extracellular inclusions cannot be observed in the absence of intracellular inclusions because neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular accumulations that may manifest extracellularly following neuronal death. Other statements given are true.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: Which receptor induces development of glioma on neuronal membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) CD-133

Receptors on neuronal membrane that induces development of glioma are CD-133
CD-133 is a common marker used for leukemia and glioblastoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1293.

questions.text: The inclusion bodies found in Alzheimer's are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hirano bodies
 
  • Hirano bodies are intracellular inclusion bodies typically observed in the neurons of individuals with Alzheimer's disease.
  • Hirano bodies are considered to be a hallmark pathological feature of Alzheimer's disease.
  • In contrast, Buschino bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in hepatocytes, and Lewy bodies and Lafora bodies are associated with other neurodegenerative disorders.

IMPORTANT INCLUSION BODIES



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: Astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are not present in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alzheimer's disease 
 
  • Astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are reactive astrocytes observed in certain conditions but not in Alzheimer's disease.
  • They are typically seen in hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson's disease, and urea cycle disorders.
  • Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the presence of neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuronal loss, but astrocytes of the Alzheimer type II are not a characteristic feature of this disease.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: All of the following, with one exception, display the Zellballen Pattern which is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Acoustic neuroma
 
  • The Zellballen pattern refers to the histological appearance of nests or clusters of cells separated by an abundant vascular stroma.
  • Conditions that display the Zellballen pattern include:
    • Pheochromocytoma: A catecholamine-producing tumor arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
    • Carotid Body Tumor: A neoplasm arising from the carotid body, a chemoreceptor organ located at the carotid bifurcation.
    • Glomus Jugulare: A tumor arising from the paraganglia of the jugular bulb.
    • Paraganglioma
Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, does not display the Zellballen pattern as it arises from Schwann cells rather than neuroendocrine cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a Neuronal tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Ependymoma 
 
  • Ependymoma is a type of primary central nervous system tumor that arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricles of the brain or the central canal of the spinal cord.
  • Ependymoma is derived from glial cells and is classified as a glioma rather than a neuronal tumor.
  • Neuronal tumors arise from neuronal cells and include various types, such as gangliocytoma, ganglioglioma, and neurocytoma.
  • Ependymoma is characterized by a range of clinical presentations depending on the location and size of the tumor and can cause symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure or local mass effect.

NEURONAL TUMORS



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1296.

questions.text: Rupture of saccular aneurysm results in:
questions.solution:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage is seen due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm.  Clinically it presents with sudden onset thunder clap headache. It maybe associated with seizures, unresponsiveness and vomiting. 

The imaging modality of choice for suspected SAH is NC-CT brain which will show hyperdense blood in basal cisterns. This should be followed by a CT Angiography to localize the site of aneurysm which appears as round contrast filled outpouching. 

Treatment is by doing craniotomy with clipping or endovascular coil embolization. 

Option B- Subdural hemorrhage occurs due to rupture of bridging cortical veins. 

Option C- Epidural hemorrhage occurs due to injury to branches of middle meningeal artery from fracture of underlying bone. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1258, 1259.

Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 335, 652, 653.

questions.text: A patient with meningitis was subjected to lumbar puncture. Gross appearance of CSF specimen is shown in the first image. CSF findings were low sugar, raised protein and mononuclear leucocytosis. Most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with CSF findings of cobweb like clot and slide showing lymphocytic predominance goes in favor of tuberculous meningitis. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1100, 1102-1106.

questions.text: Senile atrophy is due to?
questions.solution:
Senile atrophy in brain is seen due to atherosclerotic changes leading to ischemia.
 

Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of a tissue or organ due to a decrease in cell size and number. It represents a form of cellular adaptation. This process involves reduced synthesis of cellular proteins and increased protein degradation, primarily through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway.

Atrophy can be classified as either physiological or pathological:

Physiological atrophy:

  1. Loss of hormonal stimulation: Examples include uterine atrophy after childbirth and atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast tissue following menopause.
  2. During embryonic development: Structures such as the notochord and thyroglossal duct undergo atrophy during fetal development.

Pathological atrophy:
 
  1. Disuse atrophy (decreased workload): For instance, muscle atrophy in an immobilized limb after a fracture.
  2. Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply): For example, skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve damage.
  3. Ischemic atrophy: Seen in conditions like senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis.
  4. Inadequate nutrition: Such as severe muscle wasting observed in marasmus.
  5. Pressure atrophy: For instance, atrophy of tissues surrounding a benign tumor due to sustained pressure.


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 59, 60.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is caused by abnormal folding of proteins?
questions.solution:
feldt-Jakob disease is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease that causes higher cortical function deficits. This infection can be acquired by corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, dura mater grafts, and contaminated human growth hormone (hGH) preparations.

Symptoms are almost always rapidly progressive, and the clinical presentation includes the following:

• Myoclonus
• Higher cortical deficits

• Psychiatric manifestations – depression, psychosis, and visual hallucinations

• Profound dementia – memory loss, impaired judgment, intellectual decline


• Visual impairment or cerebellar gait and coordination deficits in a few patients

• Nonspecific prodromal symptoms – fatigue, sleep disturbance, weight, loss, headache, anxiety, vertigo, malaise, and ill-defined pain


• Extrapyramidal dysfunction – rigidity, masklike facies, choreoathetoid movements;

• Seizures


• Hypoesthesia

• Supranuclear gaze palsy, optic atrophy


Patients commonly present with myoclonus and dementia. EEG shows characteristic periodic electrical bursts. MRI shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning (ribbonlike signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri). On light microscopy, the pathologic hallmarks of CJD are spongiform degeneration and astrocytic gliosis.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3419-3421 .

choices.text: Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with frequent headaches. Investigation reveals raised intracranial pressure and the presence of a dural-based tumor. Which of the following histological-findings correlate with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a dural-based tumor presenting with headache and signs of raised intracranial pressure, most likely indicating a meningioma. The patient's demography: a 40-year-old female, further supports this diagnosis, as meningiomas are more common in adult women, partly because oral contraceptive pill (OCP) use is an important risk factor.

On Histopathological examination, these tumors are characterized by the presence of psammoma bodies and whorled pattern of spindle cells.




Meningiomas are typically benign tumors commonly seen in adult females. They arise from meningothelial cells of the arachnoid mater, and are attached to the duramater, also known as the characteristic “dural tail sign” on imaging.
Risk factors include prior radiation exposure and oral contraceptive use. A strong association exists with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2), where meningiomas may coexist with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors and can be multiple.
Histologically, they are well-encapsulated tumors showing a whorled pattern of spindle cells along with numerous psammoma bodies, which are structures of dystrophic calcification.

Clinical Features:

  • Often asymptomatic until large

  • Headache

  • Seizures

  • Focal neurological deficits

  • Visual disturbance (compression of optic nerve or chiasm)

  • Increased ICP in large lesions

    Treatment:

Approach Indication
Surgical resection Mainstay for accessible, symptomatic tumors
Radiotherapy Residual/recurrent tumors, inoperable cases
Observation Small, asymptomatic, elderly patients


Other Options:

Option A: Homer wright rosettes are pseudo-rosettes typically seen in tumors like medulloblastoma and ependymoma. These tumors occur in children and so this answer is incorrect.

Option C: Flexner-wintersteiner rosettes are pathognomic of Retinoblastoma, which is a tumor of the eye.

Option D: Fried egg appearance is a characteristic feature of oligodendrogliomas. These tumors can also occur in middle aged females, however they originate from the oligodendrocytes, and they are not attached to the duramater.

questions.text: The given inclusion bodies are characteristic of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The provided image displays intranuclear basophilic inclusions encircled by a clear halo, indicative of owl's eye inclusion bodies, which are characteristically associated with cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.


 

Other options:

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): Causes atypical lymphocytes (Downey cells), not owl’s eye inclusions.

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV): Shows Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusions (eosinophilic, with margination of chromatin).

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV): Shows koilocytosis (perinuclear halo with wrinkled nuclei), not owl’s eye.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department soon after a road traffic accident with intense superficial pain due to injuries. Which nerve fibre is responsible for the conduction of this pain?
questions.solution:
Fast pain, or initial pain, is the type of pain that is communicated through A-delta fibers and is covered by the clinical history of acute superficial pain. Either A-delta fibers, which represent quick pain or epicritic pain, or C fibers, which represent gradual pain or protopathic pain, can transmit pain.

Rapid pain allows for a prompt response and allows for the accurate localization of the location and strength of an unpleasant stimuli. When A-delta fibers are activated, glutamate is released, which results in this kind of pain.

On the other hand, dull, scorching, and poorly localized sensations might be felt during gradual pain. Substance P is released by C nociceptor fibers, which relay the signal.


Reference

1Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition - Page no: 158

2.Harrison's Principles Of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition - Page.no :2675
